Gift: Any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including, but not limited to, cash, food and drink, and honoraria for speaking engagements related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of an officer or employee. 
Leave of absence: Any period during which an employee does not receive (i) compensation for employment, (ii) service credit toward pension benefits, and (iii) health insurance benefits paid for by the employer. 
Officer: A person who holds, by election or appointment, an office created by statute or ordinance, regardless of whether the officer is compensated for service in his or her official capacity. 
Political activity: Any activity in support of or in connection with any campaign for elective office or any political organization, but does not include activities (i) relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action, (ii) relating to collective bargaining, or (iii) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties. 
Political organization: A party, committee, association, fund, or other organization (whether or not incorporated) that is required to file a statement of organization with the State Board of Elections or a county clerk under Section 9-3 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/9-3), but only with regard to those activities that require filing with the state board of elections or a county clerk. 
Prohibited political activity: 
(1)  Preparing for, organizing, or participating in any political meeting, political rally, political demonstration, or other political event. 
(2)  Soliciting contributions, including but not limited to the purchase of, selling, distributing, or receiving payment for tickets for any political fund raiser, political meeting, or other political event. 
(3)  Soliciting, planning the solicitation of, or preparing any document or report regarding anything of value intended as a campaign contribution. 
(4)  Planning, conducting, or participating in a public opinion poll in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question. 
(5)  Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in an election to determine probable vote outcome in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question. 
(6)  Assisting at the polls on election day on behalf of any political organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(7)  Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in an effort to get voters to the polls. 
(8)  Initiating for circulation, preparing, circulating, reviewing, or filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(9)  Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in that capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office. 
(10)  Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires. 
(11)  Distributing, preparing for distribution, or mailing campaign literature, campaign signs, or other campaign material on behalf of any candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(12)  Campaigning for any elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(13)  Managing or working on a campaign for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(14)  Serving as a delegate, alternate, or proxy to a political party convention. 
(15)  Participating in any recount or challenge to the outcome of any election. 
Prohibited source: Any person or entity who: 
(1)  Is seeking official action (i) by an officer or (ii) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; 
(2)  Does business or seeks to do business (i) with the officer or (ii) with an employee, or with the officer or another employee directing that employee; 
(3)  Conducts activities regulated (i) by the officer or (ii) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; or 
(4)  Has interests that may be substantially affected by the performance or non-performance of the official duties of the officer or employee. 
(Ord. No. 3242, § 2, 5-10-04)  
Sec. 2-332. - Prohibited political activities. 
(a)  No officer or employee shall intentionally perform any prohibited political activity during any compensated time, as defined herein. No officer or employee shall intentionally use any property or resources of the village in connection with any prohibited political activity. 
(b)  At no time shall any officer or employee intentionally require any other officer or employee to perform any prohibited political activity (i) as part of that officer or employee's duties, (ii) as a condition of employment, or (iii) during any compensated time off (such as holidays, vacation or personal time off). 
(c)  No officer or employee shall be required at any time to participate in any prohibited political activity in consideration for that officer or employee being awarded additional compensation or any benefit, whether in the form of a salary adjustment, bonus, compensatory time off, continued employment or otherwise, nor shall any officer or employee be awarded additional compensation or any benefit in consideration for his or her participation in any prohibited political activity. 
(d)  Nothing in this section prohibits activities that are permissible for an officer or employee to engage in as part of his or her official duties, or activities that are undertaken by an officer or employee on a voluntary basis which are not prohibited by this division. 
(e)  No person either (i) in a position that is subject to recognized merit principles of public employment or (ii) in a position the salary for which is paid in whole or in part by federal funds and that is subject to the federal standards for a merit system of personnel administration applicable to grant-in-aid programs, shall be denied or deprived of employment or tenure solely because he or she is a member or an officer of a political committee, of a political party, or of a political organization or club. 
(Ord. No. 3242, § 2, 5-10-04)  
Sec. 2-333. - Gift ban. 
(a)  Except as permitted by this division, no officer or employee, and no spouse of or immediate family member living with any officer or employee (collectively referred to herein as "recipients"), shall intentionally solicit or accept any gift from any prohibited source, as defined herein, or which is otherwise prohibited by law or ordinance. No prohibited source shall intentionally offer or make a gift that violates this section. 
(b)  Exceptions. Section 2-333(a) is not applicable to the following: 
(1)  Opportunities, benefits, and services that are available on the same conditions as for the general public. 
(2)  Anything for which the officer or employee, or his or her spouse or member, pays the fair market value. 
(3)  Any (i) contribution that is lawfully made under the Election Code or (ii) activities associated with a fund-raising event in support of a political organization or candidate. 
(4)  Educational materials and missions. 
(5)  Travel expenses for a meeting to discuss business. 
(6)  A gift from a relative, meaning those people related to the individual as father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, great aunt, great uncle, first cousin, nephew, niece, husband, wife, grandfather, grandmother, grandson, granddaughter, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather, stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother, stepsister, half brother, half sister, and including the father, mother, grandfather, or grandmother of the individual's spouse and the individual's fiance or fiancee. 
(7)  Anything provided by an individual on the basis of a personal friendship unless the recipient has reason to believe that, under the circumstances, the gift was provided because of the official position or employment of the recipient or his or her spouse or immediate family member and not because of the personal friendship. In determining whether a gift is provided on the basis of personal friendship, the recipient shall consider the circumstances under which the gift was offered, such as: (i) the history of the relationship between the individual giving the gift and the recipient of the gift, including any previous exchange of gifts between those individuals; (ii) whether to the actual knowledge of the recipient the individual who gave the gift personally paid for the gift or sought a tax deduction or business reimbursement for the gift; and (iii) whether to the actual knowledge of the recipient the individual who gave the gift also at the same time gave the same or similar gifts to other officers or employees, or their spouses or immediate family members. 
(8)  Food or refreshments not exceeding seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per person in value on a single calendar day; provided that the food or refreshments are (i) consumed on the premises from which they were purchased or prepared or (ii) catered. For the purposes of this section, "catered" means food or refreshments that are purchased ready to consume which are delivered by any means. 
(9)  Food, refreshments, lodging, transportation, and other benefits resulting from outside business or employment activities (or outside activities that are not connected to the official duties of an officer or employee), if the benefits have not been offered or enhanced because of the official position or employment of the officer or employee, and are customarily provided to others in similar circumstances. 
(10)  Intragovernmental and intergovernmental gifts. For the purpose of this Act, "intragovernmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or employee from another officer or employee, and "intergovernmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or employee by an officer or employee of another governmental entity. 
(11)  Bequests, inheritances, and other transfers at death. 
(12)  Any item or items from any one prohibited source during any calendar year having a cumulative total value of less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
Each of the exceptions listed in this section is mutually exclusive and independent of every other. 
(c)  Disposition of gifts. An officer or employee, his or her spouse or an immediate family member living with the officer or employee, does not violate this Division if the recipient promptly takes reasonable action to return a gift from a prohibited source to its source or gives the gift or an amount equal to its value to an appropriate charity that is exempt from income taxation under Section 501 (c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as now or hereafter amended, renumbered, or succeeded. 
(Ord. No. 3242, § 2, 5-10-04)  
Sec. 2-333.1. - Sexual harassment. 
All village officers and employees shall be subject to the policy on sexual harassment or stated in section 4.02 of section 4 of the employee handbook, as amended. 
( Ord. No. 4010 , § 1, 1-8-18)  
Sec. 2-334. - Ethics advisor. 
(a)  The village president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall designate an ethics advisor for the village. The duties of the ethics advisor may be delegated to an officer or employee of the village unless the position has been created as an office by the village. 
(b)  The ethics advisor shall provide guidance to the officers and employees of the village concerning the interpretation of and compliance with the provisions of this division and state ethics laws. The ethics advisor shall perform such other duties as may be delegated by the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 3242, § 2, 5-10-04)  
Sec. 2-335. - Ethics commission. 
(a)  There is hereby created a commission to be known as the Ethics Commission of the Village of Villa Park. The commission shall be comprised of the village president, the village clerk and the most senior trustee. In the event of a conflict of interest, the remaining trustees, in order of seniority, shall serve as alternate commissioners. 
(b)  The commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To promulgate procedures and rules governing the performance of its duties and the exercise of its powers. 
(2)  Upon receipt of a signed, notarized, written complaint, to investigate, conduct hearings and deliberations, issue recommendations for disciplinary actions, impose fines in accordance with section 2-336 of this division and refer violations of section 2-332 or 2-333 of this division to the village prosecutor for prosecution. The commission shall, however, act only upon the receipt of a written complaint alleging a violation of this division and not upon its own prerogative. 
(3)  To receive information from the public pertaining to its investigations and to require additional information and documents from persons who may have violated the provisions of this division. 
(4)  To compel the attendance of witnesses and to compel the production of books and papers pertinent to an investigation. It is the obligation of all officers and employees of the village to cooperate with the commission during the course of its investigations. Failure or refusal to cooperate with requests by the commission shall constitute grounds for discipline or discharge. 
(5)  The powers and duties of the commission are limited to matters clearly within the purview of this division. 
(Ord. No. 3242, § 2, 5-10-04)  
Sec. 2-336. - Complaints/hearings. 
(a)  Complaints alleging a violation of this division shall be filed with the ethics commission. 
(b)  Within three (3) business days after the receipt of a complaint, the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the respondent that a complaint has been filed against him or her and a copy of the complaint. The commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a confirmation of the receipt of the complaint to the complainant within three (3) business days after receipt by the commission. The notices to the respondent and the complainant shall also advise them of the date, time, and place of the meeting to determine the sufficiency of the complaint and to establish whether probable cause exists to proceed. 
(c)  Upon not less than forty-eight (48) hours' public notice, the commission shall meet to review the sufficiency of the complaint and, if the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of this division, to determine whether there is probable cause, based on the evidence presented by the complainant, to proceed. The meeting may be closed to the public to the extent authorized by the Open Meetings Act. The commission shall issue notice to the complainant and the respondent of the commission's ruling on the sufficiency of the complaint and, if necessary, on probable cause to proceed within seven (7) business days after receiving the complaint. 
(d)  If the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of section 2-333 of this division and there is a determination of probable cause, then the commission's notice to the parties shall include a hearing date scheduled within four (4) weeks after the receipt of the complaint. Alternatively, the commission may elect to notify in writing the village prosecutor and request that the complaint be adjudicated judicially. If the complaint is deemed not sufficient to allege a violation or if there is no determination of probable cause, then the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the parties of the decision to dismiss the complaint, and that notice shall be made public. 
(e)  If the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of section 2-332 of this division, then the commission shall notify in writing the village prosecutor and shall transmit to the attorney the complaint and all additional documents in the custody of the commission concerning the alleged violation. 
(f)  On the scheduled date and upon at least forty-eight (48) hours' public notice of the meeting, the commission shall conduct a hearing on the complaint and shall allow both parties the opportunity to present testimony and evidence. The hearing may be closed to the public only if authorized by the Open Meetings Act. 
(g)  Within thirty (30) days after the date the hearing or any recessed hearing is concluded, the commission shall either (i) dismiss the complaint or (ii) issue a recommendation for discipline to the alleged violator and to the officer having authority to discipline the officer or employee, or impose a fine upon the violator, or both. The particular findings in the case, any recommendation for discipline, and any fine imposed shall be a matter of public information. 
(h)  If the hearing was closed to the public, the respondent may file a written demand for a public hearing on the complaint within seven (7) business days after the issuance of the recommendation for discipline or imposition of a fine, or both. The filing of the demand shall stay the enforcement of the recommendation or fine. Within fourteen (14) days after receiving the demand, the commission shall conduct a public hearing on the complaint upon at least forty-eight (48) hours' public notice of the hearing and allow both parties the opportunity to present testimony and evidence. Within seven (7) days thereafter, the commission shall publicly issue a final recommendation to the alleged violator and to the officer having authority to discipline the officer or employee or impose a fine upon the violator, or both. 
(i)  If a complaint is filed during the sixty (60) days preceding the date of any election at which the respondent is a candidate, the commission shall render its decision as required under subsection (g) within seven (7) days after the complaint is filed, and during the seven (7) days preceding that election, the commission shall render such decision before the date of that election, if possible. 
(j)  The commission may fine any person who intentionally violates any provision of section 2-333 of this division in an amount of not less than one thousand one dollars ($1,001.00) and not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The commission may fine any person who knowingly files a frivolous complaint alleging a violation of this division in an amount of not less than one thousand one dollars ($1,001.00) and not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The commission may recommend any appropriate discipline up to and including discharge. 
(k)  A complaint alleging the violation of this Act must be filed within one year after the alleged violation. 
(Ord. No. 3242, § 2, 5-10-04)  
Sec. 2-337. - Penalties. 
(a)  A person who intentionally violates any provision of section 2-332 of this division may be punished by a term of incarceration in a penal institution other than a penitentiary for a period of not more than three hundred sixty-four (364) days, and may be fined in an amount not to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(b)  A person who intentionally violates any provision of section 2-333 of this division is subject to a fine in an amount of not less than one thousand one dollars ($1,001.00) and not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(c)  Any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation of any provision of this division to the local enforcement authorities, the state's attorney or any other law enforcement official may be punished by a term of incarceration in a penal institution other than a penitentiary for a period of not more than three hundred sixty-four (364) days, and may be fined in an amount not to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(d)  A violation of section 2-332 of this division shall be prosecuted as a criminal offense by the village prosecutor by filing in the circuit court an information, or sworn complaint, charging such offense. The prosecution shall be under and conform to the rules of criminal procedure. Conviction shall require the establishment of the guilt of the defendant beyond a reasonable doubt. 
(e)  A violation of section 2-333 of this division may be prosecuted as a quasi-criminal offense by the village prosecutor, or, if an ethics commission has been created, by the commission through the designated administrative procedure. 
(f)  In addition to any other penalty that may be applicable, whether criminal or civil, an officer or employee who intentionally violates any provision of sections 2-332 or 2-333 of this division is subject to discipline or discharge. 
(Ord. No. 3242, § 2, 5-10-04)  
ARTICLE IV. - CORPORATE AUTHORITIES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— On April 19, 1977, the voters elected to elect trustees by districts pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/3-5-6. See Ord. No. 1714 adopted April 25, 1977. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-400.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2277, § 1, adopted March 28, 1988, repealed §§ 2-400.1 and 2-400.2, pertaining to districts and election of trustees, which derived from Ord. No. 1817, §§ 1—4, adopted Nov. 13, 1978. Section 2 of said Ord. No. 2277, enacted § 2-400.2 to read as herein set out.  
Sec. 2-400.2. - Election of trustees. 
The Board of Trustees of the Village of Villa Park shall consist of the President of the Village of Villa Park and six (6) trustees. Each trustee shall be a qualified elector of the Village of Villa Park and shall have resided within the corporate limits of the Village of Villa Park for at least one (1) year next preceding the trustee's election. All trustees shall be elected on a village-wide basis. Three (3) trustees shall be elected at the consolidated election held in each odd numbered year. All trustees elected shall hold office for a term of four (4) years and until their successor's are elected and have qualified. 
(Ord. No. 2277, § 2, 3-28-88) 
Note— See editor's note at § 2-400.1.  
Sec. 2-400.3. - Commencement of terms of office. 
The term of office of each municipal elected officer shall commence on date of the first regular meeting of the corporate authorities in the month of May following each general municipal election. 
(Ord. No. 2067, § 1, 4-4-83)  
Sec. 2-401. - Regular meetings. 
(a)  The regular meetings of the board of trustees shall be held on the second and fourth Mondays of each month at 7:00 p.m. in the Village Hall. 
(b)  The village clerk shall give public notice of the schedule of regular meetings at the beginning of each calendar year and shall state the regular dates, times, and places of such meetings. An agenda for each regular meeting shall be posted at Village Hall and at the location of the meeting at least forty-eight (48) hours in advance of the holding of the meeting. 
(Ord. No. 1608, § 2, 12-15-75; Ord. No. 1911, § 1, 5-19-80; Ord. No. 2355, § 1, 6-26-89; Ord. No. 3229, § 2, 3-8-04; Ord. No. 3557, § 2, 5-11-09; Ord. No. 3771, § 2, 11-11-13; Ord. No. 3987 , § 1, 8-14-17) 
State Law reference— Power of board to prescribe times and places of board meetings, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-25; public notice of meetings, Open Meetings Act, 5 ILCS 120/2.02, 120/2.03.  
Sec. 2-402. - Special meetings. 
Special meetings of the board of trustees shall be held upon call and pursuant to law upon request of the president or any three (3) or more trustees provided such request is in writing duly signed and presented to the village clerk who shall then proceed immediately to prepare notices concerning the same and cause them to be served upon the corporate authorities at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to the commencement of such meetings, except a meeting held in the event of a bona fide emergency, which notice shall also include the agenda for the special, rescheduled, or reconvened meeting. Notice of an emergency meeting shall be given as soon as practicable, but in any event prior to the holding of such meeting, to any news medium which has filed an annual request for notice under 5 ILCS 120/2.02. Such notices shall describe briefly the nature or object of the call. 
(Ord. No. 1608, § 2, 12-15-75; Ord. No. 1911, § 1, 5-19-80; Ord. No. 3557, § 2, 5-11-09) 
State Law reference— Power of board to prescribe times and places of board meetings, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-25; public notice of meetings, Open Meetings Act, 5 ILCS 120/2.02, 120/2.03.  
Sec. 2-403. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2096, § 1, adopted Dec. 5, 1983, repealed § 2-403. Said former section, relative to required voting, derived from Ord. No. 1608, § 5, adopted Dec. 15, 1975.  
Sec. 2-404. - Reserved.  
Sec. 2-405. - Reconsideration of votes. 
No vote of the board of trustees shall be reconsidered or rescinded at a special meeting, unless there are present at the special meeting as many trustees as were present when the vote was taken. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-4.  
Sec. 2-406. - Order of business. 
The following order of business shall be followed in all meetings of the board of trustees: 
(a)  At the hour selected for the meeting, the village clerk, if present, or in the clerk's absence, someone appointed to fill his/her place, shall proceed to call the roll of members, mark the adsentees and announce whether a quorum is present. If a quorum is present, the board shall be called to order, and the president shall take the chair; if the president is absent, the board shall appoint a temporary chairman. If a quorum does not appear, the meeting shall be cancelled. 
(b)  The standing order of business for all regular meetings of the board shall be: 
(1)  Call to order—Roll call. 
(2)  Pledge of allegiance. 
(3)  Public comments on agenda items. 
(4)  Amendments to the agenda. 
(5)  Proclamations. 
(6)  Consent agenda: 
a.  Minutes. 
b.  Bill listing. 
(7)  First reading on ordinances to be codified—Introduction (no vote). 
(8)  Second reading on ordinances to be codified. 
(9)  Ordinances, resolutions, motions. 
(10)  Public comments on non-agenda items. 
(11)  Village clerk's report. 
(12)  Village trustee's report. 
(13)  Village president's report. 
(14)  Village manager's report. 
(15)  Executive session, if necessary. 
(16)  Adjournment. 
(c)  Consent agenda shall be defined as those items on the board agenda which are considered routine by the village manager and village president, e.g., reports of administrative actions and proposals, approval of minutes, referral of items to committees, acceptance of reports from departmental heads, setting of dates for hearings, request for fund drives. These items so marked shall be approved, adopted, accepted, etc., by motion of the board and roll call vote. Those items approved under the heading "consent agenda" will appear in the board minutes in their proper form, i.e., resolution accepting grant, deed or easement, adoption of ordinance upon final reading, etc. Any item shall be removed from the consent agenda upon the request of any trustee or the president. Yeas and nays shall be taken by roll call vote on approval of the consent agenda and recorded in the minutes. 
(d)  At the time of consideration of approval of the agenda, upon passage of a motion by a majority of the quorum present, the agenda may be amended to add or delete specific items. If new items are added, only discussion of such items may occur during the meeting, and no action on the new items may take place until a subsequent meeting. 
(Ord. No. 1757, § 1, 11-28-77; Ord. No. 1989, § 1, 8-3-81; Ord. No. 2270, § 1, 2-8-88; Ord. No. 3323, § 2, 11-21-05; Ord. No. 3368, § 2, 7-12-06; Ord. No. 3424, § 2, 6-11-07; Ord. No. 3681, § 1, 12-19-11; Ord. No. 3771, § 1, 11-11-13; Ord. No. 3987 , § 2, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 2-407. - Decorum. 
Upon being ruled out of order a trustee shall remain quiet. The decision of the chair in such case shall be subject to Robert's Rules of Order. 
(Ord. No. 1608, § 1, 12-15-75)  
Sec. 2-408. - Public concerns and comments. 
(a)  Persons wishing to speak during any portion of a board meeting shall sign in before the start of the meeting stating name, address and topic to be discussed or identify themselves and provide their current address at the podium before beginning their comments. Speakers shall speak their position on the issue and provide any supporting documentation. The speaker shall refrain from engaging in debates, directing threats or personal attacks at the board, staff, other speakers or members of the audience. 
(b)  Members of the audience shall refrain from applauding, cheering or booing during or at the conclusion of remarks made by any speaker, staff member or member of the board. 
(c)  Groups of residents should, whenever possible, consolidate their comments and avoid repetition through the use of representative speakers. 
(d)  Persons other than the village president, the trustees, village officials or persons invited by a majority of the board present shall address the board subject to the following additional rules and regulations: 
(1)  Public comments on agenda items shall be limited to thirty (30) minutes unless extended for a time certain by a majority of the board present. All speakers shall limit their comments to no more than three (3) minutes. Speakers who are residents shall be allowed to speak before nonresidents. 
(2)  Public comments on non-agenda items shall be limited to thirty (30) minutes unless extended for a time certain by a majority of the board present. All speakers shall limit their comments to no more than three (3) minutes. 
(Ord. No. 1608, § 7, 12-15-75; Ord. No. 1989, § 2, 8-3-81; Ord. No. 2270, § 2, 2-8-88; Ord. No. 3681, § 2, 12-19-11)  
Sec. 2-409. - Compensation. 
The compensation of each trustee of the village is hereby set at three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) per year and shall be paid in twenty-six (26) bi-weekly installments. 
(Ord. No. 851, § III, 2-4-63; Ord. No. 1967, § 3, 2-16-81; Ord. No. 3065, § 2, 11-13-00) 
State Law reference— Compensation of trustees, 65 ILCS 5/5-4-1.  
Sec. 2-410. - Robert's Rules. 
Except to the extent as otherwise provided for by law the parliamentary practice and procedure to be conducted at meetings of the board of trustees shall be those rules set forth in Robert's Rules of Order. Said rules, however, may be temporarily suspended by a vote of two-thirds of the village trustees then holding office. If notice concerning the possible suspension of said rules is provided at least twenty-four (24) hours to the board of trustees, then such rules may be temporarily suspended by a majority vote of the trustees. 
(Ord. No. 1608, § 6, 12-15-75) 
State Law reference— Authority of board to determine its rules of proceedings, 65 ILCS 5/3-11-11.  
Secs. 2-411—2-420. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PRESIDENT[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— President generally, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-1—5-3-5. 
 
Sec. 2-421. - Powers and duties generally. 
(a)  The president shall be recognized as the official head of the village. He shall be so recognized by the governor for all legal purposes, and by the courts for serving civil process. He shall have all the powers and perform all the duties hereinafter set forth and as is provided by the laws of the state. 
(b)  The president shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  He shall preside at all regular or special meetings of the board of trustees, preserve order and decorum and decide points of order and in case of disturbance or disorderly conduct, order that the council chambers or meeting room be cleared by those persons causing said disturbance or disorderly conduct. 
(2)  To act as liquor commissioner, subject to state statute, and in accordance with village ordinance. 
(3)  Make all appointments to boards and commissions pursuant and according to law with the advice and consent of the trustees. 
(4)  Sign all commissions and permits granted by authority of the board of trustees and grant all licenses as provided by law. The president may revoke such licenses pursuant to law and perform such other and further acts as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 1608, § 4, 12-15-75)  
Sec. 2-422. - Right to vote. 
(a)  The president shall not vote on any ordinance, resolution or motion except: 
(1)  Where the vote of the trustees has resulted in a tie; or 
(2)  Where one-half of the trustees then holding office have voted in favor of an ordinance, resolution or motion even though there is no tie vote; or 
(3)  Where a vote greater than a majority of the corporate authorities is required by the Illinois Municipal Code to adopt an ordinance, resolution or motion. 
In each instance specified, the president shall vote. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall deprive an acting president or president pro tem from voting in his capacity as trustee, but he shall not be entitled to another vote in his capacity as acting president or president pro tem. 
(Ord. No. 1608, § 4, 12-15-75) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILSC 5/5-3-5.  
Sec. 2-423. - Veto power. 
The president shall have veto power over all ordinances, resolutions and motions: 
(1)  Which create any liability against the village, or 
(2)  Which provide for the expenditure or appropriation of its money, or 
(3)  To sell any village property. 
All ordinances, resolutions or motions passed by the village board shall be deposited with the village clerk. If the president approves of them, he shall sign them. Those of which he disapproves he shall return to the board, with his written objections, at the next regular meeting of the board occurring not less than five (5) days after their passage. The president may disapprove of any one or more sums appropriated in any ordinance, resolution or motion making an appropriation, and, if so, the remainder shall be effective. However, the president may disapprove entirely of an ordinance, resolution or motion making an appropriation. If the president fails to return any ordinance or any specified resolution or motion with his written objections, within the designated time, it shall become effective despite the absence of his signature. 
(Ord. No. 1608, § 4, 12-15-75) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-1, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-2.  
Sec. 2-424. - Reconsideration; passage over veto. 
Every resolution and motion specified in section 2-423 of this Code, and every ordinance, which is returned to the board of trustees by the president shall be reconsidered by the board. If, after such reconsideration, two-thirds of all the trustees then holding office on the village board agree to pass an ordinance, resolution or motion, notwithstanding the president's refusal to approve it, then it shall be effective. The vote on the question of passage over the president's veto shall be by yeas and nays, and shall be recorded in the journal. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-3.  
Sec. 2-425. - Compensation. 
The compensation of the president of the village is hereby set at four thousand five hundred dollars ($4,500.00) per year and shall be paid in twenty-six (26) equal biweekly installments. 
(Ord. No. 851, § I, 2-4-63; Ord. No. 1967, § 1, 2-16-81; Ord. No. 3065, § 3, 11-13-00) 
Cross reference— Compensation of president as local liquor control commissioner, § 3-203. 
State Law reference— Compensation of president, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 5-4-1.  
Sec. 2-426. - Designation of person to sign instruments. 
The mayor may designate another to affix the signature of the president to any written instrument, which is required to be signed by the president. The president shall send written notice of this designation to the board of trustees, stating the name of the person whom he has selected and, what instrument the person will have authority to sign. A written signature of the president executed by the person so designated, with the signature of the person so designated underneath, shall have attached to the notice. The notice, with the signature attached, shall be recorded in the journal of the board of trustees and then filed with the village clerk. When the signature of the president is placed on a written instrument at the direction of the president in the specified manner, the instrument, in all respects, shall be as binding on the village as if signed by the president in person. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 3-11-5.  
ARTICLE V. - VILLAGE MANAGER[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Village manager, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 5-3-7. 
 
Sec. 2-501. - Office created. 
There is hereby created the office of village manager, an administrative office of the village. 
(Ord. No. 749, § 1, 7-11-60)  
Sec. 2-502. - Appointment and term of office. 
The village manager shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees, voting jointly. He shall be the chief executive officer and administrative head of the village government, and shall be responsible for the efficient administration of all departments. He shall be appointed without regard to his political beliefs, and need not be a resident of the village when appointed. He shall be appointed solely on the basis of his proven education, training, knowledge and ability in the field of municipal administration. The village manager shall be appointed for an indefinite term. 
(Ord. No. 749, § 2, 7-11-60)  
Sec. 2-503. - Powers and duties. 
The powers and duties of the village manager shall be: 
(1)  To enforce the laws and ordinances within the village. 
(2)  To plan and direct the operation of all village departments according to the objectives described by the village president and board of trustees. He shall hire and discharge all department heads and all other village employees except those under the jurisdiction of the board of fire and police commissioners, at such compensation as set by the board. All employees shall perform their duties subject to the direction of the village manager or that of the superior designated by the manager. The village manager shall perform all of his duties subject to the control and direction of the village president and board of trustees. 
(3)  To prepare and submit to the board of trustees an annual budget pursuant to ILCS 65, 5/8-2-9.3 and have said budget adopted pursuant to ILCS 65, 5/8-2-9.4. 
(4)  To attend all meetings of the board of trustees with the right to take part in the discussions, but with no right to vote. 
(5)  To recommend to the board of trustees for the adoption of such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient. 
(6)  To enforce the faithful performance of all contracts or public utility franchises so that the village and its inhabitants will receive full benefits thereunder. 
(7)  To make, in the ordinary course of business, all purchases of equipment, material and supplies necessary for the village as provided for in the annual appropriation ordinance; provided, that on purchases in excess of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), he shall first procure the approval of the board of trustees. In all cases he shall comply with all applicable statutory and ordinance provisions regarding contracts or purchase orders and shall submit all expenditures for payment to the board of trustees. 
(8)  To cause to be prepared and submit to the board of trustees each month a statement of the financial condition of the village as of the end of the preceding month. 
(9)  To have and exercise the power, authority and duties of any head or director of a department or division thereof prescribed by this Code or any amendment thereof, during the time when the office of any such department or division shall be vacant. 
(10)  To issue all licenses and permits, authority for issuance of which is not otherwise provided for by the statutes of the state. 
(11)  To prescribe rules and regulations for the conduct of the various departments of the village and the divisions thereunder. 
(12)  To devote full time to the performance of his duties. The manager shall not engage in any other gainful employment or business while he holds the office of village manager. 
(13)  To perform such other duties as may be required by him by ordinance or resolution or as directed by the president or the board of trustees, to the end that the policies of the board shall be faithfully and efficiently administered. 
(14)  To suspend, without pay, a department head, chief of the police department, or chief of the fire department for a period of not more than five (5) days, but he shall notify the corporate authorities in writing of such suspension. During the term of any suspension made by the village manager, the village manager may appoint an acting department head, chief of the police department, or chief of the fire department to carry out the duties of the suspended officer. 
(15)  To have the authority to dispose of personal property or equipment that is no longer necessary or useful to the Village of Villa Park and that has little or no resale value. 
(Ord. No. 749, § 4, 7-11-60; Ord. No. 1968, § 1, 2-23-81; Ord. No. 2511, § 5, 8-5-91; Ord. No. 2762, § 2, 4-10-95; Ord. No. 3334, § 2, 1-23-06; Ord. No. 3667, § 2, 8-22-11; Ord. No. 4005 , § 2, 12-4-17)  
Sec. 2-504. - Absence or disability. 
During the absence or disability of the manager, the president by and with the consent of the board of trustees, may designate some properly qualified person to perform the duties of his office. 
(Ord. No. 749, § 2, 7-11-60) 
State Law reference— Absence or disability of manager, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-7.  
Sec. 2-505. - Removal. 
The village manager may be removed from office at any time by a majority vote of the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 749, § 2, 7-11-60) 
State Law reference— Removal of manager, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-7.  
ARTICLE VI. - VILLAGE ATTORNEY 
 
Sec. 2-601. - Generally. 
There is hereby created and established the office of attorney for the village. The village attorney shall be the head of the village's in-house legal department and under the supervision and control of the village manager, and shall be responsible and report directly to the manager. The village attorney shall be appointed by the village manager and may be removed from office by the manager with the advice and consent of a majority of the corporate authorities. He shall be appointed solely on the basis of his proven education, training, knowledge and ability in the field of law. 
(Ord. No. 2633, § 1, 5-17-93) 
State Law reference— President to appoint city attorney with advice and consent of board of trustees, 65 ILCS 5/3-7-3.  
Sec. 2-602. - Suits and actions. 
The attorney for the village shall prosecute or defend any and all suits or actions at law or equity to which the village may be a party, or in which it may be interested, or which may be brought against, or by, an officer of the village on behalf of the village, or in the capacity of such person as an officer of the village. 
(Ord. No. 1142, § 2, 9-15-69)  
Sec. 2-603. - Judgment and orders. 
It shall be the duty of the attorney for the village to see the full enforcement of all judgments, decrees or awards rendered or entered in favor of the village, and of all similar interlocutory orders. 
(Ord. No. 1142, § 3, 9-15-69)  
Sec. 2-604. - Legal advice. 
The attorney for the village shall be the legal advisor of the village, and shall render advice on all legal questions affecting the village, whenever requested to do so by any elected village official or the village manager or the presiding officer of any official board or commission. Upon specific request by the president, the manager or any trustee, he shall reduce any such opinion to writing. 
(Ord. No. 1142, § 4, 9-15-69)  
Sec. 2-605. - Special assessments and condemnations. 
It shall be the duty of the attorney for the village to see the completion of all special assessment proceedings and condemnation proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 1142, § 6, 9-15-69)  
Sec. 2-606. - Ordinances and documents. 
It shall be the duty of the attorney for the village to draft or supervise the drafting, and/or to approve as to form any contract, lease or other document or instrument to which the village may be a party. Upon request by the board of trustees, he shall draft ordinances covering any subjects, as required. 
(Ord. No. 1142, § 7, 9-15-69)  
Sec. 2-607. - Compensation. 
The compensation of the village attorney shall be as established by the village board following recommendation to the board by the village manager. 
(Ord. No. 1686, § 8, 1-10-77; Ord. No. 2633, § 2, 5-17-93)  
Sec. 2-608. - Additional counsel. 
The village manager may employ or may authorize the attorney for the village to employ additional counsel to aid the village in its affairs whenever they deem it necessary or expedient. 
(Ord. No. 1142, § 5, 9-15-69)  
ARTICLE VII. - VILLAGE CLERK 
 
Sec. 2-701. - Selection. 
The village clerk shall be elected. 
Editor's note— As the village was apparently subject to the aldermanic form of government at the time of adoption of the managerial form, the village clerk apparently is to be elected and is not to be appointed by the manager. See Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 5-3-7(4).  
Sec. 2-702. - Compensation. 
The compensation of the village clerk of the village is hereby set at three thousand five hundred ($3,500.00) dollars per year and shall be paid in twenty-six (26) equal biweekly installments. 
(Ord. No. 851, § II, 2-4-63; Ord. No. 1967, § 2, 2-16-81; Ord. No. 3065, § 4, 11-13-00) 
State Law reference— Salary of clerk, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 3-13-2.  
Sec. 2-703. - Functions. 
The duties and privileges of the village clerk shall be as follows: 
(a)  To provide and perform all duties and functions provided for by law, including, but not limited to, those duties and functions as set forth in Articles 3 and 5 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(b)  To attend the following meetings: 
(1)  All regular and special meetings of the corporate authorities. 
(2)  All executive sessions which are called during any meeting which the clerk is otherwise required to attend. 
(3)  All public meetings called by the corporate authorities. 
(4)  All meetings of the board of local improvements. 
(5)  Such other meetings as the corporate authorities may direct, but not including attendance at committee of the whole meetings of the corporate authorities. 
The clerk shall take minutes of such meetings and transcribe them and distribute and disburse them as directed by the corporate authorities prior to the next scheduled meeting of the corporate authorities. 
(c)  To provide the village manager's office upon request with appropriate documentation which are in the clerk's possession including but not necessarily limited to certified copies of minutes, certified copies of ordinances, certified copies of resolutions and agreements, and certified and noncertified copies or originals of such other documents as may be requested. The manager's office shall provide for the distribution of said copies. The clerk shall refrain from directly dispersing and distributing said copies except through the manager's office as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 1608, § 8, 12-15-75; Ord. No. 3390, § 2, 10-16-06) 
State Law reference— Duties of clerk generally, 65 ILCS 5/5-10-7.  
Sec. 2-704. - Deputy village clerk. 
(a)  Appointment. The village clerk is hereby authorized from time to time to appoint a deputy village clerk for such period or term within the term of office of the village clerk as the village clerk shall determine. Such appointment shall be evidenced by a written certificate of appointment, a copy of which shall be presented to the board of trustees and shall be made a matter of record. 
(b)  Duties. 
(1)  The deputy village clerk may execute any document required by law to be executed by the village clerk and may affix the seal of the clerk wherever required. In signing any document, the deputy village clerk shall sign the name of the clerk followed with the word "By" and the deputy clerk's own name and the words "deputy clerk." 
(2)  The deputy village clerk shall, in the absence of the village clerk, perform the duties set forth in 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90 and in section 2-703 of the Villa Park Code. Such powers shall be exercised only in the absence of the village clerk from the office and only when either written direction has been given by the clerk to the deputy clerk to exercise a power or the president and board of trustees have determined by resolution that the village clerk is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to perform that function. 
(Ord. No. 3367, § 2, 7-10-06)  
ARTICLE VIII. - VILLAGE TREASURER 
 
Sec. 2-801. - Position established. 
There is hereby established the position of village treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 240, § 1, 5-21-28)  
Sec. 2-802. - Selection. 
The village treasurer shall be appointed by the village manager with the consent of the trustees. 
Editor's note— As the village apparently was subject to the aldermanic form of government at the time of the adoption of the managerial form of government and the treasurer previously had been appointed by the corporate authorities ( See 65 ILCS 5/3-8-1) the manager now appoints the treasurer. See 65 ILCS 5/5-3-7(4)).  
Sec. 2-803. - Supervision and control. 
The village treasurer shall be under the supervision and control of the village manager and shall be responsible, and report directly, to the manager. 
(Ord. No. 1504, § 1, 10-21-74)  
Sec. 2-804. - Service as finance officer. 
The village treasurer and village finance officer may be the same person. 
(Ord. No. 1504, § 2, 10-21-74)  
Sec. 2-805. - Functions generally. 
(a)  The village treasurer shall receive all money belonging to the village, and shall keep his books and accounts in the manner prescribed by ordinance. These books and accounts shall always be subject to the inspection of any member of the corporate authorities. 
(b)  He shall keep a separate account of each fund or appropriation, and the debits and credits belonging thereto. 
(c)  He shall give every person paying money into the treasury a receipt therefor, specifying the date of payment, and upon what account paid. He shall file copies of these receipts with the clerk, with his monthly reports. If he has in his possession money properly appropriated to the payment of any warrant lawfully drawn upon him he shall pay the money specified in this warrant to the person designated by the warrant. 
(Ord. No. 351, § 1, 7-5-35) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 3-10-1.  
Sec. 2-806. - Monthly statements and register of warrants. 
At the end of every month, and oftener if required by the corporate authorities, the village treasurer shall render an account under oath to the corporate authorities, or to such officer as may be designated by ordinance, showing the state of the treasury at the date of the account, and the balance of money in the treasury. He shall accompany the account with a statement of all money received into the treasury, and on what account, together with all warrants redeemed and paid by him. On the day he renders an account, these warrants, with all vouchers held by him, shall be delivered to the municipal clerk and filed, together with the account, in the clerk's office. He shall return all warrants paid by him marked "paid." He shall keep a register of all warrants, which shall describe each warrant, showing its date, amount and number, the fund from which paid, the name of the person to whom paid, and when paid. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 3-10-2.  
Sec. 2-807. - Personal use of funds. 
The village treasurer shall keep all money belonging to the municipality in his custody separate and distinct from his own money, and he shall not use, either directly or indirectly, the village's money or warrants in his custody for his own use and benefit, or that of any other person. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 3-10-4.  
Sec. 2-808. - Annual statement. 
(a)  Within six (6) months after the end of the fiscal year, the village treasurer shall annually prepare and file with the village clerk an account of all monies received and expenditures incurred during the preceding fiscal year as required by Section 3.1-35-65 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(b)  Upon receipt of such account from the village treasurer, the village clerk shall publish the account at least once, in one or more newspapers published in the village, or, if no newspaper is published therein, then in one or more newspapers having a general circulation within the village. 
(c)  Within six (6) months after the end of each fiscal year the treasurer shall file with each town or county collector of taxes who collects taxes levied by the village, a copy of such annual account, together with an affidavit of the clerk of such village stating that such copy is a true and correct copy of such annual account filed with him, that it was published as required by Section 3.1-35-65 of the Illinois Municipal Code, the date of such filing and publication, and the newspaper in which it was published. 
(Ord. No. 351, § 1, 7-5-35; Ord. No. 4025 , § 6, 4-23-18) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, §§ 3-10-5.1, 3-10-5.2.  
Sec. 2-809. - Special assessment funds. 
All money received on any special assessment shall be held by the village treasurer as a special fund, to be applied to the payment of the improvement for which the assessment was made, and the money shall be used for no other purpose, except to reimburse the village for money expended for such improvement. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 3-10-6.  
ARTICLE IX. - VILLAGE COLLECTOR 
 
Sec. 2-901. - Duties. 
The duties of the village collector and deputy village collector shall be as follows: 
(a)  To preserve all warrants returned to him. 
(b)  To keep and preserve all books and accounts in the manner as the corporate authorities may prescribe. 
(c)  To make available for examination and inspection by the corporate authorities all warrants, books and vouchers and all papers and documents concerning the office of collector or deputy collector. 
(d)  To weekly or oftener if required by the president and board of trustees to pay over to the village treasurer all money collected by him from any source whatsoever. 
(e)  To take the village treasurer's receipt for said deposits in duplicate and file one (1) of said receipts immediately with the village clerk. 
(f)  To make written reports to the corporate authorities of all money collected by him as the corporate authorities may designate. 
(g)  To file those statutory statements required pursuant to law and otherwise to perform those general duties associated with said office. 
(Ord. No. 1259, § 5, 8-9-71)  
Sec. 2-902. - Compensation of collector and deputy collector. 
The village collector shall receive the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per month as compensation and the deputy village collector shall receive no compensation or salary for said position. 
(Ord. No. 1259, § 4, 8-9-71)  
ARTICLE X. - PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR 
 
Sec. 2-1001. - Position established. 
There is hereby established by the position of public works director. 
(Ord. No. 1923, § 1, 8-18-80; Ord. No. 2619, § 1, 2-8-93)  
Sec. 2-1002. - Appointment and qualifications. 
The public works director shall be appointed by the village manager. He shall be appointed solely on the basis of his proven education, training, knowledge, and ability in the field of public works. 
(Ord. No. 1923, § 2, 8-18-80; Ord. No. 2619, § 2, 2-8-93)  
Sec. 2-1003. - Functions. 
The public works director shall be subject to the supervision of the village manager and shall direct the operation and maintenance of the water supply and distribution system, sanitary sewer system, storm sewer system, drainage facilities, streets, sidewalks, street lighting, forestry section, vehicle and equipment garage, public buildings and grounds, and all other matters that may be delegated to him by the village manager. 
(Ord. No. 1923, § 3, 8-18-80; Ord. No. 2619, § 3, 2-8-93) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 21; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 25.  
ARTICLE XI. - VILLAGE ENGINEER[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 21; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 25; zoning, App. C. 
 
Sec. 2-1101. - Position established. 
There is hereby established the position of village engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1924, § 1, 8-18-80)  
Sec. 2-1102. - Appointment. 
The village engineer shall be appointed by the village manager. He shall be appointed solely on the basis of his proven education, training, knowledge, and ability in the field of civil engineering. 
(Ord. No. 1924, § 2, 8-18-80; Ord. No. 2619, § 4, 2-8-93)  
Sec. 2-1103. - Functions. 
The village engineer shall perform the following functions under the direction and supervision of the public works director: 
(a)  Maintain village zoning, street, and utility maps. 
(b)  Prepare or review study and design reports, cost estimates, construction plans, and specifications for improvements or extensions to the village street, water, sewer, and drainage systems. 
(c)  Monitor and inspect the construction of all improvements or extension to the village street, water, sewer, and drainage systems. 
(d)  Assist the community development department by reviewing building site development plans for drainage, utility connections, and driveway access. 
(e)  Any other duties or responsibilities assigned by the village manager or public works director. 
(f)  The village engineer shall also be the assistant public works director and act as the director in this absence, at the discretion of the village manager. 
(Ord. No. 1924, § 4, 8-18-80) 
Editor's note— Section 5 of Ord. No. 2619, adopted Feb. 8, 1993, repealed § 2-1103, which pertained to qualifications of the village engineer and derived from Ord. No. 1924, § 3, adopted Aug. 18, 1980 and renumbered § 2-1104 as § 2-1103.  
ARTICLE XII. - BUDGET OFFICER 
 
Sec. 2-1201. - Office created. 
There is hereby created the office of the budget officer. 
(Ord. No. 2762, § 3, 4-10-95)  
Sec. 2-1202. - Designation, term and removal. 
The president shall, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, designate a village budget officer, who shall serve for an indefinite term at the pleasure of the president. The village budget officer may be removed at any time, with or without cause, by the president. 
(Ord. No. 2762, § 3, 4-10-95)  
Sec. 2-1203. - Qualifications. 
The village budget officer shall be, at the time of designation, a person having knowledge and experience of accepted practices in respect of municipal finance, budgeting, and accounting, and particularly, in respect of the functions and duties of the office, as hereinafter specified. The village budget officer may hold another village office or position, either elected or appointed. 
(Ord. No. 2762, § 3, 4-10-95)  
Sec. 2-1204. - Oath, bond. 
The village budget officer, before entering upon the duties of the office, shall take the oath prescribed by law, and shall execute and file with the village clerk a surety bond to the village in a penal sum determined by the president and board of trustees at the time of designation. The cost of such bond shall be paid by the village. 
(Ord. No. 2762, § 3, 4-10-95)  
Sec. 2-1205. - Powers and duties. 
The village budget officer shall have the powers and duties provided by state law to prepare the budget for each fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 2762, § 3, 4-10-95; Ord. No. 4025 , § 4, 4-23-18)  
ARTICLE XIII. - PARKS AND RECREATION ADVISORY COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 2-1301. - Created. 
There is hereby created the Villa Park Parks and Recreation Advisory Commission. 
(Ord. No. 3518, § 2, 11-10-08)  
Sec. 2-1302. - Intent and purpose. 
It shall be the intent and purpose of the parks and recreation advisory commission to advise the village board of trustees on matters relating to the administration, operation and conditions of recreation programs; and to advise the board of trustees on matters relating to facilities, including the recreation buildings, swim pools, skate park, playgrounds, etc.; and to discuss and advise the board of trustees on issues referred to the commission by the board of trustees; and to assist the director of parks and recreation and other staff on developing and maintaining comprehensive recreation programs and opportunities for the village residents. 
(Ord. No. 3518, § 2, 11-10-08)  
Sec. 2-1303. - Membership. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall consist of seven (7) members all of whom shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees and shall serve without compensation. The members of the commission shall be residents of the village. Members shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years with the terms of three (3) members expiring in the same year and the terms of four (4) members expiring the next year. The director of parks and recreation shall serve as the liaison to the commission, but shall not be a voting member of the commission. 
(b)  All appointments shall expire the thirtieth of April of the appropriate year. Any member of the commission may resign at any time during the term for which they were appointed, which resignation shall be in the manner provided in section 2-1403. Vacancies on the commission shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose position becomes vacant in the manner provided herein. 
(c)  If any member of the commission shall cease to maintain the status qualifying him for appointment to the commission, or shall fail to attend three (3) consecutive meetings of the commission without being excused by a vote of a majority of the members of the commission, such member may be considered as having resigned his membership. Report of such change of status or failure of attendance may be reported to the corporate authorities and, if such report is accepted by the corporate authorities, the membership in question shall be declared vacant and it shall be the duty of the president to appoint a qualified successor to such membership in the manner provided herein. Any member of the commission may be removed for cause by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 3518, § 2, 11-10-08; Ord. No. 3626, § 2, 11-8-10; Ord. No. 4089 , § 1, 6-24-19)  
Sec. 2-1304. - Officers. 
(a)  Annually in April a chair, vice-chair and secretary of the commission created herein shall be elected by the members of the commission for a term of one (1) year. 
(b)  Should any office become vacant before the end of its term the commission shall elect a successor by the second subsequent commission meeting after the vacancy was created. 
(c)  The chair, vice-chair and secretary shall serve no more than two (2) consecutive terms in their respective offices unless at least one (1) year has elapsed since their previous term ended. Nothing in this article shall deprive the chair, vice-chair or secretary of any duties or obligations as a commission member. 
(Ord. No. 3518, § 2, 11-10-08; Ord. No. 3626, § 2, 11-8-10)  
Sec. 2-1305. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the commission created herein shall be held at least monthly on a certain day and time as determined by the chairperson. 
(b)  Special meetings of the commission may be called by the chairperson or any two (2) voting members with at least forty-eight (48) hours' written notice prior to the special meeting. Notice of any special meeting shall be provided in accordance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act and shall be posted in the Village Hall. 
(c)  The action of a majority of the members present at a meeting at which a quorum is present shall be the action of the members. 
(d)  The presence of four (4) commission members shall constitute a quorum to transact any commission business at a regular or special meeting of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 3518, § 2, 11-10-08)  
Sec. 2-1306. - Expenditures. 
The commission created herein may recommend to the village board the expenditure of such monies as they deem appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 3518, § 2, 11-10-08)  
Sec. 2-1307. - Reports and records. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall keep permanent minutes of its meetings, which shall include topics discussed and the motions and vote of each member upon each topic submitted to it. 
(b)  The commission shall prepare and submit approved minutes of each meeting within a reasonable time after each of its meetings, and the chairperson shall forward copies of the minutes, together with any special reports regarding matters or issues of concern to the village board of trustees and village manager. The commission shall prepare an annual report covering the commission's activities each year in April. 
(Ord. No. 3518, § 2, 11-10-08; Ord. No. 3626, § 2, 11-8-10)  
Sec. 2-1308. - Task force. 
The parks and recreation advisory commission may recommend to the village board of trustees the formation of a task force, which shall operate under the direction and oversight of the commission. 
(a)  A task force shall be a subcommittee formed with the approval of the board of trustees for the purpose of assisting the commission and/or village staff in analysis, research/study or assistance with special projects, programs or assignments given by or approved by the board of trustees. 
(b)  A task force membership shall be comprised of volunteer residents or business residents who have the expertise, skills, talents and/or resources applicable to the purpose of the task force. 
(c)  A task force shall be formed for a predetermined period of time, which may be extended by the board of trustees. Members of the task force shall be appointed by the parks and recreation advisory commission, all of whom shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 3626, § 2, 11-8-10)  
ARTICLE XIV. - APPOINTED BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
 
Sec. 2-1401. - Identification cards. 
The village clerk shall issue to each duly appointed member of each board and commission of the Village established by the provisions of state law or municipal ordinance an identification card containing the following information: photo of commission member, name of commission member, commission name and expiration date of the commissioner's term. A registry of each identification card issued and of the signature of each member and commissioner shall be maintained by the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 3396, § 2, 10-23-06; Ord. No. 3441, § 2, 10-8-07)  
Sec. 2-1402. - Swearing in. 
Each duly appointed member of each board and commission of the village established by the provisions of state law or municipal ordinance shall be sworn in at the meeting of the village board where his/her appointment is made by the president and consented to by the village board or at a prearranged time and place within thirty (30) days of such meeting. 
(Ord. No. 3396, § 2, 10-23-06; Ord. No. 3441, § 3, 10-8-07)  
Sec. 2-1403. - Resignation from village board or commission. 
Upon resignation from a village board or commission, the commission/board member shall forward a letter of resignation to the village president reflecting the effective date of such resignation. The board or commission member's identification card as described in section 2-1401 and any other indicia of office shall be returned to the village president or the village clerk prior to the effective date of such resignation. 
(Ord. No. 3441, § 4, 10-8-07)  
ARTICLE XV. - LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS 
 
Sec. 2-1501. - Generally. 
In making a local improvement by special assessment, the board of local improvements and the corporate authorities shall follow the procedures as set forth in Division 2 of Article 9 of the Illinois Municipal Code as amended from time to time. The board of local improvements and the corporate authorities shall have all of the dues and powers set forth in such Division 2. 
(Ord. No. 1731, § 2, 8-15-77; Ord. No. 2267, § 1, 12-28-87; Ord. No. 2400, § 1, 3-19-90)  
Sec. 2-1502. - Board of local improvements. 
(a)  There is hereby created a board of local improvements consisting of three (3) members as follows: 
(1)  The president; 
(2)  Six (6) trustees; 
(b)  The village clerk shall be a nonvoting member who shall act as secretary of the board. 
(c)  Three (3) nonvoting members as follows: 
(1)  The village engineer; 
(2)  Two (2) members of the planning and zoning commission, both of whom shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
These three (3) nonvoting members shall merely advise and assist the board. 
(d)  There shall be such other nonvoting members as may be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 1731, § 1, 8-15-77; Ord. No. 2177, § 2, 3-3-86; Ord. No. 2267, § 2, 12-28-87; Ord. No. 2400, § 1, 3-19-90)  
ARTICLE XVI. - ZONING AND PLANNING COMMISSION[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2177, adopted March 3, 1986, provided that the "functions of planning and enforcement of the zoning regulations" be combined in "a single body serving both functions," thereby created a zoning and planning commission in lieu of the plan commission and the zoning board of appeals. The provisions of Ord. No. 2177, have been included herein as superseding Art. XVI, relative to the plan commission, and Art. XVII, relating to the zoning board of appeals, with the exception of §§ 2-1607 and 2-1702 which have been renumbered §§ 2-1605 and 2-1607, respectively. Former Art. XVI was derived from Ord. No. 1165, §§ 1, 3, 5—7, adopted Jan. 5, 1970. Art. XVII was derived from Ord. No. 1195, § 6.3(A), (C), (D), adopted Sept. 28, 1970. 
As pages in the Code are necessarily reprinted, reference to the "plan commission" and the "zoning board of appeals" will be changed to "zoning and planning commission," as provided in § 2 of Ord. No. 2177. 
Cross reference— Rules of construction and definitions, § 1-102; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; planning and development, Ch. 18; planning and zoning guidelines, § 18-201 et seq.; official plan and subdivision regulations, App. B; basic zoning ordinance, App. C; function of zoning and planning commission under zoning ordinance, App. C, § 6.4; floodplain zoning, App. D. 
 
Sec. 2-1601. - Created; designated zoning board of appeals. 
There is hereby established a zoning and planning commission for the village which shall also be known as the zoning board of appeals. Any reference in this Code or any appendix thereto to the "planning and zoning commission" for the village shall be a reference to the commission duly created and authorized under the provisions of this Article XVI and shall also mean the zoning and planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 2177, § 1, 3-3-86; Ord. No. 2725, § 1, 8-22-94)  
Sec. 2-1602. - Membership. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall consist of nine (9) members including the chairperson, appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, to serve without compensation. To be eligible to serve on the commission, persons shall be qualified electors of the village who have resided therein for one (1) year immediately preceding their appointment. Members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years, except that the members first appointed to the commission shall serve as follows: three (3) for one (1) year, three (3) for two (2) years and three (3) for three (3) years. 
(b)  All appointments shall expire the thirtieth (30th) of April of the appropriate year. Any member of the commission may resign at any time during the term for which he/she was appointed, which resignation shall be addressed to the village president. Vacancies on the commission shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose position becomes vacant in the manner provided herein. 
(c)  If any member of the commission shall cease to maintain the status qualifying him for appointment to the commission, or shall fail to attend three (3) consecutive meetings of the commission without being excused by a vote of a majority of the members of the commission, such absence shall be considered as cause for termination of commission membership. Report of such change of status or failure of attendance may be reported to the corporate authorities and, if such report is accepted by the corporate authorities, the membership in question shall be declared vacant and it shall be the duty of the president to appoint a qualified successor to such membership in the manner provided herein. Any member of the commission may be removed for cause by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2177, § 1(B), 3-3-86; Ord. No. 2983, § 2, 4-19-99; Ord. No. 3474, § 2, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-1603. - Officers. 
A chairman of the commission created herein shall be elected by the members of the commission for a term of two (2) years. The commission may designate one (1) of its members to act as secretary, together with such other officers as it deems fit. 
(Ord. No. 2177, § 1(C), 3-3-86; Ord. No. 3474, § 3, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-1604. - Powers and duties generally. 
The zoning and planning commission hereby created shall have the powers and duties designated by 65 ILCS 5/11-12-4 et seq. and 5/11-13-1 et seq., and as specified by ordinance in section 2-1605, as to planning, and in section 2-1607 as to zoning. 
(Ord. No. 2177, § 1(A), 3-3-86)  
Sec. 2-1605. - Planning powers of the commission. 
The zoning and planning commission shall have the power: 
(1)  To prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities a comprehensive plan for the present and future development or redevelopment of the village. Such plan may be developed in whole or in separate geographical or functional parts, each of which, when adopted, shall be the official comprehensive plan, or part thereof, of the municipality. This plan may include reasonable requirements with reference to streets, alleys, public grounds and other improvements hereinafter specified. The plan, as recommended by the zoning and planning commission and as thereafter adopted by ordinance may be made applicable, by the terms thereof, to land situated within the corporate limits and contiguous territory not more than one and one-half (1½) miles beyond the corporate limits and not included in any municipality. The zoning and planning commission may implement such plan by recommending such ordinances: 
(a)  Establishing reasonable standards of design for subdivisions and for resubdivisions of unimproved land and of areas subject to redevelopment in respect to public improvements as herein defined; 
(b)  Establishing reasonable requirements governing the location, width, course and surfacing of public streets and highways, alleys, ways for public service facilities, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, street lights, parks, playgrounds, school grounds, size of lots to be used for residential purposes, storm water drainage, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers, and sewage collection and treatment. 
The zoning and planning commission may also implement such plan by designating land suitable for annexation to the village and the recommending zoning classification for such land upon annexation. 
(2)  To recommend changes, from time to time, in the official comprehensive plan. 
(3)  To conduct hearings and thereafter make recommendations to the corporate authorities as required on matters referred to the zoning and planning commission including, but not limited to: 
(a)  Applications for zoning amendments; 
(b)  Applications for special use permits; 
(c)  Annexation agreements; 
(4)  To prepare and commend to the corporate authorities, from time to time, plans for specific improvements in pursuance of the official comprehensive plan. 
(5)  To give aid to the village officials charged with the direction of projects for improvement embraced within the official plan and, generally, to promote the realization of the official plan. 
(6)  To exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted by state law as may be conferred by the corporate authorities. 
(7)  To adopt rules and regulations regarding all matters coming before it which are not inconsistent with this Code, any appendix thereto, or any provision of state law, except that any rule or regulation which may have an impact upon services to be furnished by employees of the village shall not be adopted except following a recommendation of the director of community development. 
(8)  To conduct a development concept review upon the request of an applicant. The purpose of the concept review is to allow the applicant to broadly acquaint the commission with the applicant's development proposal and to provide the applicant with any preliminary views, concerns or recommendations that the members of the commission may have with respect to the proposed development. 
(a)  Not less than ten (10) days prior to the commission meeting, the director of community development shall mail a notice by first class mail to the owners of property within two hundred fifty (250) feet of the proposed project site, excluding public rights-of-way. This notice shall include the date, time and place of the commission meeting where the concept plan is to be reviewed and shall include a general description of the proposed development. The information shall also be mailed to the park and school districts in which the property is located and to other persons or entities that may have jurisdiction over the project. 
(b)  Upon completion of the commission's concept review process, the applicant may request a similar review by the village board of trustees. 
(c)  Any views expressed during the course of the review of any development concept shall be deemed to be preliminary and advisory only, and only the individual view of the member expressing them. Nothing said or done during the course of such review shall be deemed to create or to prejudice any rights of the applicant or to obligate the village, or any representative of it, to approve or deny any formal application following full consideration thereof as required by the Municipal Code of the village. 
(Ord. No. 2177, § 2, 3-3-86; Ord. No. 2725, § 2, 8-22-94; Ord. No. 3499, § 2, 7-28-08)  
Sec. 2-1606. - Jurisdiction generally. 
The zoning and planning commission shall have the jurisdiction as to planning as set forth in section 2-1605. The zoning and planning commission shall have the jurisdiction sitting as the zoning board of appeals as set forth in section 2-1607. 
(Ord. No. 2177, § 1(D), 3-3-86)  
Sec. 2-1607. - Zoning authority and jurisdiction. 
The zoning and planning commission is hereby vested with the following jurisdiction and authority: 
(1)  To hear and recommend appeals from any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the building commissioner under this ordinance, in the manner and subject to the standards set out in Section 6.3C of the zoning ordinance.
