(2)  To hear and recommend upon applications for variations from the terms provided in this ordinance in the manner and subject to the standards set out in Section 6.7B of the zoning ordinance. 
(3)  To hear and pass upon all matters upon which it is required to hear under the zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1195, § 6.3(B), 9-28-70; Ord. No. 2177, § 2, 3-3-86)  
Sec. 2-1608. - Meetings and rules of procedure. 
Meetings shall be regularly held the second Thursday evening of each month at 7:30 p.m.; and in addition, the zoning and planning commission shall hold meetings at the call of the chairperson and at such other times as such commission or the corporate authorities may determine. All hearings required by this article to be conducted by said commission shall be open to the public. Any person may appear and testify at a hearing, either in person or by duly authorized agent or attorney. All testimony shall be given under oath. The chairperson or vice-chairperson, or his or her designate, shall administer oaths and may compel the attendance of witnesses. The commission shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member upon each question, or if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact. No hearing shall be held without a quorum of the commission being present which shall consist of a majority of the members. Any formerly absent member who certifies that he or she has read the transcript of the proceedings before the commission may vote upon any question presently before the commission. 
Every rule or regulation, every amendment or repeal thereof, and every order, requirements decision or determination of the commission shall be filed immediately in the office of the building commissioner and shall be a public record. The commission shall adopt its own rules of procedure not in conflict with this article or with village resolutions and ordinances or with Illinois Statutes, and may select or appoint such other officers as it deems necessary. 
The concurring vote of five (5) members of the commission shall be necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision, or determination of an administrative official, or to decide in favor of an applicant any matter upon which it is required to pass under this article or the village basic zoning ordinance or to affect any variation or to recommend any variation or modification in the basic zoning ordinance of this article to the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. No. 2177, § 1(E), 3-3-86; Ord. No. 2725, § 3, 8-22-94; Ord. No. 3474, § 4, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-1609. - Recommendations of the commission. 
All recommendations and findings of the zoning and planning commission shall be forwarded to the village board within fifteen (15) days of the action, except those pertaining to preliminary development and final development plans or plats of subdivision for which the specified times for recommendation shall be thirty (30) and sixty (60) days, respectively, and further excepting recommendations as to the zoning of annexed areas which shall be submitted within six (6) months of the effective date of annexation. Such recommendations are advisory only and are not binding upon the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. No. 2177, § 1(F), 3-3-86)  
Sec. 2-1610. - Records; publication. 
The zoning and planning commission shall submit such recommendations in writing to the president and board of trustees, within fifteen (15) days of any public hearing or public meeting where such recommendation is required. The commission shall keep written records of its proceedings, which shall be available at the Village Hall for public inspection during ordinary business hours. 
(Ord. No. 2177, § 1(G), 3-3-86)  
Sec. 2-1611. - Annual report. 
The chairman of the zoning and planning commission shall report annually, by April 30 of each year, in writing, to the corporate authorities, setting forth the work of such commission for the preceding year. 
(Ord. No. 2177, § 1(H), 3-3-86)  
ARTICLE XVIII. - FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSION[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference— Fire department, § 9-301 et seq.; police department, Ch. 19. 
 
Sec. 2-1801. - Created. 
There is hereby created a board of fire and police commissioners.  
Sec. 2-1802. - Members—Generally. 
(a)  The board of fire and police commissioners shall consist of three (3) members appointed by the president with the consent of the board of trustees for terms of office of three (3) years and until their respective successors are appointed and have qualified, except as otherwise provided. No such appointment, however, shall be made by any president within thirty (30) days before the expiration of his term of office. 
(b)  Vacancies on the board of fire and police commissioners shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, §§ 10-2.1-1, 10-2.1.2.  
Sec. 2-1803. - Same—Qualifications, oath, removal, etc. 
(a)  The members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall be considered officers of the village, and shall file an oath and a fidelity bond in such amount as may be required by the corporate authorities. 
(b)  No person holding a lucrative office under the United States, this state or any political subdivision thereof, or a municipality, shall be a member of the board of fire and police commissioners or the secretary thereof. The acceptance of any such lucrative office by a member of the board shall be treated as a resignation of his office as a member of the board or the secretary thereof. No person shall be appointed a member of the board of fire and police commissioners who is related, either by blood or marriage up to the degree of first cousin, to any elected official of such municipality. No more than two (2) members of the board shall belong to the same political party existing in such municipality at the time of such appointments and as defined in Section 10-2 of The Election Code. If only one or no political party exists in such municipality at the time of such appointments, then state or national political party affiliations shall be considered in making such appointments. Party affiliation shall be determined by affidavit of the person appointed as a member of the board. 
(c)  A member shall not be subject to removal, except for cause, upon written charges, and after an opportunity to be heard within thirty (30) days in his own defense, before a regular meeting of the corporate authorities. A majority vote of the elected members of the corporate authorities shall be required to remove any such member from office. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 10-2.1-3.  
Sec. 2-1804. - Appointment of firemen and policemen. 
The board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all officers and members of the fire and police departments, except the chief of police, the deputy chief(s) of police, and the chief of the fire department, which appointments shall be made as provided by law and in the number of officers and in the rank thereof as may be provided from time to time by the village. 
(Ord. No. 3664, § 2, 7-25-11) 
State Law reference— Power to make appointments, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-2.1-4.  
Sec. 2-1805. - Promotions generally. 
All promotional appointments made by the board of fire and police commissioners shall be made from the next lowest rank. 
State Law reference— Promotion from next lowest rank required, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 10-2.1-4.  
Sec. 2-1806. - Appointments; competitive examinations. 
Appointments in the fire and police departments, both original and promotional, shall be made only after competitive examinations in accordance with state law. With respect to original police appointments, the board of fire and police commissioners may prepare and keep a second register of persons who have previously been full-time sworn officers of a regular police department in any municipal, county, university, or state law enforcement agency, provided they are certified by the Illinois Law Enforcement Training Standards Board and have been with their respective law enforcement agency within the state for at least two (2) years. The persons on this list shall take rank upon the register as candidates in the order of their relative excellence as determined by members of the board of fire and police commissioners. Applicants who have been awarded a certificate attesting to their successful completion of the minimum standards basic law enforcement training course, as provided in the Illinois Police Training Act, may be given preference in appointment over noncertified applicants. 
(Ord. No. 3623, § 2, 11-8-10) 
State Law reference— Appointments to be after competitive examinations, and nature of such examination, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-6, 5/10-2.1-14.  
Sec. 2-1807. - Regulations governing examinations; availability to examiners. 
The board of fire and police commissioners shall make rules governing the conduct of original and promotional examinations; such rules shall be made available to all persons seeking to take such examination. The board of fire and police commissioners may, by its rules, waive portions of the required examination for police applicants who have previously been full-time sworn officers of a regular police department in any municipal, county, university, or state law enforcement agency, provided they are certified by the Illinois Law Enforcement Training Standards Board and have been with their respective law enforcement agency within the state for at least two (2) years. 
(Ord. No. 3623, § 2, 11-8-10) 
State Law reference— Rules authorized, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-5, 5/10-2.1-6.  
Sec. 2-1808. - Hearings; discharges. 
The board of fire and police commissioners shall conduct all hearings on charges brought against any member of the police or fire department, and shall designate the penalty or punishment to be applied. No person other than the chiefs shall be discharged, except on charges brought, and after a hearing before the board. 
State Law reference— Removal and discharge of members, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 10-2.1-17.  
Sec. 2-1809. - Limitations on authority. 
Except as specifically provided otherwise by ordinance, the board of fire and police commissioners shall have no authority to make rules and regulations governing the conduct of members, or the operation of the fire or police department. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, ILCS 5/10-2.1-5.  
Sec. 2-1810. - Authority to appoint secretary; duties. 
The board of fire and police commissioners may employ a secretary, or may designate one (1) of its own members to act as such. The secretary shall keep the minutes of the board's proceedings, be custodian of all papers pertaining to the business of the board, keep a record of all examinations held, and perform such other duties as the board may prescribe. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 10-2.1-20.  
ARTICLE XIX. - DuPAGE WATER COMMISSION[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note— Pursuant to the provisions of Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-135-1 et seq., the DuPage Water Commission has been organized and the Village of Villa Park participates in same by appointing a commissioner who serves for a term of six (6) years and until his successor in office has been appointed and qualified. See Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-135-2. By statute such commission has authority to acquire and manage the water supply source. Such commission is authorized to issue revenue bonds to finance water source acquisition (Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-135-4 et seq.) and may exercise eminent domain to acquire property. (Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-135-6). 
Cross reference— Water system, Ch. 25, Art. III. 
 
Sec. 2-1901. - Generally. 
Appointments to the DuPage Water Commission shall be made in the manner provided by statute.

ARTICLE XXI. - GOLF COURSE ADMINISTRATION BOARD[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference— Parks and recreation, Ch. 17. 
 
Sec. 2-2101. - Generally. 
The creation, membership, organization and functions of the Sugar Creek Golf Course Administrative Board shall be as provided in the agreement between the village and the Elmhurst Park District.  
Sec. 2-2102. - Expenditures. 
(a)  The Sugar Creek Golf Course Administrative Board shall have authority to spend up to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) without prior consent from the political subdivisions for expenses, services and contractual obligations which arise from the administration, operation and maintenance of the golf course. These expenditures shall constitute a legal debt of the representative subdivisions. 
(b)  The authorization and delegation contained in this ordinance is conditioned upon and subject to the following: 
(1)  That no expense or contract shall be made by said administrative board unless an appropriation has been previously made concerning said expense or contract. 
(2)  Said expense or contract indicates that the same is not sole and exclusive responsibility of the village, to the exclusion of the park district, nor the sole and exclusive responsibility of the park district, to the exclusion of the village; and expenses and contractual obligations shall be the joint undertaking and obligation of the village and park district. 
(3)  No expense, contract or obligation shall be entered into by said administrative board, even though the amount of said expense, contract or obligation is not in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) where said expense, contract or obligation would otherwise, in the normal course and conduct of business, include other expenses, obligations and contracts which, when included, would exceed the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and where said other expenses, obligations and contracts are entered into for the purpose of reducing the total expense or obligation to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or less. 
(4)  Where any expense, obligation or contract which otherwise requires competitive bidding by law is let or attempted to be let without said bidding and contrary to law, said authorization will be withheld. All such bids, regardless of amounts, must be approved and accepted by the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 1545, §§ 1, 2, 4-28-75; Ord. No. 1572, 8-11-75; Ord. No. 2550, §§ 1, 2, 2-10-92)  
Sec. 2-2103. - Members. 
Members of the golf course administrative board may be members of the Village of Villa Park Board of Trustees or the Elmhurst Park District Board of Commissioners or the administrative staff of either board; or members of the respective communities. Each member, with the exception of full-time staff members employed by either municipality, must reside within the corporate boundaries of the governmental body from which the member is appointed. 
(Ord. No. 2983, § 3, 4-19-99)  
ARTICLE XXII. - TRAFFIC AND SAFETY COMMISSION[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 14. 
 
Sec. 2-2201. - Established. 
There is hereby established a commission to be known as the traffic and safety commission. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1, 5-4-64)  
Sec. 2-2202. - Intent; function. 
The commission created herein shall act in an advisory capacity to the corporate authorities in all matters of traffic and safety which are referred to the commission or which are initiated or investigated by the commission on its own motion. 
(Ord. No. 892, §§ 1—3, 5-4-64; Ord. No. 2983, § 4, 4-19-99; Ord. No. 3477, § 2, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2203. - Membership. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall consist nine (9) members including the chairperson, appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, to serve without compensation. To be eligible to serve on the commission, persons shall be qualified electors of the village who have resided therein for one (1) year immediately preceding their appointment. Members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years, except that the members first appointed to the commission shall serve as follows: Three (3) for one (1) year, three (3) for two (2) years and three (3) for three (3) years. 
(b)  All appointments shall expire the thirtieth (30th) of April of the appropriate year. Any member of the commission may resign at any time during the term for which he/she was appointed, which resignation shall be addressed to the village president. Vacancies on the commission shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose position becomes vacant in the manner provided herein. 
(c)  If any member of the commission shall cease to maintain the status qualifying him for appointment to the commission, or shall fail to attend three (3) consecutive meetings of the commission without being excused by a vote of a majority of the members of the commission, such member may be considered as having resigned his membership. Report of such change of status or failure of attendance may be reported to the corporate authorities and, if such report is accepted by the corporate authorities, the membership in question shall be declared vacant and it shall be the duty of the president to appoint a qualified successor to such membership in the manner provided herein. Any member of the commission may be removed for cause by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 3, 5-4-64; Ord. No. 3477, § 3, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2204. - Officers. 
A chairman of the commission created herein shall be elected by the members of the commission for a term of two (2) years. The commission may designate one (1) of its members to act as secretary, together with such other officers as it deems fit. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 4, 5-4-64; Ord. No. 3477, § 4, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2205. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the commission created here in shall be held on the second Tuesday of each month in the Village Hall at such time as may be established by the commission. 
(b)  Special meetings of the commission may be called by the chairperson or any two (2) voting members with at least forty-eight (48) hours' written notice prior to the special meeting. Notice of any special meeting shall be provided in accordance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act and shall be posted in the Village Hall. 
(c)  The action of a majority of the members present at a meeting at which a quorum is present shall be the action of the members. 
(d)  The presence of five (5) commission members shall constitute a quorum to transact any commission business at a regular or special meeting of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 4, 5-4-64; Ord. No. 3477, § 5, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2206. - Expenditures. 
Expenses for the operation and transaction of the affairs of the commission shall be paid from such funds as may be provided for such purpose in the annual appropriation and budget ordinances of the village; provided, however, that the village manager has approved same prior to the expense being incurred. 
(Ord. No. 1537, § 1, 6-30-75; Ord. No. 2794, § 1, 10-2-95; Ord. No. 3477, § 6, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2207. - Reports and records. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall keep permanent minutes of its meetings, which shall include topics discussed, the motions and vote of each member upon each topic submitted to it. 
(b)  The commission shall prepare and submit minutes of each meeting within a reasonable time after each of its meeting, and the chairperson shall forward copies of the minutes, together with any special reports regard matters or issues of concern, to the manager. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 4, 5-4-64; Ord. No. 3477, § 7, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2208. - Advice from certain officers. 
The village manager, the village attorney, the police chief and the fire chief shall serve the commission created herein in an advisory capacity when requested to do so by the commission's chairperson. 
(Ord. No. 3477, § 8, 4-14-08)  
ARTICLE XXIII. - POLICE PENSION BOARD[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Cross reference— Police pension fund, § 19-107 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-2301. - Generally. 
(a)  There is hereby created a board, composed of five (5) members who shall constitute a board of trustees to administer the pension fund and to designate the beneficiaries thereof. The board shall be known as the "Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund of the Village of Villa Park. 
(b)  Two (2) members of the board shall be appointed by the village president. The third and fourth members of the board shall be elected from the regular police force by the active members thereof. The fifth member shall be elected by and from the beneficiaries of the fund. 
(c)  Member terms shall be for two (2) years or until their successors are appointed and qualified. The terms for members appointed by the village president shall begin on the second Tuesday in May and shall be staggered so one (1) term shall begin every other year. The terms for the two (2) members elected by the active participants and the term of the member elected by the beneficiaries shall begin on the second Tuesday in May after the election for those members which shall be held biennially on the third Monday in April. 
(d)  The election provided for in this section for elected board members shall be held biennially on the third Monday in April, at such place or places in the municipality and under the Australian ballot system and such other regulations as shall be prescribed by the appointed members of the board. 
(e)  All members of the regular police force shall be entitled to vote only for the police force members of the board. All beneficiaries of legal age shall be entitled to vote only for the member chosen from among the beneficiaries. No person shall be entitled to cast more than one (1) ballot at such election. The members shall be elected for a term of two (2) years, beginning on the second Tuesday of the first May after such election. 
(f)  Upon the death, resignation or inability to act of any member of the board elected under this section, his successor shall be elected for the unexpired term at a special election, to be called by the board and conducted in the same manner as the regular biennial election. 
(Ord. No. 3708, §§ 1—3, 7-9-12; Ord. No. 3787, § 1, 4-28-14) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/3-128.  
Sec. 2-2302. - Rooms. 
Suitable rooms for offices and meetings of the board of trustees of the police pension fund shall be assigned by the board of trustees of the village. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/3-129.  
Sec. 2-2303. - Meetings, officers, etc. 
(a)  The board shall hold regular quarterly meetings on the second Tuesday of July, October, January and April annually, and special meetings as called by the president. 
(b)  At the regular July meeting, the board shall select from its members a president, vice-president, secretary, and assistant secretary to serve for the period of one (1) year and until his respective successor is elected and qualified. 
(c)  The vice-president of the board shall perform the duties of president during any vacancy in that office, or during such time as the president is absent from the village, or for any other reason is disqualified or by reason of illness or other causes is unable to perform his duties. 
(d)  The assistant secretary shall act for the secretary whenever necessary to discharge the functions of such office. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/3-130.  
Sec. 2-2304. - Powers and duties. 
The board of trustees of the police pension fund shall have the powers and duties stated below in addition to the other powers and duties granted it by law. 
(1)  To control and manage, exclusively, the pension fund, and all moneys donated, paid or assessed for the relief or pensioning of disabled, super-annuated and retired members of the police department, their widows, minor children and dependent parents. All such moneys shall be placed by the village treasurer to the credit of the fund, subject to the order of the pension board. 
(2)  To order and direct the payment of pensions and other benefits provided by law and to issue certificates signed by its president and secretary to the persons entitled thereto of the amount ordered paid to such persons from the fund, which certificates shall state the purpose of the payment. 
(3)  To submit annually to the village or board of trustees at the close of the fiscal year, a list of persons entitled to payments from the fund, stating the amount of the payments, and their purpose, as ordered by the board. It shall also include items of income accrued to the fund during such fiscal year. Such list shall be signed by the secretary and president of the pension board, and attested under oath. No resolution or order for the payment of money shall be valid unless approved by a majority of the members of the board, and any order for such payment shall be signed by the president and secretary of the board. 
(4)  To draw such pension funds from the treasurer or other officials of the village, and invest any part thereof in the name of the board of the police pension fund in: Interest bearing bonds or tax anticipation warrants of the United States, of the state or of any county, township or municipal corporation of the State of Illinois; insured withdrawable capital accounts of federal chartered federal savings and loan associations if the withdrawable capital accounts are insured by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation; insured investments in credit unions if the investments are insured by the National Credit Union Administration; and in savings accounts or certificates of deposit of a national or state bank. All securities shall be deposited with the village treasurer and be subject to the order of the pension board. Interest on such investments shall be credited to the account of the pension fund. 
(5)  To compel witnesses to attend and testify before it, upon all matters connected with the administration hereof, in the manner provided by law for the taking of testimony before the circuit court. The president, or any member of the board, may administer oaths to such witnesses. 
(6)  To appoint a clerk and define his duties. No person drawing a pension under this article shall be employed by the board. 
(7)  To provide for the payment from the fund of all necessary expenses, including clerk hire, printing and witness fees. 
(8)  To keep a public record of all its proceedings. 
(9)  To make necessary rules and regulations in conformity with the provisions of law, which shall be published by the board and copies transmitted from time to time to all pensioners and contributors. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 108½, § 3-131 et seq.  
Sec. 2-2305. - Reports by pension board. 
(a)  The board of trustees of the police pension fund shall report to the board of trustees of the village on the condition of the police pension fund. The report shall be made prior to the meeting of the village board held for the levying of taxes for the year for which such report is made. 
(b)  The board shall certify to the board of trustees of the village: 
(1)  The assets in its custody at such time; 
(2)  The estimated receipts during the next succeeding calendar year from deductions from the salaries of policemen, and from all other sources; and 
(3)  The estimated amount required during said calendar year to pay all pensions and other obligations provided by law, and maintain the reserve fund provided by law. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. 108½, § 3-143.  
ARTICLE XXIV. - FIREMEN'S PENSION BOARD[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
Cross reference— Fire department, § 9-301 et seq.; Firemen's pension fund, § 9-321 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-2401. - Generally. 
(a)  There is hereby created a board of trustees to be known as the "board of trustees of the firemen's pension fund", consisting of two (2) members appointed by the village president, two (2) members chosen from the active firemen and one (1) other member who shall be chosen from the firemen thereof who have been retired under the "Firemen's Pension Fund Act of 1919" or this article. 
(b)  The members of the board to be chosen from the active and retired firemen shall be elected by ballot at elections to be held on the third Monday in April of the applicable years under the Australian ballot system, at such place and places, in such municipality, and under such regulations as shall be prescribed by the board. 
(c)  No person shall cast more than one vote at such election for each candidate for whom he is eligible to vote. In the elections for board members to be chosen from the active firemen, all active firemen and none others may vote. In the elections for board members to be chosen from the firemen who have been retired, the firemen who have been so retired and none others may vote. 
(d)  Each member of the board so elected shall hold office for a term of three (3) years and until his successor has been duly elected and qualified. 
(e)  The board shall canvass the ballots at each election and declare the results as to which person or persons have been elected and for what term or terms respectively. In case of a tie vote between any two (2) ore more candidates, the board shall determine by lot which candidate or candidates have been elected and for term or terms respectively. In the event of the failure, resignation, or inability to act of any member of the board, his successor shall be elected for the unexpired time at a special election which shall be called by the board and conducted in the same manner as a regular election hereunder. 
(f)  The board shall elect from its number a president and a secretary. 
(Ord. No. 1353, § 1, 12-18-72; Ord. No. 1574, § 1, 8-17-75; Ord. No. 3338, § 2, 2-13-06)  
Sec. 2-2402. - Powers and duties. 
The board created herein shall have the powers and duties stated below in addition to the other powers and duties granted it by law, including 40 ILCS 5/4-101 et seq.: 
(1)  To control and manage the pension fund and all money donated, paid, assessed or provided by law for the relief or pensioning of disabled, superannuated and retired firefighters, their widows, minor children and dependent parents; 
(2)  To hear and decide all applications for relief or pensions and to order and direct the payment of pensions and other benefits hereunder; 
(3)  To make all rules and regulations necessary for the discharge of its duties; 
(4)  To provide for the payment from the fund of all necessary expenses of the board; 
(5)  To invest the money in the pension fund in permitted investments pursuant to 40 ILCS 5/1-113.2, as now existing or hereafter amended; and 
(6)  To keep a record of all its meetings and proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 1353, 12-18-72; Ord. No. 1574, § 1, 8-15-75: Ord. No 3671, § 2, 9-26-11) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 108½, § 4-122 et seq.  
Sec. 2-2403. - Treasurer. 
(a)  The treasurer of the board of trustees of the firemen's pension fund shall be the custodian of the pension fund and shall secure and safely keep the same, subject to the control and direction of the board; and shall keep his books and accounts concerning such fund in such manner as may be prescribed by the board; and the books and accounts shall be subject to the inspection of the board or any member thereof. 
(b)  The treasurer shall, within ten (10) days after his election or appointment, execute a bond to the municipality, with good and sufficient securities, in such penal sums as the board shall direct, to be approved by the board, conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of his office, and that he will safely keep and well and truly account for all moneys and property which may come into his hands as treasurer; and that on the expiration of his term of office he will surrender and deliver over to his successor all unexpended moneys and property which have come to his hands as treasurer of the fund. 
(c)  The bond shall be filed in the office of the village clerk. In case of a breach of the bond, or the conditions thereof, suit may be brought thereon in the name of the village for the use of the board, or of any person injured by such breach. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 108½, § 4-130.  
Sec. 2-2404. - Compensation. 
Members of the board of trustees of the firemen's pension fund shall not receive or have any right to receive any money or moneys from a pension fund as salary for service performed as a member of such board. 
(Ord. No. 1353, 12-18-72; Ord. No. 1574, § 1, 8-15-75) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 108½, § 4-137.  
ARTICLE XXV. - ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS COMMISSION[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2483, § 1, adopted May 28, 1991 amended the Code by repealing Ord. No. 1778, adopted Mar. 20, 1978; consequently, §§ 2-2501—2-2509 pertaining to the environmental control board were deleted, since they derived from §§ 1—10 of Ord. No. 1778. Said former sections also derived from Ord. No. 2286, §§ 1 and 2, adopted May 23, 1988. Section 2 of Ord. No. 2483 added new §§ 2-2501—2-2508 as herein set forth. 
Cross reference— Garbage and trash, Ch. 10; detergents containing phosphates, § 16-109; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 25. 
 
Sec. 2-2501. - Created. 
There is hereby created the Villa Park Environmental Concerns Commission. 
(Ord. No. 2483, § 2, 5-28-91)  
Sec. 2-2502. - Intent and purpose. 
It shall be the intent and purpose of the environmental concerns commission to advise the president and board of trustees on matters relating to the preservation, protection and improvement of the environment, including the quality of land, air and water affecting the village and its residents, and thereby provide information that will assist the president and board of trustees in addressing environmental issues. 
(Ord. No. 2483, § 2, 5-28-91)  
Sec. 2-2503. - Membership. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall consist of seven (7) members including the chairperson, appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, to serve without compensation. To be eligible to serve on the commission, persons shall be qualified electors of the village who have resided therein for one (1) year immediately preceding their appointment. Members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years with staggered terms so that the terms of two (2) members shall expire the first and second years and the terms of three (3) members shall expire the third year. 
(b)  All appointments shall expire the thirtieth (30th) of April of the appropriate year. Any member of the commission may resign at any time during the term for which he/she was appointed, which resignation shall be addressed to the village president. Vacancies on the commission shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose position becomes vacant in the manner provided herein. 
(c)  If any member of the commission shall cease to maintain the status qualifying him for appointment to the commission, or shall fail to attend three (3) consecutive meetings of the commission without being excused by a vote of a majority of the members of the commission, such member may be considered as having resigned his membership. Report of such change of status or failure of attendance may be reported to the corporate authorities and, if such report is accepted by the corporate authorities, the membership in question shall be declared vacant and it shall be the duty of the president to appoint a qualified successor to such membership in the manner provided herein. Any member of the commission may be removed for cause by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2483, § 2, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 2983, § 5, 4-19-99; Ord. No. 3321, § 2, 10-10-05; Ord. No. 3472, § 2, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 3865 , § 1, 5-11-15)  
Sec. 2-2504. - Officers. 
A chairman of the commission created herein shall be elected by the members of the commission for a term of two (2) years. The commission may designate one (1) of its members to act as secretary, together with such other officers as it deems fit. 
(Ord. No. 2483, § 2, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 3472, § 3, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2505. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the commission created here in shall be held on the fourth Thursday of each month in the Village Hall at such time as may be established by the commission. 
(b)  Special meetings of the commission may be called by the chairperson or any two (2) voting members with at least forty-eight (48) hours' written notice prior to the special meeting. Notice of any special meeting shall be provided in accordance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act and shall be posted in the Village Hall. 
(c)  The action of a majority of the members present at a meeting at which a quorum is present shall be the action of the members. 
(d)  The presence of four (4) commission members shall constitute a quorum to transact any commission business at a regular or special meeting of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 2483, § 2, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 2941, § 1, 5-18-98; Ord. No. 3472, § 4, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 3865 , § 2, 5-11-15) 
State Law reference— Open Meetings Act generally, 5 ILCS 120/1.01 et seq.  
Sec. 2-2506. - Expenditures. 
Expenses for the operation and transaction of the affairs of the commission shall be paid from such funds as may be provided for such purpose in the annual appropriation and budget ordinances of the village; provided, however, that the village manager has approved same prior to the expense being incurred. 
(Ord. No. 2483, § 2, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 3472, § 5, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2507. - Reports and records. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall keep permanent minutes of its meetings, which shall include topics discussed, the motions and vote of each member upon each topic submitted to it. 
(b)  The commission shall prepare and submit minutes of each meeting within a reasonable time after each of its meeting, and the chairperson shall forward copies of the minutes, together with any special reports regard matters or issues of concern, to the manager. 
(Ord. No. 2483, § 2, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 3472, § 6, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2508. - Powers and duties. 
The environmental concerns commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To make recommendations to the president and board of trustees regarding possible ways to improve, preserve and protect the environment, including the quality of land, air and water affecting the village and its residents. 
(2)  To advise the president and board of trustees and the village manager concerning any actual or potential threat of contaminative or noise sources, contamination to public water supplies and refuse disposal sites, or any other threat to the quality of the environment of the village and its residents. 
(3)  To advise the president and board of trustees of the source of any pollution or contamination and the name of any person, firm or entity that may be causing environmental pollution or contamination or that may be violating any statutes, laws, rules, or regulations either of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency or of any federal, state, county or local agency. 
(4)  To make recommendations to the president and board of trustees for the adoption of ordinances and to prepare and submit to the president and board of trustees, or to other officials with the advice and consent of the president and board of trustees, resolutions and recommendations concerning local, state and national environmental issues. 
(5)  To make recommendations to the president and board of trustees concerning materials, programs, or other methods of increasing the awareness of the residents of the village on environmental issues. 
(6)  To promote and extend cooperation and assistance to any like agencies created for similar purposes and to promote the formation of similar boards in other communities or areas. 
(7)  With the advice and consent of the president and board of trustees, and in accordance with the directives of the president and board of trustees, to testify or appear before the Illinois Pollution Control Board or the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency on any hearing concerning any proposed rule or regulation of those agencies. 
(8)  To create such subcommittees as it deems advisable to carry out the purposes of the commission; appointments to such subcommittee(s) to be made by the chairperson and vice chairperson with the concurrence of a majority of the commission members. 
(9)  To cooperate with other boards and commissions of the village to maintain and improve the quality of life for the residents of the village. 
(10)  To assist the manager and staff, as the manager or his designee requests, on matters relating to the preservation, protection and improvements of the environment. 
(11)  Such other powers and duties as the president and board of trustees, acting jointly, may from time to time designate, whether by way of motion adopted at any regular or special meeting, by resolution, or by ordinance. If by motion, the precise nature of the additional powers and duties shall be accurately described in the minutes and the village clerk shall promptly forward, upon approval of the minutes, a copy to the chairperson of the environmental concerns commission for such action as may be required. 
If in the exercise of these powers and the discharge of these duties it becomes necessary for the commission or its members to interact with employees of the village, such shall be coordinated through the village manager's office and in accordance with the directions of the village manager. 
(Ord. No. 2483, § 2, 5-28-91)  
ARTICLE XXVI. - SENIOR CITIZENS COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 2-2601. - Created. 
There is hereby created a commission which shall be known as the Villa Park Senior Citizens Commission. 
(Ord. No. 1609, § 1, 12-22-75)  
Sec. 2-2602. - Intent; function. 
It shall be the intent of this commission to make recommendations to the village board to insure and promote the well-being of the senior population of Villa Park. 
(Ord. No. 1609, §§ 2—7, 12-22-75; Ord. No. 2243, § 1, 6-1-87; Ord. No. 2983, § 6, 4-19-99; Ord. No. 3475, § 2, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2603. - Membership. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall consist of eleven (11) members including the chairperson, appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, to serve without compensation. A majority of members of the commission shall be qualified electors of the village who have resided therein for one (1) year immediately preceding their appointment. All members of the commission shall be fifty-five (55) or older. Members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. 
(b)  All appointments shall expire the thirtieth (30th) of April of the appropriate year. Any member of the commission may resign at any time during the term for which he/she was appointed, which resignation shall be addressed to the village president. Vacancies on the commission shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose position becomes vacant in the manner provided herein. 
(c)  If any member of the commission shall cease to maintain the status qualifying him for appointment to the commission, or shall fail to attend three (3) consecutive meetings of the commission without being excused by a vote of a majority of the members of the commission, such member may be considered as having resigned his membership. Report of such change of status or failure of attendance may be reported to the corporate authorities and, if such report is accepted by the corporate authorities, the membership in question shall be declared vacant and it shall be the duty of the president to appoint a qualified successor to such membership in the manner provided herein. Any member of the commission may be removed for cause by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 1609, § 8, 12-22-75; Ord. No. 3475, § 3, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 3517, § 2, 11-10-08)  
Sec. 2-2604. - Officers. 
A chairman of the commission created herein shall be elected by the members of the commission for a term of two (2) years. The commission may designate one (1) of its members to act as secretary, together with such other officers as it deems fit. 
(Ord. No. 1609, § 7, 12-22-75; Ord. No. 3475, § 4, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2605. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the commission created here in shall be held on the first Monday of each month such place and time as may be established by the commission. 
(b)  Special meetings of the commission may be called by the chairperson or any two (2) voting members with at least forty-eight (48) hours' written notice prior to the special meeting. Notice of any special meeting shall be provided in accordance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act and shall be posted in the Village Hall. 
(c)  The action of a majority of the members present at a meeting at which a quorum is present shall be the action of the members. 
(d)  The presence of six (6) commission members shall constitute a quorum to transact any commission business at a regular or special meeting of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 1609, § 9, 12-22-75; Ord. No. 3475, § 5, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2606. - Expenditures. 
Expenses for the operation and transaction of the affairs of the commission shall be paid from such funds as may be provided for such purpose in the annual appropriation and budget ordinances of the village; provided, however, that the village manager has approved same prior to the expense being incurred. 
(Ord. No. 3475, § 6, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2607. - Reports and records. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall keep permanent minutes of its meetings, which shall include topics discussed, the motions and vote of each member upon each topic submitted to it. 
(b)  The commission shall prepare and submit minutes of each meeting within a reasonable time after each of its meeting, and the chairperson shall forward copies of the minutes, together with any special reports regard matters or issues of concern, to the manager. 
(Ord. No. 3475, § 7, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2608. - Functions and duties. 
The functions and duties of the commission created herein shall be to: 
(a)  Make recommendations from time to time to the board of trustees with respect to adoption and amendments of ordinances relating to senior citizens; 
(b)  Investigate the needs and concerns of the senior citizens, including income, physical and mental health, housing, employment, education, nutrition, legal aid, retirement roles and activities, spiritual well-being, transportation, government and all other related areas of planning; 
(c)  Analyze complaints of senior citizens of the Village of Villa Park; 
(d)  Consult and cooperate with all agencies of the village, other municipalities, and federal, state and local agencies concerned with senior citizens; 
(e)  Promulgate and effect a program of publicity relating to senior citizens and public education relating to senior citizens; 
(f)  Develop action programs of benefit to senior citizens and exercise such other functions as may be delegated by the corporate authorities; 
(g)  Conduct public hearings, carry on research, or otherwise obtain such factual data and issue such reports and recommendations to the board of trustees and to the public as in the judgment of the commission will effectuate the policies and purpose of the commission; 
(h)  Adopt rules and regulations for the commission's business; 
(i)  Furnish a report covering the activities, direction and any recommendations of the commission to the president and board of trustees every six (6) months. 
(Ord. No. 3475, § 8, 4-14-08)  
ARTICLE XXVII. - HISTORICAL PRESERVATION COMMISSION[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 2482, § 1, adopted May 28, 1991 amended §§ 2-2701—2-2709 to read as herein set forth. Prior to such amendment, §§ 2-2701—2-2708 pertained to the historical preservation commission and derived from Ord. No. 1691, §§ 1—7, 9, adopted Feb. 14, 1977 and Ord. No. 2231, § 1, adopted April 27, 1987. 
Cross reference— Planning and development, Ch. 18. 
State Law reference— Historical preservation, 65 ILCS 5/11-48.2-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-2701. - Created. 
There is hereby created the Villa Park Historical Preservation Commission. 
(Ord. No. 2482, § 1, 5-28-91) 
State Law reference— Power of municipality to establish such a board, 65 ILCS 5/11-48.2-3.  
Sec. 2-2702. - Intent and purpose. 
It shall be the intent and purpose of the historical preservation commission to advise the president and board of trustees on matters relating to the preservation of areas, places, sites, buildings, structures, monuments, items, memorabilia, works of art and other objects having a special historical, community, or aesthetic interest, value, or significance to the village, including but not limited to, the former Chicago, Aurora and Eligin train stations located at 220 South Villa Avenue (the Villa Avenue Train Station) and 10 West Park Boulevard (the Ardmore Avenue Train Station). 
(Ord. No. 2482, § 1, 5-28-91)  
Sec. 2-2703. - Membership. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall consist of five (5) members including the chairperson, appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, to serve without compensation. To be eligible to serve on the commission, persons shall be qualified electors of the village who have resided therein for one (1) year immediately preceding their appointment. One (1) commission member shall be a member of the Villa Park Historical Society. Members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. 
(b)  All appointments shall expire the thirtieth (30th) of April of the appropriate year. Any member of the commission may resign at any time during the term for which he/she was appointed, which resignation shall be addressed to the village president. Vacancies on the commission shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose position becomes vacant in the manner provided herein. 
(c)  If any member of the commission shall cease to maintain the status qualifying him for appointment to the commission, or shall fail to attend three (3) consecutive meetings of the commission without being excused by a vote of a majority of the members of the commission, such member may be considered as having resigned his membership. Report of such change of status or failure of attendance may be reported to the corporate authorities and, if such report is accepted by the corporate authorities, the membership in question shall be declared vacant and it shall be the duty of the president to appoint a qualified successor to such membership in the manner provided herein. Any member of the commission may be removed for cause by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2482, § 1, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 2983, § 7, 4-19-99; Ord. No. 3473, § 2, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 3942 , § 1, 11-14-16)  
Sec. 2-2704. - Officers. 
A chairman of the commission created herein shall be elected by the members of the commission for a term of two (2) years. The commission may designate one (1) of its members to act as secretary, together with such other officers as it deems fit. 
(Ord. No. 2482, § 1, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 3473, § 3, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2705. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the commission created here in shall be held on the first Tuesday of each month in the Village Hall at such time as may be established by the commission. 
(b)  Special meetings of the commission may be called by the chairperson or any two (2) voting members with at least forty-eight (48) hours' written notice prior to the special meeting. Notice of any special meeting shall be provided in accordance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act and shall be posted in the Village Hall. 
(c)  The action of a majority of the members present at a meeting at which a quorum is present shall be the action of the members. 
(d)  The presence of three (3) commission members shall constitute a quorum to transact any commission business at a regular or special meeting of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 2482, § 1, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 2941, § 2, 5-18-98; Ord. No. 3473, § 4, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 3942 , § 2, 11-14-16) 
State Law reference— Open Meetings Act generally, 5 ILCS 120/1.01 et seq.  
Sec. 2-2706. - Expenditures. 
Expenses for the operation and transaction of the affairs of the commission shall be paid from such funds as may be provided for such purpose in the annual appropriation and budget ordinances of the village; provided, however, that the village manager has approved same prior to the expense being incurred. 
(Ord. No. 2482, § 1, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 3473, § 5, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2707. - Reports and records. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall keep permanent minutes of its meetings, which shall include topics discussed, the motions and vote of each member upon each topic submitted to it. 
(b)  The commission shall prepare and submit minutes of each meeting within a reasonable time after each of its meeting, and the chairperson shall forward copies of the minutes, together with any special reports regard matters or issues of concern, to the manager. 
(Ord. No. 2482, § 1, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 3473, § 6, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2708. - Powers and duties. 
The historical preservation commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To conduct public hearings upon its own motion, or on a citizen's petition, to implement the intent and purpose of this article as expressed in section 2-2702 of this Code for the purposes and uses set forth in 65 ILCS 5/11-48.2-1, as originally adopted or subsequently amended. Such hearings shall be pursuant to notice as is otherwise set forth in 65 ILCS 5/11-48.2-4. Within a reasonable time after the conclusion of such hearing, a written recommendation shall be made to the corporate authorities who shall take such action as they may deem fit. 
(2)  To make recommendations to the president and board of trustees concerning methods of increasing the awareness of the residents of the village of the importance of preserving items, areas, sites, buildings, or any other thing of historical importance or significance to the village. 
(3)  To aid in the development, restoration and preservation of the Villa Avenue Train Station and the Ardmore Avenue Train Station, or other sites or properties designated by ordinance by the corporate authorities in accordance with 65 ILCS 5/11-48.2-2. 
(4)  Such other powers and duties as the president and board of trustees, acting jointly, may from time to time designate, whether by way of motion adopted at any regular or special meeting, by resolution, or by ordinance. If by motion, the precise nature of the additional powers and duties shall be accurately described in the minutes and the village clerk shall promptly forward, upon approval of the minutes, a copy to the chairperson of the historical preservation commission for such action as may be required. 
(Ord. No. 2482, § 1, 5-28-91) 
State Law reference— Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-1.  
Sec. 2-2709. - Administrative review. 
Any proceedings of the historical preservation commission shall not be subject to judicial review pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois Administrative Review Act. 
(Ord. No. 2482, § 1, 5-28-91) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-48.2-4.  
ARTICLE XXVIII. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2147, §§ 1—4, adopted June 3, 1985, being not expressly amendatory of the Code, has been included as Art. XXVIII, §§ 2-2801—2-2804, at the discretion of the editor. 
 
Sec. 2-2801. - Created. 
There is hereby created the Villa Park Economic Development Commission. 
(Ord. No. 2147, § 1, 6-3-85; Ord. No. 3471, § 2, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2802. - Intent; purpose. 
It shall be the intent and purpose of the village economic development commission to prepare and recommend to the village board procedures for the planning, execution and implementation of business district plans, including plans for development of adjacent areas to provide for the housing, social and recreational needs of the business district. 
(Ord. No. 2147, § 2, 6-3-85; Ord. No. 3471, § 3, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2803. - Membership. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall consist of seven (7) members including the chairperson, appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, to serve without compensation. To be eligible to serve on the commission, persons shall be either qualified electors of the village who have resided therein for one (1) year immediately preceding their appointment, or have a place of business within the corporate limits of the village. Members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years, except that the members first appointed to the commission shall serve as follows: Two (2) for one (1) year, two (2) for two (2) years and three (3) for three (3) years. 
(b)  All appointments shall expire the thirtieth (30th) of April of the appropriate year. Any member of the commission may resign at any time during the term for which he/she was appointed, which resignation shall be addressed to the village president. Vacancies on the commission shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose position becomes vacant in the manner provided herein. 
(c)  If any member of the commission shall cease to maintain the status qualifying him for appointment to the commission, or shall fail to attend three (3) consecutive meetings of the commission without being excused by a vote of a majority of the members of the commission, such member may be considered as having resigned his membership. Report of such change of status or failure of attendance may be reported to the corporate authorities and, if such report is accepted by the corporate authorities, the membership in question shall be declared vacant and it shall be the duty of the president to appoint a qualified successor to such membership in the manner provided herein. Any member of the commission may be removed for cause by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2147, § 3, 6-3-85; Ord. No. 3471, § 4, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2804. - Officers. 
A chairman of the commission created herein shall be elected by the members of the commission for a term of two (2) years. The commission may designate one (1) of its members to act as secretary, together with such other officers as it deems fit. 
(Ord. No. 2147, § 3, 6-3-85; Ord. No. 3471, § 5, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2805. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the commission shall be held the third Wednesday of each month in the Village Hall at such time as may be established by the commission. 
(b)  Special meetings of the commission may be called by the chairperson or any two (2) voting members with at least forty-eight (48) hours' written notice prior to the special meeting. Notice of any special meeting shall be provided in accordance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act and shall be posted in the Village Hall. 
(c)  The action of a majority of the members present at a meeting at which a quorum is present shall be the action of the members. 
(d)  The presence of four (4) commission members shall constitute a quorum to transact any commission business at a regular or special meeting of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 3471, § 6, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 3724, § 1, 12-10-12; Ord. No. 3782, § 1, 3-24-14)  
Sec. 2-2806. - Expenditures. 
Expenses for the operation and transaction of the affairs of the commission shall be paid from such funds as may be provided for such purpose in the annual appropriation and budget ordinances of the village; provided, however, that the village manager has approved same prior to the expense being incurred. 
(Ord. No. 3471, § 7, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2807. - Reports and records. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall keep permanent minutes of its meetings, which shall include topics discussed, the motions and vote of each member upon each topic submitted to it. 
(b)  The commission shall prepare and submit minutes of each meeting within a reasonable time after each of its meeting, and the chairperson shall forward copies of the minutes, together with any special reports regard matters or issues of concern, to the manager. 
(Ord. No. 3471, § 8, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2808. - Powers and duties. 
Powers and duties are as follows: 
(1)  To prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities procedures for the planning, execution and implementation of business district plans, including plans for development of adjacent areas to provide for the housing, social and recreation needs of the developed or redeveloped business district. 
(2)  To act as an agent for the Village of Villa Park for the purposes of business district development and redevelopment. 
(3)  To conduct hearings and thereafter make recommendations to the corporate authorities as required on matters relating to all development and redevelopment proposals for a business district. 
(4)  To prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities, from time to time, plans for: 
a.  The use of eminent domain for the acquisition of real and personal property for the purpose of a development or redevelopment project; 
b.  The acquiring, managing, conveying or otherwise disposing of real and personal property acquired pursuant to the provisions of a development or redevelopment plan; 
c.  The application for and acceptance of capital grants and loans from the United States and the State of Illinois, or any instrumentality of the United States or the State of Illinois for business district development and redevelopment; 
d.  The borrowing of funds as it may be deemed necessary for the purpose of business district development and redevelopment, and in this connection, including the issuance of such obligation or revenue bonds as it shall be deemed necessary, subject to applicable statutory limitations; 
e.  The entering into of contracts with any public or private agency or person; 
f.  The selling, leasing, trading or improving such real property as may be acquired in connection with business district development or redevelopment plans; 
g.  The development of areas for housing, recreational, social and commercial uses necessary for the development or redevelopment of a business district. 
(5)  To collect information on opportunities for business and investment in the village. 
(6)  To prepare pamphlets explaining opportunities in the village. 
(7)  To prepare pamphlets outlining village regulations affecting businesses. 
(8)  To prepare pamphlets pointing out village regulations relating to energy conservation and environmental protection. 
(9)  To assist the corporate authorities in plans to expand the tax base of the village. 
(10)  To assist the corporate authorities in plans to increase the opportunity for village residents to obtain local employment. 
(11)  To exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted by state law as my be conferred by the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. No. 3471, § 9, 4-14-08)  
ARTICLE XXIX. - COMMUNITY PRIDE COMMISSION[20] 

Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2350, §§ 1—8, adopted June 12, 1989, not specifically amendatory of the Code, has been included herein as Ch. 2, Art. XXIX, §§ 2-2901—2-2908, at the discretion of the editor. 
 
Sec. 2-2901. - Created. 
There is hereby created the Villa Park Community Pride Commission. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 1, 6-12-89)  
Sec. 2-2902. - Intent; purpose. 
It shall be the intent and purpose of the village community pride commission to advise the president and board of trustees on matters relating to the overall image of the village including physical beautification, public relations, and coordination and promotion of volunteers and volunteerism within the village. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 2, 6-12-89)  
Sec. 2-2903. - Membership. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall consist of eleven (11) members including the chairperson and two (2) junior members, appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, to serve without compensation. To be eligible to serve on the commission, persons shall be either qualified electors of the village who have resided therein for one (1) year immediately preceding their appointment, or have a place of business within the corporate limits of the village (with the exception of the two (2) junior members). Members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years, except that the members first appointed to the commission shall serve as follows: three (3) for one (1) year, three (3) for two (2) years and three (3) for three (3) years. The term of junior members shall be for one (1) year. 
(b)  All appointments shall expire the thirtieth of April of the appropriate year. Any member of the commission may resign at any time during the term for which he/she was appointed, which resignation shall be addressed to the village president. Vacancies on the commission shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose position becomes vacant in the manner provided herein. 
(c)  If any member of the commission shall cease to maintain the status qualifying him for appointment to the commission, or shall fail to attend three (3) consecutive meetings of the commission without being excused by a vote of a majority of the members of the commission, such member may be considered as having resigned his membership. Report of such change of status or failure of attendance may be reported to the corporate authorities and, if such report is accepted by the corporate authorities, the membership in question shall be declared vacant and it shall be the duty of the president to appoint a qualified successor to such membership in the manner provided herein. Any member of the commission may be removed for cause by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 3, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 3470, § 2, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 3546, § 2, 4-13-09)  
Sec. 2-2903.1. - Junior members. 
Two (2) junior members shall be appointed to the community pride commission by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, to serve without compensation. Junior members shall be between the ages of thirteen (13) and seventeen (17) and residents of the village. Junior members under the age of sixteen (16) shall serve only with the consent of parents or legal guardian. The term for junior members shall be one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 3546, § 3, 4-13-09)  
Sec. 2-2904. - Officers. 
A chairman of the commission created herein shall be elected by the members of the commission for a term of two (2) years. The commission may designate one (1) of its members to act as secretary, together with such other officers as it deems fit. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 4, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 3470, § 3, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2905. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the commission created herein shall be held on the fourth Tuesday of each month in the Village Hall at such time as may be established by the commission. No junior member of the commission shall be required or permitted to violate curfew laws while serving on this commission, either at regularly scheduled meetings or other commission activities. 
(b)  Special meetings of the commission may be called by the chairperson or any two (2) voting members with at least forty-eight (48) hours' written notice prior to the special meeting. Notice of any special meeting shall be provided in accordance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act and shall be posted in the Village Hall. 
(c)  The action of a majority of the members present at a meeting at which a quorum is present shall be the action of the members. 
(d)  The presence of five (5) commission members shall constitute a quorum to transact any commission business at a regular or special meeting of the commission. Junior members shall not be counted toward a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 5, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 2941, § 3, 5-18-98; Ord. No. 3470, § 4, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 3546, § 4, 4-13-09)  
Sec. 2-2906. - Expenditures. 
Expenses for the operation and transaction of the affairs of the commission shall be paid from such funds as may be provided for such purpose in the annual appropriation and budget ordinances of the village; provided, however, that the village manager has approved same prior to the expense being incurred. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 6, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 3470, § 5, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2907. - Reports and records. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall keep permanent minutes of its meetings, which shall include topics discussed, the motions and vote of each member upon each topic submitted to it. 
(b)  The commission shall prepare and submit minutes of each meeting within a reasonable time after each of its meeting, and the chairperson shall forward copies of the minutes, together with any special reports regard matters or issues of concern, to the manager. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 7, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 3470, § 6, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-2908. - Powers and duties. 
The village community pride commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities procedures for the planning, execution, and implementation of the intents and purposes of the commission. 
(2)  To solicit donations, either in cash, goods, or services, for the physical beautification and enhancement of the image of the village. Any cash received shall be paid to the village treasurer who shall segregate and deposit said moneys into a special line item account which shall be known as the Community Pride Account. 
(3)  To coordinate a volunteer program and to encourage volunteerism within the village. 
(4)  To recommend to the corporate authorities activities which the commission believes will accomplish its intents and purposes. 
(5)  To prepare pamphlets to educate the citizens of the village concerning the goals and objectives of the commission. 
(6)  As the commission deems appropriate, to sponsor, and coordinate with other boards, commissions, community civic organizations, merchants groups or associations, a village "Clean-Up Week." 
(7)  To encourage neighborhoods to work together through formation of homeowners' associations or neighborhood improvement groups. 
(8)  To undertake such other activities as will promote the goals and objectives of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 8, 6-12-89)  
ARTICLE XXX. - CABLE TV COMMISSION[21] 

Footnotes: 
--- (21) --- 
Cross reference— Cable communications, Ch. 7.5. 
 
Sec. 2-3001. - Created. 
There is hereby created the Villa Park Cable TV Commission. 
(Ord. No. 2352, § 1, 6-12-89)  
Sec. 2-3002. - Intent; purpose. 
It shall be the intent and purpose of the village cable TV commission to oversee the training and scheduling of camera operators to televise village board meetings for the benefit of all citizens of the village. 
(Ord. No. 2352, § 2, 6-12-89)  
Sec. 2-3003. - Membership. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall consist of seven (7) members including the chairperson, appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, to serve without compensation. To be eligible to serve on the commission, persons shall be either qualified electors of the village who have resided therein for one (1) year immediately preceding their appointment, or have a place of business within the corporate limits of the village, or be employed within the corporate limits of the village. Members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years with staggered terms so that terms of two (2) members shall expire the first and second years and the terms of three (3) members shall expire the third year. 
(b)  All appointments shall expire the thirtieth (30th) of April of the appropriate year. Any member of the commission may resign at any time during the term for which he/she was appointed, which resignation shall be addressed to the village president. Vacancies on the commission shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose position becomes vacant in the manner provided herein. 
(c)  If any member of the commission shall cease to maintain the status qualifying him for appointment to the commission, or shall fail to attend three (3) consecutive meetings of the commission without being excused by a vote of a majority of the members of the commission, such member may be considered as having resigned his membership. Report of such change of status or failure of attendance may be reported to the corporate authorities and, if such report is accepted by the corporate authorities, the membership in question shall be declared vacant and it shall be the duty of the president to appoint a qualified successor to such membership in the manner provided herein. Any member of the commission may be removed for cause by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2352, § 3, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 3469, § 2, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 3865 , § 3, 5-11-15)  
Sec. 2-3004. - Officers. 
A chairman of the commission created herein shall be elected by the members of the commission for a term of two (2) years. The commission may designate one (1) of its members to act as secretary, together with such other officers as it deems fit. 
(Ord. No. 2352, § 4, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 3469, § 3, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-3005. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the commission shall be held on the second Monday of each month in the Village Hall at such time as may be established by the commission. 
(b)  Special meetings of the commission may be called by the chairperson or any two (2) voting members with at least forty-eight (48) hours' written notice prior to the special meeting. Notice of any special meeting shall be provided in accordance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act and shall be posted in the Village Hall. 
(c)  The action of a majority of the members present at a meeting at which a quorum is present shall be the action of the members. 
(d)  The presence of four (4) commission members shall constitute a quorum to transact any commission business at a regular or special meeting of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 2352, § 5, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 2941, § 4, 5-18-98; Ord. No. 3469, § 4, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 3865 , § 4, 5-11-15; Ord. No. 4055 , § 1, 10-22-18)  
Sec. 2-3006. - Expenditures. 
Expenses for the operation and transaction of the affairs of the commission shall be paid from such funds as may be provided for such purpose in the annual appropriation and budget ordinances of the village; provided, however, that the village manager has approved same prior to the expense being incurred. 
(Ord. No. 2352, § 6, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 3469, § 5, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-3007. - Reports and records. 
(a)  The commission created herein shall keep permanent minutes of its meetings, which shall include topics discussed, the motions and vote of each member upon each topic submitted to it. 
(b)  The commission shall prepare and submit minutes of each meeting within a reasonable time after each of its meeting, and the chairperson shall forward copies of the minutes, together with any special reports regard matters or issues of concern, to the manager. 
(Ord. No. 2352, § 7, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 3469, § 6, 4-14-08)  
Sec. 2-3008. - Powers and duties. 
The village cable TV commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities procedures for the planning, execution, and implementation of the intents and purposes of the commission. 
(2)  To receive training to operate television and video cameras and to keep a schedule of operators to use cameras and related equipment for televising public meetings of the village board for broadcast to the citizens of the village. 
(3)  To make such other recommendations to the village board which the commission considers necessary to implement the spirit and intent of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2352, § 8, 6-12-89)  
Secs. 2-3009—2-3100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXXI. - INDEMNIFICATION 
 
Sec. 2-3101. - Indemnification of officers and employees. 
To the fullest extent permitted by the Constitution of the State of Illinois and applicable state law and subject to the applicable terms, conditions and exclusions of any liability coverage documents of the village, the following officials or employees: 
(1)  All persons who were, now are, or shall be lawfully elected, appointed or employed officials of the village; 
(2)  All members of commissions, boards or other units operated by and under the jurisdiction of the village; 
(3)  All employees and all persons who perform a service on a volunteer basis for the village and under its direction and control and any persons providing services to the village under any mutual aid or similar agreement; 
(4)  Police and fire pension boards, their trustees, commissioners and public officials; and 
(5)  Employees and public officials of the village serving on the board of any independent governmental or intergovernmental or not-for-profit organization, in which the village has an affiliation, upon the following conditions: service on the board is approved by the village and furthers the interest of the village; 
shall be indemnified, defended and held harmless by the village from and against all liabilities, for compensatory damages, expenses of investigation, judgments and amounts paid in settlement which may be imposed upon or reasonably incurred or paid by such official or employee in connection with or resulting from any claim made against him/her, or any action, suit, proceeding or investigation in which he/she may be involved, by reason of his/her being or having been such official or such employee of the village and acting within the scope of his/her employment or official duties. 
The foregoing rights of indemnification shall be in addition to any other rights to which such official or employee may be entitled as a matter of law. 
(Ord. No. 3061, § 2, 10-23-00)  
Sec. 2-3102. - Police officer indemnification. 
Indemnification shall be provided by the village to police officers as provided by applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 3061, § 2, 10-23-00)  
ARTICLE XXXII. - SPECIAL EVENTS REVIEW COMMITTEE 
 
Sec. 2-3201. - Committee created. 
There is hereby created a standing special events review committee of the village. 
(Ord. No. 3896 , § 1, 12-14-15)  
Sec. 2-3202. - Intent and purpose. 
The purpose of the special events review committee shall be as follows: 
(1)  To advise the president and board of trustees on issues, events and activities relating to the identification of successful special events and make recommendations to improve or restructure existing events to make the village more visible, attract additional attendees and to ensure financial sustainability. 
(2)  To recommend to the president and board of trustees suggestions concerning the financial, event timing, event structure, event needs and location, volunteer involvement and providing recommendations for future successful village events and festivals. 
(Ord. No. 3896 , § 1, 12-14-15)  
Sec. 2-3203. - Membership.
