(Ord. No. 2730, § 2, 10-10-94)  
Sec. 4-333. - Location restrictions; maximum number of devices. 
The temporary coin-operated amusement device license shall be issued for a specific location; provided however, that such location must be located within a building or other permanent structure located in a planned unit development which houses a licensed electronic game room. The number of devices authorized under a temporary coin-operated amusement device license shall not exceed fifty (50). Once a license has been issued, the total number of authorized devices shall not be increased, but different devices may be substituted as provided in subsection 4-337(2). 
(Ord. No. 2730, § 2, 10-10-94)  
Sec. 4-334. - Compliance with codes and regulations. 
The community development department and the fire department shall inspect the premises and location for which the temporary coin-operated amusement license shall be issued to determine whether same complies with the village's electrical code and all other applicable building, zoning and fire codes of the village. 
(Ord. No. 2730, § 2, 10-10-94)  
Sec. 4-335. - Operational rules and regulations. 
(a)  Hours of operation. Operation of the coin-operated amusement devices licensed pursuant to this division 3 shall not be permitted between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
(b)  Space requirements. 
(1)  No coin-operated amusement devices shall be placed closer than one (1) foot from another coin-operated amusement device. 
(2)  A five-foot wide unobstructed aisle shall be provided at all times whenever a coin-operated amusement device(s) is located along only one (1) side of an aisle, and an eight-foot wide unobstructed aisle shall be provided whenever coin-operated amusement devices are located on both sides of an aisle. 
(c)  Age restrictions. 
(1)  During school hours when school is in session, no person under the age of sixteen (16) years shall be permitted within the area wherein coin-operated amusement devices authorized pursuant to a temporary coin-operated amusement device license are displayed or kept. 
(2)  Unless accompanied by a parent or by a guardian who is not less than eighteen (18) years old, no person under the age of eleven (11) years shall be permitted within the area wherein coin-operated amusement devices authorized pursuant to a temporary coin-operated amusement device license are displayed or kept. 
(d)  Signage requirements. A sign containing the following information in letters at least one (1) inch high shall be posted at each entrance to the area wherein coin-operated amusement devices authorized pursuant to a temporary coin-operated amusement device license are displayed or kept: 
(1)  Hours of operation. 
(2)  Age and time restrictions. 
(3)  Curfew laws. 
(e)  Other operational regulations. 
(1)  No pool tables shall be permitted as part of the coin-operated amusement devices authorized by any temporary license issued pursuant to this division 3. 
(2)  Devices may grant free games to a player upon the player attaining a certain score or scores, but shall not pay-off in money, prizes, or other tangible awards. 
(3)  A temporary coin-operated amusement device license shall be issued not more often than once every twelve (12) months for any authorized location. 
(4)  A temporary coin-operated amusement device license shall only be issued for a single consecutive period of time not to exceed fourteen (14) days. 
(5)  Not more than two (2) nonself-contained devices shall be authorized as part of the issuance of any temporary coin-operated amusement device license. 
(6)  Upon expiration of the temporary coin-operated amusement device license, the devices listed on the license shall be removed, unless otherwise licensed pursuant to the Villa Park Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 2730, § 2, 10-10-94)  
Sec. 4-336. - Fee for temporary coin-operated amusement device license. 
The fee for the license shall be an amount equal to one hundred dollars ($100.00) multiplied by the total number of coin-operated amusement devices for which the license is issued. 
(Ord. No. 2730, § 2, 10-10-94)  
Sec. 4-337. - Issuance of license. 
(a)  When issued, the license shall specify: the name of the person entitled to display for public patronage or keep for operation more than fifty (50) coin-operated amusement devices; the permitted location for the devices; the name of the owner of the devices, if different from the operator; the serial number and generic description of each device, including tradename where appropriate; the dates for which the license is issued; the total amount of fees paid; and the total number of authorized devices. Only those specific devices listed on the license shall be permitted to be operated on the dates specified on the license. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee to substitute devices without notification to and approval of the village manager. In such case, the licensee shall surrender the license and the original license shall be amended to reflect the change in authorized devices. 
(Ord. No. 2730, § 2, 10-10-94)  
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRONIC GAME ROOMS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ordinance No. 2526, adopted October 21, 1991, amended Art. IV, §§ 4-401—4-405 to read as set out herein. Prior to such amendment, said sections contained similar provisions and derived from Ord. No. 1993, § 1, adopted Sept. 28, 1981. 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and business regulations, Ch. 13. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 4-401. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise defined in this article, words and phrases used in this article shall have their commonly understood meanings. As used herein, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings set forth below: 
Electronic game room: Any facility where the principal business activity is the operation of coin-operated amusement devices. 
Person: Any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any individual, firm, partnership, company, corporation, association, society, enterprise, club, or other agency. 
All definitions contained in section 4-301 of this chapter are incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-402. - Licenses. 
(a)  Required. No person, firm or corporation shall operate or maintain an electronic game room within the corporate limits of the village without first having secured a license therefor, as provided in this section, and the license(s) required by article III of this chapter. 
(b)  Separate license required for each location; change of location. Any license issued pursuant to this article shall apply only to the location designated on said license. Such location may be changed only upon written permission of the village manager when application for such transfer shall have been made upon forms approved by the village manager, and with the same requirements for issuance of a license as for the original premises. An application for such transfer must be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of ten dollars ($10.00). No change of location shall be permitted unless the proposed new location is in compliance with the provisions of this article and any other applicable provision of this Code. 
(c)  Term of license; nontransferability. Any license issued pursuant to this article shall be valid for a period not to exceed one (1) year after issuance unless sooner revoked or expired as provided herein, and shall not constitute property; nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution; nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. Such license shall cease upon the death of the licensee, if an individual, and shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate devolution; provided that executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee may continue the business and may exercise the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the date of the death of such decedent or the filing of such insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of such license, but in no event longer than six (6) months after the death, bankruptcy, or insolvency of such licensee. 
(d)  Display. The license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall at all times be displayed in a prominent place on the licensed premises. 
(e)  Subject to changes. All licenses issued pursuant to this article shall be subject to any and all changes or amendment which may be hereafter made. 
(f)  Expiration and renewal. 
(1)  Each game room license shall terminate on the 14 th day of April of each year. All applications for renewal of any license shall be made on or before thirty (30) days prior to the expiration thereof. 
(2)  The owner, or his legal representative, of a game room license shall have and be given the privilege of renewal or reissuance of a village game room license at the same or a different place of business upon the payment of an annual fee as stated in section 4-406 of this article upon compliance with the regulations and ordinances of the village, now in force, or which may hereafter be passed governing the issuance of retail liquor licenses. The privilege of renewal or reissuance provided by this section shall apply only so long as the license in each case shall have been kept in force continually and uninterruptedly in the name of the licensee or his successor in interest. The suspension of a license shall not be construed to be an interruption and shall in nowise affect a renewal or reissuance. 
(3)  Any licensee may renew his license at the expiration thereof, provided that he is then qualified to receive a license, and the premises for which such renewal license is sought are suitable for such purpose; provided further, that the renewal privilege herein provided for shall not be construed as a vested right which shall in any case prevent the corporate authorities of the village from decreasing the number of licenses to be issued within its jurisdiction or from otherwise further regulating the operation of game rooms within the village. 
(g)  Manager's powers with reference to licenses. The village manager shall have the following powers, functions and duties with respect to licenses: 
(1)  To grant an electronic game room license to any applicant who is qualified, as hereinafter set forth, and to suspend for not more than thirty (30) days, or revoke for cause any license issued hereunder. 
(2)  To enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter at any time upon any premises licensed hereunder to determine whether any of the provisions of this Code are being violated and at such time to examine said premises of said licensee in connection therewith. 
(3)  To receive complaint from any citizen that any of the provisions of this Code have been or are being violated, and to act upon such complaint, or upon his own motion, in the manner provided herein. 
(4)  To receive license fees and pay same to the village treasurer. 
(5)  To examine, or cause to be examined under oath, any application for a game room license or for a renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of revocation or suspension has been served in the manner hereinafter provided, and to examine, or cause to be examined, the books and records of any such applicant or licensee; to hear testimony and take proof for his information in the performance of his duties, and for such purpose to issue subpoenas. For the purpose of obtaining any of the information desired under this subsection, he may authorize his agent to act on his behalf. 
(6)  To make and enforce such reasonable rules as may be necessary in the performance of his duties. 
(7)  To prescribe the form of application which each prospective licensee shall sign prior to receiving a license hereunder. 
(8)  To keep or cause to be kept a complete record of all licenses issued under this article and to cause said list to be available for public inspection during regular business hours at the village hall. 
(9)  To provide a copy of the list of license issued under this article to the village clerk, treasurer and chief of police, and upon the issuance of any new license or the revocation of any old license, to notify each of those officers within forty-eight (48) hours of such action. Failure to notify the above-named officials shall not affect the validity of any license issued hereunder. 
(10)  Such other powers and duties as may from time to time be designated by the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91; Ord. No. 3385, § 4, 9-18-06)  
Sec. 4-403. - Persons eligible for game room license. 
No license to operate a game room within the corporate limits of the village shall be issued to: 
(1)  A person whose game room license has been revoked. 
(2)  A person who does not qualify for or does not possess a coin-operated amusement device license. 
(3)  A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community in which he resides. 
(4)  A person who is not a citizen of the United States of America. 
(5)  A person who has been convicted of a felony under any federal or state law unless, after investigation, the village manager determines that such person has not been sufficiently rehabilitated to warrant the public trust. 
(6)  A person who has been convicted of any offense under Article 11 of Chapter 38 of the Criminal Code of 1961, approved July 28, 1961, as heretofore or hereafter amended, or as prescribed by a statute replacing any of the aforesaid statutory provisions. 
(7)  A person who holds a license for any liquor license establishment within the corporate limits of the village. 
(8)  A person whose liquor license, issued under chapter 3 of this Code, or under the Illinois Liquor Control Law, has been revoked for cause. 
(9)  A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license issued hereunder would not be eligible for such license upon a first application. 
(10)  A copartnership, if any general partnership thereof, or any limited partnership thereof, owning more than five (5) percent of the aggregate limited partner interest in such copartnership would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder. 
(11)  A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate amount of five (5) percent of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder. 
(12)  A corporation unless it is incorporated in Illinois, or unless it is a foreign corporation which is qualified under the Illinois Business Corporation Act to transact business in Illinois. 
(13)  A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent, unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the licensee, except for citizenship and residence within the village. 
(14)  A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor or has forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such violation. 
(15)  A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which a license is sought or does not have a lease thereof for the full period for which the license is to be issued. 
(16)  Any person, association or corporation selling or servicing coin-in-the-slot mechanical pinball devices. 
(17)  Any person already having game room licenses for any premises within the corporate limits of the village. 
(18)  Any law enforcing public official, including the village president or any member of the village board of trustees. 
(19)  A person who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated by the licensee. 
(20)  A person who has been convicted of a gambling offense as prescribed by any of subsections (a)(3) through (a)(10) of Section 28-1 of, or as prescribed by Section 28-3 of, the Criminal Code of 1961, approved July 28, 1961, as heretofore or hereafter amended, or as prescribed by a statute replaced by any of the aforesaid statutory provisions. 
(21)  A person to whom a federal gaming device stamp or a federal wagering stamp has been issued by the federal government for the current tax period. 
(22)  A copartnership to which a federal wagering stamp has been issued by the federal government for the current tax period, or if any of the partners have been issued a federal gaming device stamp or federal wagering stamp by the federal government for the current tax period. 
(23)  A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder owning in the aggregate more than twenty (20) percent of the stock of such corporation has been issued a federal gaming device stamp or a federal wagering stamp for the current tax period. 
(24)  Any premises for which a federal gaming device stamp or a federal wagering stamp has been issued by the federal government for the current tax period. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-404. - Investigation and fingerprinting of applicant. 
(a)  No license shall be issued pursuant to the provisions of this article until the applicant shall have been investigated and a report filed in the records of the village approving the issuance of such license. As a part of this investigation, all new applicants not heretofore licensed or any manager not heretofore approved shall be fingerprinted and photographed by the village police department. A copy of fingerprint cards and photographs shall be held on record by the police department and a copy of the same shall be held by the village manager. 
(b)  Completed investigations for license applications shall be valid for a period of ninety (90) days after the license applicant has been notified of approval by the village manager. Any applicant who fails to take all required action, including payment of original issuance fee and annual fee, to obtain a license within ninety (90) days after notification shall not be eligible for a license until a new background investigation is completed and additional investigation fees paid. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-405. - Investigation fee. 
There shall be a two-hundred-dollar investigation fee for each person who is required to submit to an investigation for a game room license. The fee shall be presented with the application. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-406. - Annual license and annual fee. 
(a)  The annual license fee for all game room licenses within the village shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Said annual license fee shall be payable upon the original issuance of a license by the village manager and shall not be prorated in any manner. Said annual license fee shall thereafter be paid on or before April 15 th of each year and shall accompany each request for renewal of a license. The licensee under any license issued pursuant to this section that expires on January 1, 2007 shall pay a renewal fee of three hundred thirty three dollars ($333.00) for the period January 1, 2007—May 1, 2007. Said fee shall be paid on or before January 1, 2007. 
(b)  In addition to the game room license fees and associated fees imposed by this article, the licensee shall also secure a coin-operated amusement device license and pay the appropriate fee therefore and shall also pay a fee of one hundred ten dollars ($110.00) for each coin-operated amusement device, all as set forth in article III of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91; Ord. No. 3385, § 5, 9-18-06)  
Sec. 4-407. - Disposition of fees. 
All fees shall be paid to the village manager at the time application is made, and shall be turned over to the village treasurer forthwith. In the event the license applied for is denied, the fee, with the exception of background investigation fees and other nonrefundable fees, shall be returned to the applicant. If the license is granted, then the fee shall be deposited in the general corporate fund or in such other fund as shall have been designated by the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-408. - Bond. 
All licensees shall, simultaneously with the issuance of the license applied for, file a surety company bond with the village clerk, conditioned that licensee shall in all respects, in the conduct of the business for which the license has been granted, obey and observe all the provisions of this article. Said bond shall be in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and be for the entire term of the license for which application is made. If, after hearing as provided herein, a licensee shall be found to be in violation of any of the provisions of this article, said bond shall thereupon be forfeited. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-409. - Location restrictions. 
(a)  The operation of a game room within the village shall be allowed: 
(1)  Within a planned unit development containing those uses allowed in a C-3 service business district; or 
(2)  As a conditional use within a C-3 service business district. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, electronic game rooms shall in no event be allowed: 
(1)  Within six hundred (600) feet of any church or school; 
(2)  Within one hundred (100) feet of any establishment holding any of the following liquor licenses: Class A, AA, or AAA; 
(3)  Within one thousand five hundred (1,500) feet of an establishment holding a game room license within the village. 
The determination of the foregoing distances shall be made by measuring on a straight line from the nearest point of one premises to the nearest point of the other. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Secs. 4-410—4-419. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION 
 
Sec. 4-420. - Fine in lieu of revocation or suspension. 
A license granted pursuant to the provisions of this article may be suspended by the village manager for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days for the violation of any part or portion of this article, or for any violation of any state or federal law. During such period of suspension, no business activity may be conducted on the licensed premises. In lieu of, or in addition to a period of revocation or suspension, the village manager may levy a fine on the licensee for such violations. The fine imposed shall not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation; each day on which a violation occurs shall constitute a separate violation. No more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) in fines under this section may be imposed against any licensee during any annual license period. Proceeds from such fines shall be paid into the general corporate fund. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-421. - Notice of hearing. 
Upon a complaint being made of a violation of this article or any other article or chapter of this Code or of any state or federal law, the village manager shall set the matter for hearing and shall serve notice upon the licensee or his agent of the time and place of such hearing and of the particular charge. Notice as herein required shall be by registered or certified mail, postage prepaid, or by leaving a copy of said notice at said licensed place of business at least three (3) days before the date of hearing, or by personal service. No hearing for revocation or suspension of a license or the imposition of any fine on any licensee shall take place without notice having been given in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-422. - Specific grounds. 
(a)  No licensee holding a game room license or his agent or employee shall, in the conduct of the licensed premises or upon the licensed premises: 
(1)  Violate any village ordinance or resolution regulating game rooms or coin-operated amusement devices; or 
(2)  Suffer or permit a violation of any state or federal law. 
(b)  The village manager may revoke or suspend any license for any violation of this article or any other article of this Code. 
(c)  A violation may be proved by evidence that the licensee or his agent or employee has been convicted of a violation of any law of the State of Illinois in the conduct of the licensed premises or upon the licensed premises, or has been found guilty of violating any village ordinance regulating the licensed premises. 
(d)  Evidence that any person, including but not limited to an agent or employee of the licensee, other than the licensee, has been convicted of violating a statute of the state, or found guilty of violating a village ordinance or rule regulating the operation of the business on the licensed premises, shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this article. 
(e)  Proof by a preponderance of evidence at any hearing conducted in accordance with this article shall be sufficient cause for revocation or suspension of any license issued hereunder, irrespective of whether or not a conviction has been obtained in any court. 
(f)  Any false or fraudulent statement made on any application for a game room license by any applicant therefor shall be sufficient cause for revocation or suspension by the village manager of such license. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-423. - Hearing and decision. 
No game room license shall be revoked or suspended except after a public hearing by the village manager with written notice to the licensee affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend. The village manager shall, within five (5) days after such hearing, if he determines after such hearing that the license should be revoked or suspended, state the reason or reasons for such determination in a written order of revocation or suspension and shall serve a copy of such order within the said five-day period upon the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-424. - Appeals. 
An appeal from an order or action of the village manager may be made to the president and board of trustees of the village, provided that such appeal is filed with the village clerk within ten (10) days after receipt of the order of the village manager. The determination of the president and board of trustees with respect to any appeal shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Secs. 4-425—4-429. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - OPERATIONAL RULES AND REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 4-430. - Hours of operation. 
It shall be unlawful for any game room licensed pursuant to the provisions of this article to operate between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-431. - Employees. 
(a)  At all times when any game room licensed pursuant to the provision of this article is open to the public, a manager who is not less than twenty-one (21) years of age shall be on the premises. In addition, if any game room contains more than ten (10) coin-operated amusement devices, a uniformed security guard who has been approved by the village police department must be provided at all times when school is not in session. 
(b)  No person who has been convicted of any offense under Article 11 of Chapter 38 of the Criminal Code of 1961, approved July 28, 1961, as heretofore or hereafter amended, or as prescribed by a statute replaced by any of the aforesaid statutory provisions, shall be employed in any capacity in an electronic game room. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-432. - Noise restrictions. 
(a)  Any premises used or proposed to be used as an electronic game room shall meet the following decibel (db) standards as measured with a sound level meter manufactured in compliance with the standards prescribed by the American Standards Association at the property line of the premises on which the game room is located: 
Maximum Levels(db) 
Nature of Noise 	Commercial Areas 	Residential Areas 
Cumulative 30 minutes per hour 	45 	40 
Cumulative 5 minutes per hour 	55 	50 
Cumulative 1 minute or less per hour 	60 	55 
 
(b)  Noise upon adjacent tenants shall not exceed the average interior noise level of adjacent tenant spaces. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-433. - Control of litter. 
Areas in and around game rooms, including parking areas (whether private or shared) shall be cleaned daily and shall remain free from accumulation of litter of any kind and be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition. Each owner or operator of a game room licensed hereunder shall file with the village manager, as part of his application for a game room license, a statement of responsibility or compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-434. - Structural and space requirements. 
(a)  Restroom facilities shall comply with all regulations required by the state plumbing code or any other plumbing code adopted by the village at any time, including compliance with the minimum number of plumbing fixtures. 
(b)  No coin-operated amusement device shall be placed closer than one (1) foot from another coin-operated amusement device. 
(c)  A five-foot-wide unobstructed aisle shall be provided at all times whenever a coin-operated amusement device(s) is located along only one (1) side of an aisle, and an eight-foot-wide unobstructed aisle shall be provided whenever coin-operated amusement devices are located on both sides of an aisle. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-435. - Parking requirements. 
(a)  Requirements for automobile parking. One (1) offstreet parking space shall be provided for each four (4) coin-operated amusement devices, or one (1) parking space for each two hundred (200) square feet of floor area, whichever is greater. 
(b)  Requirement for bicycle parking. Not less than one (1) space, to be designated as bicycle parking, shall be provided for each coin-operated amusement device. Bicycle parking spaces shall be located so as not to obstruct entrances, exits or walkways, and may not be located within any required parking or landscaped areas. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-436. - Age restrictions. 
No person under the age of sixteen (16) years shall be permitted on the premises of any electronic game room during school hours when school is in session. No person under the age of eleven (11) years shall be permitted on the premises of any electronic game room unless accompanied by a parent or by a guardian who is not less than eighteen (18) years old. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-437. - Signage requirements. 
A sign containing the following information in letters at least one (1) inch high shall be posted at each entrance: 
(1)  Hours of operation; 
(2)  Age and time restrictions; 
(3)  Curfew laws; and 
(4)  Prohibiting eating, drinking or smoking on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Sec. 4-438. - Other operational regulations. 
(a)  Eating, drinking or smoking shall not be permitted in any electronic game room and no cigarette vending machine shall be permitted on any portion of any premises licensed pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Pool tables shall not be permitted in electronic game rooms. 
(c)  Coin-operated amusement devices may grant free games to a player upon the player attaining a certain score or scores, but shall not pay off in money, prizes, or other tangible awards. 
(Ord. No. 2526, § 2, 10-21-91)  
Chapter 5 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Nuisances, Ch. 15; fence regulations for dog pounds or runs, App. C, Art. 22, § 22.7. 
State Law reference— Animal Control Act, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 8, § 351 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 5-101. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the following terms shall have the indicated meanings: 
Animal: Any animal, other than man, which may be affected by rabies. 
Animal control center: A place designated by the village manager for the housing of animals and the temporary custody of the village. 
Dog: All members of the family Canidae. 
Neutered animal: A male or female animal treated by a licensed veterinarian to render it incapable of reproduction. 
Owner: Any person who has 
(a)  a right of property in an animal or a dog, 
(b)  keeps an animal or a dog, 
(c)  has an animal or dog in his care or custody, 
(d)  who knowingly permits an animal or dog to remain on or about any premises occupied by him, or 
(e)  who shall harbor, suffer, or permit any animal or dog to remain on any premises within the village under his charge or control. 
Run at large: A dog or animal free of physical restraint off the premises of its owner. 
Vicious animal: Any animal or dog which bites or in any other manner attacks or attempts to attack, except that any animal or dog that bites, attacks, or attempts to attack any person entering unlawfully upon its owner's premises, or which is provoked to attack, shall not be deemed a vicious animal. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. I, § 2, 2-18-80)  
Sec. 5-102. - Enforcement officers. 
(a)  The village manager shall designate a suitable place for housing of dogs and other animals in the temporary custody of the Village of Villa Park, which place shall be a designated animal control center. The village manager shall periodically review and determine whether or not the fees imposed by the center are reasonable. Only such fees as determined by the manager as being reasonable shall be the basis for the impounding fee in subparagraph (e). 
(b)  Police officers and animal control enforcement officers so designated by the village manager shall enforce this chapter. Police officers, as well as animal control enforcement officers shall have the authority to issue citations for violation of this chapter and shall also have the power to impound dogs running at large. Said dogs shall be impounded at a designated animal control center. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. II, §§ 1, 2, 2-18-80; Ord. No. 2604, § 1, 11-23-92)  
Sec. 5-103. - Cruelty to animals. 
No person or owner may abandon, cruelly beat, torment, overload, overwork, or otherwise abuse animals or dogs in a manner to cause unnecessary suffering. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. V, § 1, 2-18-80) 
State Law reference— Power of municipality to prohibit cruelty to animals, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-5-6.  
Sec. 5-104. - Keeping poultry, cattle, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain any stable or poultry yard, or place for the housing of any poultry, cattle, horses, pigs or goats or similar animals, or to house any such animals in the village. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 1, 12-18-22)  
Sec. 5-105. - Condition of pens and premises. 
No person shall cause or allow any pen, premises or other place where any animal is or may be kept to become unclean, filthy or unwholesome. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 2, 12-18-22)  
Sec. 5-106. - Running at large. 
It shall be unlawful for the person having charge of any livestock or fowl to permit it to run at large. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any dangerous or vicious animal to run at large. 
(Ord. No. 100, § 2, 12-18-22) 
State Law reference— Power of municipality to prohibit animals from running at large, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-20-9.  
Sec. 5-107. - Vicious animals. 
(a)  No owner shall permit any vicious dog to be on any street, alley, or other public place within the village or upon the private premises of any person other than the owner of such dog, unless such dog is securely muzzled or caged. Vicious dogs on the premises of the owner shall be restrained so that they cannot attack persons lawfully on the premises and the premises shall be maintained so that children cannot gain access thereto. Any dog in violation of this section shall be impounded and shall not be returned to the owner until such time as the premises in question of the owner are in compliance with this section. 
(b)  If any vicious dog or other vicious animal cannot be safely taken and impounded when necessary for the protection of any person or property, it may be destroyed by a police officer or by a person authorized by the village to do so; provided, however, that in all cases where any animal so destroyed has bitten any person or caused an abrasion to the skin of any person, no injury shall be done to the head of such animal, and it shall be the duty of the person destroying the dog to immediately deliver the carcass to a licensed veterinarian to prepare the head and brain for delivery to the county rabies control department. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. V, § 6, 2-18-80)  
Sec. 5-108. - Diseased animals. 
No domestic animal afflicted with a contagious disease or an infectious disease shall be allowed to run at large or to be exposed in any public place whereby the health of other animals or man may be affected. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. V, § 7, 2-18-80)  
Sec. 5-109. - Impounding procedures. 
(a)  Police and animal control enforcement officers may impound in an animal control center unlicensed dogs four (4) months of age or over, any dog found running at large; any abandoned animal, or any animal maintained in violation of this chapter. A record shall be made of all impounded animals, entering the breed, color and sex, whether licensed or not, if known, and the name and address of the owner or keeper, if known. Said records shall be maintained at the police department. 
(b)  Immediately upon impoundment of any dog or animal, every effort shall be made to contact the owner of said dog or other animal. If an owner cannot be located, a description of the dog or animal shall be maintained for seven (7) days at the police department for possible inquiry by the public. 
(c)  Dogs or other animals impounded shall be held for a period of seven (7) days. The dog or other animal shall be held at the animal control center so designated by the village manager. The owner of said dog or other animal shall be responsible for the appropriate fees for boarding, impounding and release. In the event that no redemption is made of any dog or other animal thus impounded hereinabove, the chief of police may, at the expiration of seven (7) days from the time of impoundment: 
(1)  Release said dog or animal to a responsible person willing to provide a home for said dog or animal upon payment of all licenses and fees due. 
(2)  Authorize the destruction of said dog or animal by a veterinarian in a humane manner. 
(3)  Place with a humane society licensed under the Animal Welfare Act of the State of Illinois. 
Sundays and holidays shall be counted as "days" for the purpose of this section. The payment of the fees provided for in this section shall be in addition to any fines levied by the Circuit Court of DuPage County. Any dog or animal subject to this chapter not inoculated against rabies shall be taken forthwith by the owner to a licensed veterinarian for rabies inoculation. 
(d)  No person shall without authority interfere with the impounding or shall release any animal that has been impounded by the village. 
(e)  The following fees are applicable for all cases involving impounded dogs and other animals, providing, however, that the village manager has reviewed and approved the fee structure of any designated animal control center: 
(1)  Impounding fee, (first offense), one hundred fifty (150) percent of the fees imposed by the designated animal control center; 
(2)  Impounding fee, (second offense), two hundred (200) percent of the fees imposed by the designated animal control center; 
(3)  Impounding fee, (third offense), two hundred fifty (250) percent of the fees imposed by the designated animal control center; 
(4)  Impounding fee, (fourth offense or any subsequent offense), three hundred (300) percent of the fees imposed by the designated animal control center; 
(5)  Boarding fee, one hundred (100) percent of the fees imposed by the designated animal control center; 
(6)  Releasing fee, one hundred (100) percent of the fees imposed by the designated animal control center. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. IV, §§ 1—7, 2-18-80; Ord. No. 2604, § 2, 11-23-92)  
Sec. 5-110. - Nuisances. 
Any animal that repeatedly violates the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a nuisance and said animal may be destroyed in a humane fashion. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. VI, § 5, 2-18-80)  
Sec. 5-111. - Pet shops and kennels—License and regulations. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the business of pet shop operator or kennel operator or any combination thereof without a license issued by the State of Illinois in accordance with the Illinois Animal Welfare Act (225 ILCS 605/1 et seq.). 
(b)  No person shall operate a pet shop unless that pet shop is located entirely within a permanent building owned or leased for not less than one (1) year by the pet shop operator and in compliance with this Municipal Code. 
(c)  All pet shop operators and kennel operators shall: 
(1)  Comply with all sections of the Humane Care for Animals Act (510 ILCS 70). 
(2)  Have covered, leak-proof containers available for storage of waste materials before disposal to control vermin and insects. Such containers shall be maintained in a sanitary condition. 
(3)  Take effective control measures to prevent infestation of animals and premises with external parasites and vermin. 
(4)  Provide water from a source having sufficient pressure to properly sanitize and clean the facility and equipment. 
(5)  Provide hand washing facilities. 
(6)  All buildings shall be constructed so as to provide adequate shelter for the comfort of the animals and shall provide adequate facilities for their waste to avoid exposure to healthy and salable animals. 
(7)  Floors of buildings housing or displaying animals shall be able to be thoroughly cleaned and sanitized. Cleaning shall be performed daily, or more often if necessary, to prevent any accumulation of debris, dirt or waste. 
(8)  Cages shall be constructed of a material that is impervious to urine and water and able to withstand damage from gnawing and chewing. The cages must be cleaned and sanitized at least once daily or more often if necessary. All empty cages shall be kept clean at all times. Cages shall be of sufficient size to allow the animal to comfortably stand, sit, or lie and offer freedom of movement. 
(9)  Runs shall be constructed of material of sufficient strength and design to confine the animals. They shall be kept in good repair and condition. For new construction or remodeling, the licensee shall provide runs surfaced with concrete or other impervious material. Surface of the run shall be designed to permit the surface to be cleaned and kept free from excessive accumulation of animal waste. Provisions must be made for adequate drainage, including gutters and discharge of any fluid or content into a sewer, septic tank or filter field, and shall comply with this Code. 
(10)  Cages or aquariums for housing of small animals, birds, or fish shall provide space not less than two and one-half (2½) times the body volume of living creatures contained therein. 
(12)  Sufficient clean water and fresh food shall be offered to each animal daily as prescribed in the rules for the Federal Animal Welfare Act (9 CFR 3.5-3.7; 2006). In the case of young animals, they shall be fed more than once daily. Reptiles, fish or amphibians shall be fed and cared for in accordance with the eating patterns and environmental conditions compatible with each individual species. 
(13)  The licensee or his representative shall be present for general care and maintenance of the animals at least once daily. 
(14)  Aquariums containing fish shall be kept in a clean healthful condition. Live algae shall not be considered an unhealthful condition. Any dead fish shall be removed from aquariums. 
(15)  Adult cats shall be provided with litter pans at all times. The pans shall be cleaned and sanitized at least once daily or more often if necessary. 
(Ord. No. 3716, § 1, 9-24-12)  
ARTICLE II. - DOGS 
 
Sec. 5-201. - Maximum number. 
No person shall keep or permit more than three (3) dogs to be or remain in or about any single family residence, rooming house building or lot, more than one dog in any unit of a multi-family residence within the village. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. V, § 2, 2-18-80)  
Sec. 5-202. - Prohibited in public buildings and stores. 
It shall be unlawful for any dog, even though on a leash, to be in or enter any public building, food establishment, or any store except a store for the sale of animals or dogs, anywhere within the village during the time that any of said places are open for the use by the public. This section shall not apply to dogs leading blind persons, nor police-trained dogs utilized by the police for law enforcement purposes. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. V, § 4, 2-18-80)  
Sec. 5-203. - Prohibited in posted areas. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any dog, even though on a leash, or otherwise restrained, to go or be upon: 
(1)  Any school or village playground or playing field; 
(2)  Any sidewalk or walkway located within any school site or within village-owned park and recreation areas. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any dog, even though on a leash or otherwise restrained, to go or be upon any public property or public place located in the village if said property or place is posted "No Dogs Allowed". 
(c)  The provisions of subsections (a) and (b) shall not apply to leader dogs for the blind, nor police-trained dogs utilized by the police for law enforcement purposes. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. V, § 5, 2-18-80)  
Sec. 5-204. - Running at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an owner to permit a dog to use or be upon any public street, sidewalk, parkway, public area, or unenclosed premises within the village except on a leash controlled by the owner or other responsible person and obedient to the owner or responsible person's commands. If any dog is found running at large in the village, this fact shall be prima facie evidence that the owner allowed it to run at large in violation of this subsection. No leash shall be longer than eight (8) feet in length. 
(b)  Any person in control of a female dog in heat shall confine such dog in an enclosed area, as to preclude other dogs from being attracted to or coming in contact with such female dog, except for breeding planned by the person in control of said female dog. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. VI, §§ 2, 3, 2-18-80) 
State Law reference— Power of municipality to prohibit dogs from running at large, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-9.  
Sec. 5-205. - License. 
(a)  Any person owning within the village limits any dog four (4) months of age or over shall obtain a license for each dog within ten (10) days of acquiring such dog or becoming a resident of the village. Written application for such license shall be made at the village hall and shall state the name, address and telephone number of the owner and the name, breed, color, age, sex of such dog, the rabies inoculation certificate number, and any other information deemed necessary. A current rabies inoculation certificates for a dog shall be required at the time of the application for license, which shall certify that the inoculation is effective for the full current license year. No tag shall be transferred from one dog to another. The license shall expire on December 31 of each calendar year. New licenses, but not a renewal of a license for the previous year, shall be issued after July 1 for a half-year fee. 
(b)  Annual licenses are renewable on January 1 of each year. There shall be no license fee for dogs used to assist the blind or governmental police dogs. 
(c)  The annual license fee to be paid shall be four dollars ($4.00) for each dog. License fees shall be one-half price as of July 1 of each year for licensing of newly acquired dogs only. 
Multi-year licenses shall be available at the price of four dollars ($4.00) per annum for dogs which have received a rabies vaccination which has a multi-year efficiency period. 
The license fee shall be waived for dogs owned by senior citizens with proof of senior status. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. III, §§ 1, 3, 2-18-80; Ord. No. 2903, § 2, 10-20-97) 
State Law reference— Power of municipality to tax dogs, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-9.  
Sec. 5-206. - Collar. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog required to be licensed to keep such dog within the village limits unless it wears a collar with a dog license tag for the current license year attached at all times the dog is off the premises of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. III, § 2-18-80)  
Sec. 5-207. - Rabies vaccination. 
It is the duty of all persons owning or keeping a dog over four (4) months of age to have such dog vaccinated against rabies. The rabies vaccination shall be given in an amount sufficient to provide immunities from rabies for one (1) year and shall be administered by a licensed veterinarian. A certificate from a licensed veterinarian shall be furnished the village clerk. If the rabies inoculation is effective for a period in excess of one (1) year, the certificate shall so state. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. VII, § 1, 2-18-80)  
Sec. 5-208. - Dog bites. 
The police department shall cause to be investigated reports of dog bites. If a dog has bitten a person, the police department shall notify the owner of the dog and the dog shall be delivered promptly to a licensed veterinarian who shall confine or cause to be confined such dog as provided in the Animal Control Act, [Chapter 8, Section 351, et seq., Illinois Revised Statutes, 1979]. If the owner is not known, the police officer or animal control officer shall take such dog promptly to a licensed veterinarian to be confined, as provided in the Animal Control Act. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. VII, § 2, 2-18-80)  
Sec. 5-209. - Responsibility for removal of excreta. 
The owner of every dog shall be responsible for removal and sanitary disposition of any excreta deposited by his dog anywhere in the village. When accompanying the animal outside his premises, he shall have on his person means for the removal of such excreta. Failure to have means for removal on his person shall be a violation of any owner or person in control of a dog upon any public street, sidewalk, parkway, public area, or unenclosed premises within the village other than the premises of the person in control of said dog. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. VI, § 4, 2-18-80)  
Sec. 5-210. - Unauthorized removal of collars, tags, and muzzles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a police officer, animal control officer, licensed veterinarian, or owner to remove the collar, license tag, or muzzle from any dog within the limits of the village without the consent of the owner of such animal. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. V, § 3, 2-18-80)  
Sec. 5-211. - Compliance with state law. 
Every owner of a dog in the village shall comply with the Animal Control Act, the provisions of which are adopted by reference, three (3) copies of said Act being on file in the office of the village clerk, as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. VII, § 3, 2-18-80)  
Sec. 5-212. - Miscellaneous offenses. 
No owner shall permit or suffer his dog to: 
(1)  Disturb, harass, or intimidate persons or vehicles by chasing, barking at, biting, or attempting to bite. 
(2)  Attack other animals or dogs. 
(3)  Damage property other than that of the owner. 
(4)  Bark, whine, or howl excessively. 
(Ord. No. 1892, Art. VI, § 1, 2-18-80)  
Chapter 6 - BICYCLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 14. 
State Law reference— Power of municipality with reference to bicycles, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 95½, § 11-208(a)8. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 6-101. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter shall for the purpose of this ordinance have the meanings ascribed to them below: 
Bicycle: Every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having two (2) tandem wheels either of which is more than sixteen (16) inches in diameter. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 95½, § 1-106. 
Licensee: Any person who procures from the village clerk a license decal for a bicycle, together with a registration card accompanying same. 
Operate: The use, putting into action or causing to function of a bicycle by a person mounted thereon. 
Vehicle: Every device upon or by which loads are transported upon a street, alley or sidewalk, propelled by mechanical, animal or human power. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 1.2, 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-102. - Inspections. 
Each member of the police department is hereby authorized to inspect any bicycle at any reasonable time for the purpose of making a checkup of the license decal and license number, serial number and for the purpose of determining the mechanical condition of the bicycle. No person shall in any manner interfere with or hinder the making of such an inspection. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 4.2, 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-103. - Use of bicycle without consent of owner. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use or operate any bicycle within the village without the consent of its owner. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 4.4, 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-104. - Serial numbers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy, remove, alter, cover or deface the manufacturer's serial number on any bicycle. It shall be unlawful for any person to own or have custody of a bicycle on which the original serial number has been destroyed, altered, removed, covered or defaced. In the event a bicycle has been purchased which does not contain a manufacturer's serial number, the police department shall stamp an original serial number on the frame of the bicycle and this number shall be considered the original number. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person residing in the village or any dealer in bicycles operating in the village to purchase, receive in trade, or otherwise acquire any bicycle from which the serial number on the frame has been removed, destroyed, mutilated or altered, without first reporting the same to the police department. 
(Ord. No. 1294, §§ 2.10, 4.5, 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-105. - Sale by village. 
(a)  The chief of police shall sell in the manner provided in subsection (c) all bicycles and miscellaneous parts to bicycles which have been in the possession of the village for a period in excess of six (6) months after exhausting all efforts to ascertain the ownership of said bicycles and thereafter making a reasonable effort to return said bicycles and parts to the appropriate owner. 
(b)  The chief shall report to the village treasurer an inventory of all such bicycles and parts on hand and the date, place and manner of the proposed sale and shall thereafter deposit all funds from said sales with the village treasurer. 
(c)  All bicycles to be sold shall first be auctioned off in the form prescribed by the village manager, said auction to be with recourse and to be held at those times designated by the police chief. Notice of said auction shall be provided by posting a notice as to the time, place and subject matter of said auction indicating that the individual bicycles shall be sold to the highest bidder which notice shall be published in a newspaper published in the village at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to said auction and shall also be posted at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to said auction in the village hall. Said notice shall indicate that said sale shall occur within five (5) days from the date of said publication. Any bicycles not sold at said auction may be sold and disposed of by the chief of police without bid pursuant to the terms and conditions herein stated. 
(Ord. No. 1606, §§ 1—5, 12-8-75) 
State Law reference— Sale of unclaimed property, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 141, § 141 et seq.  
Sec. 6-106. - Rental agencies. 
(a)  Bicycle rental agencies shall comply in all respects, with all the provisions of this chapter and shall be responsible for the condition of the bicycles they rent. 
(b)  A bicycle rental agency shall not rent or offer to rent any bicycle unless the bicycle is licensed and the license decal is firmly attached as provided herein, and such bicycle is equipped with lamps and other equipment as required in this ordinance and by law. 
(Ord. No. 1294, §§ 4.1, 4.6, 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-107. - Dealers. 
Every person engaged in the business of buying, selling or exchanging bicycles in the village shall maintain for five (5) years a record containing the name, color, type and serial number of each bicycle bought, sold or exchanged, and the name and address of each person buying, selling or exchanging a bicycle, which record shall be open to inspection by a representative of the police department during reasonable business hours. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 5.0, 3-20-72)  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Power of municipality to regulate bicycles, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 95½, § 11-208(a)8. 
 
Sec. 6-201. - Required. 
No person who resides in the village shall ride or propel a bicycle on any street or upon any public way within the village unless such bicycle has been licensed and the license decal is attached thereto as prescribed herein. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 2.1, 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-202. - Application and fee. 
An application for a bicycle license shall be made upon a form provided by the village and shall be made to the village clerk. No fee shall be required for a bicycle license. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 2.2, 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-203. - Issuance. 
(a)  The chief of police shall not approve the issuance of a license for any bicycle when he knows or has reasonable grounds to believe the applicant is not the owner of or entitled to the possession of such bicycle. 
(b)  Upon receipt of a proper application and the approval of the chief of police the village clerk shall issue the bicycle license. 
(Ord. No. 1294, §§ 2.3, 2.4, 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-204. - Attachment to bicycle. 
The police department upon issuing a license, which shall contain the name Villa Park, Illinois and a number, shall cause the same to be mounted and firmly attached to the left front axle of the bicycle for which the license is issued. Such license shall be in the form of a decal which shall be renewed every four (4) years. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 2.6, 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-205. - Inspection of bicycle. 
The chief of police shall cause the inspection of each bicycle before approving the licensing of same and shall refuse to approve a license for any bicycle which he determines is in unsafe mechanical condition. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 2.8, 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-206. - Removal from bicycle, injury, etc. 
No person shall remove, destroy, mutilate or injure a bicycle license from the bicycle, except upon transfer of ownership or in the event the bicycle is wrecked, junked or dismantled and is no longer used upon the streets of the village. 
(Ord. No. 1294, §§ 2.7, 4.3, 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-207. - Transfer of ownership. 
Upon the sale of a bicycle, the village license shall be removed and the police department notified that the bicycle is no longer in the possession of the former owner. Any bicycle registered by a new owner shall have a new license. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 2.9, 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-208. - Loss of license. 
The licensee shall report immediately to the police the loss or destruction of a bicycle license, and the circumstances surrounding the loss or destruction thereof. With the approval of the police, the village clerk shall issue a duplicate license decal upon payment to the village clerk by the licensee of a fee of twenty-five cents ($0.25). 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 2.11, 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-209. - Records. 
The police department shall keep a record of the number of each bicycle licensed, the name and address of the person to whom the license was issued, and the color and serial number of the bicycle for which the license was issued. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 2.5, 3-20-72)  
ARTICLE III. - OPERATING RULES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Power of municipality to license bicycles, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 95½, § 11-208(a)8; bicycle regulations generally, Ch. 95½, § 11-1501 et seq. 
 
Sec. 6-301. - Compliance. 
Every person operating a bicycle upon any street, alley or sidewalk in the village shall comply with the provisions of this article and the applicable provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 3.1, 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-302. - Trick riding. 
No person while operating a bicycle shall indulge or engage in any kind of trick or unsafe riding. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 3.1(a), 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-303. - Parking. 
Bicycles when parked in the business district shall be parked in zones or places officially designated for that purpose. Bicycles, shall not, at any time, in any place, be indiscriminately parked along buildings in such a manner as to interfere with pedestrians, or along roadways where they may interfere with traffic, or with persons getting into or out of motor vehicles. No person shall move or in any manner interfere with any bicycle properly parked, nor shall any person interfere or in any manner hinder any person from properly parking a bicycle, except that members of the police department and fire department may move or, in proper cases, prevent the parking of the bicycle, when, in the judgment of the policeman or fireman, his action is necessary in order to properly safeguard persons or property. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 3.1(i), 3-20-72)  
Sec. 6-304. - Mechanical condition. 
No person shall operate a bicycle which is not in such mechanical condition so that it can be safely operated. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 3.1, 3-20-72)  
Chapter 7 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 3662, adopted July 25, 2011, amended Ch. 7 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 7 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from the original codification. The amendatory history for the chapter can be found in the Code Comparative Table located at the back of this volume. 
Cross reference— Datum plane, § 2-101; zoning and planning commission, § 2-1601 et seq.; historical preservation commission, § 2-2701 et seq.; fire prevention code, § 9-201 et seq.; planning and development, Ch. 18; burglar alarms, § 19-201 et seq.; excavations, § 21-201 et seq.; encroachments on streets, § 21-501 et seq.; swimming pools, Ch. 22; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 25; official plan and subdivision regulations, App. B; basic zoning ordinance, App. C; fencing of excavations, App. C, § 22.8; flood control, App. D. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 7-101. - Community development department. 
There is hereby established a department of the village which shall be known as the "community development department." This department shall consist of the director of community development and such other assistants, deputies and employees as may from time to time be assigned thereto. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-102. - Certificates of occupancy. 
(a)  Prior to the issuance of any certificate of occupancy or occupancy permit, the community development department shall: 
(1)  Place on file with the county supervisor of assessments and the York and/or Addison Township assessors an unexecuted certificate of occupancy, said unexecuted copy to be in the same form and manner as the proposed certificate of occupancy save for the approval and execution by the community development department; 
(2)  Obtain from the person applying for said certificate of occupancy or occupancy permit a receipt to be obtained by the owner from the supervisor of assessments or township assessor indicating that said unexecuted certificate of occupancy or occupancy permit has been filed as indicated above. 
(b)  Upon the issuance of a certificate of occupancy or occupancy permit, whether said certificate or permit be of an interim or permanent nature, the director of community development shall file with the county supervisor of assessments and the York and/or Addison Township assessor's office a certified copy of said certificate of occupancy or occupancy permit. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-103. - Conflict. 
In the event of a conflict between this chapter or the codes adopted by this chapter, and any other ordinance or code of the Village of Villa Park, the more specific and more stringent provision or standard shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-104. - Saving clause. 
Nothing in this chapter or in the codes adopted hereby, shall be construed to affect any litigation, lawsuit or impending court proceeding, or any rights acquired, liability incurred or any cause or causes of action acquired or existing, under any act or ordinance hereby repealed by the adoption of this chapter, nor shall just or legal right or remedy in law or in equity, be lost, impaired or affected by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-105. - Regulations for fences for excavations. 
(a)  Excavations. All excavations, not properly attended, large enough to be considered a hazard or an attractive nuisance to children shall either be filled or covered to grade or completely enclosed within a four-foot fence the same day the excavation is created, unless an extension of time has been obtained from the director of community development. 
(b)  Construction sites. All construction sites large enough to be considered a hazard or an attractive nuisance to children shall be completely enclosed within a six-foot fence that is securely anchored prior to the commencement of any construction activities, unless an extension of time has been obtained from the director of community development. The fence shall be constructed and located so as to prevent unauthorized access to the site and shall be equipped with lockable gates to be secured and locked when workers are not on the site. 
(c)  Additional restrictions. In granting any extension of time under this section the director of community development may impose such additional conditions and restrictions as may be reasonably necessary to protect the health, safety and welfare of the community. 
(d)  Construction sites. In granting any building or other permit, or during any on-site field inspections, the director of community development or his/or her agents may require fencing as a condition of permitting construction to continue. Any fencing requirements imposed under this section shall be such as may be reasonably necessary to protect the health, safety and welfare of the community. 
(Ord. No. 3861 , § 2, 4-13-15)  
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Power of municipality to regulate the strength and manner of building construction, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-4. 
 
Sec. 7-201. - Adoption of a building code. 
A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of the village clerk of the Village of Villa Park, being marked and designated as the "International Building Code, 2009 Edition," as published by the International Code Council, Inc., be and is hereby adopted as the building code of the Village of Villa Park, in the State of Illinois; for the control of buildings and structures as herein provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said International Building Code, are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as it fully sets out in this ordinance, with the additions, insertions, deletions, and changes, if any, as prescribed in section 7-202 of this article II. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-202. - Amendments to building code—Additions, insertions, deletions, and changes. 
The following sections of the code herein adopted are amended and revised by addition, insertion, deletion and change as follows: 
Chapter 1—Administration 
Section 101.1 Title (page 1, second line): Insert "the Village of Villa Park, DuPage County, State of Illinois." 
Section 105.3.2 Time limitation of application (page 4): Delete entire section and replace with: 
"An application for which no permit is issued within 90 days of filing shall be deemed expired unless such application has been diligently prosecuted. Reapplication shall include resubmittal of plans and fee. One or more extensions of time for periods of not more than 90 days each shall be permitted to be allowed by the building official for the application, provided justifiable cause is demonstrated." 
Add new subsection (page 4): 
"Section 105.3.2.1 Time Limit for Obtaining Building Permits: An applicant must take possession of a permit within 30 days after notification by the Community Development Department that his/her permit has been approved. If the applicant does not take possession of a permit within 30 days, then the permit application shall be considered null and void. The application for permit shall be destroyed after 60 days if the applicant has not reapplied." 
Insert a new subsection (page 4): 
"Section 105.3.3 Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to proceed with the erection, enlargement, alteration, repair, removal, demolition or construction of any building or any structural part thereof and associated electrical, plumbing and HVAC systems, or to construct or resurface a driveway or parking lot within the village unless a permit therefore shall have been first obtained from the Community Development Department. A completed permit application with all required drawings and specifications shall be submitted in its entirety prior to commencement of review. Such permit shall be posted in a conspicuous place upon the premises for which it is issued, and shall remain so posted at all times until the work is completed and approved." 
Insert a new subsection (page 4): 
"Section 105.3.4 By whom application is made: Application for a permit shall be made by the owner or lessee of the building or structure, or agent of either, the registered design professional or contractor employed in connection with the proposed work." 
Section 105.5 Expiration (page 4): Delete section in its entirety and add: 
"Any permit issued shall become invalid if the authorized work is not commenced within 180 days after the time of commencing the work or if the building or work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned for a period of 180 days or more after the work has commenced. After the building permit is issued, it shall be the obligation of the applicant to take reasonable and appropriate action so that the work, which is the subject of the permit, is commenced and completed in a diligent manner. Before such work commences or is resumed, a permit extension or renewal is required." 
Add new subsection (page 4): 
"Section 105.5.1 Permit extension. A permittee holding an unexpired permit shall be permitted to apply for a one-time 180-day extension, provided the permittee shows good and satisfactory reasons beyond their control that the work cannot be commenced within the 180-day period from the original permit issue date. No additional fee is required for the one time extension." 
Add new subsection (page 4): 
"Section 105.5.2 Permit renewal. A permit, which has expired for 180 days or less shall be permitted to be renewed provided no changes have been made in the original plans and specifications for such work. The renewal fee shall be one-half the amount required for a new permit. Permits which have been expired for greater than 180 days require a new application and payment of the full permit fee." 
Add new subsection (page 4): 
"Section 105.5.3 Time limit of building permit. A permit, once issued, shall be valid for a period of one year, provided work has commenced and the permit has not been suspended per Section 108.2. The Community Development Director or his/her designee may grant two extensions of time for additional periods not to exceed 180 days each, provided a fee of one-half of the original cost of the permit shall be charged at the time each extension is granted. Where, under authority of a permit or extended permit, work has been started and has been abandoned for a period of 180 days, the building permit shall become invalid." 
Add new subsection (page 4): 
"Section 105.5.4 Invalid permits. Nothing in this section shall prevent the building permit from remaining valid by the Director of Community Development or his/her designee where it can be shown that a hardship not caused in whole or in part by the applicant would occur in enforcing the strict letter of this provision. If the permit does become invalid, all rights under such permit shall thereupon terminate by limitations, and a new permit, including fees, shall be secured before such work is started or continues." 
Add new subsection (page 5): 
"Section 105.8 Hours for Construction: Noise emanating from any construction activity shall be allowed only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday and 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. on Sunday." 
Add new subsection (page 5): 
"Section 105.9 Maintenance of Construction Areas: All construction areas are to be maintained in a safe manner, free of excessive accumulation of building materials, clear of blowing debris and roadways and sidewalks are to be kept clear and passable." 
Section 107.1 Construction documents (page 5): Replace "two sets of construction documents" with "six sets of construction documents". 
Add new subsection (page 7): 
"Section 109.7 Waiving of Fees: Upon presentation of acceptable documentation, which may include certificates of incorporation, building permit fees for the remodeling, repair, alteration or similar improvement to buildings or structures owned by bona fide governmental agencies, public or private schools, churches and not-for-profit organizations shall be waived. Fees shall not be waived for new construction or additions, nor shall fees be waived for deposits, bonds, water and/or sewer tap fees, and inspections and/or reviews performed by outside consultants or for any out-of-pocket expenses incurred by the Village associated with the construction permit process. The burden of proving that the organization qualifies for the waiver as set forth in this paragraph shall be the organization asserting the entitlement to a waiver." 
Section 109.8 Fee Schedule (page 7): Insert: 
"VILLAGE OF VILLA PARK 
Building Permit Requirements and Fee Schedule 
I.  Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to proceed with the erection, enlargement, alteration, repair, removal, demolition, or construction of any building or any structural part thereof and any associated electrical, plumbing and HVAC systems, or to construct or resurface a driveway or parking lot within the village unless a permit therefore shall have been first obtained from the Community Development Department. A completed permit application with all required drawings, specifications and fees must be submitted in their entirety prior to commencement of review. Such permit shall be posted in a conspicuous place upon the premises for which it is issued, and shall remain so posted at all times until the work is completed and approved. 
All plan review, engineering review, plan review consultant and fire system plan review fees shall be deposited with the Village for costs incurred prior to the commencement of review. Any costs in excess of the amount deposited shall be paid prior to permit issuance. 
Exceptions: A permit shall not be required for any minor repairs as may be necessary to maintain existing parts of buildings. Roof repair or replacements constituting less than 25% of the total roof area shall not require a village building permit. 
Starting Work Without a Permit: For starting work prior to the issuance of a permit an additional fee of $100.00 or 2% of the total construction cost whichever is greater will be charged. 
II.  Plan Review: The plan review procedure shall begin within a reasonable time after the submission of all required documents. All required drawings and specifications must be submitted in their entirety prior to commencement of review. All plan review, engineering review, plan review consultant and fire system plan review fees shall be deposited with the Village for costs incurred prior to commencement of review. Any costs in excess of the amount deposited shall be paid prior to permit issuance. The time frame for review shall be determined by the Director of Community Development or his/her designee and may be subject to change based upon the number and type of permit applications submitted and awaiting review.

III.  Submission of Building Plans and Documents: 
Architectural Plans: Application for a building permit shall require submission of three (3) sets of stamped and signed architectural plans or drawings complete with all details showing plumbing, electrical, heating, and ventilation schedules and diagrams. Plans or drawings for additions or any type of remodeling with a construction cost over $5,000 shall be required to be signed and sealed by an Illinois licensed architect or structural engineer. 
Landscaping/Lighting Plans: For all new commercial and industrial construction, landscaping and lighting plans, when required, shall be submitted with the building permit application. 
Topographical Survey: Three sets of topographical survey prepared by a registered engineer based on one-foot intervals, including surrounding adjacent buildings and other appurtenances within 20 feet of the subject property with foundation elevation and elevation of other permanent structures, using truss U.S.G.S. elevation standards plus existing grade of curb, sidewalks, and roadways shall be submitted. 
Any new construction or addition over 500 square feet, except for garages, shall submit a topographic survey. All garages and other accessory structures which require foundations must submit elevations. 
Engineering Drawings: Applications for building permits for all development shall include seven (7) sets of engineered drawings. Drawings shall be prepared by all Illinois Registered Engineer and include but not be limited to: all existing and proposed grades, proposed storm water runoff and storm water management facilities, existing and proposed curb cuts for street access, and other details as required by the Director of Community Development to determine compliance with Village regulations. 
Plat of Survey: One original and one copy of a plat of survey prepared by a registered land surveyor shall be submitted. 
Plot/Site Plan: A plot plan shall also be filed or made part of the prepared plans showing size of the proposed building, distances of yards or setbacks, parking spaces, and maneuvering areas. 
Traffic Impact Study: In addition to other fees established by this chapter, all applications for development that have a traffic impact as determined by Ordinance Number 4096 , AN ORDINANCE OF THE VILLAGE OF VILLA PARK, DUPAGE COUNTY, ILLINOIS ADOPTING TRAFFIC IMPACT STUDY REGULATIONS, shall perform a traffic impact study or traffic assessment in compliance with that ordinance. Until such time that the Village has received the traffic impact study or traffic assessment no permits for the use or development of land shall be issued.

VILLA PARK CASH RESTORATION DEPOSIT 
(based on type of construction)
