SURETY BOND 
All contractors shall execute and file a ten thousand dollar ($10,000.00) surety bond with the community development department in the form approved by the Village of Villa Park for surety bonds. 
INSURANCE 
For construction value less than $25,000: 
All contractors listed on the building permit application shall show proof of public liability insurance in the amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) and property damage limited to not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). 
For construction value over $25,000: 
All contractors listed on the building permit shall show proof of public liability insurance in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000) and property damage insurance in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000) or 100% of the construction value whichever is greater. 
All certificates of insurance shall name the Village of Villa Park as certificate holder as well as additional non-contributory insured. 
REGISTRATION 
All construction involving electricity and plumbing, exclusive of normal maintenance, requires licensed contractors. 
Plumbers must have a valid state registration. 
Electrical contractors must have a valid license from an Illinois municipality. Roofers must have a valid state registration. 
All general contractors must be registered in the Village of Villa Park. The fee for such registration is seventy-five dollars ($75.00). Homeowners wishing to be the general contractor must be registered as a general contractor and submit all required documents. 
Section 113.0 Means of Appeal (page 8): Delete section in its entirety and replace with: 
"a) Any person affected by any notice which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any provision of this Code or any code, rule or regulation adopted pursuant thereto (the "Petitioner"), shall have the right to request, and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the Director of Community Development (the "Director") of the Village of Villa Park, provided that such person shall file in the office of Community Development a notice, in writing, requesting such a hearing and containing a statement of the grounds therefore within ten (10) business days after the notice was served. The Director shall issue a written decision with regard to such appeal within twenty (20) business days of the hearing. 
b) The Petitioner shall have the right to request, and shall be granted, a hearing before the Village Manager of the Village of Villa Park with regard to the Director's decision, provided that the Petitioner shall file in the office of the Village Manager a notice, in writing, requesting such a hearing and containing a statement of the grounds therefore within ten (10) business days after the date of the Director's decision. The Village Manager shall issue a written decision with regard to such appeal within twenty (20) business days of the hearing. 
c) The Petitioner shall have the right to request, and shall be granted, a hearing before the Village Board of the Village of Villa Park with regard to the Village Manager's decision, provided that the Petitioner shall file in the office of the Village Clerk a notice, in writing, requesting such a hearing and containing a statement of the grounds therefore within ten (10) business days after the date of the Village Manager's decision. The Village Board shall issue a written decision with regard to such within twenty (20) business days of the hearing." 
Section 115.0 Stop Work Order. 
115.2 (page 9): Delete the entire paragraph and replace with the following: 
" 115.2 Issuance: Upon notice from the code official that work on any building or structure is being prosecuted contrary to the provisions of this code or in an unsafe and dangerous manner, such work shall be immediately stopped. The stop work order shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property involved, or to the owner's agent, or to the person doing the work; and shall state the conditions under which work will be permitted to resume. 
115.3 Unlawful continuance: Any person who shall continue any work in or about the structure after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine or not less than "seventy-five dollars ($75.00) or more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)."

Section 903.0—Automatic Sprinkler Systems 
Section 903.2 Where required: Delete sections 903.2 through 903.2.10 and insert the following: 
All new buildings and structures shall be provided with an approved fire sprinkler system. Exception: Detached structures, which comply with the following, do not require automatic fire sprinklers: 
A.  1.  Less than or equal to eight hundred sixty-four (864) square feet in area, and 
2.  Single story, and 
3.  Not used as a dwelling or sleeping, and 
4.  Not an High Hazard Group, and 
5.  Not used for high hazard products or hazardous materials storage, and 
6.  No basements; or 
B.  A single-family dwelling. 
903.2.1 Additions and alterations: An approved automatic fire suppression system shall be installed and maintained in all buildings and structures added to or altered according to the following: 
1. For existing buildings and structures, any modifications and/or additions that result in the total building area being increased by 1,500 square feet or more in area over a three-year period. 
903.2.2 Change of Use Group: An approved automatic fire suppression system shall be installed and maintained in existing buildings. When the Use Group of the existing building or structure is changed to a Use Group with a higher relative hazard (lower number) rating according to table 903.2.2.

Section 906.0—Fire Sprinkler Systems 
Section 903.3.1.2 NFPA 13R systems. (page 187): Delete entire section and add the following: 
"NFPA 13R systems: In residential building four stories or less in height, systems designed and installed in accordance with NFPA 13R listed in Chapter 35 shall be permitted in Use Group R fire areas. Sprinklers shall be required in all bathrooms located within individual dwelling units or guestrooms in Use Groups R-1, R-2 and Use Group R residential care facilities. 
Section 903.3.1.3 is deleted. 
Add the following section 903.3.7: 
" 903.3.7-Fire Hose Valves: In all warehouse and/or storage areas, 2½" fire hose valves with a 1½" reducer to a 1½" male connection shall be provided. The valves shall be located at each door entrance to the warehouse and/or storage area. Additional 2½" fire hose valves shall be provided so that no portion of the warehouse and/or storage area is situated more than 120 feet travel distance to a 2½" fire hose valve. All obstructions and/or racks shall be shown on the fire suppression system drawings. The fire hose valve(s) system piping shall be: 
a) A separate riser piping system. 
b) Hydraulically calculated for a minimum of 250 gallons per minute flow to the most hydraulically remote fire hose valve. 
c) Where system pressures exceed 100 PSI, a listed and approved pressure-reducing field-adjustable type valve(s) shall be provided." 
Add the following section 903.3.8: 
" 903.3.8 Design: 
A 10% or 5 PSI safety factor, whichever is greater, shall be provided in the fire protection system hydraulic calculations. The system demand shall be at least 5 PSI below the seasonal low water flow test supply." 
Section 903.6 Horn strobe. Add the following: 
"A horn strobe shall be installed above the fire department connection, which shall be activated upon a water flow."

A zoning indicator panel and the associated controls shall be provided in an approved location. The visual zone indication shall lock in until the system is reset and shall not be cancelled by the operation of an audible alarm-silencing switch. All alarm devices, including smoke detectors, heat detectors, flame detectors, manual fire alarm boxes, automatic sprinkler or standpipe water flow devices, other approved types of automatic fire detection devices and suppression and alarm system supervisory devices in any building greater than 1 story in height, including any story or level below grade, or 2,500 square feet gross area shall be of the addressable type. "Means of egress lighting in all buildings or portions of buildings serving rooms or spaces with an occupant load greater than 20 shall be connected to an emergency electrical system that complies with Section 2702.0 to assure continued illumination for a duration of not less than 1 hour in case of emergency or primary power loss."

Sec. 7-203. - Sections and chapters not adopted. 
The following chapters and sections of the International Building Code, 2009 Edition, have not been adopted: 
(1)  Section 113.0—Means of Appeal; 
(2)  Section 903.3.5.1.1—Limited Area Sprinkler Systems; 
(3)  Chapter 27—Electric Wiring, Equipment and Systems; 
(4)  Chapter 28—Mechanical Systems; 
(5)  Chapter 29—Plumbing System; 
(6)  Chapter 31—Special Construction; 
(7)  Chapter 32—Construction in the Public Right-of-Way. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-203.1. - Fees in connection with certain alterations, repairs or improvements. 
(a)  Definitions. The following definitions shall apply only to the provisions of this section: 
Check valve: A manual or automatic device intended to prevent the flow of sanitary sewerage from a public sanitary sewer main into a structure by way of a building drain. 
Overhead sewer: A plumbing system within a structure carrying sanitary sewerage that contains no gravity-fed building drains below grade. 
Underground sewer: A plumbing system within a structure carrying sanitary sewerage that contains gravity-fed building drains below grade. 
(b)  Eligibility. To be eligible for a waiver of fees for the installation of an overhead sewer in lieu of an underground sewer or for the installation of check valve(s) upon application for a permit, the department of public works will first ascertain if the structure has had at least one (1) verifiable sanitary sewer backup and advise the community development department in writing. Only if the structure has had at least one (1) verifiable sanitary sewer backup will the permit fees be waived. 
(c)  Types of work. The permit fees and inspection fees designated herein will be waived for the following types of work: 
(1)  Installation of check valve(s); 
(2)  Installation of overhead sewer and/or removal of underground sewer; 
(3)  Removal or disconnection of any of the items or articles specified in subsections 25-431(b)(1) through (14) provided that the same was lawfully installed; 
(4)  Any work or improvements required to be done in connection with the foregoing types of work. 
(d)  Specific sections. The permit and inspection fees imposed by the following sections of the Municipal Code are waived for the types of improvements specified in subparagraph (c) provided that the work is eligible in accordance with subparagraph (b): 
(1)  Section 7-202 of Chapter 7: Article II, Article III, Article IV, Article VI and Article XVII. 
(2)  Section 25-421 of Chapter 25. 
(3)  Section 25-428 of Chapter 25. 
(e)  Proper application. The waiver of permit and inspection fees provided herein shall not relieve any person from making proper application to the village or to any other proper governmental agency for all necessary permits for the improvements or work. Any cash bonds required shall be deposited with the village notwithstanding the waiver of permit fees provided by this section. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-204. - Enforcement. 
The provisions of this article and the International Building Code, 2009 Edition, which it adopts and incorporates, shall be enforced by the Villa Park Department of Community Development, its director and his/her designated representatives. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICITY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Power of municipality to regulate the installation, alteration and use of electrical equipment, 65 ILCS 5/11-37-2; power of municipality to prevent the dangerous construction, installation and condition of electrical wiring, 65 ILCS 5/11-8-2. 
 
Sec. 7-301. - National Electrical Code—Adoption. 
A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of the village clerk of the Village of Villa Park, being marked and designated as "National Electrical Code, 2005 Edition," as published and copyrighted by the National Fire Protection Association, be and the same is hereby adopted as the electrical code of the Village of Villa Park, State of Illinois; for the regulation of the installation, alteration and use of electrical conductors, electric equipment and other equipment installed in buildings, structures, and other premises for the utilization of electricity for light, heat or power and each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions, and terms of said National Electrical Code, 2005 Edition, are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this ordinance, with the additions, insertions, deletions, and changes, if any, as prescribed in section 7-302 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-302. - Same—Deletions and modifications. 
(a)  Articles repealed. The following articles of the National Electrical Code, 2005 Edition, are hereby repealed: 
(1)  Article 334—Nonmetallic-Sheathed Cable; 
(2)  Article 330—Metal-Clad Cable; 
(3)  Article 382—Nonmetallic Extensions; 
(4)  Article 398—Open Wiring on Insulators; 
(5)  Article 394—Concealed Knob-and-Tube Wiring. 
(b)  Articles modified. The following articles of the National Electrical Code, 2005 Edition, are hereby modified: 
(1)  Article 110-14—Electrical Connections. 
a.  The use of device terminals for splicing is prohibited. 
b.  The use of stab-type screwless pressure terminals of the conductor push-in type is strictly prohibited. 
(2)  Article 110.26(E)—Headroom. Amended by deleting the "Exception." 
(3)  Article 210.6—Branch Circuit Voltage Limitations (C) 277 volts to ground is amended by adding: "Fixtures shall be mounted not less than 8 feet above the finished floor. 
Wall switching shall not exceed 150 volts to ground. All switching mechanisms, including wiring shall be enclosed in conduit. All wall switching shall be installed only in one of the following methods: Low voltage relay switches, panel board switches, SWD rated circuit breakers or approved 277 volt switching mechanisms." 
(4)  Reserved. 
(5)  Article 210.8—Ground-Fault Circuit—Interrupter Protection for Personnel. (A) Dwellings units is amended by adding the following: "No wiring shall be installed that will reduce the effectiveness of the ground-fault interrupter." 
(6)  Article 210.19—Conductors—Minimum Ampacity and Size (A)(1) General, is amended by adding the following: "All branch circuits shall be wired with copper conductors only." 
(7)  Article 210.70—Lighting Outlets Required. Amended by changing the first sentence to read: "Lighting outlets shall be installed where specified in (A) through (C) below", and adding a subsection (D) as follows: "(D) Residential. In all habitable rooms with more than one entrance, at least one lighting outlet shall be switched from at least two of the entrances. In all hallways, at least one lighting outlet shall be switched from the entrances at each end of the hallway when the length is 15 feet or longer." 
(8)  Article 230.1. Amended by adding the following: "Whenever a service is revised or replaced all pertinent articles of the then enforced version of the National Electrical Code and this Ordinance shall apply. 
In residential occupancies, the laundry circuit required by Article 210.11(C)(2) of the 2005 National Electrical Code shall be provided." 
(9)  Article 230.42—Size and Rating (A) General. Amended by adding the following: "Service conductors shall be all copper for 200 ampere services or less and 100 ampere service require No. 3 copper conductors, 200 ampere service requires 3/0 copper conductors." 
(10)  Article 230.43—Wiring Methods for 600 Volts, Nominal or Less. Amended by deleting the following: "(1) Open Wiring on insulators; (7) Service-entrance cables; (13) Type MC cable; (14) Mineral-insulated, metal-sheathed cable; (15) Flexible metal conduit not over 6 feet (1.83) long between raceway and service equipment, with equipment bonding jumper routed with the flexible metal conduit according to provisions of Section 250-79(A), (C), (D) and (F); and (16) Liquid tight flexible nonmetallic conduit." 
(11)  Article 230.70—General. (A) Location. Amended to read as follows: "The service disconnecting means shall be installed at a readily accessible location either outside of a building or structure, inside nearest the point of entrance of the service conductors, in any case within five (5) feet of conduit and conductor entrance to the building." 
(12)  Article 230.71(A) Maximum Number of Disconnects. Amended by adding to this section the following: "It is the intent of this Section to require no more than six (6) operations of switches, buttons, breakers, etc. to disconnect all power entering the service location. 
Each service more than 250 volts to ground and in excess of 800 AMPS shall have a single main to open all ungrounded conductors." 
(13)  Article 250.62—Material. Grounding Electrode Conductor. Amended by deleting the words: "Aluminum, or copper-clad aluminum" from the first sentence. 
(14)  Article 250.64. Delete paragraph (A) Grounding Electrode Conductor. Deleted in its entirety and rewritten as follows: "The grounding electrode conductor for the service shall terminate at the street side of the domestic water service and shall be protected by rigid metal conduit, intermediate metal conduit, electrical metallic tubing, or approved ground conductor cable. The grounding electrode conductor shall be copper and the water meter shall be provided with an adequate jumper." 
(15)  Article 310.5—Minimum Size Conductors. Amended by adding: "Except in residential uses, conductors used in systems exceeding 50 volts shall be #12 or larger." 
(16)  Article 310.14—Aluminum Conductor Material. Amended by deleting the text of the article in its entirety and inserting the words: "All conductors #2000 AWG and smaller shall be copper." 
(17)  Article 320—Armored Cable. Armored cable, as provided in Article 320, shall not be permitted to be used as an initial installation, but only upon reworking and remodeling and then only if installed in existing enclosed walls or inaccessible ceilings. 
(18)  Article 338—Service-Entrance Cable. Service-entrance cable as provided in Article 338, shall be permitted only by special permission of the Director of Community Development of the Village of Villa Park and then only for good cause shown. 
(19)  Article 340.10—Uses Permitted. Amended by deleting subsection 340.10 in its entirety. 
(20)  Article 358.10(B) Use. Amended by deleting the following paragraph: "Ferrous or nonferrous electrical metallic tubing, elbows, couplings, and fittings shall be permitted to be installed in concrete, in direct contact with the earth, or in areas subject to severe corrosive influences, when protected by corrosion protection and judged suitable for the condition." 
(FPS): See Section 300.6 for protection against corrosion. 
(21)  Article 358.42—Couplings and Connectors. Amended by adding the words: "Only set-screw type fittings and compression type fittings shall be installed." 
(22)  Article 410.8—Fixtures in Clothes Closets. (A) Definition. Storage Space. Amended by adding the following: "In residential occupancies, all clothes closets over six (6) square feet shall have an approved light fixture installed." 
(c)  Additions for grounding of service. The following provisions shall control the grounding of services and shall supersede any conflicting provisions in the National Electrical Code, 2005 Edition: 
(1)  When water is supplied by the village, the service grounding conductor shall be connected to the water pipe on the supply side of the meter unless otherwise approved by the director of community development of the Village of Villa Park. 
(2)  The grounding conductor shall be installed in EMT or rigid conduit. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-303. - Enforcement. 
The provisions of this article and the National Electrical Code, 2005 Edition, which it adopts and incorporates, shall be enforced by the Village of Villa Park department of community development, its director, and his or her designated representatives. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-304. - Fees. 
The fees for all permits for electrical work, inspections and/or periodic inspections, shall be as prescribed by the Village of Villa Park in section 7-201 et seq., as originally adopted and subsequently amended. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-305. - Violation; penalty. 
(a)  Any person, firm, company, corporation or other entity which disobeys, violates, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with this article or the provisions thereof shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this article, punishable by a fine of not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day or portion thereof a violation or noncompliance continues or exists shall be considered a separate offense. 
(b)  In addition to the penalties provided herein, the director of community development may seek to enforce the provisions of this article in any court of competent jurisdiction by injunctive or other relief. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)

ARTICLE V. - PLUMBING CODE 
 
Sec. 7-501. - Adoption of a plumbing code. 
The Illinois Plumbing Code, as amended and published by the Illinois Department of Public Health (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890), is adopted and incorporated by reference as the rules and regulations governing the design and installation of new plumbing or plumbing systems and the alteration of plumbing systems including new construction and any remodeling or renovation that alters, renovates or replaces existing plumbing or plumbing systems except as hereinafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11; Ord. No. 3952 , § 1, 12-5-16)  
Sec. 7-502. - Amendments to plumbing code; additions, insertions and changes. 
A.  WaterSense Requirements. Pursuant to 17 Ill. Admin. Code 3730.307(c)(4) and subject to the Illinois Plumbing Code (77 Ill. Admin. Code 890) and the Lawn Irrigation Contractor and Lawn Sprinkler System Registration Code (77 Ill. Admin. Code 892) all new plumbing fixtures and irrigation controllers installed after June 27, 2016 shall bear the WaterSense label (as designated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency WaterSense Program) when such labeled fixtures are available. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11; Ord. No. 3952 , § 1, 12-5-16)  
Sec. 7-503. - Enforcement. 
This article shall be enforced by the Village's Plumbing Inspector. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11; Ord. No. 3952 , § 1, 12-5-16)  
Sec. 7-504. - Fees. 
The fees for all permits for plumbing work, inspections and, or, periodic inspections, shall be as prescribed in article II of chapter 7 of the Villa Park Municipal Code as originally adopted and subsequently amended. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-505. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3700, § 3, adopted May 21, 2012, deleted § 7-505, entitled "Violations; penalties", which derived from: Ord. No. 3662, § 2, adopted July 25, 2011.  
Sec. 7-506. - Reserved.  
Sec. 7-507. - Responsibility of plumbing contractors. 
(a)  Plumbing contractors shall be solely responsible for requesting plumbing inspections; twenty-four (24) hours' notice of such inspections shall be given to the manager. 
(b)  A copy of the plumbing contractor's current state or City of Chicago plumbing license shall be left on file with the community development director prior to issuing a plumbing permit. 
(c)  Plumbing contractors shall be responsible for any changes in design or addition of fixtures. The community development director shall be notified of any changes on which original permit was issued. Mechanical drawings shall be required on all plans of commercial, industrial and multiple-family structures. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-508. - Water conservation. 
All plumbing work to be in strict accordance with the village's water conservation program. Plumbing contractors shall be responsible for the installation of suitable flow control devices where manufacturers' items do not conform to regulations. The addition of aerators with flow control features will not be permitted on new or replacement installations. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
ARTICLE VI. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE 
 
Sec. 7-601. - Adoption of a property maintenance code. 
A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of the village clerk of the Village of Villa Park, being marked and designated as the "International Property Maintenance Code, 2009 Edition" as published by the International Code Council, Inc., be and is hereby adopted as the property maintenance code of the Village of Villa Park, in the State of Illinois; for the regulation and control of existing structures and buildings as herein provided; and each and all of the regulations, standards, provisions, guidelines, penalties, conditions and terms of said International Code Council's International Property Maintenance Code, are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference and made a part hereof as if fully set out herein, with the additions, deletions, insertions and changes, if any, as prescribed and stated in section 7-602 of this article VI. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-602. - Amendments to the property maintenance code. 
The following sections of the code herein adopted are amended and revised by addition, insertion, deletion and change as follows: 
Chapter 1—Administration

Section 102.3 Application of other codes (page 1): Delete entire paragraph and insert: 
" Section 102.3 Application of other codes. Repairs, additions, or alterations to a structure, or changes of occupancy, shall be done in accordance with the procedures and provisions of the building, plumbing, mechanical and fire codes adopted by the Village of Villa Park. Nothing in this code shall be construed to cancel, modify or set aside any provisions of the jurisdiction's zoning code. In the event of conflict, the most restrictive provision shall apply." 
Section 102.7 Referenced codes and standards (page 1): Delete entire section and insert: 
" Section 102.7 Referenced codes and standards: The codes and standards referenced in this code shall be those that have been adopted by the Village of Villa Park and considered part of the requirements of this code to the prescribed extent of each such reference."

Insert a new subsection (page 2): 
" Section 104.7 Relief from personal liability: Any code official, officer or employee who acts in good faith in the discharge of duties of enforcement of this code is relieved of all personal liability for any damage accruing to persons or property as a result of such acts or alleged failure to act. Further, the code official shall not be held liable for any costs in any action, suit or proceeding that is instituted by the code official in the enforcement of this code. In any of these actions, the official or employee shall be defended or represented by the jurisdiction's attorney-at-law until the final termination of the proceedings."

Chapter 2—Definitions 
Section 201.3 Terms defined in other codes (page 9): Delete entire paragraph and replace with: "Where terms are not defined in this code and are defined in the building, plumbing, mechanical and fire codes adopted by the Village of Villa Park, such terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them as in those codes." 
Section 202—General Definitions 
Bathroom (page 9): Delete and replace with: "A room containing a lavatory, water closet, bathtub and/or shower." 
Insert new definition (page 9): "Debris: An accumulation of one or more of the following items; tin cans, glass jars, bottles, scrap glass, paper cartons, scraps of paper, boxes, ashes, iron, old hot water tanks, oil storage tanks, tin or other metal materials, refuse, rubbish, junk, waste, manure, straw, piles of grass clippings, lumber, old bricks, concrete blocks, chunks of broken concrete, plaster board, discarded furniture, mattresses, bed springs, portable swimming pools in disrepair, operable or inoperable household appliances, lawn and garden equipment, inoperable bicycles, plumbing materials, electrical supplies or cords, or other like matter or things." 
Insert new definition (page 9): "Public nuisance: Includes the following: 
1.  The physical condition, or use of any premises regarded as a public nuisance at common law; or 
2.  Any physical condition, use or occupancy of any premises or its appurtenances considered an attractive nuisance to children, including, but not limited to, abandoned wells, shafts, basements, excavations and unsafe fences or structures; or 
3.  Any premises which has unsanitary sewerage of plumbing facilities; or 
4.  Any premises designated as unsafe for human habitation or use; or 
5.  Any premises which is manifestly capable of being a fire hazard, or is manifestly unsafe or unsecured as to endanger life, limb or property; or 
6.  Any premises from which the plumbing, heating and/or facilities required by this code have been removed, or from which utilities have been disconnected, destroyed, removed or rendered ineffective, or the required precautions against trespassers have not been provided; or 
7.  Any premises which is unsanitary, or which is littered with rubbish, debris or garbage, or which has an uncontrolled growth of weeds; or 
8.  Any structure or building that is in a state of dilapidation, deterioration or decay; faulty construction; overcrowded; open, vacant or abandoned; damaged by fire to the extent so as not to provide shelter; in danger of collapse or failure; or dangerous to anyone on or near the premises." 
Chapter 3—General Requirements 
Section 301.2 Responsibility (page 11 second line): Delete first sentence and replace with: "The owner of the premises shall maintain the structures, fixtures and exterior property in compliance with these requirements, except as otherwise provided for in this code." 
Section 302.1 Sanitation (page 11, second line): Insert after sanitary condition: "and free from any accumulation of rubbish, debris or garbage."

" Section 302.10 Open Fires: Open fires shall be prohibited except as specifically approved by the fire official."

Any vegetation that is dead and in the opinion of the code official is capable of causing property or utility damage shall be removed. Any vegetation that is dead and within any yard shall be removed. Any vegetation removed that is a part of a required landscaping area shall be replaced with live plants as approved by the Director of Community Development or his/her designee." 
Section 304.3 Premises identification (page 12): Delete: "... minimum of 4 inches ..." and insert "minimum of 3 inches ..." 
Insert new subsection (page 12): 
" Section 304.3.1 Multi-premises identification: 
a. Where there are more than four (4) spaces/units located in a single commercial or industrial structure, each rear street level exterior door shall be marked with the corresponding street address and the identification of the occupancy. The numbering and lettering shall be no less than two and one-half (2½) inches in height and in contrast coloring to that of the coloring of the door(s). The placement of the numbering and lettering shall be a height of six (6) feet from the door threshold and shall be uniform throughout the commercial or industrial structure. All fire protection rooms, with direct outside ground access, shall be identified with the words, "Fire Protection Equipment Room" which shall appear on the door to said room in the same manner as the street address. Where fire protection rooms have interior access only, these rooms shall be identified as such with lettering or acceptable symbols, in the same manner as the street address, except that said lettering or acceptable symbols shall be no less than one (1) inch in height. 
b) Where there are more than four (4) multi-family residential units, addresses shall be displayed on both the front and rear of the buildings."

Section 307.1 Handrails and Guardrails General (page 15): Delete entire section and insert: 
" Section 307.1 Handrails and Guardrails General: Every exterior and interior flight of stairs having three or more risers shall have a handrail on one side of the stair and every open portion of a stair, landing, balcony, porch, deck, ramp or other walking surface which is more than 30 inches above the floor or grade below shall [have] guards. Handrails shall not be less than 34 inches high or more than 38 inches high measured vertically above the nosing of the tread or above the finished floor of the landing or walking surfaces. Guards shall not be less than 36 inches high above the floor of the landing, balcony, porch, deck or ramp or other walking surface. Open sides of stairs with a total rise of more than 30 inches above the floor or grade below shall have guardrails not less than 34 inches in height measured vertically from the nosing of the treads. 
Exception: Guards shall not be required where exempted by the adopted building code." 
Section 308.1 Accumulation of rubbish or garbage (page 15, line 3): Delete: "rubbish or garbage" and insert "rubbish, debris or garbage." 
Insert a new subsection (page 15): 
" Section 308.4 Disposal of Debris: Every occupant of a structure shall dispose of debris in a clean and sanitary manner by placing such debris in an approved debris disposal facility or approved debris containers, and such disposal shall take place in compliance with the provisions of Chapter 10 of the Villa Park Municipal Code." 
Chapter 4—Light, Ventilation and Occupancy Limitations 
Section 404.4 Bedroom Requirements (page 18): Delete: "404.4.5" and replace with "404.4.6." 
Section 404.4.4 Prohibited occupancy (page 18): Delete entire section and insert: 
" Section 404.4.4 Prohibited occupancy/prohibited sleeping areas. It shall be prohibited to use for sleeping purposes any kitchen, hallway, closet, basement (unless it meets the bedroom requirements listed herein), storage room, public area, dining room, living room or nonhabitable space." 
Insert a new subsection (page 18): 
" Section 404.4.6 Definitions. 
Bedroom. A bedroom is defined as a segregated and separate room or space used or intended to be used for sleeping purposes and delineated by four (4) fixed walls and a door containing a minimum of at least seventy (70) square feet of floor area for a single occupant and every bedroom occupied by more than one person shall contain at least fifty (50) square feet of floor area for each occupant thereof, for the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the Village of Villa Park, excepting studios. It shall be prohibited to occupy any residence that fails to satisfy the minimal floor area set forth herein for any residential occupancy. 
Bedroom Requirements. For all sleeping areas, whether above or below grade, the following requirements shall be met, except where noted: 
1.  All walls and ceilings in bedrooms on any floor shall have, as a minimum, a layer of one-half inch (½") gypsum board or equivalent, taped and finished so as to provide a continuous surface with no breaks or gaps. 
2.  For all bedrooms, ceiling height shall not be less than seven (7) feet high. 
3.  Doors, with minimum dimensions of one and five-eighths (1 5/8 ) inch thick and six (6) feet eight (8) inches height, shall be required for all bedrooms. The door shall be side-hinged, readily operable, and provided with latching hardware. 
4.  A smoke detector shall be installed in each bedroom. 
5.  Basement bedrooms, as well as other habitable space, shall be free of excess moisture, dampness and ground water seepage. All excess moisture shall be removed by mechanical or gravitational means. 
6.  All habitable rooms shall be provided adequate light and ventilation in accordance with the most current adopted Village of Villa Park Building Code. 
7.  Every sleeping room shall have at least one openable window or exterior door approved for emergency escape or rescue. The units must be operable from the inside to a full clear opening without the use of a key, tool or special knowledge. Windows that are provided as a means of escape or rescue, including basement bedrooms, shall have a sill height of not more than forty-four (44) inches above the floor. 
8.  Escape or rescue windows with a finished sill height below the adjacent ground elevation shall be provided with a window well. The escape window well shall have an accessible and clear opening of not less than nine (9) square feet and with a length and width of not less than thirty-six (36) inches. 
9.  Furthermore, the escape window well shall have horizontal dimensions that allow the window to be fully opened. 
Prohibited sleeping areas. Prohibited sleeping areas are defined as kitchens, as well as living rooms, dining rooms and other rooms which are not designated or qualified as bedrooms, as defined and qualified herein, which shall not be used for sleeping purposes." 
Section 404.5 Overcrowding : Insert at end of sentence: "Overcrowding shall also be determined in a residential dwelling unit as any qualified bedroom occupied by one (1) person which does not consist of at least seventy (70) square feet of floor area and any qualified bedroom occupied by more than one (1) person which does not consist of at least fifty (50) square feet of floor area for each occupant thereof." 
Section 404.5 Overcrowding (page 18): Delete entire section and insert the following: 
" 404.5 Dwelling units shall not be occupied by more than permitted by the minimum area requirements of Table 404.5

a  See section 404.5.2 for combined living room/dining room spaces. 
;sup\sup; See section 404.5.1 for limitations on determining the minimum occupancy area for sleeping purposes. 
404.5.1 Sleeping area. The minimum occupancy area required by Table 404.5 shall not be included as a sleeping area in determining the minimum occupancy area for sleeping purposes. All sleeping areas shall comply with section 404.4. 
404.5.2 Combined living room and dining room spaces shall comply with the requirements of Table 404.5 if the total area is equal to that required for separate rooms if the space is located so as to function as a combination living room/dining room."

ARTICLE VII. - RESIDENTIAL CODE 
 
Sec. 7-701. - International Residential Code; adoption. 
A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of the village clerk of the Village of Villa Park, being marked and designated as the "International Residential Code, 2009 Edition," as published by the International Code Council, Inc., be and the same is hereby adopted as the one and two-family dwelling code of the village governing the design, construction, alteration, enlargement, repair, maintenance and use of one- and two-family dwellings, as herein provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions, and terms of the said International Residential Code, 2009 Edition, are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions, and changes, if any, prescribed in section 7-702 of this article VII. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)

a.)  For 1-story framed additions, a trench foundation may be permitted. The width of the trench shall be a minimum of ten (10") inches belled to sixteen (16") inches at bottom. Depth minimum of forty-two (42") inches or below frost line. 
b.)  For open porches, concrete or pressure treated piers may be permitted. ARTICLE VIII. - ACCESSIBILITY FOR THE HANDICAPPED 
 
Sec. 7-801. - Adoption of code and standards. 
A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of the Village Clerk of the Village of Villa Park, being marked and designated as the "Illinois Accessibility Code, effective April 24, 1997" as printed by the State of Illinois and is hereby adopted as the accessibility code for the Village of Villa Park, in the State of Illinois; for the control and regulation [regulation] of providing access to the built environment by environmentally limited persons as therein provide; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of said Illinois Accessibility Code and standards referenced therein are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this article. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-802. - Enforcement; penalty. 
(a)  The provisions of this article and the Illinois Accessibility Code, effective April 24, 1997, shall be enforced by the Village of Villa Park Community Development Department, its director, and his or her designated representative or may be referred to the appropriate agency or official as set forth in section 400.140 of the Illinois Accessibility Code for civil enforcement. 
(b)  Any person, firm, company, corporation or other entity which disobeys, violates, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with this article or the provisions thereof, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this article, punishable by a fine of not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day or portion thereof a violation or noncompliance continues or exists shall be considered a separate offense. 
(c)  In addition to the penalties provided herein, the director of community development may seek to enforce the provisions of this article in any court of competent jurisdiction by injunctive or other relief. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-803. - Conflicting provisions. 
The provisions of the Illinois Accessibility Code and referenced standards contained therein shall constitute the minimum standards for accessibility and to the extent that any other ordinance of the village conflicts with the provisions of this article or the publications adopted by the provisions of this article, the provisions of this article or the publications adopted hereby shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-804. - Effect. 
Except to the extent required by the Environmental Barriers Act or the Illinois Accessibility Code, nothing in this article or the Illinois Accessibility Code and reference standards adopted hereby shall be construed to affect any litigation, lawsuit or impending court proceeding, or any rights acquired, liability incurred, or any cause or cause of action acquired or existing; nor shall any just or legal right or remedy of any character be lost, impaired, or affected by this article. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)

ARTICLE XII. - FIRE CODE 
 
Sec. 7-1201. - Adoption of a fire code. 
A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of the village clerk of the Village of Villa Park, being marked and designated as the "International Fire Code, 2009 Edition," as published by the International Code Council, Inc., and "NFPA 96: Standard for Ventilation Control and Fire Protection of Commercial Cooking Operations, 2008 Edition," as published by the National Fire Protection Association be and the same are hereby adopted as the fire code of the Village of Villa Park, State of Illinois; for the control of fire hazards as herein provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of the said International Fire Code, 2009 Edition, and NFPA 96: Standard for Ventilation Control and Fire Protection of Commercial Cooking Operations, 2008 Edition, as published by the National Fire Protection Association are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 7-1202 of this article XII. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11; Ord. No. 3683, § 2, 1-9-12) 
State Law reference— Power of municipality to adopt technical codes by reference, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-2.  
Sec. 7-1202. - Amendments of fire code; additions, insertions, deletions and changes.

Each day that a violation or noncompliance continues or exists shall be considered a separate offense. 
(b) In addition to the penalties provided herein, the Director of Community Development may seek to enforce the provisions of this article in any court of competent jurisdiction by injunctive or other relief."

The wood used shall be cut into logs and freshly cut or "green." The appliance used shall have secure, suitable cover and suitable screening in place on its sides. The fire code official or his designate may prohibit the use of an outdoor fireplace if the products of combustion create or add to a hazardous or objectionable situation.

Additional 2½" fire hose valves shall be provided so that no portion of the warehouse and/or storage area is situated more than 120 feet travel distance to a 2½" fire hose valve. (Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)

The fees for all permits for mechanical work, inspections and/or periodic inspections shall be prescribed in section 7-202 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)

ARTICLE XIII. - VACANT BUILDING AND PROPERTY REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 7-1301. - Declaration of policy. 
The purpose of this article is to protect the public health, safety and welfare by enactment of this article which: 
(a)  Establishes a program for identification, registration, and regulation of buildings which are or become vacant on and after the effective date of this article. 
(b)  Determines the responsibilities of owners of vacant buildings. 
(c)  Provides for administration, enforcement of property regulations, including prevention and abatement of public nuisances, and imposition of penalties. 
This article shall be construed liberally to effect its purposes. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-1302. - Other ordinances. 
This article shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other applicable ordinances, codes, legislation, and regulations which prescribe standards other than those provided herein, and in the event of conflict, the most restrictive shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-1303. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise expressly stated or clearly indicated by the context, the following terms shall, for the purpose of this article, have the meanings indicated in this section: 
Boarded building means a building which has had, in a manner intended to be temporary or permanent, any or all openings, which openings are windows or doors which were present for the purpose of light, ventilation or egress, some material whether opaque, solid or transparent, affixed to such openings, from the interior or exterior of the building, for the purpose of securing or preventing access or damage to the building or its components. 
Building means any structure occupied or intended for supporting or sheltering any occupancy. 
Dangerous building or structure means a building or structure defined as a "nuisance" in section 15-102 of this Code, as now existing or hereafter amended. 
Director means the director of community development or the director's designee. 
Owner means any person, agent, operator, firm, or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in the property; or recorded in the official records of the state, county, or municipality as holding title to the property; or otherwise having control of the property, including the guardian of the estate of any such person, and the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if ordered to take possession of real property by a court. 
Person includes a corporation, a partnership, or other entity as well as an individual. 
Premises means a lot, plot, or parcel of land, including any structure thereon. 
Public nuisance includes the following: 
(a)  The physical condition, or uses of any building, structure or premises regarded as a public nuisance at common law, under the Illinois Compiled Statutes, or under this Code; or 
(b)  Any physical condition, use or occupancy of any premises, structure, building or appurtenances considered an attractive nuisance to children, including, but not limited to, abandoned wells, shafts, basements, excavations, and unsafe fences or structures; or 
(c)  Any building which has unsanitary sewerage or plumbing facilities; or 
(d)  Any building designated by the director as unsafe for human habitation or use; or 
(e)  Any building which is manifestly capable of being a fire hazard, or manifestly unsafe or insecure so as to endanger life, limb or property; or 
(f)  Any building or premises which is unsanitary, or which is littered with rubbish or garbage, or which has an uncontrolled growth of weeds; or 
(g)  Any building or structure that is dangerous, in a state of dilapidation, deterioration or decay; faulty construction; unsecure; vacant and the doors, windows, or other openings are boarded up or secured by any means other than conventional methods used in the design of the building or permitted for new construction of similar type; damaged by fire to the extent as not to provide shelter, in danger of collapse or failure; and dangerous to anyone on or near the premises; or 
(h)  Any building or structure defined as a "dangerous building" hereinabove. 
Unoccupied building means a building or portion thereof which lacks the habitual presence of human beings who have a legal right to be on the premises, including buildings ordered vacated by the director pursuant to authority granted to him/her by this Code. In determining whether a building is "unoccupied", the director may consider these factors, among others: 
(a)  A building at which substantially all lawful residential or business activity has ceased. 
(b)  The percentage of the overall square footage of occupied to unoccupied space or the overall number of occupied and unoccupied units shall be considered. 
(c)  The building is substantially devoid of contents. The condition and value of fixtures or personal property in the building are relevant to this determination. 
(d)  The building lacks utility services, i.e., water, sewer, electric or natural gas. 
(e)  The building is the subject of a foreclosure action. 
(f)  The building is not actively for sale as part of a contractual agreement to sell the building, the building lacks "for sale", "for rent" or similar signage. 
(g)  The presence or recurrence of uncorrected code violations. 
Vacant building means a building or portion of a building which is: 
(a)  Unoccupied and unsecured; or 
(b)  Unoccupied and secured by boarding or other similar means; or 
(c)  Unoccupied and a dangerous structure; or 
(d)  Unoccupied and condemned by the director pursuant to applicable provisions of this Code; or 
(e)  Unoccupied and has multiple code violations; or 
(f)  Unoccupied and the building or its premises has been the site of unlawful activity within the previous six (6) months; or 
(g)  Condemned by the director and unlawfully occupied; or 
(h)  Unoccupied for over one hundred eighty (180) days and during which time the director has issued an order to correct public nuisance conditions and same have not been corrected in a code-compliant manner; or 
(i)  Unoccupied for over two (2) years; 
but not including, unoccupied buildings which are undergoing construction, renovation, or rehabilitation and which are in compliance with all applicable ordinances, codes, legislation, and regulations, and for which construction, renovation or rehabilitation is proceeding diligently to completion. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-1304. - Vacant building determination. 
(a)  Within sixty (60) days after the effective date of this article, the director shall evaluate all buildings in the village he or she believes to be unoccupied on the effective date of this article and make a determination for each as to whether the building is a vacant building within the meaning of this article. The determination shall be in writing and shall state the factual basis for the determination. For buildings the director determines to be vacant buildings, she/he shall, within seven (7) days of making that determination, send notice of the written determination with the factual findings to the last taxpayer of record listed on the most recent DuPage County tax roll. Said notice of determination shall be sent certified mail, return receipt requested. Failure of delivery shall not excuse a person from complying with this article. Any person making such service shall execute an affidavit attesting to the facts of service. The director shall maintain an affidavit of such mailing for each notice of determination sent. 
(b)  The director shall cause an inspection of the interior of all vacant buildings to determine compliance with village health and fire codes. 
(c)  The notice of determination shall set a tentative date and time for the code-compliance inspection of the interior of the vacant building to determine the extent of compliance with village health and fire codes. After receipt of the notice of determination, if the owner does not appeal the determination, the owner shall either confirm the tentative date for the inspection or shall schedule a new date and time for same. If the owner fails to confirm the tentative date and time for the inspection or refuses to schedule or permit the inspection it shall be the responsibility of the village to obtain an administrative search warrant to accomplish the inspection. 
(d)  The village shall charge the owner a fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) to offset the cost to the village of said inspection. The owner shall pay the inspection fee to the village within thirty (30) days of receipt of the bill for same. 
(e)  The notice of determination shall contain a statement of the obligations of the owner of a building determined to be a vacant building, a copy of the registration form the owner is required to file pursuant to section 7-1006 and a notice of the owner's right to appeal the determination. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-1305. - Appeal of director's determination of vacant buildings. 
(a)  An owner of a building determined by the director to be a vacant building as provided for in this article may appeal that determination to the village manager. Such appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with the village manager within fifteen (15) days of the date of mailing of the notice of determination. The filing of an appeal stays the owner's obligation to register his or her building as required by section 7-1006. The appeal shall contain a complete statement of the reasons the owner disputes the director's determination, shall set forth specific facts in support thereof, and shall include all evidence the owner relies upon to support the appeal. The village manager shall decide the appeal on the basis of facts presented by the owner in his or her written appeal and the director's written determination. 
(b)  The burden is upon the owner to present sufficient evidence to persuade the village manager that it is more likely than not that the subject building is not a vacant building within the meaning of this article. 
(c)  The village manager shall send written notice of his or her decision to the owner within ten (10) days of his or her receipt of the appeal. The village manager may, but is not required to, seek additional information from the owner. The village manager may, upon written notice thereof to the owner, take no more than ten (10) additional days to decide the appeal if he or she determines that such additional time is required for consideration of the appeal. 
(d)  An owner who wishes to challenge applicability of this article to his/her building without the director's determination having been made shall set forth specific facts to support nonapplicability in writing to the director. In the event the director determines that the subject building is a vacant building, the owner shall have the right to appeal the director's determination to the village manager as provided for herein. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-1306. - Owner's obligation to register vacant buildings and unoccupied buildings acquired through mortgage foreclosure. 
(a)  The owner of a vacant building and a mortgage lender who acquires title to an unoccupied building shall be required to register same with the director as prescribed below; and the owner of a building who knows, or from all the facts and circumstances should know, that his or her building is or has become a vacant building within the meaning of this article after the effective date of this article or the owner of a building which the director determines at any time to be a vacant building, or the owner of a building whose appeal from the director's determination has been denied by the village manager, shall take the actions provided for in this section 7-1006 within fifteen (15) days after either the date of director's notice of determination or occurrence of the facts which would cause a reasonable person to believe that the building was a vacant building, or denial of the appeal, whichever is applicable. 
Registration requirements: 
(1)  Register the building with the director, on a form provided by the director and pay the two hundred dollar ($200.00) annual nonprorated vacant building registration fee. The form shall include, as a minimum, the name, street address, and telephone number of the owner; the case name and number of any litigation pending concerning or affecting the building, including bankruptcy cases; and the name, street address, and telephone number of all persons with any legal interest in the building or the premises. The form shall require the owner to identify a natural person twenty-one (21) years of age or older who maintains a permanent address in DuPage County, Illinois to accept service on behalf of the owner with respect to any notices the director sends pursuant to this article or service of process in any proceeding commenced to enforce any provision of this article, and file with the director on the registration form, the name, address, telephone number, of said person. A street address is required. A post office box is not an acceptable address. 
(2)  The form shall require the owner to indicate his or her "acceptance of notice by posting" consenting to service of notices sent or required to be sent, pursuant to this article, by posting on the building if the owner fails to renew the registration if required, or maintain as current with the director the information required regarding the person designated to accept notice and service of process. 
(b)  The owner shall renew the vacant building registration each year on the anniversary date of the first filing for the time the building remains vacant and pay the required two hundred dollar ($200.00) annual fee; and file an amended registration within fifteen (15) days of any change in the information contained in the annual registration. A new registration is required for any change in ownership whatsoever. 
(c)  Registration does not exonerate the owner from compliance with all applicable codes and ordinances, including this article, nor does it preclude any of the actions the village is authorized to take pursuant to this article or elsewhere in the Village Code. 
(d)  Inspection: The village shall conduct a comprehensive code-compliance inspection of the interior of the vacant building and the owner shall pay a five hundred dollar ($500.00) fee to the village to defray the village's cost of same within thirty (30) days of the inspection. Such inspection will determine the extent of compliance with village property maintenance, building, health, water, sewer and fire codes. The village shall send the inspection report to the owner within thirty (30) days. Periodic reinspections shall take place, as necessary, until code compliance is achieved. Timely code compliance is required. 
(e)  Vacant building plan: At the time a building is registered as required herein, the owner shall submit a vacant building plan. The director may prescribe a form for the plan. If the owner fails to submit the plan as provided for by this article, the director may determine the plan. The plan shall contain the following as a minimum: 
(1)  A plan of action to repair any doors, windows, or other openings which are boarded up or otherwise secured or covered by any means other than conventional methods used in the design of the building or permitted for new construction or similar type. The proposed repair shall result in openings being secured by conventional methods used in the design of the building or by methods permitted for new construction of similar type with board removed. Boarding shall be accomplished with materials and methods described by the director and available from the director. The owner shall maintain the building in an enclosed and secure state until the building is reoccupied or made available for immediate occupancy. If the owner demonstrates that securing of the building will provide adequate protection to the public, the director may waive the requirement of an enclosure. 
(2)  For buildings and/or premises which are determined by the director as being or containing public nuisances, as defined in section 7-1003, then the vacant building/premises plan shall contain a plan of action to remedy such public nuisance(s). 
(3)  A time schedule identifying a date of commencement of repair and date of completion of repair for each improperly secured opening and nuisance identified by the director. 
(4)  When the owner proposes to demolish the vacant building, then the owner shall submit a plan and time schedule for such demolition. 
(5)  A plan of action to maintain the building and/or premises thereof in conformance with this article. 
(6)  A plan of action, with a time schedule, identifying the date the building will be habitable and occupied or offered for occupancy or sale. The time schedule shall include date(s) of commencement and completion of all actions required to achieve habitability. No plan which fails to provide for compliance with this article or, which will not, as determined by the director, achieve such compliance, within three (3) months, in the case of a vacant boarded building, and two (2) years, in the case of a vacant, unbounded, and code-compliant building will be approved, except that the director may approve an extension of the time during which the building will be unoccupied beyond two (2) years to a date certain but then only based upon clear and documented evidence of good cause shown by the owner as determined by the director. 
(f)  All premises upon which unoccupied or vacant buildings, are located and the exteriors shall at all time be maintained in compliance with the Village Code. 
(g)  Exterior lighting shall be maintained according to standards established by the director and available from the director. 
(h)  All ground floor windows facing street frontage, including, but not limited to, all display windows in unoccupied or vacant commercial buildings shall be kept in a well maintained and clean condition and shall be covered on the interior side in a professionally finished manner with an opaque window covering material manufactured for that purpose and approved by the director, or in the case of display windows, such windows shall be kept in a well maintained and clean condition and the display area shall be enclosed with a professionally finished backdrop, floor, side walls and ceiling all of which shall be kept in a well maintained and clean condition and shall be well lighted from 10:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. each day. Photographs, paintings and other works of art or other tasteful forms of decoration may be professionally displayed in these properly enclosed clear glass display windows. If opaque window covering material is used, a one-inch by one-inch clear glass opening through which the interior space is clearly visible shall be maintained at standing eye level along one (1) edge of one (1) such window. 
(i)  Security: On written notice of the director, the owner shall provide bonded, licensed, and insured security guard service at the building between the hours of 3:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. Such service shall remain in place until the director gives written notice that the service is no longer required. Such service shall be required when the director makes a written determination that the vacant building constitutes a fire hazard, is otherwise dangerous to human life or the public welfare, involves illegal or improper use, occupancy, or maintenance, under such conditions that securing the building is insufficient to prevent the actual or threatened harm. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-1307. - Mortgage lender's obligation to register unoccupied buildings acquired through mortgage foreclosure. 
The obligation to register buildings shall extend to mortgage lenders that have obtained title to unoccupied buildings through a mortgage foreclosure action. 
(a)  Mortgage lenders shall register unoccupied buildings with the director within fifteen (15) days of obtaining title to same. 
(b)  The registration obligation of mortgage lenders under section 7-1006 shall be limited to providing the director with the same information required under subsection 7-1006(a) on the registration form prescribed by the director. 
(c)  Except as provided in subsection 7-1007(e) below, mortgage lenders shall not be responsible for paying the two hundred dollar ($200.00) registration fee and shall not be required to comply with subsections 7-1006(b) through (i). 
(d)  An amended registration form shall be filed in accordance with subsection 7-1006(b) within fifteen (15) days of any change in the information provided in any registration form provided hereunder. 
(e)  If such unoccupied, registered building is later determined to have become a "vacant building" as defined in section 7-1003, then such building and building owner shall be required to comply with all of the provisions of section 7-1006. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-1308. - Approval of plan. 
(a)  The director shall review the proposed vacant building plan in accordance with the standards below. The director shall send notice to the owner of the vacant building of his or her determination. 
(b)  In considering the appropriateness of a vacant building plan, the director shall include the following in his or her consideration and shall make written findings as to each: 
(1)  The purposes of this article and intent of the village board to minimize the time a building is boarded or otherwise vacant. 
(2)  The effect of the building and the proposed plan on adjoining property. 
(3)  The length of time the building has been vacant. 
(4)  The presence of any public nuisances on the property. 
(5)  The likelihood that the plan or portion(s) thereof will prevent or ameliorate the condition it is designed to address. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-1309. - Authority to modify plan; right to appeal. 
The director shall, upon notice to the vacant building owner, have the right to modify the vacant building plan by modifying the dates of performance, the proposed methods of action, or by imposing additional requirements consistent with this article he or she deems necessary to protect the public health, safety or welfare. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-1310. - Failure to comply with plan. 
Failure to have an approved plan within thirty (30) days of filing the registration form or failure to comply with the approved plan shall constitute a violation of this article subjecting the owner of the building to penalties as provided in this article and to any remedies the village may avail itself of as provided for herein and elsewhere in the Village Code, including, but not limited to, an action to compel correction of health or fire code violations. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-1311. - Other enforcement. 
The registration of a vacant building shall not preclude action by the village to demolish or to take other action against the building pursuant to other provisions of this article, the Village Code, or other applicable legislation. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-1312. - Certification. 
A certificate of compliance with this for vacant buildings article issued by the director and payment in full of all fees imposed pursuant to this article are required prior to any occupancy of a vacant building. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-1313. - Time restrictions, vacant buildings. 
It is the policy of the village that boarding is a temporary solution to prevent unauthorized entry into a vacant building and that boarded buildings are a public nuisance. A vacant building may not remain boarded longer than three (3) months unless an extension of that time is part of a plan approved by the director. 
A vacant building which is otherwise code-compliant and secure as determined by the director on the basis of police reports, citizen complaints, and other information considered reliable by reasonable persons, may not remain vacant for more than two (2) years and must have an approved plan for occupancy, sale, demolition, or other disposition of the building in place within the timeframes established in this article, except as otherwise provided for in section 7-1006 hereinabove. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Sec. 7-1314. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3700, § 3, adopted May 21, 2012, deleted § 7-1314, entitled "Enforcement and penalties", which derived from: Ord. No. 3662, § 2, adopted July 25, 2011.  
Sec. 7-1315. - Severability. 
In the event any section of this article or any part of any section of this article is declared to be unconstitutional, such decision shall in no way affect the operation of any other section or part thereof [and] the remainder of this article shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 7-25-11)  
Chapter 7.5 - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Building regulations, Ch. 7; cable TV commission, 2-3001 et seq.; licenses, permits and business regulations, ch. 13; table of franchises, App. A. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
(RESERVED)  
ARTICLE II. - CABLE T.V. ETHICS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2059, adopted Feb. 7, 1983, added a new Ch. 26, §§ 26-101—26-110 to the Code. In order to maintain the alphabetical sequence of chapters in this Code, the editor has redesignated said provisions as Ch. 7.5, Art. II, §§ 7.5-201—7.5-210. 
 
Sec. 7.5-201. - Definitions. 
Cable T.V. franchise means granting by the Village of Villa Park the right and privilege to establish, construct, operate and maintain a system and facilities in, over, upon and under the public right-of-way and within easements or other rights to use property which are effective for the purpose of that grant; said system defined in Illinois Revised Statutes Chapter 24, Section 11-42-11. 
Communication means a discussion, presentation, either oral or written, or other transmission of information relating in any way to cable communications in the Village of Villa Park. 
Expenditure means the payment, distribution, loan, advance, deposit, political or campaign contribution or load, a gift of money or anything of value, or employment, or the conferring of an economic benefit or the incurring of an economic cost, and includes a contract, promise or agreement; whether or not legally enforceable; whether or not made or incurred in the Village of Villa Park; relating in any way to cable communications in the Village of Villa Park. An expenditure includes expenditures by a person's parent corporation, subsidiary, predecessor, or other affiliated entity, or by any business or professional entity with which a person is affiliated or associated. 
Family member includes spouse, parent and children if they are members of the same household. 
Franchisee means any person who applies for cable T.V. communications franchise in the Village of Villa Park and with whom the corporate authorities have agreed to negotiate regarding a cable communications franchise. 
Grantee means any person granted a cable communications franchise, and the person's lawful and approved successors, transferees or assignees. 
Interest means any economic interest or relationship, whether by ownership, purchase, sale, lease, contract, option, investment, employment, gift, fee, or otherwise; whether present, promised, or reasonably expected; whether direct or indirect; whether or not legally enforceable; whether in person itself or in a parent or a subsidiary corporation, or another subsidiary of the same parent. Interest shall not include any interest provided without discrimination to all cable subscribers or to all persons who agree to become cable subscribers, or any publicly disclosed minority interest determined by the village board to be so minor that it does not reasonably constitute a natural or apparent conflict of interest. 
Manager means the village manager of the Village of Villa Park. 
Municipal Code means the Municipal Code of the Village of Villa Park. 
Person means an individual, firm, corporation, cooperative, association, trust, partnership, joint venture, combination or other legally recognized entity. 
Person with whom a village representative maintains a close economic association means a person associated with a village representative in a partnership, professional service corporation, or other form of business association or professional association, whether as a partner, officer, employee, associate, principal, agent or otherwise. 
Representatives includes any persons who, at any time, since January 1, 1982, are or were authorized to speak on behalf of a franchisee, or otherwise represent the franchisee, or to service the franchisee or an agency capacity or by contract, with respect to any matters relating to cable communications within the Village of Villa Park. Representatives include, but are not limited to, all attorneys, consultants, franchise representatives, advertising agencies, marketing research firms, persons conducting needs' assessments on behalf of the franchisee, and the like, and any persons who are or were authorized to or who, on behalf of the franchisee, make any communication or engage in any activity relating to the content or approval of any requests for proposal, franchise applications, franchise, or ordinance concerning the cable communications within the Village of Villa Park. In the case of an individual representative, a representative also includes any firm or other business or professional association by which the individual is employed, or with which he or she is otherwise affiliated. In the case of a firm or other entity, a representative also includes any individuals who perform or will perform any of the activities as representative. Representative includes any person employed or retained by the franchisee or a parent corporation, subsidiary, or other affiliated entity whose responsibilities include any of the foregoing communications or activities. 
Requests for proposal means the village's requests for proposal to construct and operate a cable communication system within the corporate limits of Villa Park. 
Village means the Village of Villa Park. 
Village advisor means any outside consultant, counsel or other person retained by the village with respect to cable communications within the Village of Villa Park. 
Village employee means any employee who is working in a department. 
Village representative means members of the village board, all village officers whose positions are created by state statute and all supporting staff of the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. No. 2059, § 1, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 7.5-202. - Ineligible franchisees. 
The following shall not be eligible to be or to remain franchisees where any interest might exceed one per cent franchise value or constitute a continuing financial interest in the Villa Park Cable T.V. Franchise: 
(1)  Any person in whom a village employee, or family member of a village employee has an interest; 
(2)  Any person in whom a village representative, or a family member of a village representative has an interest; 
(3)  Any person in whom a village advisor, or family member of the village advisor has an interest; 
(4)  Any person in whom an interest is held by a person with whom a village representative maintains a close economic relationship; 
(5)  Any person whom, directly or indirectly, knowingly offers, promises, suggests, or otherwise communicates the possible provision of an interest to a village employee, family member of a village employee, to a village advisor, to a family member of a village advisor, to a village representative, to a family member of a village representative, or to a person with whom a village representative maintains a close economic association to a village representative; 
(6)  Any person who, directly or indirectly, knowingly communicates with a village employee in violation of the restrictions in ex parte communications provided in section 7.5-208 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2059, § 1, 2-7-83)  
Sec. 7.5-203. - Disclosure by franchisee and grantees. 
Each franchisee, or an authorized officer of the franchisee, shall file with the village manager a written statement, subscribed under oath before a notary public, publicly disclosing the following information: 
(1)  The name and addresses of all representatives for the franchisee; the capacity in which each acts as representatives, the amounts of all compensation paid to or reasonably expected by each representative for services rendered with respect to any matter relating to Villa Park cable communications at any time since January 1, 1982 or to be rendered as a representative for the franchisee. 
(2)  All expenditures by or on behalf of the applicant at any time since January 1, 1982, itemized by categories and amounts regarding expenditures performed in regards to the village. 
(3)  All information concerning ownership of franchisee. Such ownership information shall include disclosure of owners, including any beneficiary or beneficiaries of any trust or similar entity, and disclose their principals whenever any ownership is held by an agent or nominee. 
(4)  The identity of all village employees, and family members of village employees, all village advisors and family members of village advisors, village representatives, family members of village representatives, and persons with whom a village representative maintains a close economic association who have or at any time since January 1, 1982, have had an interest in the franchisee, and the nature and amount of such interest. 
(5)  All communications by or on behalf of the franchisee with any village representatives, family member, or person with whom a village representative maintains a close economic association, at any time since January 1, 1982, outside of the scope of public meetings in accord with the Open Meetings Act.
