State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 108½, § 4-132.  
ARTICLE IV. - HAZARDOUS MATERIALS CONTROL 
 
Sec. 9-401. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
Combustible: Any substance with a flash point greater than one hundred (100) degrees Fahrenheit. 
Corrosive: Any substance which, in contact with living tissue, causes destruction of tissue by chemical action. (Does not refer to action on inanimate surfaces.) 
Flammable: Any substance which has a flash point of less than one hundred (100) degrees Fahrenheit. 
Hazardous material or hazardous substance: Any material or substance or mixture of substances which is toxic, corrosive, an irritant, a strong sensitizer, radioactive, flammable, combustible, or which generates pressure through decomposition, heat or other means and which may cause injury or illness to humans, domestic livestock, or wildlife as defined by the Illinois Environmental Protection Act or any federal law. 
Hazardous material incident: An incident which threatens public health or safety involving the actual or potential release of a hazardous substance or hazardous material. 
Irritant: Any substance, not corrosive, which, on immediate, prolonged or repeated contact with normal living tissue will induce local inflammatory reaction. 
Person: Any individual, partnership, corporation, trust, firm, company, estate, association or other legal entity. 
Radioactive: Any substance which emits ionizing radiation. 
Strong sensitizer: Any substance which will cause, on normal living tissue through an allergic or photodynamic process, a hypersensitivity which becomes evident on reapplication of the same substance. 
Toxic: Any substance (other than a radioactive substance) which has the capacity to produce bodily injury or illness to humans through ingestion, inhalation, or absorption through any body surface. 
(Ord. No. 2533, § 2, 11-18-91)  
Sec. 9-402. - Control of hazardous substances or hazardous materials. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use, store, deliver or transport hazardous substances or hazardous materials, or cause the use, storage, delivery or transporting of hazardous substances or hazardous materials, in any manner inconsistent with the requirements of chapter 9 of the Villa Park Municipal Code or any other applicable ordinance, state law or federal law. 
(b)  Transportation of hazardous materials by motor vehicle. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle carrying, transporting or containing a hazardous substance or hazardous material to park or stand, other than temporarily for the purpose of, and while actually engaging in, loading or unloading, on private property, without the knowledge and express consent of the person who is in charge of the property and who is aware of the nature of the hazardous substance or hazardous material the motor vehicle contains. 
(2)  No motor vehicle shall transport or carry hazardous materials through the corporate limits of the village except on Routes 83, 38 and 64. It shall not be lawful under this article for a motor vehicle carrying, transporting or containing a hazardous substance or material to make deliveries within the village, provided that all such deliveries comply with all applicable ordinances of the village, including but not limited to zoning regulations, and are otherwise done in full accordance with all laws, ordinances, or regulations of any governmental agency or administration. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle carrying, transporting or containing a hazardous substance or hazardous material to fail to comply with all applicable provisions of this article. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person using, storing, manufacturing, producing, disposing, treating, transporting or causing the use, storage, manufacture, production, disposal, treatment or transportation, of any hazardous substance or hazardous material in any manner which results in a hazardous material incident. 
(Ord. No. 2533, § 2, 11-18-91)  
Sec. 9-403. - Recovery of costs. 
(a)  Any person causing or permitting a hazardous material incident shall be responsible for all costs incurred in connection with a response to a hazardous material incident, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Any and all costs incurred by the village in connection with the operation, maintenance, and staffing required to respond to such hazardous material incident at the rate of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per hour per vehicle (or any fraction of an hour) and the hourly rate of pay, together will all benefits, taxes, administrative overhead, worker's compensation claims, and any other expense or cost, for each employee who participates in any response to a hazardous material incident. 
(2)  Any and all costs incurred by the village for equipment and materials used, damaged, lost, spent, destroyed, or rendered irreparable in connection with a hazardous material incident. 
(3)  Any and all costs, expenses and liabilities set forth in subparagraphs (1) and (2), hereinabove, incurred by any federal, state, or local governmental agency responding to a hazardous material incident. 
(4)  Assumption of, and all liability and costs for, cleanup or removal resulting from a hazardous material incident, including, but not limited to, any independent cleanup contractor required by such hazardous material incident. 
(b)  The village shall prepare and forward to the person or persons causing or permitting a hazardous material incident a bill for the total costs and expenses incurred for which such person or persons are responsible pursuant to this article; provided, however, any cost in connection with any independent cleanup contractor shall be billed directly by such contractor. Payment of the total bill shall be made within thirty (30) days of receipt. Any bill or portion of a bill remaining unpaid after thirty (30) days of receipt shall accrue interest on the unpaid balance at the rate of one and one-half (1½) percent per month. 
(Ord. No. 2533, § 2, 11-18-91)  
ARTICLE V. - FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE BOARD[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 3595, adopted March 8, 2010, amended Art. V in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. V pertained to the same subject matter, was comprised of §§ 9-501—9-511, and derived from Ord. No. 2536, adopted Dec. 9, 1991. 
 
Sec. 9-501. - Established. 
There is hereby established a board to be known and designated as the foreign fire insurance board (the "fire board") for the village fire department. The purpose of the board is to receive and account for revenues received from the tax on fire insurance policies sold by foreign (out of state) insurance companies, and to use such funds for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the department, as set forth in 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1. 
The tax on fire insurance policies sold by foreign insurance companies is established pursuant to article VI of chapter 23 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 3595, § 2, 3-8-10)  
Sec. 9-502. - Size and composition of the fire board. 
(a)  The fire board established hereby shall be comprised of seven (7) trustees. The fire chief, who shall hold office by virtue of rank, shall be one (1) of the trustees. The remaining six (6) trustees shall be elected by the sworn members of the fire department as hereinafter provided. If there are an insufficient number of candidates to fill the trustee positions, the number of fire board members shall be reduced, but not to fewer than three (3) trustees. The trustees of the board shall annually elect the officers of the fire board. 
(b)  Six (6) trustees shall be elected at large by the sworn members of the department from among themselves. The first elected board shall consist of two (2) trustees elected for one-year terms, two (2) trustees elected for two-year terms, and two (2) trustees elected for three-year terms. In every year thereafter, two (2) trustees shall be elected for three-year terms to fill the positions of the two (2) trustees whose terms are expiring that year. Trustees shall be eligible for reelection. Elections shall be held in the first week of November and terms shall begin on the first day of December. Officers shall be elected in accordance with the Australian ballot system. 
(c)  Elected members of the board shall serve until their successors are elected and installed. 
(d)  Vacancies shall be filled by election if more than one (1) year remains in the term of office. Otherwise, the board shall fill the vacancy and appoint as a member a person who would be eligible for election to that vacancy. 
(Ord. No. 3595, § 2, 3-8-10)  
Sec. 9-503. - Fire board officers. 
(a)  The trustees shall annually elect a chairman, a secretary and a treasurer from among their members in the month following each annual election. 
(b)  The chairman or, in the chairman's absence, the treasurer shall preside over all meetings of the board. 
(c)  The treasurer shall assume the duties of the chairman in the absence or incapacity of the chairman. 
(d)  The secretary shall record and keep accurate minutes of all meetings conducted by the board, which shall include, but need not be limited to: 
(1)  The date, time and place of the meeting; 
(2)  The members of the board recorded as either present or absent; and 
(3)  A summary of discussion on all matters proposed, deliberated, or decided, and a record of any votes taken. 
(e)  The secretary shall make all minutes of board meetings available for public inspection within seven (7) days of approval of such minutes by the board, including posting on its website if one is maintained. If the secretary is absent from a meeting, another board member shall be appointed by the chairman to record the minutes. In addition, the secretary shall be responsible for the board's written communications and shall be the custodian of the board's nonfinancial records. 
(f)  The treasurer shall be responsible for receiving all funds appropriated to the board and implementing expenditures for the maintenance, use and benefit of the department upon the order of the board. The treasurer shall keep accurate and current records of the fund and all accounts maintained thereunder, including all deposits thereto, withdrawals and disbursements therefrom, balances therein, and all other regular and customary financial and accounting information. 
(g)  The officers of the fire board shall develop and maintain a listing of those items that the fire board feels are appropriate expenditures under 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1. 
(h)  The treasurer of the fire board shall give a sufficient bond to the village. This bond shall be approved by the village president conditioned upon the faithful performance by the treasurer of his or her duties under the ordinance and the rules and regulations provided for in this article. The treasurer of the fire board shall receive the appropriated money and shall pay out the money upon the order of the fire board for the maintenance, use and benefit of the department. 
(Ord. No. 3595, § 2, 3-8-10)  
Sec. 9-504. - Board meetings. 
(a)  The board shall comply with the Open Meetings Act, 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq. Within thirty (30) days of their election, all trustees must successfully complete an electronic training curriculum on the Open Meetings Act, and thereafter must successfully complete an annual training program, as required by 5 ILCS 120/1.05. 
(b)  The board shall meet at least quarterly and more often as is necessary to discharge the responsibilities imposed on it by law and ordinance. All meetings shall be held in conformity with the Illinois Open Meetings Act. If the board has six (6) or seven (7) members, four (4) members constitute a quorum required to conduct business, and a majority of those present shall be necessary to adopt any motion or resolution, with the exception of a vote to adopt or amend the board's rules and regulations, which shall require the affirmative vote of four (4) members. If the board has four (4) or five (5) members, three (3) members constitute a quorum required to conduct business, and an affirmative vote of three (3) members is necessary to adopt any motion or resolution, including a vote to adopt or amend the board's rules and regulations. If the board has three (3) members, two (2) members constitute a quorum required to conduct business, and an affirmative vote of two (2) members is necessary to adopt any motion or resolution, including a vote to adopt or amend the board's rules and regulations. 
(c)  The board shall establish a regular time and place for its meetings, which shall be open to the public. 
(d)  Board meetings shall be noticed in accordance with the Open Meetings Act, which provides, among other things, that "every public body shall give public notice of the schedule of regular meetings at the beginning of each calendar or fiscal year and shall state the regular dates, times and places of such meetings"; that "an agenda for each regular meeting shall be posted at the principal office of the public body and at the location where the meeting is to be held at least 48 hours in advance of the holding of the meeting"; and that "public notice shall be given by posting a copy of the notice at the principal office of the body holding the meeting or, if no such office exists, at the building in which the meeting is to be held," and "on its website," if it maintains one (5 ILCS 120/2.02). 
(e)  Meetings shall be conducted in accordance with Robert's Rules of Order. 
(Ord. No. 3595, § 2, 3-8-10)  
Sec. 9-505. - Budget. 
(a)  Preliminary budget. By November 1 of each year, the officers of the board shall approve a preliminary budget for the expenditure of the funds received pursuant to the foreign fire insurance tax. 
(b)  Final budget. The officers of the board shall, no later than December 1, adopt a final budget for the collection and payment of the foreign fire insurance tax. The final budget shall be approved by ordinance by the village board of trustees in the same fashion as any other village ordinance. 
(c)  Budget amendments. The final budget may be amended at any time by the unanimous vote of the officers of the board and a majority vote of the village board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 3595, § 2, 3-8-10; Ord. No. 4025 , § 3, 4-23-18)  
Sec. 9-506. - Fire board regulations. 
(a)  The trustees of the fire board shall make all needful rules and regulations with respect to the fire board and the management of the money to be appropriated to the fire board. At a minimum, said rules and regulations shall require: 
(1)  The investment of board funds as are not immediately required in such securities as the village board of trustees shall specifically or generally from time to time designate; 
(2)  The deposit of all such monies in the name of the foreign fire insurance board for the village fire department in such banks, savings and loan associates, or other depositories as shall be authorized by the village board of trustees; and 
(3)  The maintenance of the financial books and records of monies received by the fire board; provided, however, that all investments of foreign fire insurance tax shall be made only in those securities which may be purchased by Illinois nonhome rule municipalities under the applicable provisions of the Illinois Compiled Statutes. 
(b)  The board shall authorize use of money from the fund by written resolution setting forth with particularity the items on which funds are to be expended and the amounts approved for expenditure, provided that such items approved for funding shall be contained within the list described in subsection 9-503(g) above. The treasurer shall pay out money from the fund as authorized by resolution of the board. The signatures of two (2) of the three (3) officers of the board shall be required on any check, draft or other order drawn on the account of the fund. 
(c)  The board shall not incur debt or enter into any contract or other agreement for any expenditure in excess of the unencumbered funds currently on deposit in, and authorized for expenditure from, the fund at the time of execution of any such contract or agreement. 
(Ord. No. 3595, § 2, 3-8-10)  
Sec. 9-507. - Payment of funds. 
Upon receipt of the funds from the insurance companies specified in 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1, the village treasurer shall pay to the treasurer of the foreign fire insurance board such sums. 
(Ord. No. 3595, § 2, 3-8-10)  
Sec. 9-508. - Annual audit. 
The trustees of the fire board shall provide to the village board of trustees an annual audit of the financial affairs of the department. The audit shall be performed at the end of each fiscal year in accordance with generally accepted auditing principles by a certified public accountant as part of the annual municipal audit. The annual audit report shall be delivered to the village president, each village trustee and the village manager. 
(Ord. No. 3595, § 2, 3-8-10)  
Sec. 9-509. - No interference with operations. 
At no time shall the actions of the officers of the fire board interfere with the powers of the chief, the composition of the fire department, the board of fire and police commissioners, or in any way impede the ordinary operation of the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 3595, § 2, 3-8-10)  
ARTICLE VI. - FIRE ALARM REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 9-601. - Definitions. 
Whenever the following terms are used in this article, they shall be interpreted in accordance with the definitions hereinafter set forth, unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
Alarm company: Any individual, partnership, corporation or other entity selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving or installing any alarm system or causing to be sold, leased, maintained, serviced, repaired, altered, replaced, moved or installed any alarm system in or on any building, structure or facility. 
Alarm user: Jointly and severally, any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization that owns, leases or occupies the premises or property where a fire alarm system is maintained. 
Designated proprietary agent: The agent designated by Villa Park to operate the village system or by DuComm with respect to the operation of the remote receiving station. 
Fire alarm system: A system or portion of a combination system that consists of components and circuits arranged to monitor and annunciate the status of fire alarm or supervisory signal-initiating devices and to initiate the appropriate response to those signals. 
Remote receiving station: DuComm, 600 Wall Street, Glendale Heights, Illinois. 
Village system: The Village of Villa Park alarm receiving and monitoring panel as installed and maintained by ADT/Tyco, at DuComm, 600 Wall Street, Glendale Heights, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96; Ord. No. 3434, § 2, 7-23-07)  
Sec. 9-602. - Connection to village system. 
Any property owner, lessee, person, firm, partnership, association, corporation or organization in control of property may connect automatic fire alarm transmitting equipment to the village's alarm receiving and monitoring panels as installed and maintained by the village operations center at DuComm (hereinafter referred to as "DuComm"). 
The alarm user shall be responsible for compliance with the terms of this article with regard to all applications, requirements, and fees associated with connection to DuComm. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96; Ord. No. 3434, § 2, 7-23-07)  
Sec. 9-603. - Required connection of fire alarm systems. 
All new required fire alarm systems, as mandated by BOCA National Building Code 1999 Edition, as now or hereafter amended by chapter 7, article II of the Municipal Code, shall transmit trouble, supervisory, and fire signals to the ADT receiving point in the village via a wireless transmitter in accordance with NFPA 72. Only equipment certified and approved by the remote receiving station and/or its designated proprietary agent may be installed. The designated proprietary agent shall be the only authorized installer of the approved radio transmitters. Existing systems shall be changed to wireless either (a) upon the alarm owner's request; or (b) when the existing equipment is updated; or (c) when an alarm has been in a trouble or out of service condition for a time period of over thirty (30) days caused by a problem with the dedicated telephone fire alarm circuit; or (d) an alarm has three (3) or more line troubles lasting forty-eight (48) hours or more in any twelve-month period. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96; Ord. No. 3434, § 2, 7-23-07)  
Sec. 9-604. - Fire alarm system plan review. 
The following shall apply to all structures except R3 and R4: 
Fire alarm system plans shall be submitted for review for any new fire alarm system and or upgrade to an existing system. No work shall begin prior to the approval of the plan by the Fire Department and the issuance of a permit for the work by the community development department. 
A system upgrade shall be defined as any one (1) or more of the following: 
(a)  Replacement of the main fire alarm control panel. 
(b)  Replacement of more than one-half (½) the alarm initiating devices. 
(c)  Replacement of more than one-half (½) the alarm notification devices. 
(d)  Any addition of alarm initiating devices. 
(e)  Addition, repair or replacement of any fire alarm wiring. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96; Ord. No. 3434, § 2, 7-23-07)  
Sec. 9-605. - Fire alarm system requirements for connection. 
Fire alarm system connections to DuComm shall be made only after compliance with the following requirements: 
(a)  Connection shall not overburden or otherwise interfere with the operation of DuComm. 
(b)  The alarm system shall be installed according to the manufacturer's directions. 
(c)  Fire alarm systems shall be compatible with the village's system. 
(d)  The alarm user shall make arrangements with the company installing the alarm system and with ADT/Tyco for the installation of a wireless transmitter. The designated proprietary agent shall be the only authorized installer of the approved radio transmitters. 
(e)  The alarm user shall purchase and install a standard security lock box in the manner and location prescribed by the fire department and containing keys to all entrances and exits to the building to allow immediate access in emergency situations. At the request of the alarm user, the fire department may permit the installation of a securing lock box tamper switch connected to a security system; however no such connection to the fire alarm system shall be allowed. 
(f)  All fire alarm systems shall be installed, maintained and tested in accordance with NFPA 72 and Chapter 35 of the BOCA national Building Code 1999 Edition, as now or hereafter amended by chapter 7, article II of the Municipal Code. 
(g)  The fire department shall inspect the property prior to connection and make a written finding as to whether the above requirements have been met. For fire alarm systems required to be installed by the fire department, the inspection shall be a prerequisite for the final occupancy permit given by the building official of the village for new construction or remodeling of buildings. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96; Ord. No. 3434, § 2, 7-23-07)  
Sec. 9-606. - Fees. 
There shall be an alarm system plan review fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) plus two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) per accessory device. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96; Ord. No. 3434, § 2, 7-23-07)  
Sec. 9-607. - Alarm system posting requirements. 
The alarm user shall post or cause to be posted at or near the location where such alarm system can be deactivated, a notice containing the name, address and telephone number of the alarm user and the person, firm or corporation responsible for the maintenance and repair of such alarm system. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96; Ord. No. 3434, § 2, 7-23-07)  
Sec. 9-608. - Maintenance and testing requirements. 
(a)  All alarm users shall maintain the alarm system in good working order. 
(b)  The alarm user shall have any fire alarm system tested according to the following schedule by a licensed testing agency or licensed electrical contractor approved by the fire department. 
Sprinkled buildings—Annually 
Nonsprinkled buildings—Annually 
(1)  Tests under this section shall be conducted according to the standards as set forth in section 9-605(f). Each test shall also include the testing of the systems battery under load conditions. 
(2)  The results of the testing agency or electrical contractors test shall be in writing, signed by the agency or contractor, and kept on file at the premises where the alarm system is being used. A copy of the test results shall be forwarded to the fire department upon completion of the alarm system test. The test shall not be considered completed until the village receives the written results thereof. If the written results are not received by the village within thirty (30) days after the end of the applicable testing interval, the alarm user shall be subject to the additional fee set forth in section 9-617. 
(3)  New and upgraded systems shall be acceptance tested according to the standards as set forth in section 9-605(f). 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96; Ord. No. 3434, § 2, 7-23-07)  
Sec. 9-609. - Time limits—Alarm sound; response to village notification. 
The alarm user shall respond or cause his representative to appear at the alarm system location within one (1) hour from notification by the village to reset an alarm system, to provide access to the premises, or to provide securing for the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96)  
Sec. 9-610. - Automatic telephone alarm prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall install, or cause to be installed, or maintain any automatic telephone alarm in the village. 
Any automatic telephone alarm installed and operative on the effective date of this article shall be and is hereby declared to be a nuisance. Any such automatic telephone alarm shall be removed by the owner thereof within thirty (30) days following the effective date of this article. Automatic telephone alarms not so removed shall be subject to abatement as a nuisance and to the penalties hereinafter provided. 
(b)  No person shall make or cause to be made telephone calls utilizing an automatic telephone alarm to any telephone line which terminates at any office or telephone registered to the village. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96)  
Sec. 9-611. - False alarms—Determination; definition. 
Upon receipt of any reports or information from the responding department, the fire department shall determine whether an alarm was a false alarm. A "false alarm" is an alarm signal requiring a response by the fire department when a situation requiring such a response by the fire department does not exist. False alarm shall not include alarms of the following nature: 
(a)  Fire or smoke causes activation as verified by the fire department. 
(b)  Physical damage to the property caused by lightning. 
(c)  Telephone line malfunction as determined by the fire department. 
(d)  Securing alarm systems affected by electrical service interruption as determined by the fire department. 
(e)  The alarm system was newly installed within the last thirty (30) days in full compliance with the requirements of this article. 
Upon determination that the alarm was false, the fire department shall so notify the alarm user. If the alarm user objects to such determination, a written appeal shall be filed with the fire chief within fifteen (15) days from receipt of the fire department's decision. The fire chief, after a review of all information, reports and evidence, including those submitted by the alarm user, shall make a written decision on whether to uphold the fire department's decision within twenty (20) days of receipt of the appeal; such written decision to be sent certified mail to the alarm user. The decision of the fire chief shall be the final decision on the matter. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96)  
Sec. 9-612. - Conducting tests, maintenance or repair work. 
Whenever an alarm user, or agent(s) of the alarm user, conducts tests, maintenance work, or repair work on any alarm system connected to the village system, the alarm user shall notify DuComm of that fact prior to conducting such tests or work, and shall notify DuComm that such tests or work has been completed immediately after such completion. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96)  
Sec. 9-613. - False alarms—Negligence. 
If the fire department responds to a false alarm and it is determined by the fire department that the cause of the false alarm was negligence in failing to contact DuComm as required by section 9-612, the alarm user shall be subject to the fee set forth in section 9-616. This determination of the fire department can be appealed pursuant to the procedures in section 9-611. If an alarm user is assessed the fee under this section, the alarm shall not be counted toward the accumulation of false alarms subject to further fees in section 9-616(d). 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96)  
Sec. 9-614. - Alarm systems subject to disconnection from DuComm. 
The following alarm systems shall be subject to disconnection as provided in section 9-615. 
(a)  Any alarm system which does not or no longer meets the requirements for connection as set forth in section 9-605. 
(b)  Any alarm system for which connection fees, false alarm fees or additional charges under this article have been assessed and are thirty (30) days overdue. 
(c)  Any alarm system which has ten (10) or more false alarms within a sixty-day period. 
For properties required to be connected to DuComm according to the Villa Park Municipal Code and subject to disconnection pursuant to this section, the procedures for disconnection in section 9-615 shall be followed, but a fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) shall be assessed in lieu of disconnection. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96)  
Sec. 9-615. - Disconnection procedures. 
Prior to disconnecting the alarm system from DuComm, the following procedures shall be followed: 
(a)  The village shall notify the alarm user by certified mail that the alarm system is subject to disconnection for one (1) of the causes set forth in section 9-614. The alarm user has fifteen (15) days from receipt of the notice to either (1) submit proof to the fire department that the alarm meets the requirements under section 9-605; (2) to pay the outstanding balance due the village; or (3) submit a report to the fire department describing the actions to be taken to eliminate the cause of the false alarms. 
(b)  If the fire department determines that the proof submitted establishes that the alarm system is in compliance with the requirements of section 9-605, that any overdue payments have been made, or that the action to be taken by the alarm user as described in the report will substantially reduce the likelihood of false alarms, the fire department shall notify the alarm user that the alarm system will not be disconnected from DuComm, but that if any subsequent violations of this article occur, the alarm system may be disconnected. 
(c)  If the alarm user is dissatisfied with the decision of the fire department, the alarm user may request in writing a hearing on the matter. Such requests for a hearing must be filed within ten (10) days of the receipt of the fire department's decision. Written notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be served on the alarm user by the fire chief by certified mail at least ten (10) days prior to the date set for the hearing, which date shall not be more than twenty-one (21) nor less than ten (10) days after the filing of the request for the hearing. 
(d)  Should the fire department determine that the nature of the alarm user's business or the complexity of the alarm system causes continued false alarms, which are not the result of any substantial negligence or disregard on the part of the alarm user, the fire department may permit the alarm user to retain the alarm system connection to DuComm despite the occurrence of ten (10) or more false alarms. However, the alarm user shall take such actions as the fire department deems necessary to reduce the occurrence of false alarms. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96)  
Sec. 9-616. - Additional fees and charges. 
In addition to any fines or penalties which may be assessed pursuant to this Code, persons violating provisions of this article shall be subject to the following additional charges: 
(a)  An alarm user who fails to provide the written results of the alarm system test pursuant to section 9-608(b) shall be subject to a one hundred fifty dollar ($150.00) additional fee. 
(b)  An alarm user who violates any provision of section 9-609 of this article shall be subject to a one hundred dollar ($100.00) charge. 
(c)  An alarm user who violates sections 9-612 and 9-613 of this article shall be subject to a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(d)  If the Villa Park Fire Department responds to four (4) or more false alarms within a twelve-month period, the alarm user shall be subject to the following additional charges: 
Fire alarm systems additional charges for each occurrence: 
Fourth, fifth, or sixth alarm within twelve (12) months ..... $100.00 
Seventh or more false alarms within twelve (12) months ..... 200.00 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96)  
Sec. 9-617. - Liability of village limited. 
(a)  The village assumes no liability for any defects in the operation of an alarm system because of the failure or neglect of any person associated with the installation, operation or maintenance of the alarm system, or for the transmission of alarm signals or other relaying of such signals and messages. 
(b)  The village shall not be liable for any claimed failure of service or any consequential damages claimed to result from such failure, or the installation, surveillance or operation of DuComm or any component part of its total automatic alarm system, whether or not due to the negligent, willful or reckless acts or omissions of the village or its employees or agents. 
(c)  The alarm user, by connection to DuComm, agrees that the alarm user shall defend, indemnify, hold harmless and save the Village of Villa Park, its officers and employees, from any claim or liability whatsoever, arising out of the application for connection, the alarm user's connection to DuComm, the operation of DuComm, or the response or nonresponse of village employees to the alarm user's property. Specifically, and without limitation to the foregoing, the alarm user shall defend, indemnify and hold harmless the village, its officers and employees, from any claim with respect to the property of the alarm user (for example, without limitation, if the property of the alarm user is the situs of the beginning of a fire), which claim arose of the incident on which such claim is based [or] occurred during which the alarm user's alarm transmitting equipment was connected to DuComm. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96)  
Sec. 9-618. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3700, § 3, adopted May 21, 2012, deleted § 9-618, entitled "Penalty", which derived from: Ord. No. 2823, § 2, adopted May 13, 1996.  
Sec. 9-619. - Severability clause. 
If any provision or part of this article is declared invalid and of no further force and effect, the other provisions of this chapter shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 2823, § 2, 5-13-96)  
Chapter 10 - GARBAGE AND TRASH[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Environmental control board, § 2-2501 et seq.; nuisances, Ch. 15; abandoned vehicles, § 15-401 et seq.; litter control, § 16-114. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 10-101. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall mean as indicated herein: 
Ashes: The residue from residential fireplaces and barbecue grills. 
Brush: Any and all shrubbery, tree limbs and branches no larger than four (4) inches in diameter and no longer than eight (8) feet in length. 
Domestic garbage: Ashes, garbage, refuse, large refuse items but excluding brush and landscape wastes. 
Dwelling unit: Any single-family dwelling or residence and each unit of a multifamily dwelling of three (3) units or less. 
Garbage: Wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food; wastes from the handling, storage and sale of products. 
Landscape waste: All accumulations of weeds, grass, thatch, shrubbery cuttings, shrubbery clippings, leaves and other materials accumulated as the result of the care of lawns, shrubbery, vines and trees but expressly excluding sod and any brush larger than one (1) inch in diameter or three (3) feet in length. 
Large refuse items: Shall include discarded water softener tanks, iceboxes, stoves, refrigerators, water heaters, furniture and furnishings, but shall exclude any building materials such as bricks, concrete blocks, structural iron, roofing materials or lumber. 
Refuse: Combustible trash, including but not limited to, paper, cartons, boxes, barrels, wood (excluding building lumber), excelsior, wood furniture, bedding; noncombustible trash, including but not limited to, metals, tin cans, metal furniture, small quantities of rock and pieces of concrete, glass, crockery and other mineral waste; the term shall not include earth and waste from building operations; building materials, such as bricks, concrete, concrete block, structural iron and roofing materials; nor shall it include solid waste resulting from industrial processes and manufacturing operations, such as food processing waste, boiler-house cinders, lumber, scraps and shavings; street rubbish, street sweepings, dirt, leaves or landscape waste. 
(Ord. No. 1454, § 2, 2-11-74; Ord. No. 2389, § 1, 12-11-89; Ord. No. 2427, § 1, 6-25-90)  
Sec. 10-102. - Disposal. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of any ashes, garbage or refuse (but excluding large refuse items) or material subject to decay except in a disposal device or container meeting specifications established by the village manager. It shall be unlawful for any person to place any landscape waste with domestic garbage for purposes of disposal, and all landscape waste shall be disposed of strictly in accordance with the specific regulations therefor provided in this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owners, tenants, licensees, operators or occupants of all multifamily dwellings in excess of three (3) units and any manufacturing, industrial, business or commercial establishment to place or allow garbage, refuse or ashes to remain in any disposal container which does not meet the specifications established by the village manager. 
(Ord. No. 1454, §§ 1, 3, 4, 7, 2-11-74; Ord. No. 2389, § 2, 12-11-89; Ord. No. 2427, § 2, 6-25-90)  
Sec. 10-103. - Vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful to deposit or permit to fall from any vehicle any domestic garbage, brush or landscape waste on any public street or alley in the village provided that this section shall not be construed to prohibit placing domestic garbage, brush or landscape waste in a container complying with the provisions of this article preparatory to having such material collected and disposed of in the manner provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 1454, § 5, 2-11-74; Ord. No. 2427, § 3, 6-25-90)  
Sec. 10-104. - Dumping on another's land. 
It shall be unlawful to dump or place any domestic garbage, landscape waste or brush on any premises or property in the village without the consent of the owner of such premises or property and then only in accordance with the provisions of this article; and it shall be unlawful to dump or place any domestic garbage, landscape waste or brush on any parkway, street, alley or property owned by the village except for the purpose of being picked up by a regularly scheduled scavenger service and then only in accordance with established ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1454, § 6, 2-11-74; Ord. No. 2427, § 4, 6-25-90)  
Sec. 10-105. - Rates for collection and disposal services. 
(a)  Commencing July 1, 2013 the rate for collection and disposal services for garbage, landscape waste, recyclables, white goods, waste tires and other special collections shall be those rates as established in the current contract between the village and the village's collection and disposal service contractor on file in the office of the village clerk. 
(b)  The base rate established in subsection (a) above, shall be increased by a monthly two dollar ($2.00) administrative fee and a monthly fifty cent ($0.50) recycling surcharge. 
(c)  The fees shall be added to each water bill of a dwelling unit as defined in this chapter and shall be multiplied by the number of months covered by that water bill. If a dwelling unit is not billed for water service, then the bill shall be established as if the dwelling unit did receive a water bill. 
(Ord. No. 1925, §§ 2, 4, 8-18-80; Ord. No. 2288, § 1, 5-23-88; Ord. No. 2349, § 1, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 2427, § 5, 6-25-90; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 5-6-91; Ord. No. 2583, § 1, 7-6-92; Ord. No. 3135, § 2, 6-17-02; Ord. No. 3304, § 2, 7-11-05; Ord. No. 3360, § 2, 6-19-06; Ord. No. 3428, § 2, 6-25-07; Ord. No. 3612, § 2, 6-14-10; Ord. No. 3767, § 1, 10-14-13; Ord No. 3911 , § 1, 4-25-16)  
ARTICLE II. - REGULATIONS GOVERNING THE DISPOSAL OF GARBAGE, ASHES AND REFUSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Nuisances, Ch. 15; nuisances enumerated, § 15-102(2), (16); changing lot elevation by using garbage or refuse, § 18-104(d). 
 
Sec. 10-201. - Utilization of scavenger service. 
Single-family dwellings and multifamily dwellings of three (3) units or less shall be required to utilize the regular garbage collection service provided by the village subject to the regulations contained in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2389, § 3, 12-11-89)  
Sec. 10-202. - Acceptable containers. 
(a)  All garbage, ashes and refuse shall not be set out on the parkway for purposes of collection except in an approved disposal device or container, the size of which shall be not greater than thirty-five (35) gallons, or in plastic garbage bags, not larger than thirty-five (35) gallons. 
(b)  Large refuse items need not be contained in any container; provided, however, that only one (1) large refuse item shall be disposed of per dwelling unit per week. 
(Ord. No. 2389, § 3, 12-11-89; Ord. No. 2427, § 6, 6-25-90)  
Sec. 10-203. - Placement on parkway. 
Domestic garbage and landscape waste as defined in this chapter shall not be placed or permitted to remain upon any parkway within the village for purposes of being picked up by a regularly scheduled scavenger service sooner than one (1) day before their regularly scheduled day for pickup, and any disposal device or container shall be removed from the parkway no later than one (1) day after the scheduled day for pickup. 
(Ord. No. 2389, § 3, 12-11-89; Ord. No. 2427, § 7, 6-25-90; Ord. No. 3083, § 2, 4-9-01)  
Sec. 10-204. - Enforcement. 
In addition to the penalties otherwise provided for herein, in the event that garbage or landscape waste or a disposal device or container is placed or permitted to remain upon the parkway for more than one (1) day or in the event that an owner or occupant not authorized to use village collection services places garbage or landscape waste on the parkway, the director of community development or his/her designee shall cause written notice to be served upon the property owner or occupant demanding that the garbage, landscape waste, disposal device or container be removed from the parkway within forty-eight (48) hours. Said notice shall also advise the owner or occupant that in the event that said garbage or landscape waste or device or container is not removed by the expiration of that time, the village will proceed to remove or cause the removal of said garbage or landscape waste or device or container immediately upon the expiration of the notice and surcharge the account of the owner or occupant for the cost of the removal together with a reasonable fee for processing. 
(Ord. No. 2389, § 3, 12-11-89; Ord. No. 2427, § 8, 6-25-90; Ord. No. 3083, § 3, 4-9-01)  
Sec. 10-205. - Regulations for brush removal. 
(a)  Collection. 
(1)  All brush, including thorny species and climbing vines, less than one (1) inch in diameter and three (3) feet in length shall be bundled and tied with string or placed in an authorized container for the disposal of landscape waste. 
(2)  Brush may be placed on the parkway not sooner than one (1) day prior to any regularly scheduled day for pickup. Brush shall be permitted to remain on the parkway for a period of two (2) days following the regularly scheduled day for pickup. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful to place on the parkway for disposal by regularly scheduled scavenger service any whole trees or any tree part resulting from the removal of a whole tree or any brush resulting from trimming by outside contractors. All brush larger than four (4) inches in diameter or longer than eight (8) feet in length is not eligible for collection by the village or its contractor but shall be removed by a private contractor retained at the property owner's or occupant's sole expense. 
(b)  Enforcement. In the event that brush is placed or remains on the parkway not in accordance with the provisions contained in this section or brush larger than four (4) inches in diameter or longer than eight (8) feet in length are placed on the parkway, the director of community development or his/her designee shall cause written notice to be served upon the property owner or occupant demanding that the aforesaid brush be removed from the parkway within forty-eight (48) hours. Said notice shall also advise the owner or occupant that in the event that said items are not removed by the expiration of that time, the village will proceed to remove or cause the removal of said items immediately upon the expiration of the notice and surcharge the account of the owner or occupant for the cost of the removal together with a reasonable fee for processing. 
(Ord. No. 2389, § 3, 12-11-89; Ord. No. 2427, § 9, 6-25-90)  
Sec. 10-206. - Regulations for landscape waste removal. 
(a)  All landscape waste shall be disposed of in kraft paper bags approved by the village containing the emblem of the village and the name Villa Park Disposal on said kraft paper bag. It shall be unlawful to place in such kraft paper bags any domestic garbage or brush larger than one (1) inch in diameter and three (3) feet in length. Brush smaller than one (1) inch in diameter and three (3) feet in length or less may be disposed of either in such kraft paper bags or pursuant to section 10-205. 
(b)  Landscape waste may be placed on the parkway not sooner than one (1) day prior to any regularly scheduled day for pickup. 
(Ord. No. 2427, § 10, 6-25-90) 
Editor's note— Former § 10-206 pertained to surcharge for removal, which provisions are now codified in § 10-207.  
Sec. 10-207. - Surcharge for removal. 
In addition to the penalties otherwise provided for herein, there shall be added to the regular charge for garbage collection service provided by section 10-105 a surcharge for removal as provided in either section 10-204 or subsection 10-205(b) of this article, which surcharge shall be equal to the actual cost of removal by the village or a private contractor together with a ten dollar ($10.00) fee for administrative expenses. The surcharge shall be in addition to the regularly charged fees for garbage collection service and shall appear as an addition to the regularly scheduled garbage collection fee. 
(Ord. No. 2389, § 3, 12-11-89; Ord. No. 2427, § 11, 6-25-90; Ord. No. 3083, § 4, 4-9-01) 
Editor's note— Former § 10-207 pertained to article interpretation, which provisions are now codified in § 10-208.  
Sec. 10-208. - Interpretation. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall be interpreted to the extent practicable, consistent with all other ordinances of the village, so as to give effect to the purposes of all ordinances; but, as to any inconsistency, this article shall supersede and take precedence. 
(b)  Whenever the regularly scheduled day for pickup falls on a holiday, the time period for the placement of garbage or other wastes and the time period for removal of disposal devices or containers, as provided in this article, shall be extended by an additional twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Ord. No. 2389, § 3, 12-11-89; Ord. No. 2427, § 12, 6-25-90; Ord. No. 3083, § 4, 4-9-01) 
Editor's note— Former § 10-208 pertained to article remedies, which provisions are now codified in § 10-209.  
Sec. 10-209. - Remedies. 
The remedies set forth in this article shall be cumulative to all other provisions concerning the removal of garbage, ashes or refuse, including those set forth in chapter 15 of the Villa Park Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 2389, § 3, 12-11-89; Ord. No. 2427, § 13, 6-25-90)  
Sec. 10-210. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3700, § 3, adopted May 21, 2012, deleted § 10-210, entitled "Penalty", which derived from: Ord. No. 3083, § 5, adopted Apr. 9, 2001.  
Chapter 11 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 

Footnotes:
