Sec. 11-101. - County authorized to enforce its food and beverage ordinances. 
The county health department is hereby authorized to enforce in the village, the provisions of the county ordinance regulating the sale and handling of food intended for human consumption, and of milk and milk products. No person shall violate such ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 642, 11-5-56) 
Cross reference— Food or beverage vending trucks, Ch. 13, Art. II.  
Sec. 11-102. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3463, § 2, adopted March 10, 2008, repealed § 11-102 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to smoking during public meetings prohibited as enacted by Ord. No. 2249, §§ 1—7, adopted July, 20, 1987.  
Sec. 11-103. - Smoking in public places prohibited. 
(a)  In accordance with the terms and provisions of the Smoke Free Illinois Act (410 ILCS 82/1 et seq.), as now existing or hereafter amended, which Act is adopted by reference herein, smoking in public places or places of employment within the Village is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited under this Section shall be fined in an amount that is not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). A person who owns, operates or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment that violates the provisions of this Section shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the first offense and not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each subsequent offense occurring within one (1) year from the date of the first offense. 
(Ord. No. 3453, § 2, 1-14-08)  
Chapter 13 - LICENSES, PERMITS AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Amusement license, Ch. 4, Art. II; coin-operated amusement games and similar devices, Ch. 4, Art. III; electronic game rooms, Ch. 4, Art. IV; bicycle license, Ch. 6, Art. II; peddling from parked vehicles, § 14-217; burglar alarm user permits, § 19-221 et seq.; land modification permits, § 19.5-103; solicitors, Ch. 20; retailers' occupation tax, Ch. 23, Art II; service occupation tax, Ch. 23, Art. III; use tax, Ch. 23, Art. IV; utility tax, Ch. 23, Art. V; tax on foreign fire insurance companies, Ch. 23, Art. VI; automobile renting occupation and use tax, Ch. 23, Art. VII; taxicabs, Ch. 24. 
State Law reference— Power of corporate authorities to set licensing procedures, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-1. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3789, §§ 1, 2, adopted Apr. 28, 2014, amended Art. I in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. I, § 13-101, pertained to garage sales, and derived from Ord. No. 1914, § 1, adopted June 16, 1980. 
 
DIVISION 1. - BUSINESS REGISTRATION 
 
Sec. 13-101. - Purpose. 
This division is adopted because each commercial establishment located in the village is a basic part of and affects the physical and economic well-being of the village necessitating special services to promote, protect and safeguard the public health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the village and to enable the creation of an accurate record of commercial establishments located and carrying on commercial activities or commerce within the village. 
(Ord. No. 3789, §§ 1, 2, 4-28-2014)  
Sec. 13-102. - Definitions. 
Business: For purposes of this chapter, the term "business" shall include any and all persons engaging in business. Businesses that operate from distinct spaces or buildings with separate addresses shall be deemed to be separate businesses regardless if such businesses are owned or operated by the same person. 
Educational, governmental, religious or political organizations and home-based businesses shall not be considered businesses for the purpose of registration but may register at their sole discretion. 
Place of business: The premises, main business location or an outlet, branch, or other location thereof, temporary or otherwise, to which the public is expressly or impliedly invited for the purpose of transacting of business. Unless a construction contractor has at least one (1) permanent location within the village, a place of business includes a construction site located therein. Place of business shall not include a business conducted at a personal residence or to an itinerant business that has sales that are of a transient nature not to exceed ten (10) days in the village in one (1) calendar year. 
Engaging in business: Means persons operating, conducting, doing, carrying on, causing to be carried on or pursuing any business, profession, occupation, trade, pursuit or activity for the purpose of profit. 
(Ord. No. 3789, §§ 1, 2, 4-28-2014)  
Sec. 13-103. - Registration required. 
(a)  Every place of business, whether or not subject to any other licensing requirements of the village, shall be annually registered with the village as required in this division. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any business at a place of business in the village without obtaining registration. 
(c)  A place of business must be registered prior to the issuance of any occupancy permit for that place of business or request for village services. 
(d)  No registration shall be issued to a place of business that does not comply with the Villa Park Zoning Ordinance. 
(e)  No registration shall be issued whose business owners or owners of the place of business are indebted to the village. 
(Ord. No. 3789, §§ 1, 2, 4-28-2014)  
Sec. 13-104. - Application for registration. 
(a)  All places of business shall be registered with the village no later than December 31 of each year or at such times as the business desires to commence operation at its place of business in the village. 
(b)  Registration forms shall be available on the village website, in Village Hall and from the fire department and departments of community and economic development. Such forms shall include the business name, business address, business phone, business fax, business email, the business owner and manager(s), if operated by manager, with their address and phone number,, the type of business, the square footage of the place of business, the emergency contact person(s) of the business and that person's address and phone number, the building owner's name, address, phone, email and the name(s) of the building owner's emergency contact person(s) and that person's address and phone number, and the number of the certificate of registration issued pursuant to the Retailer's Occupation Tax Act (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1), the Service Occupation Tax Act (65 ILCS 5/8-11-5), and/or the Use Tax Act (65 ILCS 5/8-11-6), if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 3789, §§ 1, 2, 4-28-2014)  
Sec. 13-105. - Services and assistance to registered businesses. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a completed application, the village's fire department in conjunction with the village's community development and police departments shall attempt to provide during the registration year not less than one inspection of the place of business for compliance with the village's fire safety, property maintenance, and health, safety and welfare regulations as adopted in the Villa Park Municipal Code. 
(b)  Each registered business shall also receive such additional information and village services from the village's economic development director for the support and development of each registered business to develop that business into a stronger component of the village's business community. 
(c)  Information received from each business shall also be used as part of the notification system for any emergencies regarding that place of business or business. 
(Ord. No. 3789, §§ 1, 2, 4-28-2014)  
Sec. 13-106. - Transfer of registration. 
Registration is not transferable to a new business owner, a new location or a new business. A new business occupying a place of business that is currently registered shall obtain a new registration for that place of business. 
(Ord. No. 3789, §§ 1, 2, 4-28-2014)  
Sec. 13-107. - Changes to registration. 
If at any time during the term of any registration the information filed with the village for the registration changes, the applicant shall provide the updated or revised information to the department of community development within twenty-one (21) days of such change. 
(Ord. No. 3789, §§ 1, 2, 4-28-2014)  
Sec. 13-108. - Registration to be posted. 
When a registration certificate is issued to a business owner, the business owner shall post and keep posted the registration in a conspicuous public location upon the place of business within five (5) days of its receipt. 
(Ord. No. 3789, §§ 1, 2, 4-28-2014)  
Secs. 13-109—13-119. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BUSINESS REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 13-120. - Garage sales. 
Garage sales or sales otherwise similarly named, wherein personal property, or privately owned merchandise is placed on sale to the public, shall be limited to two (2) sales per year per residence. The length of time of such sale shall be limited to three (3) days. No fee shall be required to conduct such sale. Posting of such signs advertising such sale shall be limited to the property upon which the sale is being held. 
(Ord. No. 3789, §§ 1, 2, 4-28-2014)  
ARTICLE II. - FOOD OR BEVERAGE VENDING TRUCKS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Applicability of county health ordinances, § 11-101. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 13-201. - Traffic regulations. 
No person conducting a business from a vehicle on the public roads, streets and highways within the village shall sell any food or beverage from said vehicles less than fifty (50) feet from the nearest intersecting road, street or highway. 
(Ord. No. 1641, § 2, 4-19-76)  
Sec. 13-202. - Hours of operation. 
Food or beverages shall be sold from vehicles on the public roads, streets, and highways only during the hours from 11:00 a.m. to sundown daily. 
(Ord. No. 1641, § 2, 4-19-76)  
Sec. 13-203. - Vehicle specifications. 
Any vehicle used for the sale of food and beverage upon public roads, streets and highways shall possess the following equipment which shall be in good working order and in operation at the time which the sales are taking place. 
(1)  A sign on the front and back of the vehicle which shall consist of letters no less than five (5) inches in height and shall state "CAUTION, CHILDREN CROSSING." 
(2)  A foldout diamond-shaped sign on the left side of the vehicle which shall consist of letters no less than five (5) inches in height and shall state "SLOW." 
(3)  Two (2) amber lights eight (8) inches in diameter mounted both on front and back of the vehicle capable of flashing alternately and be seen at a distance of five hundred (500) feet in normal daylight. 
(Ord. No. 1641, § 2, 4-19-76)  
Sec. 13-204. - Chimes. 
The operator of a food or beverage vending truck shall turn off any monotonous, attention-getting chimes or tunes while waiting for or making a sale and may use same only when the vehicle is in motion. 
(Ord. No. 1641, § 2, 4-19-76)  
Sec. 13-205. - Health regulations. 
(a)  All ice cream or milk vending trucks shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be thoroughly cleaned at the end of each day of use. 
(b)  The operator of a food or beverage vending truck shall comply with all requirements of the county health department. 
(Ord. No. 541, § 4, 3-21-49; Ord. No. 1641, § 2, 4-19-76)  
Sec. 13-206. - Inspections. 
The village manager shall cause such inspections to be made as will insure compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 541, § 5, 3-21-49)  
Secs. 13-207—13-220. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE FOR MILK OR ICE CREAM VENDING TRUCKS 
 
Sec. 13-221. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use or permit the use of any ice cream or milk vending truck without a license issued by the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 541, § 1, 3-21-49)  
Sec. 13-222. - Application. 
A person desiring the license required by the provisions of this division shall apply to the village clerk upon a form furnished by the clerk giving the information required on the form. 
(Ord. No. 541, § 2, 3-21-49)  
Sec. 13-223. - Fee. 
A person desiring the issuance or renewal of the license required by the provisions of this division shall pay a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 541, § 2, 3-21-49) 
State Law reference— Power of municipality to set license fee, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-60-1.  
Sec. 13-224. - Expiration. 
The license required by the provisions of this division shall expire at the end of one year. 
(Ord. No. 541, § 2, 3-21-49)  
Sec. 13-225. - Revocation. 
The board of trustees may revoke any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this division for any violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 541, § 6, 3-21-49)  
ARTICLE IV. - VENDING MACHINES[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2028, § 2, adopted March 22, 1982, has been treated as amendatory of Art. IV, relative to vending machines, and codified as herein set out in Div. 1, § 13-401 and Div. 2, §§ 13-416—13-420, at the discretion of the editor. Prior to amendment Art. IV contained §§ 13-401, 13-402 and 13-416—13-423 and derived from Ord. No. 1076, §§ 2—12, adopted Aug. 25, 1975 and Ord. No. 1612, §§ 1—5, adopted Dec. 22, 1975. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 13-401. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise provided by this section, words and phrases shall have their commonly understood meaning: 
Proprietor means any person, corporation, partnership or association who, as owner or lessee, places or displays a vending machine. 
Vending machine means any machine or device which upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disk dispenses a product(s), commodity or item(s) of personal property and any machine where the operator of the device pays or gives consideration for the privilege of using the machine. "Vending machine" as used in this article shall not mean "coin-operated amusement devices" as defined in Article III, section 4-301, stamp machines in United States Post Offices, or coin-changing machines for no profit. 
(Ord. No. 2028k, § 2(1), 3-22-82)  
Secs. 13-402—13-415. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 13-416. - Required. 
No proprietor shall display a vending machine for operation by the public generally without having first obtained a vending machine license. 
(Ord. No. 2028, § 2(2), 3-22-82)  
Sec. 13-417. - Applications. 
(a)  Applications for vending machine licenses shall be in writing, under oath or affirmation and upon a form provided by the village. 
(b)  The applicant shall provide the following information: 
(1)  Name of applicant; 
(2)  Address of applicant; 
(3)  Description of vending machine(s); 
(4)  Proposed location of vending machine(s); 
(5)  Name of person or corporation who will service the vending machine(s); 
(6)  Address of person or corporation who will service the vending machine(s); 
(7)  Phone number of person or corporation who will service the vending machine(s); 
(8)  No prior vending machine license issued to the applicant has been revoked by the village. 
(c)  The application fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) shall accompany each application. 
(Ord. No. 2028, § 2(3), 3-22-82; Ord. No. 3385, § 6, 9-18-06)  
Sec. 13-418. - License fees. 
(a)  The annual fee per machine for vending machines shall be determined by the price each machine charges for the commodity involved and shall be as follows per machine: 
Price of commodity 
(in cents) 	License fee 
$0.01—0.05 	$15.00 
0.06—0.24 	20.00 
0.25—0.49 	25.00 
0.50 and up 	30.00 
 
The licensee under any license issued pursuant to this section that expires on June 1, 2007 shall pay a renewal fee equal to eleven-twelfths ( 11/12 ) of the amount due under this section for the period ending April 14, 2008. Thereafter, on or before each April 15, each such licensee shall pay the full amount due hereunder. 
(b)  The license shall be issued annually effective on April 15 and expiring on April 14 each year. 
(c)  For those proprietors owners and operators not using a machine on or before the 14 th day of October each year, but who acquire and use a machine on or after October 15 th of each year, the annual fee per machine shall be one-half (½) of the fees set forth in subsection (a) above. 
(d)  In the event any license fee established herein has not been paid to the village prior to May 1, a late fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or twenty-five (25) percent of the fee due, whichever amount is greater, shall be paid. 
(Ord. No. 2028, § 2(6), 3-22-82; Ord. No. 2113, § 1, 6-4-84; Ord. No. 3385, § 7, 9-18-06)  
Sec. 13-419. - Granting or denial of a license. 
(a)  The village manager, or his designee, shall grant or deny in writing the application for a vending machine license. 
(b)  The basis for denial of a vending machine license shall be: 
(1)  Application for the license is incomplete; 
(2)  A false statement of a material fact has been made in the application for the license; or 
(3)  A prior vending machine license granted under this ordinance to the applicant has been revoked. 
(Ord. No. 2028, § 2(4), 3-22-82)  
Sec. 13-420. - Appeal of denial. 
(a)  An applicant shall have the right to appeal the denial of a vending machine license to the corporate authorities. The right to a review of a denial is waived unless exercised within thirty (30) days of the denial. 
(b)  The right to appeal shall be exercised by filing a notice of review on a form provided by the village with the office of the village clerk. The date of filing if filed by mail shall be the date which the notice was mailed as evidenced by the postage mark of the United States Postal Service. 
(c)  The hearing before the corporate authorities shall be in the same manner as other administrative hearings. The person requesting the review shall have the burden of proving he was wrongfully denied a license. 
(d)  The decision of the corporate authorities shall be reviewable in the Circuit Court, 18th Judicial Circuit, pursuant to the Administrative Review Act, Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 110, Paragraph 264 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2028, § 2(5), 3-22-82)  
Sec. 13-421. - Revocation. 
(a)  A license may be revoked by the village manager. After notice of revocation hearing and a revocation hearing has been held, based upon: 
(1)  Allowing minors to purchase products the sale of which is a violation of the Illinois Revised Statutes; 
(2)  Knowingly failing to maintain a licensed vending machine; or 
(3)  Making a false statement of a material fact on a vending machine license application. 
(b)  Review of the revocation of a vending machine license shall be provided in accordance with section 13-419. 
(Ord. No. 2028, § 2(7), 3-22-82)  
ARTICLE V. - RAFFLES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2018, enacted Jan. 25, 1982, did not expressly amend the Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1—8 as herein set out in §§ 13-501—13-508 was at the editor's discretion. 
State Law reference— Licensing of raffles, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 85, § 2301 et seq. 
 
Sec. 13-501. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article the terms defined in this section have the meanings given them. 
Net proceeds means the gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less reasonable sums expended for prizes, local license fees and other reasonable operating expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle. 
Raffle means a form of lottery, as defined in Section 28-2(b) of the "Criminal Code of 1961," conducted by an organization licensed under this article, in which 
(1)  The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance, represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or by some other medium, one or more of which chances is to be designated the winning chance; 
(2)  The winning change is to be determined through a drawing or by some other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part of persons conducting or connected with the lottery, except that the winning chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting contest. 
(Ord. No. 2018, § 1, 1-25-82)  
Sec. 13-502. - Organizations eligible for license. 
(a)  Licenses shall be issued only to bona fide religious, charitable, labor, fraternal, educational or veterans' organizations that operate without profit to their members and which have been in existence continuously for a period of five (5) years immediately before making application for a license and which have had during that entire five-year period a bona fide membership engaged in carrying out their objects. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the following definitions apply. 
(1)  Nonprofit: An organization or institution organized and conducted on a non-for-profit basis with no personal profit inuring to anyone as a result of the operation. 
(2)  Charitable: An organization or institution organized and operated to benefit an indefinite number of the public. The service rendered to those eligible for benefits must also confer some benefit on the public. 
(3)  Educational: An organization or institution organized and operated to provide systematic instruction in useful branches of learning by methods common to schools and institutions of learning which compare favorable in their scope and intensity with the course of study presented in tax-supported schools. 
(4)  Religious: Any church, congregation, society, or organization founded for the purpose of religious worship. 
(5)  Fraternal: An organization of persons having a common interest, the primary interest of which is to both promote the welfare of its members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to lessen the burdens of government by caring for those that otherwise would be cared for by the government. 
(6)  Veterans': An organization or association comprised of members of which substantially all are individuals who are veterans, or spouses, widows, or widowers of veterans, the primary purpose of which is to promote the welfare of its members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to confer a public benefit. 
(7)  Labor: An organization composed of workers organized with the objective of betterment of the conditions of those engaged in such pursuit and the development of a higher degree of efficiency in their respective occupations. 
(Ord. No. 2018, § 2, 1-25-82)  
Sec. 13-503. - License required; applications; issuance; restrictions; persons ineligible. 
Licenses issued by the village are subject to the following restrictions. 
(1)  No person, firm or corporation shall conduct raffles or chances without having first obtained a license therefor pursuant to this article. 
(2)  The license and application for license must specify the area or areas within the licensing authority in which raffle chances will be sole or issued, the time period (calendar dates) during which raffle chances will be sold or issued, the time of determination (calendar dates) of winning chances and the location or locations at which winning chances will be determined. 
(3)  The license application must contain a sworn statement attesting to the non-for-profit character of the prospective licensee organization, signed by the presiding officer and the secretary of that organization. 
(4)  A license authorizes the licensee to conduct raffles as defined in this article. Each such license shall be ten dollars ($10.00) and shall be valid for one raffle. 
(5)  The following are ineligible for any license under this article: 
a.  Any person who has been convicted of a felony; 
b.  Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling promoter; 
c.  Any person who is not of good moral character; 
d.  Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in a., b., or c. has a proprietary, equitable or credit interest, or in which such a person is active or employed; 
e.  Any organization in which a person defined in a., b., or c. is an officer, director or employee, whether compensated or not; 
f.  An organization in which a person defined in a., b., or c. is to participate in the management or operation of a raffle as defined in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2018, § 3, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3962 , §, 3-13-17)  
Sec. 13-504. - Issuance of license to qualified applicants. 
The village manager shall issue a raffle license to all qualified applicants. 
(Ord. No. 2018, § 8, 1-25-82)  
Sec. 13-505. - Conduct of raffles. 
The conduct of raffles is subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that game. 
(2)  No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may participate in the management or operation of the raffle. 
(3)  No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in the management or operation of the raffle. 
(4)  A licensee may rent a premises on which to determine the winning chance or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed under this article. 
(5)  Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified on the license and winning chances may be determined only at those locations specified on the license. 
(6)  No person under the age of eighteen (18) years may participate in the conducting of raffles or chances. A person under the age of eighteen (18) years may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when accompanied by his parent or guardian. 
(Ord. No. 2018, § 4, 1-25-82)  
Sec. 13-505.1. - Limitations. 
(a)  The maximum aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise awarded in a single raffle shall be one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) unless the applicant follows the procedure as established in paragraph (e). 
(b)  The maximum retail value of each prize awarded by a licensee in a single raffle shall be one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) unless the applicant follows the procedure as established in paragraph (e). 
(c)  The maximum price which may be charged for each raffle chance issued or sold shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(d)  The maximum number of days during which chances may be issued or sold for any raffle shall be three hundred sixty-four (364) days. 
(e)  Any applicant requesting a license for a raffle in which the maximum retail value of all prizes or the maximum retail value of each individual prize will exceed one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.000) must receive prior approval of the village board of trustees. The application will be placed on the meeting agenda for action by the board of trustees prior to the issuance of said license. 
(Ord. No. 3109, § 2, 12-17-01)  
Sec. 13-506. - Raffles manager, bond. 
(a)  All operation of and the conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of a single raffles manager designated by the organization. The manager shall give a fidelity bond in the sum of an amount determined by the licensing authority in favor of the organization conditioned upon his honesty in the performance of his duties. Terms of the bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing to the licensing authority not less than thirty (30) days prior to its cancellation. 
(b)  The village may waive this bond requirement by including a waiver provision in the license issued to an organization under this article, provided that a license containing such waiver provision shall be granted only by unanimous vote of the members of the licensed organization. 
(Ord. No. 2018, § 5, 1-25-82)  
Sec. 13-507. - Records. 
(a)  Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deductions from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the purchased item or service or other reason for the deduction, and the recipient. The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee, purpose, amount and date of payment. 
(b)  Gross receipts from the operation of raffles programs shall be segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization pursuant to license therefor issued by the Department of Revenue of the State of Illinois, and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have separate records of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same person who accounts for other revenues of the organization. 
(c)  Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall report monthly to its membership, and to the village, its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from raffles, and the distribution of net proceeds itemized as required in this section. 
(d)  Records required by this section shall be preserved for three (3) years, and organizations shall make available their records relating to operation of raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places. 
(Ord. No. 2018, § 6, 1-25-82)  
Sec. 13-508. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3700, § 3, adopted May 21, 2012, deleted § 13-508, entitled "Penalty", which derived from: Ord. No. 2018, § 7, adopted Jan. 25, 1982.  
ARTICLE VI. - MASSAGE BUSINESS LICENSING 
 
Sec. 13-601. - Permit required. 
No person, individual, firm, corporation, association, partnership or any other organization, entity or group, including schools for massage therapy, shall engage in the practice of massage without first obtaining a valid massage business license, and in addition, an individual massage practitioner permit for each and every person who has been, is engaged, or will engage in the business or profession of massage therapy. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 3, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 2, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-602. - Zoning districts in which massage therapy clinics shall be allowed. 
Massage businesses shall only be located in such districts as permitted by the village zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 4, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 2, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-603. - Compliance with village codes. 
Massage businesses shall comply with all applicable codes, ordinances and regulations of the Village of Villa Park. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 6, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 2, 1-21-02)

(Ord. No. 2225, § 7, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 2273, § 2, 3-14-88; Ord. No. 3112, §§ 5, 6, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-605.1. - Approval of original license application and approval of renewal licenses. 
All original applications for a massage business license shall be approved by a majority of a quorum of the president and board of trustees, and the license shall be signed and issued by the village manager on behalf of the Village of Villa Park following such approval. All original applications for individual massage practitioner permit shall be approved by the village manager on behalf of the Village of Villa Park. Renewals of all licenses and permits shall be made and issued by the village manager on behalf of the Village of Villa Park on an annual basis. 
(Ord. No. 2273, § 3, 3-14-88; Ord. No. 3112, § 7, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-606. - License and permit fees, renewal and transferability. 
All massage related licenses and permits shall be issued on an annual basis and shall expire on December 31 and shall be non-transferable. Application fees shall be payable only upon the initial application and not as a renewal, unless the applicant has had such license or permit previously suspended or revoked. Renewal license fees shall be payable six (6) weeks in advance of license or permit expiration. The initial license or permit fee shall be prorated on a quarterly basis upon in which yearly quarter the initial license or permit has been obtained. Fees paid shall be nonrefundable. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 8, 3-16-87)  
Sec. 13-607. - Inspections. 
Village enforcement authorities shall have the right to inspect the premises of a massage business during business hours for the purposes of determining compliance with this article or any other code or ordinance of the village, in the valid exercise of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 9, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-608. - Suspension or revocations. 
Any massage license or permit issued hereunder may be suspended or revoked, upon good cause shown, at the discretion of the village board, after due notice and public hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 10, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-609. - Display of license and, or permits. 
Every massage business license and massage practitioner permit granted shall be displayed in a conspicuous place where it may readily be observed by persons entering the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 11, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-610. - Nontransferability. 
Any massage business license issued hereunder shall be valid only at the location specified upon the initial application and shall be nontransferable. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 12, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-611. - Compliance with village codes; facilities necessary. 
No massage business license shall be issued unless such establishment complies with applicable village codes and ordinances as to: 
(1)  Building, including lighting and ventilation. 
(2)  Fire and fire safety. 
(3)  Health and sanitation. 
(4)  Safety. 
(5)  Signage. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 13, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-612. - Hours of operation. 
No massage business shall be open to the public for business between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 14, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-613. - Unlawful activities. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to massage or administer massage for any illegal purposes: i.e., in any manner calculated to arouse, appeal or gratify sexual desires, lust or to engage in prurient contact with the genitalia of any person, for any consideration of any kind. Violation hereof shall constitute grounds for revocation of any license or permit issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 15, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-614. - Uniforms. 
Massage practitioners shall wear nontransparent uniforms or garments covering the torso and genitalia while attending patrons. Such garments shall be clean and kept in a sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 16, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-615. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
No person on the premises of any massage business shall sell, dispense, provide, give, keep or cause to be sold, dispensed, provided, given or kept, any alcoholic beverage. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 17, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-616. - Tipping. 
Massage practitioners shall not solicit tips or gratuities and "tipping" shall not be encouraged. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 18, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-617. - Minor patrons. 
Patrons under eighteen (18) years of age, shall be accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 19, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-618. - Dressing rooms. 
Dressing room facilities shall be provided, to be used separately by each sex, including separate bathing facilities, if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 20, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-619. - Genital areas of patrons. 
Genital areas of patrons must be covered while in the presence of a massage practitioner or employee and it shall be unlawful for any patron to expose their genitalia to a massage practitioner or employee for any prurient purpose. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 21, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-620. - Linens. 
All massage businesses shall have on hand at all times a sufficient quantity of clean, laundered linens, as sheets and towels and similar, in sufficient quantity, which shall be changed after each use by a patron. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 22, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-621. - Massage therapist or technician handwashing. 
Each massage practitioner shall wash their hands in hot running water with soap or disinfectant before administering massage therapy to each patron. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 23, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-622. - Cleanliness of supplementary aids. 
Any and all supplementary aids or devices shall be suitably washed and/or disinfected before and between each use by a patron. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 24, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-623. - Application of regulation to pre-existing business. 
Provisions of this article shall be applicable to all massage businesses, schools and individuals, engaged in the practice thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 25, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 3112, § 8, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 13-624. - Exemptions. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Licensed medical doctors, doctors of osteopathic medicine, chiropractors or licensed physical therapists. 
(2)  Licensed nurses or nursing homes which administer such massages in the normal course of their medical duties. 
(3)  Any physical trainer of any duly constituted athletic team who administers such athletic-related massage in the normal course of training duties. 
(4)  Any licensed barber or beautician who administers a massage in the normal course of his or her duties. 
(Ord. No. 2225, § 26, 3-16-87)  
Secs. 13-625—13-700. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - FILMING AND VIDEOTAPING REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 13-701. - Purpose and intent. 
The intent of this article is to provide regulations governing the filming and/or taping of certain television shows, commercials, feature films and/or video tapes, movie productions and other related activities within the corporate limits of the Village of Villa Park, including the use in such productions of the streets, rights-of-way, equipment and personnel of the village. 
(Ord. No. 2654, § 1, 8-16-93)  
Sec. 13-702. - Village approval required. 
Except as otherwise provided herein, no person, firm, individual, corporation, association, partnership, or any other organization, entity or group, shall engage in the production of feature films, television shows, commercials, or other commercial filming, taping, or videotaping without first obtaining the approval of the village as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2654, § 1, 8-16-93)  
Sec. 13-703. - General requirements. 
(a)  Application. Prior to commencement of any filming activities, the producer, his representative, or an agent for the production company, shall submit to the village manager or his designee, an application for commercial filming or taping in a form prescribed by village manager or his designee and approved by the village attorney. Included within the application shall be a proposed "Notice to Affected Property Owners," as set forth in subparagraph (b) of this section. In addition, applicants shall submit such other information as may be requested by the village manager. The producer or his representative shall sign the application. 
Upon approval of the application, the producer shall enter into such agreements with the village as determined necessary by the village manager and village attorney. Any such agreement must be signed by the village manager or his designee prior to any production activity taking place, and a signed copy will be returned to the producer or his representative. 
Authorization shall be granted for a specific period of time and the hours of production shall be designated on the approval, giving due consideration to the requirements of the production. 
Any producer or production company intending to commence filming or taping within the corporate limits of the Village of Villa Park, shall be required to complete and return such informational forms as may be reasonably requested by the village, whether as part of the application submitted or at any other time. 
(b)  Notice to affected property owners. Prior to commencement of production, and at a time set by the village, the producer shall circulate a notice to all property owners in the area of production as defined by the village's representative. Such notice shall include a short description of the proposed project and the filming or taping schedule. A copy of the notice shall be reviewed by the village prior to circulation. The producer shall record any reaction from residents and shall submit a report to the village manager or his designee noting any residents' reactions, along with a list of the addresses and phone numbers of all property owners within the affected area. This completed report must be delivered to the office of the village manager not less than five (5) days prior to the commencement of the production. 
(c)  On-site location coordinator. For the duration of the production, the producer shall provide a permanent on-site location coordinator who shall act as liaison between the production company, the village, property owner(s) and village residents. The on-site location coordinator shall be available at the location during the filming period. The producer shall provide the following information regarding the on-site location coordinator: 
(1)  Name 
(2)  Title 
(3)  On—Site Location Phone 
(4)  Office Phone 
(5)  Beeper Number 
(d)  Security. The applicant shall contact the Villa Park Police Department as soon as filming locations and schedules are known. The village will review all plans for production and advise the applicant of the extent of the security that must be provided. All traffic protection and devices (signs, barricades, etc.) shall be provided by the applicant. 
(e)  Use of village personnel/equipment. The producer shall pay for the costs of any police, fire, public works, or other village personnel assigned to the project (whether specifically requested by the producer or not) at a rate equal to the salary and benefits paid to the individual employee by the village, including overtime pay as necessary. Remuneration rates for the use of any village equipment shall be established on a case-by-case basis, giving due consideration to the nature of the vehicle, cost of the vehicle, the proposed use of the vehicle, comparable schedules for vehicle usage adopted by any other public agency, and the useful life of the vehicle. 
(f)  Use of village property. Producer shall pay a fee for inconvenience caused by use of public property in accordance with the following rate schedule: 
Disruptive use 	$500.00 per day 
Nondisruptive use 	$250.00 per day 
Total closure of a public street or right-of-way 	$50.00 per hour 
Partial closure or obstruction of public street or right-of-way 	$25.00 per hour 
 
The above fees shall be paid upon the conclusion of production. Based upon the schedule submitted by the producer at the time of application, the village may require a deposit against costs and expenses anticipated to become due to the village. If it appears that damage to property, public streets, or rights-of-way may occur, producer shall make a deposit in an amount equal to one and one-half (1½) times the anticipated cost of restoration. Upon completion of the restoration and determination of actual cost, any excess restoration deposit shall be returned to the producer. In the event of any deficiency in the deposit, the corporate authorities shall submit an invoice to the producer and producer shall pay same within thirty (30) days. 
(g)  Alterations to property. Upon completion of the production, producer shall restore any and all property of the village to its original condition, unless the corporate authorities have previously agreed to allow any alteration to the property to remain. 
(h)  Control of hours and locations; inspections, etc. 
(1)  The village reserves the right or shall have the right to regulate the hours and general locations of filming and taping to the extent necessary to preserve the health, safety and welfare of the community. Normal operating hours for movie production shall be between 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. and filming during other than such normal operating hours shall be so controlled so as not to cause a nuisance. The village shall at all times have the authority to determine the extent of use of public streets, rights-of-way, and public property owned by the village, and general location of the film production activities. 
(2)  Producer shall advise the village manager or his designee of any potential for extraordinary noise, smoke, light, vibrations, etc., that may occur during the production and the times when such will occur. The village may request the producer to provide special notice to affected property owners in the vicinity of the production regarding the anticipated potential for any extraordinary noise, smoke, light, vibrations, etc. 
(3)  The village shall have the right to inspect any location to be used for filming or taping, to inspect all structures and/or devices and equipment to be used in connection with the filming or taping, and the producer or production company shall fully and completely cooperate with the village in granting access at all reasonable times for purposes of inspection. 
(i)  Parking of production vehicles. Adequate arrangements shall be made for off-street parking of production vehicles not utilized during actual filming or taping, and there shall be no parking on village streets between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. unless permission is received from the office of the village manager. Should street parking that interferes with vehicular traffic be necessary for the production, the village shall be entitled to the fees in subparagraph (f) above. 
(j)  Insurance. The producer shall secure a policy or policies of insurance, naming the Village of Villa Park, its corporate authorities, elected officials, officers, boards, commissions, attorneys, employees and agents as additional insured with respect to any and all claims which arise out of, or are in any way related to, the operations of the film maker in filming, taping, production, or movie production, while present within the corporate limits of the Village of Villa Park, such policies to be in the following amounts and coverages: one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit and two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) aggregate general liability, including bodily injury and property damage; and automobile liability, including bodily injury and property damage. The producer shall provide a certificate of insurance evidencing that the village has been named as an additional insured on the appropriate policies of insurance, and no production activity shall take place until the certificate of insurance is provided. Upon request by the village, the producer shall furnish copies of the actual endorsement. 
(k)  Indemnification. The producer shall sign an indemnification and hold harmless agreement in substantially the following form: 
To the fullest extent permitted by law, the producer hereby agrees to defend, indemnify and hold harmless the Village of Villa Park, its officials, agents and employees, against all injuries, deaths, loss, damages, claims, patent claims, suits, liabilities, judgments, cost and expenses, which may in anywise accrue against the municipality, its officials, agents and employees, arising in whole or in part or in consequence of the performance of this work by producer, its employees, or subcontractors, or which may in anywise result therefrom, except that arising out of the sole legal cause of the municipality, its agents or employees, the producer shall, at its own expense, appear, defend and pay all charges of attorneys and all costs and other expenses arising therefrom or incurred in connections therewith, and, if any judgment shall be rendered against the municipality, its officials, agents and employees, in any such action, the producer shall, at its own expense, satisfy and discharge the same. The person signing below further certifies that he or she is authorized on behalf of the producer to execute this agreement and bind the producer to the agreement. 
The agreement shall be executed by the village manager on behalf of the village. 
(l)  Liability. The producer shall pay all fees assessed by the village and shall reimburse the village for all costs and expenses incurred by the village related to any filming or taping activity undertaken by the applicant. The producer shall pay in full, promptly upon receipt of an invoice, the costs of repair for any and all damage to public or private property resulting from or occurring in connection with the production and restore the property to its condition prior to the production. 
(Ord. No. 2654, § 1, 8-16-93)  
Sec. 13-704. - Applicability. 
The provisions set forth in this article shall not apply to the following types of filming or videotaping: 
(a)  Any filming or videotaping undertaken solely for personal use and not intended as part of any commercial enterprise for future viewing on a fee basis or for resale to the general public, or for broadcast to the general public, including but not limited to filming and videotaping of weddings, sporting events, musical events, educational films, or instructional films. 
(b)  Videotaping of newscasts and any similar filming or videotaping not intended for resale to the general public and not intended for viewing on a fee basis, but which may be broadcast by network or cable television to the general public as part of any regularly scheduled or special news program. 
(c)  Any filming or videotaping for commercial purposes of any commercial, educational video, instructional video, music video, television show, movie, film, etc., involving a production crew of ten (10) people or less, except when such filming or videotaping involves the use of public streets or rights-of-way, or village property (real or personal), or village personnel, or village equipment. Whenever such film or videotape involves the use of public streets or rights-of-way, or village property (real or personal), or village personnel, or village equipment, then the provisions of this article shall apply. Whenever any production claimed exempt under this subsection occurs in a residential zoning district, the producer shall notify the village not less than three (3) business days in advance of the filming or taping. In addition, the producer or filmmaker shall also timely notify the residents in the affected area on a form approved by the village of the date filming is to commence. 
(Ord. No. 2654, § 1, 8-16-93)  
ARTICLE VIII. - PAWNBROKERS 
 
Sec. 13-801. - Pawnbroker defined. 
Every person or company engaged in the business of receiving property in pledge or as security for money or other thing advanced to the pawner or pledger shall be held and is hereby declared and defined to be a pawnbroker. 
(Ord. No. 2831, § 2, 6-24-96)  
Sec. 13-802. - License required; license fee. 
No person, firm or corporation shall conduct or operate the business of pawnbroker without having a valid license therefor, as hereinafter provided. The annual fee for a pawnbroker's license shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 2831, § 2, 6-24-96)  
Sec. 13-803. - Application for license. 
(a)  An application for any license provided for in this article shall be made to the village manager, in writing, signed by the applicant if an individual, by all the partners of a partnership, or by a duly authorized agent thereof if a club or corporation, and verified by oath or affidavit, and filed with the village clerk. Such application shall contain the following statements and information: 
(1)  The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an individual; in the case of a partnership, the persons entitled to share in the profits thereof, in the case of a corporation, the names and addresses of the officers and directors, and if a majority interest of the stock of such corporation is owned by one (1) person or his nominee, the name and address of such person. 
(2)  The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth, and if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization. 
(3)  The character of business of the applicant, and in the case of a corporation, the objects for which it was formed as set forth in the corporate charter. 
(4)  The length of time said applicant has been in business, or in the case of a corporation, the date when its charter was issued. 
(5)  The amount of goods, wares, and merchandise on hand at the time application is made. 
(6)  The location and description of the premises or place of business which is to be operated under such license. 
(7)  A statement whether applicant has made application for a similar or other license on premises other than described in this application, and the disposition of such application. 
(8)  A statement that applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing contained in any ordinance or state law. 
(9)  Whether a previous pawnbroker license issued by any state or subdivision thereof has been revoked and the reasons therefor. 
(10)  A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the state or of the United States, or any ordinance of the village, in the conduct of his place of business. 
(11)  Such other statements and information as may be required on such form. 
(b)  When any applicant for license is a corporation, said application shall be signed by the president and secretary thereof, and should the applicant be a partnership, then each and every member of the partnership including silent or limited partners, if any, shall sign such application. 
(c)  In each instance where business is being conducted by a manager or agent, such person or persons must comply with the applicable provisions of this section. 
(d)  The chief of police shall investigate any applicant for a pawnbroker's license and shall file a report with the village manager prior to the issuance of any such license. 
(e)  All licenses shall expire on December 31 of each year. 
(f)  Any person holding a valid pawnbroker license issued by the village shall not be required to obtain a secondhand goods dealer license. 
(Ord. No. 2831, § 2, 6-24-96; Ord. No. 3675, § 2.1, 11-14-11)  
Sec. 13-804. - Signed memorandum, contract or note. 
Every pawnbroker shall, at the time of making any advancement or loan, deliver to the person pawning or pledging any property a memorandum, contract, or note signed by him containing an accurate account and description, in the English language, of all the goods, articles or other things pawned or pledged, the amount of money, value of things loaned thereon, the time of pledging the same, the rate of interest to be paid on the loan, the name and residence of the person making the pawn or pledge, and the amount of any fees. 
(Ord. No. 2831, § 2, 6-24-96)  
Sec. 13-805. - Records required to be kept—Identification required. 
(a)  Every pawn and loan broker shall keep a standard record book in computer (electronic) form which has been approved in writing by the Police Chief of the Village of Villa Park, in which shall be recorded at the time of each and every loan or taking of a pledge, an accurate account and description, in the English language, of all the goods, articles and other things pawned or pledged, the amount of money, value or thing loaned thereon, the time of pledging the same, the rate of interest to be paid on such loan, and the name and residence of the person making such pawn or pledge. Such entry shall include the serial number or identification number of items received which are required to bear such number. Every pawnbroker shall also record an accurate account and description, in the English language, of all goods, articles and other things purchased or received for the purpose of resale or loan collateral by the pawnbroker from any source, not in the course of a pledge or loan, the time of such purchase or receipt and the name and address of the person or business which sold or delivered such goods, articles, or other things to the pawnbroker. No entry shall be erased, deleted, mutilated or changed. 
(b)  The pawn or loan broker shall also have installed, and operating at all times during business hours, a video surveillance camera positioned so as to record all transactions, as well as the facial features of those persons selling any item or pawning or pledging any item. Said video surveillance shall be recorded, stored and maintained for viewing at the request of the police department for at least thirty (30) days from the date of the transaction. 
(c)  Every pawnbroker shall require two (2) forms of identification to be shown him by each person pledging or pawning any goods, articles or other things to the pawnbroker. One (1) of the two (2) forms of identification must include his or her residence address. These forms of identification shall include, but not be limited to, any of the following: Driver's license, Social Security card, utility bill, employee or student identification card, credit card, or a civic, union or professional association membership card. 
(Ord. No. 2831, § 2, 6-24-96; Ord. No. 3675, § 2.2, 11-14-11)  
Sec. 13-806. - Inspections by police. 
The police chief or any officer designated by him shall have general supervision over all pawn or loan brokers, and shall also have power to inspect their respective places of business, computer generated records, video surveillance records, digital photographs taken, and all articles or things kept therein, whenever he shall deem it necessary to do so. 
(Ord. No. 2831, § 2, 6-24-96; Ord. No. 3675, § 2.2, 11-14-11)  
Sec. 13-807. - Daily report. 
It shall be the duty of every pawnbroker to make out and deliver to the chief of police of the village, on each day before the hour of 12:00 p.m. noon, a legible and exact copy from computer records as required by section 13-805 in the form specified by the police chief, that lists all personal property and other valuable things received on deposit or purchased during the preceding day, together with the exact time when received or purchased, and a description of the person or persons by whom left in pledge, or from whom the same were purchased. 
(Ord. No. 2831, § 2, 6-24-96; Ord. No. 3675, § 2.2, 11-14-11)  
Sec. 13-808. - Property from minor. 
No pawnbroker shall take or receive any pawn or pledge for any advancement or loan, any property of any kind from any minor who is under eighteen (18) years of age, or the ownership of which is in, or which is claimed by, any such minor, or which may be in the possession or under the control of any such minor. 
(Ord. No. 2831, § 2, 6-24-96)  
Sec. 13-809. - Property from intoxicated person or thief—Return of stolen property. 
No pawnbroker shall purchase or take any article in pawn or pledge from any person appearing to be intoxicated, nor from any person known to have been convicted of theft. A law enforcement officer may provide such criminal conviction information to a pawnbroker. When any person is found to be the owner of stolen property which has been pawned, such property shall be returned to the owner thereof without the payment of the money advanced by the pawnbroker thereon or any costs or charges of any kind which the pawnbroker may have placed upon the same. 
(Ord. No. 2831, § 2, 6-24-96)  
Sec. 13-810. - Sale of property. 
No personal property received on deposit or pledge, or purchased by any such pawnbroker, shall be sold or permitted to be redeemed or removed from the place of business of such pawnbroker for the space of twenty-four (24) hours after the delivery of the copy and statement required by section 13-807 to be delivered to the chief of police; and no personal property pawned or pledged shall be sold or disposed of by any such pawnbroker within one (1) year from the time when the pawner or pledger shall make default in the payment of interest on the money so advanced by such pawnbroker, unless by the written consent of such pawner or pledger. 
(Ord. No. 2831, § 2, 6-24-96)  
Sec. 13-811. - Employment of minors prohibited. 
No pawnbroker's license shall be issued to any person who is not eighteen (18) years of age or over, and no pawnbroker shall employ a person of less than eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 2831, § 2, 6-24-96)  
Sec. 13-812. - Personal nature of license. 
A license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be a purely personal privilege, valid for not to exceed one (1) year after issuance unless sooner revoked or expired as provided by ordinance, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. 
(Ord. No. 2831, § 2, 6-24-96)  
Sec. 13-813. - Revocation or suspension of license. 
(a)  No licensee holding a pawnbroker's license or his agent or employee shall, in the conduct of the licensed business or upon the licensed premises: 
(1)  Violate any law of the State of Illinois; or 
(2)  Violate any village ordinance or resolution regulating pawnbrokers; or 
(3)  Suffer or permit a violation of any law of the State of Illinois; or 
(4)  Suffer or permit a violation of a village ordinance or resolution regulating pawnbrokers. 
(b)  The village manager may revoke or suspend any license for any violation of this article. 
(c)  A violation of subsection (a) may be proved by evidence that the licensee or his agent or employee has been convicted of a violation of the law of the State of Illinois in the conduct of the licensed business or upon the licensed premises, or has been found guilty of violating any village ordinance regulating pawnbrokers. 
(d)  Evidence that any person, including but not limited to an agent or employee of the licensee, other than the licensee has been convicted of violating a statute of the state regulating pawnbrokers shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this article. 
(e)  Proof by a preponderance of evidence before the village manager of facts which establish a violation of any state statute, or village ordinance or resolution shall be sufficient cause for revocation or suspension of any license issued by the village, irrespective of whether or not a conviction has been obtained in any court. 
(f)  Should any applicant for license make a false or fraudulent statement in such application, the same shall be sufficient cause for revocation or suspension by the village manager of such license. 
(Ord. No. 2831, § 2, 6-24-96)  
Sec. 13-814. - Hearing and decision. 
No pawnbroker's license shall be revoked or suspended except after a public hearing by the village manager with written notice to the licensee affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend. The village manager shall, within five (5) days after such hearing, if he determines after such hearing that the license should be revoked or suspended, state the reason or reasons for such determination in a written order of revocation or suspension and shall serve a copy of such order within the five (5) days upon the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 2831, § 2, 6-24-96)  
Secs. 13-815—13-900. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - RESERVED[7] 

Footnotes:

ARTICLE X. - TATTOO AND 
BODY PIERCING ESTABLISHMENTS [8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 4047 , § 1, adopted Aug. 27, 2018, repealed the former Art. X, §§ 13-1001—13-1014, and enacted a new Art. X as set out herein. The former Art. X pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2964, § 2, adopted Nov. 26, 2007. 
 
Sec. 13-1001. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this article, the words and terms defined in the Tattoo and Body Piercing Establishment Registration Act (410 ILCS 54/1 et seq.) and Title 77, Chapter 1, subchapter m, Part 797 of the Illinois Administrative Code (33 Ill. Reg. 246) are hereby adopted into this article 
( Ord. No. 4047 , § 1, 8-27-18)  
Sec. 13-1002. - License required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to maintain and/or operate a tattoo and/or body piercing establishment without first having obtained a license as hereinafter provided. 
( Ord. No. 4047 , § 1, 8-27-18)  
Sec. 13-1003. - Application; fee. 
Every applicant for a license to maintain, operate or conduct a tattoo and/or body piercing establishment shall file an application upon a form provided by the village manager and pay a nonrefundable filing fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to the village. The village manager shall, within fifteen (15) days thereafter, refer copies of such application and all additional information to the police department, director of community development and village president. The village departments shall, within forty-five (45) days, inspect the premises proposed to be operated as a tattoo and/or body piercing establishment, and make recommendations to the clerk concerning compliance with the codes of the village. Upon receipt of the recommendations of the respective village departments, the village manager shall notify the applicant as to whether his application has been granted, denied or held for further investigation. The period of such additional investigation shall not exceed an additional thirty (30) days. 
( Ord. No. 4047 , § 1, 8-27-18)  
Sec. 13-1004. - Duration of license; renewal. 
Any license as provided for herein shall be issued on an annual basis and shall expire on December 31. The annual fee for renewal of such license shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) and shall be payable six (6) weeks in advance of the expiration of the license. If more than six (6) months of such current year shall have expired, a license fee of one-half the full fee shall be charged. 
( Ord. No. 4047 , § 1, 8-27-18)  
Sec. 13-1005. - Premises. 
No tattoo and/or body piercing establishment shall receive a license or be operated, established or maintained unless the establishment shall comply with each of the following minimum requirements and regulations: 
(1)  The establishment shall have a certificate of compliance with or inspection by the DuPage County Health Department, if available, 
(2)  The requirements and regulations of the Tattoo and Body Piercing Establishment Registration Act and Title 77, Chapter 1, subchapter m, Part 797 of the Illinois Administrative Code (33 Ill. Reg. 246) hereby adopted into this article by reference, 
(3)  No tattoo and/or body piercing establishment shall be open to the public for business between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., 
(4)  The main entrance door of any tattoo and/or body piercing establishment shall be visible from a public street and shall remain unlocked during business hours. 
( Ord. No. 4047 , § 1, 8-27-18)  
Sec. 13-1006. - Operating requirements. 
(a)  The licensee or operator shall comply with the requirements and regulations of the Tattoo and Body Piercing Establishment Registration Act and Title 77, Chapter 1, subchapter m, Part 797 of the Illinois Administrative Code (33 Ill. Reg. 246) hereby adopted into this article by reference. 
(b)  No person while on the premises of any tattoo and/or body piercing establishment shall possess, sell, dispense, provide, give, keep or maintain any alcoholic beverage. 
(c)  No intoxicated person shall be tattooed by a licensee on the license premises. 
( Ord. No. 4047 , § 1, 8-27-18)  
Sec. 13-1007. - Inspections. 
Any village department or agency may make an inspection of each establishment granted a license under the provisions of this article for the purposes of determining compliance with the provisions of this article or if an inspection is refused to seek a court order or warrant to investigate and enter the establishment. 
( Ord. No. 4047 , § 1, 8-27-18)  
Sec. 13-1008. - License revocation and suspension. 
It shall be cause for revocation or suspension that a licensee has violated the provisions of this article or any code or ordinance of the village, or Title 77, Chapter 1, subchapter m, Part 797.1700(c) of the Illinois Administrative Code relative to the operation of the business or use of the premises, has made a false statement on any application for license under this article. No license shall be revoked or suspended without notice and hearing first being provided to the licensee. 
( Ord. No. 4047 , § 1, 8-27-18)  
Sec. 13-1009. - Transfer of license prohibited. 
No license for the operation of a tattoo and/or body piercing establishment shall be transferable. 
( Ord. No. 4047 , § 1, 8-27-18)  
Sec. 13-1010. - Display of license required. 
Each licensee shall display a valid current license in a conspicuous place within the licensed establishment so that the same may be readily seen by persons entering the establishment. 
( Ord. No. 4047 , § 1, 8-27-18)  
Sec. 13-1011. - Tattooing or body piercing of minors. 
In accordance with 720 ILCS 5/12C-35, no person may tattoo a person under the age of eighteen (18) except by a person licensed to practice medicine in all its branches. In accordance with 720 ILCS 5/12C-40, no person may body pierce a minor under the age of eighteen (18) without permission of that minor's parents or legal guardians. 
( Ord. No. 4047 , § 1, 8-27-18)  
ARTICLE XI. - CONSTRUCTION OF UTILITY FACILITIES IN THE PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3444, § 2, adopted Nov. 26, 2007, amended art. XI in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, said article pertained to similar subject matter as enacted by Ord. No. 2967, § 2, 12-21-98; as subsequently amended. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion. 
 
Sec. 13-1101. - Purpose and scope. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to establish policies and procedures for constructing facilities on rights-of-way within the village's jurisdiction, which will provide public benefit consistent with the preservation of the integrity, safe usage, and visual qualities of the village rights-of-way and the village as a whole. 
(b)  Facilities subject to this article. This article applies to all facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within the public rights-of-way within the jurisdiction of the village, except as may be otherwise provided in any applicable franchise, license or similar agreement. 
(c)  Franchises, licenses, or similar agreements. The village, in its discretion and as limited by law, may require utilities to enter into a franchise, license or similar agreement for the privilege of locating their facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within the village rights-of-way. Utilities that are not required by law to enter into such an agreement may request that the village enter into such an agreement. In such an agreement, the village may provide for terms and conditions inconsistent with this article. 
(d)  Effect of franchises, licenses, or similar agreements. 
(1)  Utilities other than telecommunications providers. In the event that a utility other than a telecommunications provider has a franchise, license or similar agreement with the village, such franchise, license or similar agreement shall govern and control during the term of such agreement and any lawful renewal or extension thereof. 
(2)  Telecommunications providers. In the event of any conflict with, or inconsistency between, the provisions of this article and the provisions of any franchise, license or similar agreement between the village and any telecommunications provider, the provisions of such franchise, license or similar agreement shall govern and control during the during the term of such agreement and any lawful renewal or extension thereof. 
(e)  Conflicts with other articles. This article supersedes all policies, resolutions, ordinances, or parts thereof adopted prior hereto that are in conflict herewith, to the extent of such conflict. 
(f)  Conflicts with state and federal laws. In the event that applicable federal or state laws or regulations conflict with the requirements of this article, the utility shall comply with the requirements of this article to the maximum extent possible without violating federal or state laws or regulations. 
(g)  Sound engineering judgment. The village shall use sound engineering judgment when administering this article and may vary the standards, conditions, and requirements expressed in this article when the village so determines. Nothing herein shall be construed to limit the ability of the village to regulate its rights-of-way for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 3444, § 2, 11-26-07)  
Sec. 13-1102. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this article, unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the words and terms listed shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section. Any term not defined in this section shall have the meaning ascribed to it in 92 Ill. Adm. Code § 530.30, unless the context clearly requires otherwise. 
AASHTO means American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials. 
ANSI means American National Standards Institute. 
Applicant means a person applying for a permit under this article. 
ASTM means American Society for Testing and Materials. 
Backfill means the methods or materials for replacing excavated material in a trench or pit. 
Bore or boring means to excavate an underground cylindrical cavity for the insertion of a pipe or electrical conductor. 
Cable operator is that term as defined in 47 U.S.C. 522(5). 
Cable service is that term as defined in 47 U.S.C. 522(6). 
Cable system is that term as defined in 47 U.S.C. 522(7). 
Carrier pipe means the pipe enclosing the liquid, gas or slurry to be transported. 
Casing means a structural protective enclosure for transmittal devices such as carrier pipes, electrical conductors, and fiber optic devices. 
Clear zone means the total roadside border area, starting at the edge of the pavement, available for safe use by errant vehicles. This area may consist of a shoulder, a recoverable slope, a nonrecoverable slope, and a clear run-out area. The desired width is dependent upon the traffic volumes and speeds, and on the roadside geometry. Distances are specified in the AASHTO Roadside Design Guide. 
Coating means protective wrapping or mastic cover applied to buried pipe for protection against external corrosion. 
Code means the Municipal Code of the Village of Villa Park. 
Conductor means wire carrying electrical current. 
Conduit means a casing or encasement for wires or cables. 
Construction or construct means the installation, repair, maintenance, placement, alteration, enlargement, demolition, modification or abandonment in place of facilities. 
Cover means the depth of earth or backfill over buried utility pipe or conductor. 
Crossing facility means a facility that crosses one or more right-of-way lines of a right-of-way. 
Director of public works means the village director of public works or his or her designee. 
Disrupt the right-of-way, for the purposes of this article, means any work that obstructs the right-of-way or causes a material adverse effect on the use of the right-of-way for its intended use. Such work may include, without limitation, the following: Excavating or other cutting; placement (whether temporary or permanent) of materials, equipment, devices, or structures; damage to vegetation; and compaction or loosening of the soil, and shall not include the parking of vehicles or equipment in a manner that does not materially obstruct the flow of traffic on a highway. 
Emergency means any immediate maintenance to the facility required for the safety of the public using or in the vicinity of the right-of-way or immediate maintenance required for the health and safety of the general public served by the utility. 
Encasement means provision of a protective casing. 
Equipment means materials, tools, implements, supplies, and/or other items used to facilitate construction of facilities. 
Excavation means the making of a hole or cavity by removing material or laying bare by digging. 
Extra heavy pipe means pipe meeting ASTM standards for this pipe designation. 
Facility means all structures, devices, objects, and materials (including track and rails, wires, ducts, fiber optic cable, communications and video cables and wires, poles, conduits, grates, covers, pipes, cables, and appurtenances thereto) located on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within rights-of-way under this article, except those owned by the village. 
Freestanding facility means a ground-mounted facility that is not a crossing facility, an overhead facility, or a parallel facility, such as an antenna, transformer, pump, equipment enclosure, meter station, equipment cabinet or similar ground-mounted appurtenance. 
Frontage road means roadway, usually parallel, providing access to land adjacent to the highway where it is precluded by control of access on highway. 
Hazardous material means any substance or material which, due to its quantity, form, concentration, location, or other characteristic, is determined by the director of public works to pose an unreasonable and imminent risk to the life, health or safety of persons or property or to the ecological balance of the environment, including, but not limited to explosives, radioactive materials, petroleum or petroleum products or gases, poisons, etiology (biological) agents, flammables, corrosives or any substance determined to be hazardous or toxic under any federal or state law, statute or regulation. 
Highway Code means the Illinois Highway Code, 605 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq., as amended from time to time. 
Highway means a right-of-way used for vehicular traffic, including rural or urban roads or streets, whether classified as arterial, collector, minor or local. Highway includes all highway land and improvements, including roadways, ditches and embankments, bridges, drainage structures, signs, guardrails, protective structures and appurtenances necessary or convenient for vehicle traffic. 
Holder means a person or entity that has received authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the ICC pursuant to the Illinois Cable and Video Competition Law, 220 ILCS 5/21-401. 
IDOT means Illinois Department of Transportation. 
ILCC means Illinois Commerce Commission. 
Jacking means pushing a pipe horizontally under a roadway by mechanical means with or without boring. 
Jetting means pushing a pipe through the earth using water under pressure to create a cavity ahead of the pipe. 
Joint use means the use of pole lines, trenches or other facilities by two (2) or more utilities. 
J.U.L.I.E. means the Joint Utility Locating Information for Excavators Utility Notification Program. 
Major intersection means the intersection of two (2) or more arterial highways. 
Occupancy means the presence of facilities on, over or under right-of-way. 
Overhead facility means a facility that is mounted on a pole. 
Parallel facility means a facility that is generally parallel or longitudinal to the centerline of a right-of-way.
