A fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall be charged for a small wireless facility including a new utility pole. The fee shall accompany the application. 
(9)  Exemption from fees. Fee exemptions shall be as stated in section 15(f) of the Act. 
(10)  Village-owned infrastructure. Small wireless facilities shall only be mounted to village owned infrastructure including, but not limited to, streetlights, traffic signal, towers or buildings, if authorized by a license agreement between the owner and the village. 
(11)  Base of equipment above grade. The operator of a small wireless facility shall locate the base of the equipment or appurtenances on a pole at a height of no lower than eight (8) feet above grade. 
(12)  Screening. In the event that the operator of a small wireless facility proposes to install a facility where equipment or appurtenances are to be installed at grade, screening shall be installed to minimize the visibility of the facility. Screening must be installed at least three (3) feet from the equipment installed at-grade and eight (8) feet from a roadway. 
(13)  Color. A small wireless facility, including all related equipment and appurtenances, shall be a color that blends with the surroundings of the pole, structure or infrastructure on which it is mounted and use non-reflective materials which blend with the materials and colors of the surrounding area and structures. Any wiring must be covered with an appropriate cover or cable shield. 
(14)  Electrical code. Wires and cables connecting the antenna to the remainder of the facility shall be installed in accordance with the electrical code currently adopted by the village and in force at the time of the installation of the facility. In no event shall wiring and cabling serving the facility interfere with any wiring or cabling installed by a cable television or video service operator, electric utility or telephone utility. 
(15)  Structural integrity. The small wireless facility, including the antenna, pole extension and all related equipment must be designed to withstand a wind force and ice loads in accordance with applicable standards established in Chapter 25 of the National Electric Safety Code for utility poles, Rule 250-B and 250-C standards governing wind, ice, and loading forces on utility poles, in the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) in TIA/EIA Section 222-G established by the Telecommunications Industry Association (TIA) and the Electronics Industry Association (EIA) for steel wireless support structures and the applicable industry standard for other existing structures. For any facility attached to village-owned infrastructure or, in the discretion of the village, for a utility pole, tower, or alternative antenna structure, the operator of the facility must provide the village with a structural evaluation of each specific location containing a recommendation that the proposed installation passes the standards described above. The evaluation must be prepared by a professional structural engineer licensed in the State of Illinois. 
(16)  Signs. Other than signs required by federal law or regulations or identification and location markings, installation of signs on a small wireless facility is prohibited. 
(17)  Screening. If screening is required under this section, it shall be natural landscaping material or a fence subject to the approval of the village and shall comply with all regulations of the village. Appropriate landscaping shall be located and maintained and shall provide the maximum achievable screening, as determined by the village, from view from adjoining properties and public or private streets. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no such screening is required to extend more than nine (9) feet in height. Landscape screening when permitted in the right of way, shall be provided with a clearance of three (3) feet in all directions from the facility. The color of housing for ground-mounted equipment must blend with the surroundings. For a covered structure, the maximum reasonably achievable screening must be provided between such facility and the view from adjoining properties and public or private streets. In lieu of the operator installing the screening, the village, at its sole discretion, may accept a fee from the operator of the facility for the acquisition, installation, or maintenance of landscaping material by the village. 
(18)  Variance requirements. Each location of a personal wireless telecommunication facility within a right of way shall meet all of the requirements of this section unless a variance is requested pursuant to the procedure and standards set forth in section 13-1121 of this article. 
(d)  Removal of abandoned small wireless facilities. Small wireless facilities that are not operated for a continuous period of twelve (12) months shall be considered abandoned and the owner of the facility must remove the small wireless facilities within ninety (90) days after receipt of written notice from the village in compliance with section 15(k) of the Act. 
(e)  Indemnification and insurance. A wireless provider shall indemnify the village as provided in section 30 of the Act and provide a certificate of insurance to the village in compliance with the requirements for a permit within the village's right-of-way in section 13-1108 of the village Code. 
( Ord. No. 3961 , § 2, 2-27-17; Ord. No. 4033 , § 5-21-18)  
ARTICLE XII. - SCAVENGERS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2976, adopted Mar. 15, 1999, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as art. IX, §§ 13-901—13-911. Inasmuch as there were already provisions so designated, the provisions have been redesignated as art. XII, §§ 13-1201—13-1211, at the discretion of the editor. 
 
Sec. 13-1201. - Definitions. 
Whenever the following terms are used in this article, they shall be interpreted in accordance with the definitions hereinafter set forth, unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
Brush means any and all shrubbery, tree limbs and branches no larger than four (4) inches in diameter and no longer than four (4) feet in length. 
Commercial means any property within the village which is not residential. 
Curbside means a position immediately behind the curb and within the parkway area used for the collection of refuse, yard waste and recycling containers. 
Domestic garbage includes ashes, garbage, refuse, large refuse items, but excluding brush, landscape wastes, and white goods. 
Garbage means wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food; wastes from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
Landscape waste means all accumulations of grass or shrubbery cuttings, brush, leaves, tree limbs and other materials accumulated as the result of the care of lawns, shrubbery, vines and trees. 
Recyclables means materials to be picked up in separate collections from refuse including, but not limited to, green, brown and clear glass containers; aluminum, steel and bi-metal cans; HDPE and PET plastic bottles (including detergent, milk, water jugs and soda bottles); newspapers, magazines, telephone books, mixed paper, paperboard, aerosol cans, aseptic packaging, paint cans, six-pack rings, polystyrene containers, and corrugated cardboard; and such other materials as may be approved for delivery to any intermediate processing facility approved by the County of DuPage or operated by the County of DuPage or other approved recycling facility. 
Refuse means combustible trash, including, but not limited to paper, cartons, boxes, barrels, wood, excelsior, wood furniture, bedding; noncombustible trash, including, but not limited to metals, tin cans, metal furniture, small quantities of rock and pieces of concrete, glass, crockery, and other mineral waste; the term shall specifically include small amounts of building and construction materials resulting from "do-it-yourself" projects; the term shall not (except for "do-it-yourself" projects) include land clearing debris, earth and waste from building operations, building or construction materials, such as bricks, concrete, concrete block, structural iron and roofing materials, nor shall it include solid waste resulting from industrial processes and manufacturing operations, such as food processing waste, boiler- house cinders, lumber, scraps and shavings; street rubbish, street sweepings, dirt, leaves, or landscape waste. 
Residential means all single-family, duplex and triplex residential properties within the village. 
White goods means any domestic and/or commercial large appliance which contains CFC or HCFC refrigerant gas, PCB containing capacitors, mercury switches, or other hazardous components. Examples include, but are not limited to, refrigerators, freezers, air conditioners, ranges (both electric and gas), humidifiers, dehumidifiers, water heaters, furnaces and other similar large appliances. 
(Ord. No. 2976, § 2, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 13-1202. - License required; fee. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of scavenger or the collection or disposal of residential or commercial domestic garbage, refuse, landscape waste, recyclables or white goods in the village without having first secured a license therefor. 
(b)  The license period shall be from May 1 through April 30 of the following year. Before a license may be issued hereunder, the scavenger shall pay the village a license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per year or portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2976, § 2, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 13-1203. - Application for license. 
Application for license shall be made prior to May 1. Application for license shall be made to the village clerk, and payment for such license shall be tendered at the time of application. 
(Ord. No. 2976, § 2, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 13-1204. - Insurance reporting requirement. 
Such application shall be accompanied by copies of all insurance certificates required by law or otherwise held by the scavenger. 
(Ord. No. 2976, § 2, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 13-1205. - Vehicles. 
Any vehicle used by such scavenger in his business shall be watertight and equipped with airtight covers. 
(Ord. No. 2976, § 2, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 13-1206. - Dumping. 
It shall be unlawful for any scavenger to dispose of or store any refuse, garbage or other waste in any place within the village limits, excepting with the written permission of the village manager. 
(Ord. No. 2976, § 2, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 13-1207. - Exclusive method of disposal. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this article IX, where the village has entered into a contract with a private scavenger with respect to the disposal of residential or commercial domestic garbage, landscape waste, refuse, recyclables or white goods collected within the village, then that contract shall constitute the exclusive method for the collection and disposal of such materials within the village in accordance with the terms thereof. 
(b)  Insurance requirements and any other matters pertinent to the regulation of scavenger service, which may be provided for in a contract with the village, shall be governed exclusively by the contract documents. The license fees set forth in the ordinances of the village shall be paid by the contractor per said contract document. 
(c)  Any scavenger who collects or disposes of residential or commercial domestic garbage, landscape waste, recyclables or white goods collected within the village in a manner contrary to the village's exclusive method for disposal shall be subject to the penalties hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 2976, § 2, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 13-1208. - Recyclable materials. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any scavenger to provide collection services within the village unless such scavenger also provides a recycling program. The recycling program required by this section shall, at a minimum, permit customers to separately dispose of the following materials for recycling: 
(1)  Nonpaper items: Cloudy white HDPE (#2) plastic milk and water jugs; colored HDPE (#2) plastic blow molded containers; PET (#1) plastic blow molded containers; LDPE and HDPE soft plastic 6 and 12 pack rings; brown, green and clear glass containers; aluminum formed containers/ wrap; steel/tin/bi-metal cans; aerosol cans; formed steel containers; aluminum cans; polystyrene (#6); and aseptic packaging and Gabletop containers. 
(2)  Paper items: Corrugated cardboard; chipboard (paperboard); newspaper (ONP); magazines and catalogs (glossy and nonglossy); telephone directories; brown kraft paper bags; frozen food packages; mixed paper; and wet strength carrier stock. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than persons authorized by the village, to collect, pick up, or otherwise dispose of any recyclable materials described hereinabove, which have been set out at curbside for collection. Recyclable materials, which are combined with garbage or waste by the customer and not separately packaged, may be collected by a licensed scavenger. 
(Ord. No. 2976, § 2, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 13-1209. - Reporting requirement. 
A report shall be supplied to the village by such licensed scavenger, in a format acceptable to the village, within fifteen (15) days of the end of each quarter and year. The report shall set forth the amount of: (a) residential recyclables; (b) residential landscape wastes and brush; (c) domestic residential garbage; (d) commercial recyclables; and (e) commercial garbage collected. The licensed scavenger shall also supply monthly, quarterly and yearly reports setting forth the amount of solid waste collected within the village during each month, quarter and year. 
(Ord. No. 2976, § 2, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 13-1210. - Hours of operation. 
It shall be unlawful for any scavenger to collect or dispose of any refuse, garbage, or other waste between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 2976, § 2, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 13-1211. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3700, § 3, adopted May 21, 2012, deleted § 13-1211, entitled "Penalty", which derived from: Ord. No. 2976, § 2, adopted Mar. 15, 1999.  
ARTICLE XIII. - CABLE/VIDEO SERVICE PROVIDER FEE AND PEG ACCESS SUPPORT FEE 
 
Sec. 13-1301. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this article, unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the words and terms listed shall have the meanings ascribed to them below: 
Cable operator: That term as defined in 47 U.S.C. § 522(5). 
Cable service: That term as defined in 47 U.S.C. § 522(6). 
Commission: The Illinois Commerce Commission. 
Gross revenues: All consideration of any kind or nature, including, without limitation, cash, credits, property, and in-kind contributions received by the holder or cable operator for the operation of a cable or video system to provide cable service or video service within the holder's or cable operator's cable service or video service area within the village. 
A.  Gross revenues shall include the following: 
1.  Recurring charges for cable or video service. 
2.  Event-based charges for cable service or video service, including, but not limited to, pay-per-view and video-on-demand charges. 
3.  Rental of set top boxes and other cable service or video service equipment. 
4.  Service charges related to the provision of cable service or video service, including but not limited to, activation, installation and repair charges. 
5.  Administrative charges related to the provision of cable service or video service, including but not limited to, service order and service termination charges. 
6.  Late payment fees or charges, insufficient funds check charges, and other charges assessed to recover the costs of collecting delinquent payments. 
7.  A pro rata portion of all revenue derived by the holder or cable operator or its affiliates pursuant to compensation arrangements for advertising or for promotion or exhibition of any products or services derived from the operation of the network to provide cable service or video service within the village. The allocation shall be based on the number of subscribers in the village divided by the total number of subscribers in relation to the relevant regional or national compensation arrangement. 
8.  Compensation received by the holder or cable operator that is derived from the operation of the holder's network to provide cable service or video service with respect to commissions that are received as compensation for promotion or exhibition of any products or services on the network, such as a "home shopping" or similar channel, subject to subsection 9. 
9.  In the case of a cable service or video service that is bundled or integrated functionally with other services, capabilities, or applications, the portion of the holder's revenue attributable to the other services, capabilities, or applications shall be included in the gross revenue unless the holder or cable operator can reasonably identify the division or exclusion of the revenue from its books and records that are kept in the regular course of business. 
10.  The service provider fee permitted by 220 ILCS 5/21-801(b). 
B.  Gross revenues do not include any of the following: 
1.  Revenues not actually received, even if billed, such as bad debt, subject to 220 ILCS 5/21-801(c)(1)(vi). 
2.  Refunds, discounts, or other price adjustments that reduce the amount of gross revenues received by the holder of the state-issued authorization to the extent the refund, rebate, credit, or discount is attributable to cable service or video service. 
3.  Regardless of whether the services are bundled, packaged, or functionally integrated with cable service or video service, any revenues received from services not classified as cable service or video service, including, without limitation, revenue received from telecommunication services, information services, or the provision of directory or internet advertising, including yellow pages, white pages, banner advertisement, and electronic publishing or any other revenues attributed by the holder or cable operator to noncable service or nonvideo service in accordance with the books and records and records kept in the regular course of business and any applicable laws, rules, regulations, standards, or orders. 
4.  The sale of cable services or video services for resale in which the purchaser is required to collect the service provider fee from the purchaser's subscribers to the extent the purchaser certifies in writing that it will resell the service within the village and pay the fee permitted by 220 ILCS 5/21-801(b) with respect to the service. 
5.  Any tax or fee of general applicability imposed upon the subscribers or the transaction by a city, state, federal, or any other governmental entity and collected by the holder of the State-issued authorization and required to be remitted to the taxing entity, including sales and use taxes. 
6.  Security deposits collected from subscribers. 
7.  Amounts paid by subscribers to "home shopping" or similar vendors for merchandise sold through any home shopping channel offered as part of the cable service or video service. 
C.  Revenue of an affiliate of a holder or cable operator shall be included in the calculation of gross revenues to the extent the treatment of the revenue as revenue of the affiliate has the effect of evading the payment of the fee permitted by 220 ILCS 5/21-801(b) which would otherwise be paid by the cable service or video service. 
Holder: A person or entity that has received authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the commission pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-401. 
PEG: Public, education and governmental. 
PEG access support fee: The amount paid under this article and 220 ILCS 5/21-801(d) by the holder or cable operator to the village for the service areas within its territorial jurisdiction. 
Service: The provision of "cable service" or "video service" to subscribers and the interaction of subscribers with the person or entity that has received authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the commission pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-401. 
Service provider fee: The amount paid under this article and 220 ILCS 5/21-801 by the holder or cable operator to a municipality for the service areas within its territorial jurisdiction. 
Video service: Video programming and subscriber interaction, if any, that is required for the selection or use of such video programming services, and which is provided through wireline facilities located at least in part in the public right-of-way without regard to delivery technology, including Internet protocol technology. This definition does not include any video programming provided by a commercial mobile service provider defined in 47 U.S.C. § 332(d) or any video programming provided solely as part of, and via, service that enables users to access content, information, electronic mail, or other services offered over the public internet. 
(Ord. No. 3445, § 2, 11-26-07)  
Sec. 13-1302. - Cable/video service provider fee imposed. 
(a)  Fee imposed. A fee is hereby imposed on any holder or cable operator providing cable service or video service in the village. 
(b)  Amount of fee. The amount of the fee imposed hereby shall be five (5) percent of the holder's or cable operator's gross revenues. 
(c)  Notice to the village. The holder or cable operator shall notify the village at least ten (10) days prior to the date on which the holder begins to offer cable service or video service in the village. 
(d)  Holder's liability. The holder or cable operator shall be liable for and pay the service provider fee to the village. The liability for the fee shall commence on the first day of the calendar month following thirty (30) days after receipt of the ordinance adopting this article by the holder or cable operator. The ordinance adopting this article shall be sent by the village clerk via regular or certified mail, postage prepaid, to the address listed on the holder's application notice sent pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-401(b)(6) to the village and to any cable operator. 
(e)  Payment date. The payment of the service provider fee shall be due on a quarterly basis, forty-five (45) days after the close of the calendar quarter. If mailed, the fee is considered paid on the date it is postmarked. Each payment shall include a statement explaining the basis for the calculation of the fee. 
(f)  Exemption. The fee hereby imposed does not apply to existing cable service or video service providers that have an existing franchise agreement in effect with the village in which a fee is paid. 
(g)  Credit for other payments. An incumbent cable operator that elects to terminate an existing agreement pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-301(c) with credit for prepaid franchise fees under that agreement may deduct the amount of such credit from the fees that operator owes under section 13-1302(b). 
(Ord. No. 3445, § 2, 11-26-07)  
Sec. 13-1303. - Peg access support fee imposed. 
(a)  PEG fee imposed. A PEG access support fee is hereby imposed on any holder or cable operator providing cable service or video service in the village in addition to the fee imposed pursuant to section 13-1302. 
(b)  Amount of fee. The amount of the fee imposed hereby shall be one percent of the holder's or cable operator's gross revenues or, if greater, the percentage of gross revenues that incumbent cable operators pay to the village or its designee for PEG access support in the village as of January 1, 2007, as provided in 220 ILCS 5/21-801(d)(1). 
(c)  Payment. The holder or cable operator shall pay the PEG access support fee to the village or to the entity designated by the village to manage PEG access. The holder's liability for the PEG access support fee shall commence on the date set forth in section 13-1302. 
(d)  Payment due. The payment of the PEG access support fee shall be due on a quarterly basis, forty-five (45) days after the close of the calendar quarter. If mailed, the fee is considered paid on the date it is postmarked. Each payment shall include a statement explaining the basis for the calculation of the fee. 
(e)  Credit for other payments. An incumbent cable operator that elects to terminate an existing agreement pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-301(c) shall pay, at the time they would have been due, all monetary payments for PEG access that would have been due during the remaining term of the agreement had it not been terminated pursuant to that section. All payments made by an incumbent cable operator pursuant to the previous sentence may be credited against the fees that operator owes under subsection (b) hereinabove. 
(Ord. No. 3445, § 2, 11-26-07)  
Sec. 13-1304. - Applicable principles. 
All determinations and calculations under this article shall be made pursuant to generally accepted accounting principles. 
(Ord. No. 3445, § 2, 11-26-07)  
Sec. 13-1305. - No impact on other taxes due from holder or cable operator. 
Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to exempt a holder or cable operator from any tax that is or may later be imposed by the village, including any tax that is or may later be required to be paid with respect to cable service or video service. A state-issued authorization shall not affect any requirement of the holder with respect to payment of the village's simplified municipal telecommunications tax or any other tax as it applies to any telephone service provided by the holder. A state-issued authorization shall not affect any requirement of the holder with respect to payment of the local unit of government's 911 or E911 fees, taxes or charges. 
(Ord. No. 3445, § 2, 11-26-07)  
Sec. 13-1306. - Audits of cable/video service provider. 
(a)  Audit requirement. The village will notify the holder of the requirements it imposes on other cable service or video service providers to submit to an audit of its books and records. The holder shall comply with the same requirements the village imposes on other cable service or video service providers in its jurisdiction to audit the holder's books and records and to recompute any amounts determined to be payable under the requirements of the village. If all local franchises between the village and cable operator terminate, the audit requirements shall be those adopted by the village in chapter 23, article X of the Village Code pursuant to the Local Government Taxpayers' Bill of Rights Act, 50 ILCS 45/1 et seq. No acceptance of amounts remitted should he construed as an accord that the amounts are correct. 
(b)  Additional payments. Any additional amount due after an audit shall be paid within thirty (30) days after the municipality's submission of an invoice for the sum. 
(Ord. No. 3445, § 2, 11-26-07)  
Sec. 13-1307. - Late fees/payments. 
All fees due and payments which are past due shall be governed by chapter 23, article X of the Village Code adopted by this municipality pursuant to the Local Government Taxpayers' Bill of Rights Act, 50 ILCS 45/1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 3445, § 2, 11-26-07)  
ARTICLE XIV. - CABLE AND VIDEO CUSTOMER PROTECTION LAW[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note— Section 5 of Ord. No. 3446 provided that this ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and approval and publication in the manner provided by law. The provisions of this ordinance as to incumbent cable operators shall take effect on Jan. 1, 2008. 
 
Sec. 13-1401. - Customer service and privacy protection law. 
(a)  Adoption. The regulations of 220 ILCS 5/70-501 are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the cable or video providers offering services within the village's boundaries. 
(b)  Amendments. Any amendment to the Cable and Video Customer Protection Law that becomes effective after the effective date of this article shall be incorporated into this article by reference and shall be applicable to cable or video providers offering services within the municipality's boundaries. However, any amendment that makes its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this article by reference without formal action by the corporate authorities of the village. 
(Ord. No. 3446, § 2, 11-26-07)  
Sec. 13-1402. - Enforcement. 
The village does hereby pursuant to law declare its intent to enforce all the customer service and privacy protection standards of the Cable and Video Protection Law with respect to complaints received from residents within the village. 
(Ord. No. 3446, § 2, 11-26-07)  
Sec. 13-1403. - Penalties. 
The village, pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/70-501(r)(1), does hereby provide for a schedule of penalties for any material breach of the Cable and Video Protection Law by cable or video providers in addition to the penalties provided in the law. The monetary penalties shall apply on a competitively neutral basis and shall not exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each day of the material breach and shall not exceed twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for each occurrence of a material breach per customer. 
A.  Material breach means any substantial failure of a cable or video provider to comply with service quality and other standards specified in any provision of the law. 
B.  The village shall give the cable or video provider written notice of any alleged material breaches of the law and allow such provider at least thirty (30) days from the receipt of the notice to remedy the specified material breach. 
C.  A material breach, for the purposes of assuming penalties, shall be deemed to occur for each day that a material breach has not been remedied by the cable or video service provider after the notice in subsection B. 
(Ord. No. 3446, § 2, 11-26-07)  
Sec. 13-1404. - Customer credits. 
The village hereby adopts the schedule of customer credits for violations. Those credits shall be as provided for in the provisions of 220 ILCS 5/70-501(s) and applied on the statement issued to the customer for the next billing cycle following the violation or following the discovery of the violation. The cable or video provider is responsible for providing the credits, and the customer is under no obligation to request the credit. 
(Ord. No. 3446, § 2, 11-26-07)  
ARTICLE XV. - SECONDHAND GOODS DEALERS[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to license, tax, locate and regulate all places of business of dealers in junk, rags and any secondhand article whatsoever, 625 ILCS 5/11-42-3. 
 
Sec. 13-1501. - Licenses; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase or sell any type of secondhand goods, wares, merchandise or other property without having first obtained from the village and kept in full effect a license therefor. This shall include, but not be limited to, the purchase and sale of personal items, metals, scrap metal, electronic and digital devices, jewelry and gems. The license period shall be from May 1 through April 30 of the following year. Application for license shall be made to the village clerk, and payment for such license shall be tendered at the time of application. Before a license may be issued hereunder, the secondhand goods dealer shall pay the village a license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per year or portion thereof and shall submit a license application: 
(1)  Application for a secondhand goods dealer license shall be made on a form provided by the village clerk, who shall provide a copy of the application to the Chief of Police, or his designee, to investigate each licensee applicant. No license shall be issued to any person, partnership, corporation or other entity, if any owner, manager, partner, officer, director or shareholder owning more than five (5) percent of the shares of stock in the corporation has been convicted of any felony offense or convicted of the offense(s) of possession of stolen goods, burglary, robbery, or who has been convicted of any criminal offense involving dishonesty or moral turpitude. 
(2)  Every applicant for a secondhand goods dealer license, as well as every owner, partner, manager, officer, director, employee, and in this case, of a corporate applicant, every shareholder owning more than five (5) percent of the shares of stock in the corporation shall undergo a criminal background investigation, which investigation may include fingerprinting, prior to the issuance of a secondhand goods dealer license. For the second and subsequent applicant, a fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) each shall be paid for the required background check. 
(b)  Secondhand good is defined as any item of merchandise which was owned or used by any person other than the manufacturer, wholesaler, or retailer. 
(c)  Nothing herein shall apply to those isolated transactions commonly known as "garage sales," as defined in section 13-101. 
(d)  Nothing herein shall apply to those persons whose business is not primarily dealing in secondhand goods, and who may in the ordinary and regular course of their business receive or take a secondhand article in trade and subsequently dispose of the same. 
(e)  Nothing herein shall apply to charitable organizations that do not purchase goods for resale. 
(f)  Nothing herein shall apply to purchase or sale of items of used clothing, used books, used or antique furniture or any personal property for which a title is issued. 
(g)  No more than fourteen (14) secondhand goods dealer licenses shall be issued. 
(Ord. No. 3665, § 2, 8-8-11; Ord. No. 3705, § 1, 6-25-12)  
Sec. 13-1502. - License to indicate place of business. 
Any license for a secondhand dealer issued under the provisions of this division shall designate the premises in which the person so licensed shall carry on the business for which he is licensed. Such business shall not be carried on or conducted in any other place than that designated by the license. 
(Ord. No. 3665, § 2, 8-8-11)  
Sec. 13-1503. - Purchases from minors. 
No secondhand dealer shall purchase any goods, article or thing whatsoever from any minor under the age of eighteen (18) years. 
(Ord. No. 3665, § 2, 8-8-11)  
Sec. 13-1504. - Records required; inspection of records and goods. 
(a)  Every secondhand dealer shall keep a permanent record book in which shall be legibly written in ink at the time of each purchase, an accurate account and description of the article or thing so purchased or sold, and the name and residence of the person to whom or from whom such purchase was made. The record book as well as every article of merchandise shall at all reasonable times be open to the inspection of any member of the police force. 
(b)  In addition to a record book, the secondhand goods dealer shall maintain such records required by this section in a computer form which has been approved in writing by the Police Chief of the Village of Villa Park. 
(c)  The secondhand goods dealer shall also have installed, and operating at all times during business hours, a video surveillance camera positioned so as to record all transactions, as well as the facial features of those persons selling any item to the secondhand goods dealer or pawning or pledging any item, or in the alternative shall take and keep on record a picture of those persons. 
(Ord. No. 3665, § 2, 8-8-11)  
Sec. 13-1505. - Daily report. 
It shall be the duty of every licensed person under this article to make out and deliver to the police chief in person or via email, every day before the hour of 12:00 noon, a legible and correct copy of the book or computer records required in section 13-1504 in the form specified by the police chief. 
(Ord. No. 3665, § 2, 8-8-11)  
Sec. 13-1506. - Inspection of premises by police. 
The police chief or any officer designated by him shall have general supervision over all dealers in secondhand articles and shall also have power to inspect their respective places of business, record book, computer generated records, video surveillance records, digital photographs taken, and all secondhand articles or things kept therein, whenever he shall deem it necessary to do so. 
(Ord. No. 3665, § 2, 8-8-11)  
Sec. 13-1507. - Stolen goods. 
(a)  Every secondhand store dealer who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles or things of value which may have been lost or stolen, shall upon demand, produce such article or thing to any member of the police department for examination, and it shall be the duty of every dealer hereunder to report to the police department any article or thing which was sold to him or which is offered to him for purchase if he shall have reason to believe that the article or thing was stolen. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any secondhand goods dealer to knowingly purchase any article from any person appearing to be intoxicated or under the influence of any drug or controlled substance or from any person known to have been convicted of theft, burglary, deceptive practices, robbery or armed robbery. It shall further be the duty of every secondhand goods dealer, or agent or employee thereof, to return any sold property to the rightful owner of such property without the payment of the money advanced by secondhand goods dealer, or employee or agent, or any other cost or charge of any kind any such property which has been stolen. 
(Ord. No. 3665, § 2, 8-8-11)  
Sec. 13-1508. - Prohibited items. 
No secondhand goods dealer, or agent or employee thereof, shall receive or purchase any firearm, stun gun or taser or any article, the possession of which is prohibited pursuant to section 24-1(a)(1) of the Illinois Criminal Code, 720 ILCS 5/24-1(a)(1). 
(Ord. No. 3665, § 2, 8-8-11)  
Sec. 13-1509. - Hours of operation. 
Every secondhand store dealer shall be open for business only between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. daily. 
(Ord. No. 3665, § 2, 8-8-11)  
Sec. 13-1510. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3700, § 3, adopted May 21, 2012, deleted § 13-1510, entitled "Penalty", which derived from: Ord. No. 3665, § 2, adopted Aug. 8, 2011.  
ARTICLE XVI. - REVOCATION OF LICENSES 
 
Sec. 13-1601. - Revocation or suspension; hearing. 
(a)  Any license issued under this chapter may be revoked or suspended by the village administrator by reason of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, following a hearing. 
(b)  When a hearing is set by the village administrator in a revocation or suspension procedure, the licensee shall receive not less than twenty (20) days' written notice, which notice shall contain charges made, as well as the time and place when the hearing will be held. 
(c)  At a hearing conducted pursuant to this article, the licensee shall have the right to be represented by counsel, to present witnesses, to testify and cross-examine any other witnesses. Proceedings shall be conducted under oath. 
(d)  The village administrator shall preside at the hearing and shall make the final determination. 
(e)  If any decision adverse to the licensee is made by the village administrator after a hearing as provided above, the village administrator shall provide the licensee with a written reason for such decision, as well as a notice of the licensee's right to seek judicial review of the decision. 
(Ord. No. 3665, § 2, 8-8-11)  
ARTICLE XVII. - PARADES AND OPEN AIR MEETINGS 
 
Sec. 13-1701. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
Assembly. Any meeting, demonstration, picket line, rally, gathering, or group of ten (10) or more persons, animals, or vehicles, or combination thereof, having a common purpose, design, or goal, upon any public street, sidewalk, alley, parkway, or other public place, which assembly substantially inhibits the usual flow of pedestrian or vehicular travel or which occupies any public area, other than a parade, as defined in this section. 
Block party. An assembly of village residents on a public residential street for a distance not to exceed one (1) block and for a time period not to exceed twelve (12) hours. 
Parade. Any march, demonstration, procession, motorcade, or promenade consisting of persons, animals, or vehicles, or a combination thereof, having a common purpose, design, destination, or goal, upon any public place which parade, march, demonstration, procession, motorcade, or promenade does not comply with normal and usual traffic regulations or control. 
Sidewalk. Any area or way set aside or open to the general public for purposes of pedestrian traffic, whether or not it is paved. 
Street. Any place or way set aside or open to the general public for purposes of vehicular traffic, including any berm or shoulder parkway, right-of-way, or median strip thereof. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 13-1702. - Permit required; exemptions. 
(a)  Permit required. No person shall engage in, conduct, or carry on the activity of a parade or assembly without a permit issued under the provisions of this article. The permit shall not authorize the use of sound amplifying equipment in conjunction with a parade or assembly without a separate permit. 
(b)  Exemptions. The provisions of this article shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Funeral processions. 
(2)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(3)  Spontaneous events occasioned by news or affairs first coming into public knowledge within three (3) days of such parade or assembly, provided that the organizers thereof give written notice to the village at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to such parade or assembly. 
(4)  Block parties, when approval of the date, time and place has been given by the village manager, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld unless the event conflicts with any other approved parade, event or assembly of the village or such circumstances which limit or impair the ability to provide emergency services. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 13-1703. - Application for permits. 
(a)  A person seeking a parade or public assembly permit (other than a block party) shall file an application with the chief of police or his designee on forms provided by such officer, and the application shall be signed by the applicant and notarized. 
(b)  For single, nonrecurring parades or public assemblies, an application for a permit shall be filed with the chief of police at least ten (10) and not more than one hundred eighty (180) days before the parade or public assembly is proposed to commence. The chief of police may waive the minimum ten-day filing period and accept an application filed within a shorter period if, after due consideration of the date, time, place, and nature of the parade or public assembly, the anticipated number of participants, and the village services required in connection with the event, the chief of police determines that the waiver will not present a hazard to public safety. 
(c)  For parades or public assemblies held on a regular or recurring basis at the same location, an application for a permit covering all such parades or assemblies during that calendar year may be filed with the chief of police at least sixty (60) and not more than one hundred eighty (180) days before the date and time which the first such parade or public assembly is proposed to commence. The chief of police may waive the minimum sixty-day period after due consideration of the factors specified in subsection (b) above. 
(d)  The application for a parade or public assembly permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such a parade or assembly; 
(2)  If the parade or assembly is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization; 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the designated person who will be responsible for the receipt and holding of the permit; 
(4)  The date when the parade or assembly is to be conducted; 
(5)  The amount of any admission or attendance charge expected to be required from those participating; 
(6)  The route to be traveled, the starting point, the termination point, the location of speaker's platforms and the total time and distance expected; 
(7)  The appropriate number of persons who will, and animals and vehicles which will, constitute such parade or assembly and the type of animals and description of the vehicles; 
(8)  The hours when such parade or assembly will start and terminate; 
(9)  A statement as to whether the parade or assembly will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed or public area to be assembled upon; 
(10)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade or assembly; 
(11)  The time at which units of the parade or assembly will begin to assemble at any such assembly areas. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 13-1704. - Permit fees. 
(a)  A nonrefundable fee as established by the village board to cover administrative costs of processing the permit shall be paid to the village by the applicant when the application is filed. 
(b)  If the application is for the use of any village property or if any village services shall be required for the parade or public assembly, the applicant shall pay, prior to the issuance of a permit, the charges for those services in accordance with a schedule of service costs approved by the village board. 
(c)  The applicant shall also be responsible for reimbursement of additional village costs not reimbursed in subsection (b) above, including but not limited to personnel and equipment that shall be paid no later than thirty (30) days following the event. 
(d)  The village board may reduce or waive its costs when done so on a nondiscriminatory basis when in the best interest of the village and there shall be no costs reimbursed for police protection when the sole purpose of the parade or public assembly is for the purpose of public issue speech protected under the First Amendment. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 13-1705. - Action on permits. 
The chief of police shall either, within forty-eight (48) hours, issue a written permit for the holding of a parade or assembly or deny the application. Applications may be denied on the basis of incompleteness or as not being in compliance with this article. The reasons for denial shall be made known to applicant, in writing, at the time of denial. The applicant shall be allowed to correct or complete the improper application and resubmit it to the chief of police or immediately appeal pursuant to section 13-1710. If a corrected application is resubmitted the chief of police shall issue the permit or deny the application within forty-eight (48) hours, in writing, as with an original application. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 13-1706. - Issuance or denial of permit. 
The chief of police shall issue a permit as provided herein unless, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The information contained in the application is false or intentionally misleading in some material or substantial regard; 
(2)  The parade or assembly will endanger public health, welfare or safety for the reasons set forth herein and that reasonable adjustments to the village traffic control, street and property maintenance, or police, fire or ambulance protection would not alleviate such danger; 
(3)  The time, duration, route and size of the parade or assembly will substantially and unreasonably disrupt the movement of traffic; 
(4)  The parade or assembly is of a size or nature that it would require the diversion of such a great number of police officers of the village to properly police the line of movement or assembly area and the areas contiguous thereto as to impair reasonable police protection to the village; 
(5)  The permittee has failed to provide for the services of sufficient monitors to control the orderly conduct of the parade or assembly; 
(6)  The permittee has failed to provide a reasonable means of informing all the persons participating therein of the terms and conditions of the permit; 
(7)  The concentration or number of persons, animals, or vehicles, or a combination thereof, is such as to prevent or substantially impair police, fire and ambulance vehicles and/or personnel from responding to emergency calls within the village, including within the immediate area of the proposed parade or assembly; 
(8)  The parade will not progress from its assembly area to its disbanding area as expeditiously as reasonably required for the safe and orderly conduct of the parade; 
(9)  The parade or assembly will interfere with another parade or assembly for which a permit has previously been granted except as set forth in section 13-1708; 
(10)  The parade or assembly is reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property; 
(11)  The assembly on a public sidewalk in a business district will interfere with the normal egress and ingress of pedestrians to and from a business establishment. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 13-1707. - Nondiscrimination. 
The chief of police shall uniformly consider each application upon its merits and shall not discriminate in granting or denying the application and shall not deny any permit based upon political, religious, ethnic, racial or gender-related grounds or upon sexual orientation or disability. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 13-1708. - Multiple permits. 
If the chief of police shall receive more than one (1) application for a parade or assembly at the same time and the same place, or on the same day, the application filed first in time shall take precedence. An application shall be considered to be at the same time if the event is scheduled to commence within two (2) hours before or after the holding of another event at the same place. An application shall be considered to be at the same place if the assembly is to be conducted within one-half mile of another assembly. If the chief of police receives an application for more than one (1) parade or assembly in a single day, the chief of police may set a time for the duration of each parade or assembly, which time shall not, without the consent of the group seeking the permit, be less than three (3) hours. The chief of police shall issue permits for more than a single parade during one (1) day in accordance with the requirements of this section and section 13-1705; provided, however, that the chief of police may not issue multiple permits beyond the point at which the issuance of an additional permit would require the continuing diversion of so great a number of police officers or other village personnel so as to prevent normal police protection or other services to the village. A single permit may cover more than one (1) group or person if their identities are properly reported on the application. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 13-1709. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to stage, present, or conduct any parade or public assembly without first having obtained a permit as herein provided. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to participate in a parade or public assembly for which the person knows a permit has not been granted. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of, or responsible for the conduct of, a duly licensed parade or public assembly to knowingly fail to comply with any condition of the permit. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any parade or public assembly activity that would constitute a substantial hazard to the public safety or that would materially interfere with or endanger the public peace or rights of residents to the quiet and peaceful enjoyment of their property. 
(e)  No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct or impede, or interfere with any parade or public assembly or with any person, vehicle or other object lawfully participating or lawfully used in a parade or public assembly. 
(f)  No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade or public assembly when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade or public assembly. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 13-1710. - Appeal to village board. 
(a)  Any final decision of the chief of police may be appealed to the corporate authorities by the applicant, permittee, or any person affected by the decision. Any appeal shall be filed with the village president within two (2) business days after notice of the decision. The corporate authorities shall act upon the appeal at the next regularly scheduled village board meeting held more than two (2) days and less than fourteen (14) days after the filing of the appeal. If no such meeting is scheduled or if a regularly scheduled meeting is not held within such time, the mayor shall call a special board meeting to consider and act upon the appeal within fourteen (14) days after the filing of such appeal. 
(b)  In the event that the village board rejects an applicant's appeal, the applicant may file an immediate request for review with a court of competent jurisdiction; provided, however, nothing in this article shall be construed, nor is intended, to prevent or prohibit an applicant from seeking immediate judicial review from a denial of a permit request or from any action or inaction on the part of the village, its officers or agents. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 13-1711. - Hours. 
All parades shall be held during daylight hours at times other than peak traffic periods (7:30 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday) and not before 12:00 noon on Sundays. All assemblies shall conclude by 10:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 13-1712. - Traffic limits. 
Parades and assemblies shall be limited to such numbers as will not obstruct traffic either vehicular or pedestrian in an unreasonable manner. The chief of police may impose as a condition of the permit reasonable regulations as to spacing of paraders, length of parade, duration of the parade or assembly so police manpower will not be diverted for too long a period of time from its other duties, giving consideration to the day of the week, the expected amount of vehicle and pedestrian traffic, weather conditions and the holiday conditions, if any. The time requested may be reset or diminished if necessary to avoid relocating or rerouting overly large amounts of vehicles or pedestrian traffic covered by peak periods of traffic. The chief of police may then issue a permit with those conditions. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 13-1713. - Distributing literature. 
Literature may be passed from person to person, but may not be put upon or affixed to any public or private property without the permission of the owner of the property. The materials cannot be passed out to moving cars or cars on public or private roadways. Material can be handed out to passersby on sidewalks if such distribution does not unreasonably interfere with the flow of the pedestrian traffic. If permittee chooses to hand out any such material then the permittee shall be responsible for removing any discarded materials from the area of the parade or assembly. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 13-1714. - Revocation of permit. 
The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke a parade or public assembly permit instantly upon violation of the conditions or standards for issuance as set forth in this article or when a public emergency arises where the police resources required for that emergency are so great that deployment of police services for the parade or public assembly would have an immediate and adverse effect upon the welfare and safety of persons or property. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 13-1715. - Penalty. 
Any person, firm or entity violating the terms and conditions of this article shall be subject to a fine as set forth in section 1-108 each and every day that the violation is allowed to exist. Each day that a violation exists constitutes a distinct and separate offense under the terms of this article. In addition, the corporate authority may take whatever action it deems appropriate to enforce the terms of this article, including an action for injunction. All attorney fees and costs incurred by the municipality in enforcing the terms of this article shall be paid by the violator. 
(Ord. No. 3682, § 1, 1-9-12)  
ARTICLE XVIII. - SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT 
 
Sec. 13-1801. - Purpose. 
The purpose of a special event permit is to establish a single point of contact with the village by an applicant for a special event for coordination of the activities of the special event and the various and separate village approvals for any related activities. 
( Ord. No. 3962 , § 3, 3-13-17)  
Sec. 13-1802. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
Special event: means any event in the village that: uses village park or other village-owned property, temporarily provides food service, will use a public address or sound system, will use portable toilets, will conduct a raffle, will require additional refuse receptacles, will require safety or special fencing, will require special street lighting or electrical service, will require special water service, will use stages or other temporary structures, will require the closing of a village street, will require the closing of an off-street parking facility, will require the use of village barricades, will require the services of the police or fire department, will require an emergency evacuation plan, will sell or serve alcoholic beverages, will display fireworks, will need the services of village maintenance workers or other employees, or will require an additional village license or permit. 
( Ord. No. 3962 , § 3, 3-13-17)  
Sec. 13-1803. - Permit required. 
No person shall engage in, conduct or carry on the activity of a special event without a permit issued under the provisions of this article. The permit shall not authorize any activity that is also required to have a separate license or permit as required by the Villa Park Municipal Code. 
( Ord. No. 3962 , § 3, 3-13-17)  
Sec. 13-1804. - Application for permit. 
A person seeking a special event permit shall file an application and site plan with the department of public works on forms provided by that department not less than thirty (30) days prior to the event and attach all other related village forms for other activities separately licensed or permitted by the village. Applications filed less than thirty (30) days before the event may be accepted by the village if the village still has sufficient time to review the application which must be accompanied with a late filing fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
( Ord. No. 3962 , § 3, 3-13-17)  
Sec. 13-1805. - Permit fee—Payment of costs. 
A nonrefundable fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) shall be paid to the village by the applicant when the application is filed in addition to any other fee for related activities separately licensed or permitted. Special events sponsored or co-sponsored by the village shall be exempt from the special event fee. 
In addition, the applicant shall pay any village cost as established by the village for additional services provided by the village as stated on the most recent list of fees for available village services. The applicant shall pay to the village prior to the event all fees and costs that can be determined prior to issuance of the permit and any balance within thirty (30) days after the event. 
( Ord. No. 3962 , § 3, 3-13-17)  
Sec. 13-1806. - Action on permit. 
Applications may be denied on the basis of incompleteness or as not being in compliance with this article or in compliance with any other ordinance, rule or regulation for a related permit or license. The reason(s) for the denial shall be made known to the applicant in writing at the time of denial. The applicant shall be allowed to correct or complete the application and resubmit it to the department of public works or appeal to the village manager by the procedure provided in article XVI. 
( Ord. No. 3962 , § 3, 3-13-17)  
Sec. 13-1807. - Penalty. 
Any person violating this article shall be subject to a minimum fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) each day that the violation exists. 
( Ord. No. 3962 , § 3, 3-13-17)  
ARTICLE XIX. - CHARITABLE GAMES 
 
Sec. 13-1901. - Charitable games defined. 
Charitable games shall be defined as Section 30/2 of the Charitable Games Act (230 ILCS 30/2) and includes the fourteen (14) games of chance involving cards, dice, wheels, random selection of numbers, and gambling tickets which may be conducted at charitable games events listed as follows: roulette, blackjack, poker, pull tabs, craps, bang, beat the dealer, big six, gin rummy, five card stud poker, chuck-a-luck, keno, hold-em poker, and merchandise wheel. 
( Ord. No. 4027 , § 1, 4-23-18)  
Sec. 13-1902. - Exceptions to gambling. 
None of the sections of the Municipal Code of Villa Park dealing with gambling shall apply to participation in charitable games, as defined in this article when said game is conducted by nonprofit organizations possessing the required state license and meeting the requirements and regulations of the Charitable Games Act. 
( Ord. No. 4027 , § 1, 4-23-18)  
Sec. 13-1903. - Minors. 
(a)  No person under twenty-one (21) years of age shall make a wager on any charitable game. No person, nonprofit organization or premises owner, where such games are held, shall permit a person less than twenty-one (21) years of age to make a wager on any charitable game. 
(b)  Each nonprofit organization or premises owner, where such games shall be conducted, shall prominently display or cause to be displayed a sign indicating the prohibition contained in subsection (a) of this section. Each nonprofit organization, supplier of devices and/or premises owner, where such games will be conducted, shall provide or cause to be provided proper supervision and security to ensure that the prohibition contained in subsection (a) of this section is followed. Further, each premises owner shall affirmatively advise each nonprofit organization using its premises of said provision. 
( Ord. No. 4027 , § 1, 4-23-18)  
Sec. 13-1904. - Conduct of games. 
(a)  Pursuant to the Charitable Games Act, no state licensee shall hold charitable games night more than four (4) days with one each quarter of the calendar year nor rent or provide its premises for the conducting by another eligible charitable organization of more than twelve (12) charitable games nights, including its games, with not more than three (3) days per quarter of a calendar year that the premises are used. 
(b)  Within fourteen (14) days of receiving the necessary license from the Illinois Department of Revenue, but in no event less than seven (7) days before the commencement of any charitable games event, the licensee shall furnish to the chief of police a copy of said license, the specific dates and location of the charitable games event, and the name, address and the date of birth of the person in charge of the event, and each and every member of the organization engaged in the management or operation of the event. 
(c)  The license, the documentation for the license and the premises where the charitable games event is held shall be subject to inspection by the police department at any time during the event. 
( Ord. No. 4027 , § 1, 4-23-18)  
Chapter 14 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 14-101. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter the following terms shall mean as indicated below: 
Emergency vehicle: Vehicles of the police or fire department, ambulances, or any vehicle conveying a village official or utility, state or county employees in response to an emergency official call. 
Loading zone: The space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
Operator: Every person, other than a chauffeur, who drives or is in actual physical control of a motor vehicle upon a highway or who is exercising control over or steering a vehicle being towed by a motor vehicle. 
Parkway: That area between the outer edge of the traveled portion of the highway and the nearest lot line. 
Property line: The line marking the boundary between any street and the lots or property abutting thereon. 
Right-of-way: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 791, Art. I, 7-11-61)  
Sec. 14-102. - Provisions of Illinois Vehicle Code adopted. 
(a)  The provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.), as now existing or hereafter amended, except for those provisions which by their nature can have no application to the village, are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter with the same force and effect as if set forth at length herein. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(b)  Citations for violations of the aforesaid chapters of the Illinois Vehicle Code adopted by reference herein may be issued by authorized personnel of the village, using the appropriate Illinois Vehicle Code section which shall, by the effect of this section, represent identically and specially numbered sections of the Villa Park Municipal Code. 
(c)  Without limiting the generality of subsection (a) hereinabove: 
(1)  The following provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code, as may be amended from time to time, are hereby expressly adopted by reference pursuant to the authority granted in 625 ILCS 5/20-204; Sections 11-501, 11-501.1, 11-501.2, 11-501.4, 11-501.4-1, 11-501.5, 11-501.6, 11-501.7, and 11-501.8, excepting Section 11-501(d). 
Reference to this subsection 14-102(c) can be made in the following manner: Villa Park Municipal Code, chapter 14, article I, subsection 14-102(c) followed by the applicable Illinois Vehicle Code section number, e.g., subsection 14-102(c) of the Village Park Village Code/IVC 11-501(a). 
(2)  Except as otherwise provided in subsection (c)(3) herein below, the court, upon making a finding of guilty for any offense under this subsection, in addition to any sentencing alternative selected by the court, shall impose a fine of not less than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such offense. In the event the Illinois Vehicle Code imposes a minimum fine greater than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for such an offense, the greater of the statutory minimum fine or seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) shall be imposed. 
(3)  With respect to vehicle equipment compliance violations, upon making a finding of guilty, the court or the administrative hearing officer shall impose a fine in accordance with the fine schedule set forth in section 14-220 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3514, § 2, 10-13-08; Ord. No. 3532, § 2, 2-23-09)  
Sec. 14-103. - Authority of police to enforce chapter and to direct traffic. 
The members of the police department shall enforce the provisions of this chapter and are hereby authorized to direct, control or regulate traffic. 
(Ord. No. 791, Art. XVII, § 2, 7-11-67) 
State Law reference— Obedience to police officers, 625 ILCS 5/11-203.  
Sec. 14-104. - Speed limits.

(b)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of that indicated below in the indicated area:

St. Charles Road, thirty (30) miles per hour.

Wildwood Avenue, between Euclid Avenue and Villa Avenue, twenty (20) miles per hour. 
Yale Avenue from the entrance to the North Side Swim Pool to the parking area, ten (10) miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 661, § 1, 7-22-57; Ord. No. 918, § 1, 4-26-65; Ord. No. 1161, § 1, 12-1-69; Ord. No. 1179, § 3, 6-8-70; Ord. No. 1221, § 1, 3-1-71; Ord. No. 1363, § 1, 1-29-73; Ord. Sec. 14-106. - Through streets. 
Through street, as used in this section, shall mean every street on which vehicular traffic is given preferential right-of-way, and at the entrances to which vehicular traffic from intersecting streets are required by law to yield the right-of-way on such street in obedience to either a stop sign or a yield sign. 
The following streets and parts of streets are hereby declared to constitute through streets which require a stop sign or yield sign at all intersecting streets: 
North Avenue (Route 64) east and west, from Villa Avenue to Kramer Avenue. 
Roosevelt Road east and west, from Euclid Avenue to Wisconsin Avenue. 
St. Charles Road east and west, from Riverside Drive to Westmore Avenue. 
All vehicles shall stop before entering the through streets designated herein at intersections. 
(Ord. No. 791, Art. IX, § 7, 7-11-61; Ord. No. 837, § 1, 9-10-62; Ord. No. 918, § 1, 4-26-65; Ord. No. 1000, § 1, 6-19-67; Ord. No. 1032, 12-18-67; Ord. No. 1083, § 1, 10-7-68; Ord. No. 1238, 5-17-71; Ord. No. 2507, § 1, 7-15-91)
