The proper grade at which such sidewalk or sidewalks shall be constructed shall be furnished by the village engineer, and all costs incurred by the village, in connection therewith, shall be paid by the person, firm or corporation applying for and receiving said permit. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to those premises abutting State of Illinois Highways Roosevelt Road (Rt. 38), North Avenue (Rt. 64), and Kingery Highway (Rt. 83). 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall also apply to all planned unit developments approved and passed by the village. In the event a site plan for a planned unit development is submitted to and approved by the village which specifically includes the location of nonexistent, but proposed, sidewalks, the approved site plan relative to proposed sidewalk locations shall prevail over this section; further, the other provisions of this section shall prevail over all planned unit development ordinances unless specifically exempted by said planned unit development ordinance from the provisions of this section. 
(d)  The president and board of trustees, by a vote of at least three-fourths of the members elected to office, may waive the provisions of all or any part of this article. In enacting such waiver, the president and board of trustees may at its option, require the permittee to deposit with the village treasurer an amount of money estimated to cover the cost of the installation of such sidewalks in the future, and which sum may be used by the village only for the installation of such sidewalks. If the sum of money so deposited shall not be used for the construction of such sidewalks, at the expiration of ten (10) full years from the date of such deposit, the deposit shall be returned in full to the then record owner of the subject premises without further referral to the corporate authority. The village treasurer shall be authorized to make such refund upon the presentation of an owner's guaranty policy issued by a title company authorized to do business in the state covering the date upon which said deposit shall be required to be refunded. 
(Ord. No. 1934, §§ 1—4, 9-8-80)  
Secs. 21-210—21-220. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 
 
Sec. 21-221. - Required. 
No person shall construct, place or repair a driveway approach, sidewalk, curb or gutter or dig in a street or parkway without a permit from the manager. 
(Ord. No. 1323, § 2, 8-14-72)  
Sec. 21-222. - Application. 
A person desiring the permit required by the provisions of this division shall apply in writing to the manager upon a form furnished by the manager giving the information required on the form. The application shall be accompanied by a drawing showing the location of proposed driveway approach, sidewalk, curb and gutter, or where the street or parkway opening will be made. 
(Ord. No. 1323, § 2, 8-14-72)  
Sec. 21-223. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3974 , § 4, adopted May 22, 2017, repealed § 21-223 which pertained to fees and derived from Ord. No. 1323, § 3, adopted Aug. 14, 1972.  
Sec. 21-224. - Bond. 
A person applying for the permit required by this division shall supply to the village the appropriate guarantee as required by appendix B of the Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 1323, § 4, 8-14-72; Ord. No. 3053, § 4, 8-28-00)  
Secs. 21-225—21-229. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - SIDEWALK REPLACEMENT PROGRAM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2199, §§ 1—5, enacted Aug. 11, 1986, did not specifically amend the Code, hence inclusion herein as div. 3, §§ 21-230—21-234 was at the discretion of the editor. Sections 6—8 of said ordinance, pertaining to conflict, severability and validity have not been codified. 
 
Sec. 21-230. - Definitions. 
(a)  Appurtenant stairs or steps. Exterior changes in elevation made by risers and treads which constitute stairs or steps located upon public property and which touch upon, abut, face upon, or are contiguous with, any public sidewalk, pavement or curbing in such a manner as to link with and constitute a continuation or termination of such sidewalk. 
(b)  Defective sidewalk. One which is so imperfect, incomplete, flawed or faulty so as to require repair or replacement. 
(c)  Deficient sidewalk. One inadequate in construction, quality or any essential requisite necessary to be safe and adequate for its intended function. 
(d)  Designated sidewalk. One identified, selected and noted to be in need of repair, reconstruction or replacement, as determined by the village director of public works, or his or her appointed representative, in the reasonable exercise of that person's discretion. 
(e)  Hazardous sidewalk. One having an abrupt, vertical difference in grade of one (1) inch or more, caused by cracking, settlement or upheaval of the concrete sidewalk slab. 
(f)  Substantially deteriorated sidewalk. One which is materially substandard, unsound or degenerated to a degree that such sidewalk constitutes a threat to public health and safety and is in need of repair, reconstruction or replacement. 
(Ord. No. 2199, § 1, 8-11-86)  
Sec. 21-231. - Created. 
There is hereby created and established a "sidewalk replacement program" in the Village of Villa Park, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 2199, § 2, 8-11-86)  
Sec. 21-232. - Intent and purpose. 
The sidewalk replacement program established hereby, is for the purpose of repair, replacement and reconstruction of defective, substantially deteriorated, deficient and hazardous public sidewalks; and appurtenant stairs and steps within the boundaries of said village. By means of such program the village intends to protect and preserve the built environment, enhance the public health, safety and welfare and promote community development. 
(Ord. No. 2199, § 3, 8-11-86)  
Sec. 21-233. - Implementation. 
(a)  Inspection. The village department of public works shall establish a program of sidewalk inspection and shall inspect designated village sidewalks and appurtenant stairs and steps at the request of an abutting landowner, citizen, resident or village employee, and shall determine such sidewalks as safe and sufficient or as hereinafter set forth in subsection (b) below. Upon notification of the existence of a deficient, defective or hazardous sidewalk or appurtenant stair or step by an owner, citizen, resident or employee of the village, the department of public works shall inspect such sidewalk and appurtenant stairs and steps in a reasonable time thereafter. Such notification and citizen participation shall be encouraged. In conducting such inspection, the department of public works will ascertain whether or not the damage has been caused by trees planted on public property and shall so note on any report whether or not the complained of condition, or any part thereof, has been caused by a tree growing on public property. The determination by the department of public works as to whether or not the condition of the sidewalk has been caused in whole or in part by a tree growing on public property shall be final. 
(b)  Sidewalk and appurtenant stairs and steps designation. Sidewalks and appurtenant stairs and steps shall be designated as in need of repair, replacement or reconstruction after inspection and determination thereof by the village public works director, or his or her designated representative, in the reasonable exercise of their discretion. 
(c)  Property owner notification. Upon designation of a sidewalk as in need of repair or replacement, the village department of public works shall cause written notice thereof, describing the exact location of such sidewalk, its deficiencies and the extent of repair or reconstruction required to bring such sidewalk into conformance herewith, to be mailed to the last owner of record of the lot, tract or parcel of real property touching upon, abutting, contiguous to, or which fronts upon, said sidewalk. 
(d)  Sidewalk repair or replacement. Within thirty (30) days of receipt of such notice, the property owner shall: 
(1)  Repair, replace or reconstruct such designated sidewalk to specifications as set forth in this division at his or her own expense and forego construction and financial participation by the village. 
(2)  Elect to participate in the sidewalk replacement program in the manner hereinafter specified. 
(3)  Failure to either repair or to elect to participate pursuant to the aforestated options shall result in the Village of Villa Park undertaking and completing needed repairs or replacement, and upon the completion thereof, a bill of costs shall be prepared by the Village of Villa Park Department of Public Works and tendered to the owner of the relevant lot, tract or parcel. Such bill of costs shall contain, although not be limited to, the use and cost of materials, labor, excavation, paving and supervision. 
(e)  Owner participation. 
(1)  Notice: A property owner who chooses to participate in the sidewalk replacement program shall, upon receipt of written notice that his or her sidewalk has been designated as in need of repair or replacement, notify the Village of Villa Park Department of Public Works within thirty (30) days of receipt of such notice. The village shall then contract out for the repair or replacement upon competitive, qualified bid, at the lowest cost for good and sufficient construction. 
(2)  Completion: Upon completion of needed repairs of the fronting, abutting, touching and contiguous sidewalk and appurtenant stairs and steps, the property owner shall pay fifty (50) percent of the cost per square foot of repaired or replaced sidewalk surface (based upon the unit prices contained in any contract entered into by the village for the repair or replacement) and/or the total of one hundred (100) percent of the cost of repairing or replacing any appurtenant stairs and steps, or sidewalk connecting the property to the edge of the adjacent street. There shall be no charge to the resident for the replacement of any sidewalk or portion thereof which has been determined by the department of public works to have been damaged by a tree growing on public property. The determination of the department of public works shall be final. Any and all charges for the repair or replacement of sidewalks damaged by trees growing on public property and other charges, expenses or fees shall be paid or assumed by the village. 
(3)  Payment: Such cost or repair or replacement charged to the property owner shall be fully paid within ninety (90) days of receipt of the bill of costs therefore. 
(4)  Nonpayment: If the property owner shall fail to pay the costs of repair as herein set forth for owner participation in the manner described, such failure will be deemed nonparticipation on behalf of such owner and the total unpaid cost of repair of designated sidewalks shall be levied and specially taxed against such lot, tract or parcel as provided by statute. 
(f)  Special taxation of adjoining property. If a property owner fails or refuses to repair or replace designated sidewalks or to elect to participate in the sidewalk replacement program, in addition to any other manner provided by law, the village shall repair or replace such sidewalks to specification and specially tax the whole cost thereof upon the lots, tracts or parcels touching upon, contiguous to or abutting the designated sidewalk, in proportion to the frontage of such property. The Village of Villa Park Department of Public Works shall prepare a bill of costs as set forth in subsection (d)(3) herein and prepare a list of such lots, blocks, tracts and parcels of land, containing the names of the parties who last paid the general taxes thereon. Upon failure to repair or to elect to participate, the village department of public works will cause to be prepared a special tax list against those lots, blocks, tracts or parcels on account of the repair or replacement of designated sidewalks. Such special tax shall then be levied against the property in the method and manner as provided in Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 24, Paragraph 11-84-3 to 11-84-8. 
(Ord. No. 2199, § 4, 8-11-86; Ord. No. 2466, §§ 1, 2, 3-11-91)  
Sec. 21-234. - Construction; repair standards. 
(a)  Repair; reconstruction. Designated sidewalks and appurtenant stairs and steps shall be repaired or replaced, if done by the village, by contract construction awarded on the basis of competitive bidding and let to the lowest, qualified bidder. 
(b)  Supervision. All sidewalk and appurtenant stairs and steps repair, replacement or reconstruction, whether undertaken by a property owner, the village or any other person or entity, shall be under the supervision of the village department of public works. 
(c)  Inspection. Completed sidewalk repair, replacement or reconstruction shall be inspected by the village public works director, or his or her designated representative for compliance with this division. 
(d)  Approval. All completed sidewalk repair, replacement or reconstruction must be approved by the public works director, or his or her designated representative. Such approval shall be mandatory. 
(e)  Nonapproved; nonconforming sidewalks. Sidewalks which fail to comply with the specification herein or which fail to meet the approval of the village as aforestated, shall be re-repaired or re-replaced as necessary within thirty (30) days of written notification that such sidewalk is nonapproved or nonconforming. Failure to do so will result in necessary repairs or replacement by the village and special taxation procedures, where required. 
(f)  Standards. 
(1)  Defective, substantially deteriorated, deficient and/or hazardous sidewalks shall be repaired or replaced to match the width of the existing, adjacent sidewalk or pavement, provided that the minimum width thereof shall be no less than four (4) feet, six (6) inches. 
(2)  Sidewalk shall be constructed of a concrete having a minimum of six (6) bags of cement per cubic yard and an air content of not less than five (5) per cent or more than eight (8) per cent, by volume. Samples shall meet testing requirements of not less than two (2) or more than four (4) inches of slump and have a compressive strength of not less than three thousand, five hundred (3,500) pounds per square inch at the age of fourteen (14) days. 
(3)  Concrete sidewalks shall have a minimum thickness of six (6) inches at driveway crossings and four (4) inches elsewhere. 
(4)  Sidewalk concrete shall be placed upon a compacted, grade No. 8, crushed stone subbase having a thickness of six (6) inches at driveway crossings and four (4) inches elsewhere. 
(5)  Outside stairs or steps upon public property touching upon or abutting contiguous sidewalks shall be considered a part thereof and shall be constructed of approved concrete and so as to be safe and able to support anticipated loads. Such steps shall meet minimum standards as to dimensions of treads and risers as specified in the relevant building or structures code as adopted by the village. Every such set of steps or stairs more than three (risers) high, shall have a good and sufficient handrail not less than thirty (30) inches or more than thirty-four (34) inches high, measured vertically above the nosing of the treads. 
(Ord. No. 2199, § 5, 8-11-86)  
ARTICLE III. - TREES ON PUBLIC PROPERTY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3345, § 1, adopted April 10, 2006, amended art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, art. III pertained to similar subject matter as enacted by Ord. No. 1267, adopted Oct. 25, 1971; and as subsequently amended by Ord. No. 2158, adopted Sept. 3, 1985. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion. 
 
Sec. 21-301. - Scope. 
The provisions of this article shall apply to the planting, maintenance, and removal of trees on public property. This article establishes policies, regulations and standards necessary to ensure the Village of Villa Park will realize the benefits provided by its community forest. The article is enacted to: 
Promote and protect the public health, safety, and general welfare by providing for the regulation of the planting, maintenance, and removal of trees on village property in the village. 
Protect trees on streets and other publicly owned property of the Village of Villa Park. Trees, as defined, regulated and protected herein, are declared to be a natural public resource and the Village of Villa Park encourages planting, replacement and protection of trees. 
To regulate the cutting down, damaging, poisoning or in any other manner destroying of any trees under the protection of the department of public works as covered by the terms of this article. 
The Villa Park Public Works Department shall have the authority and jurisdiction of regulating the planting, maintenance, and removal of trees within the public right-of-way of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. Only village employees shall be involved with the planting, removal, trimming, insect and disease control, and tree surgery of village trees. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06)  
Sec. 21-302. - Permits. 
No person, other than authorized village public works employees, shall plant, cut, trim, destroy, or remove any tree, bush, hedge, or shrubs on or from any village property, including, but not limited to, street rights-of-way and parkways. 
Provided, however, that utility company maintenance crews or licensed contractors may trim trees on the public right-of-way after receiving a permit from the village. Utility companies are specified as, but not limited to, the following: Commonwealth Edison, Comcast Cable Company; American Telephone & Telegraph Company; and Northern Illinois Gas Company. Trimming done by or for the utility companies shall be subject to inspection by authorized village employees. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06)  
Sec. 21-303. - Authorized trees. 
Trees which are to be planted in village parkways shall be selected from the following list of trees and/or other species as approved by the village manager. 
Sugar maple 	Norway maple 	Scarlet (red) maple 
Crimson King maple 	American linden 	European linden 
Busiman elm 	Liberty elm 	Accolade elm 
Triumph elm 	Gingko 	Kentucky Coffee 
Pin oak 	Red oak 	Swamp white oak 
Hackberry tree 	Tulip tree 	Beech tree 
Sweet Gum tree 	Crab tree 	River birch 
Skyline locust 		
 
Trees that have been planted on village rights-of-way, which are not on the authorized list and are under two and one-half (2½) inches in diameter, at a distance of twelve (12) inches above ground, shall be removed. 
Likewise, all crippled, deformed, hazardous, or noncurable diseased trees, regardless of species, if professional opinion indicates recovery cannot be expected, shall be removed and gradually replaced. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06; Ord. No. 3657, § 3, 6-27-11; Ord. No. 3889 , § 1, 12-14-15)  
Sec. 21-304. - Specifications. 
(a)  Trees, when planted, shall have a minimum diameter of one and one-half (1½) to two and one-half (2½) inches at a distance of twelve (12) inches above the ground, shall have a continuous single six- to eight-foot trunk for large trees and four- to five-foot trunk for small trees before pruning, and shall be free from deformity and indication of undesirable growth characteristics. 
(b)  Trees, when planted, shall be free of infectious disease or insect infestation. 
(c)  Trees shall be planted on the center line of the parkways. No trees may be planted on parkways less than four (4) feet wide, unless in the opinion of the village manager or his authorized representative the planting and the species of the tree approved will not endanger sidewalk, curb, or other physical property. 
(d)  The planting of trees is prohibited if such planting will interfere with existing sewer connections. 
(e)  Species of trees which by reason of size, spread of crown, or other characteristics could interfere with overhead utility lines, are prohibited in all locations where such lines exist. 
(f)  Parkway trees shall be planted at least four (4) feet from any sidewalk or curb wherever possible, and shall be spread not less than fifty (50) feet apart. No tree shall be planted within thirty (30) feet of the closed point of any actual or plotted corner sidewalk intersection. No planting ever shall be allowed within intersection corner crosswalks. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06)  
Sec. 21-305. - Subdivisions. 
In subdivisions and in all new residential and nonresidential development, not less than one (1) parkway tree per lot, centered, shall be required to be installed at the expense of the subdivider. The minimum diameter of trees planted shall be two and one-half (2½) inches at a distance of twelve (12) inches above the ground. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06)  
Sec. 21-306. - Maintenance. 
(a)  Spraying by the village for the prevention and elimination of tree disease and insect infestation shall be performed to meet the specific requirements of the species of tree and the particular disease or insect infestation which exists or threatens. It shall be the village manager's or his authorized representative's responsibility to determine the need and extent of spraying requirements, and make recommendations to the village board. 
(b)  Systematic trimming and pruning should be carried out to: 
(1)  Restore physiological balance between the root system and leaf surface at the time of planting. 
(2)  Remove dead branches, seriously damaged branches, and unbalanced branches and limbs. 
(3)  Gradually remove lower branches to provide a minimum overhead clearance of fifteen (15) feet above street and sidewalk. 
(4)  Shape young trees so that they will develop a single tall straight trunk, a strong central framework or branch structure, and a symmetrical balanced crown. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on village property. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical, may be exempted from this article at the determination of the village public works department. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06)  
Sec. 21-307. - Removal of infected trees. 
(a)  All trees on private property infected with Dutch Elm Disease (Ceratosystis ulmi) or ash trees infected with the emerald ash borer (Agrilus planipennis fairmaire) are declared to be a nuisance. It shall be unlawful to permit any such tree or part thereof so infected to remain within the village corporate limits whether on private or public property. 
(b)  The village manager or his authorized representative shall inspect and examine any tree within the village corporate limits to determine whether or not it is infected by either disease. Upon discovering that any such tree is so infected, the owner of the property shall be notified of this fact by mail. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner of any land upon which such diseased tree or part thereof exists to have the same removed from the village corporate limits within thirty (30) days of notice by the village that such tree or part thereof is so infected. 
(d)  The tree removal contract shall include tree felling, clean up, and hauling from the village corporate limits. 
(e)  When the owner of such property refuses or neglects to remove any such tree, the village manager shall provide for its removal and cause a lien to be filed on such property for the reasonable cost thereof in the manner and form provided by 65 ILCS 5/11-20-12. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06; Ord. No. 3657, § 2, 6-27-11)  
Sec. 21-308. - Guards during construction. 
(a)  Prior to erection, alteration, repair or removal of any building or structure, the owner thereof shall place, or cause to be placed, such guards around all nearby trees on the parkway as will effectively prevent injury to such trees. 
(b)  Where in authorized excavations, it becomes necessary to expose or cut roots that are greater than one (1) inch in diameter or are within the drip line of any tree, it shall be the duty of the contractor to protect the roots from damage. 
(c)  Excavation/grading equipment and all other implements, machines and tools shall be used or operated in such a manner as not to damage or destroy any tree, shrub or plant in any village parkway, property or park. (No person, firm or corporation shall strip, excavate or otherwise remove top soil except in connection with the construction or alteration of a building on such premises and excavation or grading incidental thereto. Grade level in the immediate vicinity of existing trees, shrubs, or plants in any right-of-way shall not be altered unless said planting is replanted to new grade level.) 
(d)  In the erection, alteration or repair of any building or structure, or the construction, installation, alteration or repair of any street, sidewalk or utility, trees in the right-of-way or on any village owned or maintained property shall be protected from damage or removal unless otherwise authorized by the public works department. Tree crowns and trunks shall not suffer any branch or bark loss. Roots shall be protected from compaction, storage of materials, and severing within a circle around the tree with the tree trunk as the focal point. The tree protection fencing detail and post and fence detail is as follows: 
 
(e)  Roots located within the determined circle shall be protected by such practices as temporary bridges for vehicles or auguring for utility installation. Any factors that would cause any deviations from this section shall be noted on the permit issued for such work. In addition to any fines that may be assessed for violation of this section, the person shall pay to the village a sum equal to the value or partial value of the tree lost as a result of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06; Ord. No. 3889 , §§ 2, 3, 12-14-15)  
Sec. 21-309. - Attachments to trees. 
(a)  No person shall be allowed to post any bills, advertisements, cards or notices of any kind, upon village owned trees, placed in any street or square, within the limits of the village, without permission of the public works department. In addition, no person shall be allowed to fasten any rope, wire, electric attachment, sign or other devices to a tree or to any guard about such tree, including temporary holiday or temporary ornamental lighting. 
(b)  No person shall whitewash, paint or in any way discolor the stem base, bole or root of any tree or shrub upon any public property in the village. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06)  
Sec. 21-310. - Paving and snow plowing near parkway trees. 
(a)  No person shall deposit, place, store or maintain upon any public place of the municipality, any stone, brick, sand, concrete, or other materials which may impede the free passage of water, air or fertilizer to the roots of any parkway tree growing therein, without leaving an open space of not less than two (2) feet in width all around the tree. 
(b)  Snow will not be plowed, blown, shoveled from roof tops, or piled in a manner that damages parkway trees. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06)  
Sec. 21-311. - Prohibited growth. 
Bushes, hedges and other low growth obscuring vehicular vision are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06)  
Sec. 21-312. - Protection from fire and toxins. 
(a)  No person shall allow fire or heat to come in contact with any tree on land owned or maintained by the village or set fire or permit any fire to burn when such fire or the heat thereof will injure any portion of any tree owned or maintained on village property. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or public utility to place salt, brine, petroleum products, herbicides, or any other substances in such amounts as to be toxic or injurious to the health, growth or vitality of any street tree, park tree or shrub in any public area or public way. 
(c)  In addition to any fines that may be assessed for violation of this section, the resident or person determined to be at fault shall pay to the village a sum equal to the value or partial value of the tree lost as a result of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06)  
Sec. 21-313. - Protection from utilities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or public utility to cut, carve, scrape or girdle, burn, char, or otherwise deface any street tree, park tree or other shrub or tree in any public area or public way. A public utility, with easement rights, removing branches interfering with overhead lines is held to the same standards for tree pruning and tree care as required in this article. 
(b)  No person, firm, or corporation owning, maintaining or operating any natural gas pipes or mains laid beneath the surface of any parkway in the village, shall permit any leak to occur in such pipes. In the event that a leak exists or occurs in any pipe or main, the person owning or operating such defective pipe or main shall repair the same immediately and stop such leak in a manner so as to prevent a recurrence of the same after receiving notice from the village manager, calling the attention of such person to the fact that such leak exists or has occurred. Such person shall, promptly and in any event within five (5) days after the receipt of such notice, stop such leak in a manner so as to prevent a recurrence thereof. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06; Ord. No. 3889 , § 4, 12-14-15)  
Sec. 21-314. - Violations. 
(a)  In addition to the penalty imposed for violations of the Code, violators of the article shall be subject to payment of labor and material costs to the village for replanting or removal of noncomplying plantings. 
(b)  No person shall unreasonably hinder, prevent, delay, or interfere with the village public works department or its authorized agents while engaged in the execution or enforcement of this article. 
(c)  Whenever any work is being done contrary to the provisions of this article, the public works department may order the work stopped by serving written notice on any persons engaged in the doing or causing such work to be done, and any such persons shall forthwith stop such work until authorized by the public works department to proceed with the work. 
(d)  The appraised tree value or the partial loss in tree value shall be determined by the Villa Park Public Works Department using the most current edition of the Guide for Plant Appraisal, prepared by the Council of Tree and Landscape Appraisers, and edited, published and copyrighted by the International Society of Arboriculture. Various factors used in the tree value calculations for northern Illinois shall be obtained from the most current edition of the Species Ratings and Appraisal Factors for Illinois, prepared by the Illinois Arborist Association. 
(e)  Where practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships inconsistent with the purposes of this article result from its literal interpretation or enforcement, the village public works department may waive, modify or delay the enforcement of these provisions, upon written request from the developer or the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06; Ord. No. 3700, § 3, 5-21-12)  
Sec. 21-315. - Severability clause. 
If any section of this article is found to be invalid or unconstitutional, it does not affect the validity of remaining sections. 
(Ord. No. 3345, § 1, 4-10-06)  
ARTICLE IV. - PARADES AND OPEN AIR MEETINGS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 21-401. - Definition. 
(a)  The term "open air meeting" as used in this article shall be defined as any congregation of people held outdoors and upon any public property for the purpose of hearing speakers or discussing some matter of common interest where the number of participants expected may reasonably be assumed to exceed fifty (50). 
(b)  The term "parade" as used herein shall mean a parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, park or other public place in the village. 
(Ord. No. 1099, § 2, 2-17-69)  
Sec. 21-402. - Hours. 
All parades shall be held during the daylight hours at times other than peak traffic periods (7:30 a.m. to 9:00 a.m.) and (4:30 p.m. to 6:00 p.m.) Monday through Saturday and not before noon on Sundays unless otherwise approved by the corporate authorities. All open air meetings shall conclude by 12:00 midnight and shall not be held before 12:00 noon on Sunday, unless otherwise approved by the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. No. 1393, § 1, 4-30-73)  
Sec. 21-403. - Maximum size. 
Parades and open air meetings shall be limited to such numbers as will not obstruct traffic either vehicular or pedestrian, in an unreasonable manner, and in any event, no such parade or open air meeting shall consist of more than five hundred (500) persons. For purposes of this section, children under the age of twelve (12) years shall not be counted. 
(Ord. No. 1099, § 5, 2-17-69)  
Secs. 21-404—21-415. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 21-416. - Required. 
No person shall participate in a parade or open air meeting held on any public way or on any public property unless a written permit therefor shall first be obtained from the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1099, § 1, 2-17-69)  
Sec. 21-417. - Application. 
An application to conduct a parade or open air meeting shall be made in writing to the chief of police at least five (5) days prior to the event, by a representative of the group seeking the permit, and shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade or open air meeting; 
(2)  If the parade or open air meeting is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization; 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman or chairman of the open air meeting; 
(4)  The date when the parade or open air meeting is to be conducted; 
(5)  The route to be traveled, the starting point, the termination point and the location of speakers' platforms; 
(6)  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade or open air meeting; the type of animals, and description of the vehicles; 
(7)  The hours when such parade or open air meeting will start and terminate; 
(8)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed; 
(9)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade or open air meeting; 
(10)  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly area or areas. 
(Ord. No. 1099, § 3, 2-17-69)  
Sec. 21-418. - Issuance or denials. 
(a)  The chief of police shall issue or deny a permit for a parade or open air meeting within thirty-six (36) hours after receipt of the permit application. 
(b)  The chief of police shall issue a parade or open air meeting permit when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade or open air meeting will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route; 
(2)  The conduct of the parade or open air meeting will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of this municipality to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to this village; 
(3)  The conduct of such parade or open air meeting will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of this village other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march or assembly and areas contiguous thereto; 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade or open air meeting will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas; 
(5)  The conduct of such parade or open air meeting will not interfere with the movement of fire-fighting equipment en route to a fire; 
(6)  The conduct of the parade or open air meeting is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance; 
(7)  The parade or open air meeting is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route; 
(8)  The parade or open air meeting is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, cause, goods or events and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. 
(b)  Permits may also be denied on the basis of the filing of an improper or incomplete application. The reasons for denial shall be made known to the applicant, in writing, at the time of denial. The applicant shall be allowed to correct or complete an improper or incomplete application and resubmit to the chief of police the original seventy-two-hour required advance notification time still being valid if a corrected application is resubmitted within twenty-four (24) hours prior to the time of the event. If a corrected application is not received by the chief of police twenty-four (24) hours prior to the time of the event, a new period of forty-eight (48) hours will be imposed prior to which the event may not be held. Such forty-eight-hour period shall commence upon receipt of the corrected application. 
(Ord. No. 1099, §§ 6, 8, 2-17-69)  
Sec. 21-419. - Conflicting applications. 
If the chief of police receives more than one (1) application for a parade or open air meeting permit for the same time and the same place, or on the same day, the application filed first in time shall take precedence. The parade or meeting shall be considered to be "at the same time" if the event is scheduled to commence within two (2) hours of the holding of another event. The parade or meeting shall be considered to be "at the same place" if the requested parade route comes at any point within six (6) blocks of or any equivalent distance from the route of another parade or if the open air meeting is conducted within one-half mile of another open air meeting. If the chief of police receives an application for more than one (1) parade or open air meeting in a single day, he may set a time for the duration of each parade or open air meeting which time shall not, without the consent of the group seeking the permit, be less than three (3) hours. 
(Ord. No. 1099, § 8, 2-17-69)  
ARTICLE V. - ENCROACHMENTS 
 
Sec. 21-501. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following definitions will apply: 
Construction easement area is defined as the area lying between the project right-of-way limits and the platted street limits within which the village by concurrence in the establishment of the project right-of-way lines, will permit the state to enter to perform all necessary construction operations. 
Encroachment is defined as any building, fence, sign or any other structure or object of any kind (with exception of utilities and public road signs), which is placed, located or maintained in, or, under or over any portion of the project right-of-way or the roadway right-of-way where no project right-of-way line has been established. 
Permissible encroachment is defined as any existing awnings, marquees, signs, advertising activity on the property and similar overhanging structures supported from buildings immediately adjacent to the highway right-of-way at locations where there is a sidewalk extending to the building line and which do not impair the free and safe flow of traffic on the highway. 
The permissive retention of overhanging signs does not apply to those signs supported from poles located outside the right-of-way line and not hidden by adjacent buildings. However, if a building is set back from the right-of-way line and the adjacent buildings are on the right-of-way line flush with the back of the sidewalk, signs supported from a pole advertising the enterprise conducted in the set back building may be permitted to overhang the project right-of-way line to the same degree as if supported from a building if they do not impede the free and safe flow of traffic. 
Project right-of-way is defined as those areas within the project right-of-way lines established jointly by the village and state, which will be free of encroachments except as hereinafter defined. 
Roadway right-of-way is defined as those areas existing or acquired by dedication or by fee simple for highway purposes; also, the areas acquired by temporary easement during the time the easement is in effect. 
(Ord. No. 2053, § 1, 1-3-83)  
Sec. 21-502. - Prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to erect or cause to be erected, to retain or cause to be retained, an encroachment (hereinabove defined), except as provided in section 21-504, within the limits of the project right-of-way or roadway right-of-way where no project right-of-way lines have been established. 
(Ord. No. 2053, § 1, 1-3-83)  
Sec. 21-503. - Project right-of-way. 
Project right-of-way lines have been established at the back of curb or shoulder line. 
(Ord. No. 2053, § 1, 1-3-83)  
Sec. 21-504. - Permissible encroachments. 
(a)  Revocable permits may be issued by the village for the temporary retention of permissible encroachments (hereinabove defined) subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  It must be a permissible encroachment, as defined in subsection 21-501(4). 
(2)  Said revocable permit shall be approved by the state and federal highway administration as a condition of its issuance. 
(3)  Said revocable permit shall be revoked when the encroachment impairs the highway or the free and safe flow of traffic as determined by either the Illinois Department of Transportation or the Federal Highway Administration or the Village of Villa Park. 
(4)  Said revocable permit shall be expressly limited to the property specified in the permit and only for those encroachments which fall under the definition of permissible encroachments (hereinabove defined). 
(b)  Revocable permits have been issued by the village for the temporary retention of the following permissible encroachments (hereinabove defined): 
(1)  Andrew and Evelyn Milletto, their assigns, successors in interest or heirs, owners of the property described as: 
Lots 204 and 205 in F. D. Payne's Addition to Villa Park, being a subdivision in the Southwest quarter of Section 3, Township 39 North, Range 11 East of the Third Principal Meridian, according to the Plat thereof recorded April 8, 1922, as document 155003, in DuPage County, Illinois. 
Commonly known as 150, 152, and 154 St. Charles Road, Villa Park, Illinois with encroachments being fixed or rigid metal awnings overhanging said rights-of-way attached to the building and/or buildings on said premises. 
(Ord. No. 2053, § 1, 1-3-83)  
Sec. 21-505. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3700, § 3, adopted May 21, 2012, deleted § 21-505, entitled "Penalties", which derived from: Ord. No. 2053, § 1, adopted Jan. 3, 1983.  
ARTICLE VI. - PARKWAY PARKING IN THE NORTH AVENUE INDUSTRIAL AREA 
 
Sec. 21-601. - Parking permitted. 
Notwithstanding any other section of this Code, parking on the paved parkway within the village's right-of-way shall be a permissible encroachment within the North Avenue Industrial Area ("NAIA") pursuant to this article. The NAIA shall include the following village rights-of-way: 
(1)  Michigan Avenue. CN Railroad right-of-way to North Avenue; east and west sides. 
(2)  Harvard Avenue. CN Railroad right-of-way to North Avenue; east and west sides. 
(3)  Yale Avenue. CN Railroad right-of-way to North Avenue; east and west sides. 
(4)  Princeton Avenue. CN Railroad right-of-way to North Avenue, east and west sides. 
(5)  Schiller Street. Yale Avenue to Ardmore Avenue, north and south sides. 
(6)  West Frontage Road of Ardmore Avenue. East side. 
It shall be unlawful for any parkway parking to block the street, sidewalk or driveway. 
(Ord. No. 3737, § 2, 3-18-13)  
Sec. 21-602. - Construction and maintenance of parking. 
(a)  An adjoining owner to the right-of-way within the NAIA shall be allowed to construct or continue to maintain parking spaces in the parkway. These parking spaces shall be considered an extension of the driveway apron and can exceed the width requirements for driveway aprons and extend from side lot line to side lot line. 
(b)  New parking shall be allowed when constructed with a permit in compliance with all village requirements and conditions imposed by the director of public works. No tree or other existing village structures shall be removed or interfered with to construct the parking. 
(c)  Existing parking and newly constructed parking after its completion, shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary manner and in compliance with all village requirements. 
(Ord. No. 3737, § 2, 3-18-13)  
Sec. 21-603. - Conditions. 
Parking on the parkway is subject to the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  The owner agrees to comply with all rules and regulations imposed by the village regulating parking in the parkway. 
(2)  The village at its sole discretion may prohibit, impose additional regulations, or remove the parkway parking area without compensation to the owner. 
(3)  The village or other public utility may permanently or temporary remove the parkway parking for the installation or maintenance of utilities in the right-of-way without compensation to the owner. 
(4)  The owner agrees to not allow any mechanic's lien or other encumbrance to be filed against the adjoining right-of-way. 
(5)  The owner agrees that as long as parking is permitted, to the fullest extent permitted by law, to defend, indemnify and hold harmless the village, its officials, agents and employees, against all injuries, deaths, loss, damages, claims, suits, liabilities, judgments, cost and expenses, which may in anywise accrue against the village, its officials, agents and employees, arising in whole or in part or in consequence of the use of the parkway for parking. 
(Ord. No. 3737, § 2, 3-18-13)  
ARTICLE VII. - PARKWAY PARKING IN THE HOME AVENUE INDUSTRIAL AREA 
 
Sec. 21-701. - Parking permitted. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other section of this Code, parking on the paved parkway within the village's right-of-way shall be a permissible encroachment within the Home Avenue Industrial Area ("HAIA") pursuant to this article. The HAIA shall include the village right-of-way of West Home Avenue from South Harvard Avenue to South Ardmore Avenue on its north and south sides. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any parkway parking to block the street, sidewalk or driveway. 
(Ord. No. 3923 , § 2, 7-25-16)  
Sec. 21-702. - Construction and maintenance of parking. 
(a)  An adjoining owner to the right-of-way within the HAIA shall be allowed to construct or continue to maintain parking spaces in the parkway. These parking spaces shall be considered an extension of the driveway apron and can exceed the width requirements for driveway aprons and extend from side lot line to side lot line. 
(b)  New parking shall be allowed when constructed with a permit in compliance with all village requirements and conditions imposed by the director of public works. No tree or other existing village structures shall be removed or interfered with to construct the parking. 
(c)  Existing parking and newly constructed parking after its completion shall be maintained by the adjoining owner in a safe and sanitary manner and in compliance with all village requirements. 
(Ord. No. 3923 , § 2, 7-25-16)  
Sec. 21-703. - Conditions. 
Parking on the parkway is subject to the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  The owner agrees to comply with all rules and regulations imposed by the village regulating parking in the parkway. 
(2)  The village at its sole discretion may prohibit, impose additional regulations, or remove the parkway parking area without compensation to the owner. 
(3)  The village or other public utility may permanently or temporary remove the parkway parking for the installation or maintenance of utilities in the right-of-way without compensation to the owner. 
(4)  The owner agrees to not allow any mechanic's lien or other encumbrance to be filed against the adjoining right-of-way. 
(5)  The owner agrees that as long as parking is permitted, to the fullest extent permitted by law, to defend, indemnify and hold harmless the village, its officials, agents and employees, against all injuries, deaths, loss, damages, claims, suits, liabilities, judgments, cost and expenses, which may in anywise accrue against the village, its officials, agents and employees, arising in whole or in part or in consequence of the use of the parkway for parking. 
(Ord. No. 3923 , § 2, 7-25-16)

ARTICLE II. - RETAILER'S OCCUPATION TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3349, § 3, adopted April 24, 2006, amended art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, said article pertained to similar subject matter as enacted by Ord. No. 1135, §§ 1—3, adopted Sept. 4, 1969. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion. The non-rule rule taxes imposed by this article shall be in addition to the use and occupation taxes assessed and collected pursuant to 35 ILCS 105/1 et seq. through and including 35 ILCS 120/1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 23-201. - Non-home rule retailer's occupation tax imposed. 
A non-home rule tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property, other than an item of tangible personal property titled or registered with an agency of this state's government, at retail in the village at the rate of one percent (1.0%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business. This non-home rule municipal retailers' occupation tax shall not be applicable to the sales of food for human consumption which is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes, and needles used by diabetics. 
The imposition of this non-home rule tax is in accordance with the provisions of Section 8-11-1.3 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3). 
(Ord. No. 3349, § 3, 4-24-06; Ord. No. 3967 , § 1, 4-24-17)  
Sec. 23-202. - Collection and enforcement. 
The tax hereby imposed and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereto shall be collected and enforced by the Department of Revenue of the State of Illinois. The department of revenue shall have full power to administer and enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3349, § 3, 4-24-06)  
Sec. 23-203. - Use of tax revenues. 
The tax revenues received by the village pursuant to this article shall be maintained in a special fund and shall only be expended for public infrastructure or for property tax relief as defined in 65 ILCS 8-11-1.2, as now existing or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 3349, § 3, 4-24-06)

Sec. 23-301. - Non-home rule municipal service occupation tax imposed.

This non-home rule municipal service occupation tax shall not be applicable to the sales of food for human consumption which is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes, and needles used by diabetics.

(Ord. No. 3349, § 4, 4-24-06)  
Sec. 23-303. - Use of tax revenues.

Footnotes:

Sec. 23-401. - Non-home rule municipal service tax. 
A non-home rule tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using, in the village, any item of tangible personal property which is purchased at retail from a retailer, and which is titled or registered with an agency of the government of the State of Illinois, based on the selling price of such tangible personal property, as selling price is defined in 35 ILCS 105/1 et seq. (the "Use Tax Act"), as now existing or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 3349, § 5, 4-24-06)

The tax imposed by this article shall be collected from persons whose Illinois address for title or registration purposes is given as being in the village. The village shall collect such tax in the manner hereinafter set forth. 
(Ord. No. 3349, § 5, 4-24-06)

Upon receiving information that a tax is due under this article, the director of finance shall send notice to the taxpayer of the amount due and owing the village and shall cause the person liable for the tax to make immediate payment thereof to the village. 
(Ord. No. 3349, § 5, 4-24-06)  
Sec. 23-404. - Penalty. 
Any person found guilty of violating, disobeying, omitting, neglecting, or refusing to comply with, or resisting or opposing the enforcement of any provision of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) and, in addition shall be liable in a civil action for the amount of the tax due plus a late charge in the amount of one (1) percent per month. A separate offense shall be determined to have been committed each day during which or on which the violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 3349, § 5, 4-24-06)

(Ord. No. 3349, § 5, 4-24-06)  
ARTICLE V. - UTILITY TAX[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 2946, adopted July 13, 1998, amended Art. V as herein set out. Formerly, Art. V pertained to similar subject matter and derived from §§ 1, 4, and 6—8 of Ord. No. 974, adopted Nov. 21, 1966; § 1 of Ord. No. 1004, adopted July 10, 1967; § 1 of Ord. No. 1124, June 2, 1969; §§ 3, 4, 6, 7 and 9 of Ord. No. 2007, adopted Jan. 4, 1982; § 1 of Ord. No. 2063, adopted Mar. 7, 1983; §§ 1—6 of Ord. No. 2521, adopted Sept. 23, 1991; §§ 1—6 of Ord. No. 2530, adopted Oct. 28, 1991; §§ 1, 2 of Ord. No. 2549, adopted Feb. 10, 1992; and §§ 2—5 of Ord. No. 2774, adopted July 10, 1995. 
 
DIVISION 1. - OCCUPATION/PRIVILEGE TAX 
 
Sec. 23-501. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of Division 1 of this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
Gross receipts means the consideration received for distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling gas for use or consumption and not for resale, the consideration received for distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling electricity for use or consumption and not for resale, and for all services rendered in connection therewith valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including cash, credit, services and property of every kind and material and for all services rendered therewith, and shall be determined without any deduction on account of the cost of the service, product or commodity supplied, the cost of materials used, labor or service cost, or any other expenses whatsoever. 
Person means any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint adventure, corporation, municipal corporation or political subdivision of this state, or a receiver, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court. 
(Ord. No. 2946, § 2, 7-13-98) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-2.  
Sec. 23-502. - Imposed. 
(a)  A tax is imposed on all persons engaged in the following occupations or privileges: 
(1)  Persons engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling gas for use or consumption within the corporate limits of the village, and not for resale, at the rate of five (5) percent of the gross receipts therefrom. 
(2)  Persons engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling electricity for use or consumption within the corporate limits of the village, and not for resale, at the rate of five (5) percent of the gross receipts therefrom. 
(b)  No tax is imposed by this division with respect to any transaction in interstate commerce or otherwise to the extent to which such business may not, under the constitution and statutes of the United States, be made subject to taxation by this state or any political subdivision thereof, nor shall any persons engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling gas or electricity, be subject to taxation under the provisions of this division for such transactions as are or may become subject to taxation under the provisions of the Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax Act authorized by 65 ILCS 5/8-11-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(c)  Such tax shall be in addition to the payment of money, or value of products or services furnished to the village by the taxpayer as compensation for the use of its streets, alleys, or other public places, or installation and maintenance therein, thereon or thereunder of poles, wires, pipes or other equipment used in the operation of the taxpayer's business. 
(d)  The tax imposed under this division shall not apply with respect to gross receipts pertaining to bills for the distribution, supply, furnishing or sale of electricity where the use or consumption of the electricity is subject to the tax imposed under Division 2 of this Article V. 
(Ord. No. 2946, § 2, 7-13-98)  
Sec. 23-502.1. - Tax rate based on gross receipts. 
The new tax rate provided pursuant to section 23-502(a)(1) and (2), shall be based on the gross receipts, as herein defined, actually paid to the taxpayer for services billed on or after the first day of August 1995. Any amounts due and payable for any tax period ending prior to August 1, 1995 shall be subject to the tax imposed at the rate of four (4) percent. 
(Ord. No. 2946, § 2, 7-13-98)  
Sec. 23-503. - Tax return. 
(a)  Each taxpayer shall make a tax return as required by this Division 1, to the village treasurer on or before the last day of each month stating: 
(1)  His name; 
(2)  His principal place of business; 
(3)  His gross receipts during the second preceding month upon the basis of which the tax is imposed; 
(4)  Amount of tax; 
(5)  Such other reasonable and related information as the corporate authorities may require. 
(b)  The taxpayer making the return shall, at the time of making such return, pay to the village finance department the amount of tax herein imposed. In connection with any return, the taxpayer may, if he so elects, report and pay an amount based upon his total billings of business subject to the tax during the period for which the return is made (exclusive of any amounts previously billed) with prompt adjustments of later payments based upon any differences between such billings and the taxable gross receipts. 
(Ord. No. 2946, § 2, 7-13-98)  
Sec. 23-504. - Credits. 
If it shall appear that an amount of tax has been paid which was not due under the provisions of this division, whether as the result of a mistake of fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be credited against any tax due or to become due under this division from the taxpayer who made the erroneous payment; provided that no amounts erroneously paid more than three (3) years prior to the filing of a claim therefor shall be so credited. 
If a taxpayer under this Division 1 is unable to use a credit authorized by this section solely because the tax imposed by this division has been replaced by the tax imposed under Division 2 of this article, then the taxpayer may apply such credit against any tax due under Division 2. 
(Ord. No. 2946, § 2, 7-13-98)  
Sec. 23-505. - Limitation on commencement of actions. 
No action to recover any amount of tax due under the provisions of this Division 1 shall be commenced more than three (3) years after the due date of such amount. 
(Ord. No. 2946, § 2, 7-13-98)  
DIVISION 2. - PURCHASE AT RETAIL TAX 
 
Sec. 23-506. - Definitions. 
As used in this Division 2 of Article V, unless the context otherwise requires: 
Village means the Village of Villa Park. 
Person means any natural, individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint venture, corporation, limited liability company, municipal corporation, the state or any of its political subdivisions, any state university created by statute, or a receiver, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court. 
Person maintaining a place of business in this state means any person having or maintaining within this state, directly or by a subsidiary or other affiliate, an office, generation facility, distribution facility, transmission facility, sales office or other place of business, or any employee, agent, or other representative operating within this state under the authority of the person or its subsidiary or other affiliate, irrespective of whether such place of business or agent or other representative is located in this state permanently or temporarily, or whether such person, subsidiary or other affiliate is licensed or qualified to do business in this state. 
Purchase at retail means any acquisition of electricity by a purchaser for purposes of use or consumption, and not for resale, but shall not include the use of electricity by a public utility, as defined in Section 8-11-2 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-2), directly in the generation, production, transmission, delivery or sale of electricity. 
Purchaser means any person who uses or consumes, within the corporate limits of the village, electricity acquired in a purchase at retail. 
Tax collector means the person delivering electricity to the purchaser. 
(Ord. No. 2946, § 2, 7-13-98)  
Sec. 23-507. - Tax imposed. 
(a)  Pursuant to Section 8-11-2 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-2) and any and all other applicable authority, a tax is imposed upon the privilege of using or consuming electricity acquired in a purchase at retail and used or consumed within the corporate limits of the village at the following rates, calculated on a monthly basis for each purchaser: 
(i)  For the first 2,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.574 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(ii)  For the next 48,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.394 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(iii)  For the next 50,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.376 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(iv)  For the next 400,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month; 0.277 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(v)  For the next 500,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month; 0.250 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(vi)  For the next 2,000,00 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month; 0.220 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(vii)  For the next 2,000,00 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.190 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(viii)  For the next 5,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.150 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(ix)  For the next 10,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month: 0.110 cents per kilowatt-hour; and 
(x)  For all electricity used or consumed in excess of 20,000,000 kilowatt-hours in a month: 0.080 cents per kilowatt-hour. 
(b)  The tax is in addition to all taxes, fees and other revenue measures imposed by the village, the State of Illinois or any other political subdivision of the state. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this division, the tax shall not be imposed if and to the extent that imposition or collection of the tax would violate the Constitution or statutes of the United States or the Constitution of the State of Illinois. 
(d)  The tax shall be imposed with respect to the use or consumption of electricity by residential customers beginning with the first bill issued on or after September 1, 1998; and, with respect to the use or consumption of electricity by nonresidential customers, beginning with the first bill issued to such customers for delivery services in accordance with Section 16-104 of the Public Utilities Act (220 ILCS 5/16-104), or the first bill issued to such customers on or after January 1, 2001, whichever issuance occurs sooner. 
(Ord. No. 2946, § 2, 7-13-98)  
Sec. 23-508. - Collection of tax. 
(a)  Subject to the provisions of section 23-510 regarding the delivery of electricity to resellers, the tax imposed under this division shall be collected from purchasers by the person maintaining a place of business in this state who delivers electricity to such purchasers. This tax shall constitute a debt of the purchaser to the person who delivers the electricity to the purchaser and is recoverable at the same time and in the same manner as the original charge for delivering the electricity. 
(b)  Any tax required to be collected by this division, and any tax in fact collected, shall constitute a debt owed to the village by the person delivering the electricity, provided, that the person delivering electricity shall be allowed credit for such tax related to deliveries of electricity the charges for which are written off as uncollectible, and provided further, that if such charges are thereafter collected, the delivering supplier shall be obligated to remit such tax. 
(c)  Persons delivering electricity shall collect the tax from the purchaser by adding such tax to the gross charge for delivering the electricity. To the extent permitted by law, persons delivering electricity shall also be authorized to add to such gross charge an amount equal to three (3) percent of the tax they collect to reimburse them for their expenses incurred in keeping records, billing customers, preparing and filing returns, remitting the tax and supplying data to the village upon request. For purposes of this division, any partial payment of a billed amount not specifically identified by the purchaser shall be deemed to be for the delivery of electricity. 
(Ord. No. 2946, § 2, 7-13-98)  
Sec. 23-509. - Tax remittance and return. 
(a)  Every tax collector shall on a monthly basis file a return in a form prescribed by the village manager or his designee. The return and accompanying remittance shall be due on or before the last day of the month following the month during which the tax is collected or is required to be collected under this division. 
(b)  If the person delivering electricity fails to collect the tax from the purchaser or is excused from collecting the tax under section 23-510, then the purchaser shall file a return in a form prescribed by the village manager, or his designee, and pay the tax directly to the village finance department on or before the last day of the month following the month during which the electricity is used or consumed. 
(Ord. No. 2946, § 2, 7-13-98)  
Sec. 23-510. - Resales. 
(a)  Electricity that is delivered to a person in this village shall be considered to be for use and consumption by that person unless the person receiving the electricity has an active resale number issued by the village manager or his designee and furnishes that number to the person who delivers the electricity, and certifies to that person that the sale is either entirely or partially nontaxable as a sale for resale. 
(b)  If a person who receives electricity in the village claims to be an authorized reseller of electricity, that person shall apply to the village manager or his designee for a resale number. The applicant shall state facts showing why it is not liable for the tax imposed by this division on any purchases of electricity and shall furnish such additional information as the village may reasonably require. 
(c)  Upon approval of the application, the village manager, or his designee, shall assign a resale number to the applicant and shall certify the number to the applicant. 
(d)  The village may cancel the resale number of any person if the person fails to pay any tax payable under this division for electricity used or consumed by the person, or if the number: 
(1)  was obtained through misrepresentation, or 
(2)  is no longer necessary because the person has discontinued making resales. 
(e)(1) If a reseller has acquired electricity partly for use or consumption and partly for resale, the reseller shall pay the tax imposed by this division directly to the village finance department pursuant to section 23-509, on the amount of electricity that the reseller uses or consumes, and shall collect the tax pursuant to section 23-508 and remit the tax pursuant to section 23-509 on the amount of electricity delivered by the reseller to a purchaser. 
(2)  Any person who delivers electricity to a reseller having an active resale number and complying with all other conditions of this section shall be excused from collecting and remitting the tax on any portion of the electricity delivered to the reseller, provided that the person reports to the village manager or his designee the total amount of electricity delivered to the reseller, and such other information that the village may reasonably require. 
(Ord. No. 2946, § 2, 7-13-98)  
Sec. 23-511. - Books and records. 
Every tax collector and every taxpayer required to pay the tax imposed by this division shall keep accurate books and records of its business or activity, including contemporaneous books and records denoting the transactions that gave rise, or may have given rise, to any tax liability under this division. The books and records shall be subject to and available for inspection at all times during business hours of the day. 
(Ord. No. 2946, § 2, 7-13-98)  
Sec. 23-512. - Credits and refunds. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this division, in order to permit sound fiscal planning and budgeting by the village, no person shall be entitled to a refund of, or credit for, a tax imposed under this division unless the person files a claim for refund or credit within one (1) year after the date on which the tax was paid or remitted to the village finance department. 
(Ord. No. 2946, § 2, 7-13-98)  
Sec. 23-513. - Violations. 
Any taxpayer who fails to make a return, or who makes a fraudulent return, or who wilfully violates any other provision of this Article V is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and, in addition, shall be liable in a civil action for the amount of tax due. 
(Ord. No. 2946, § 2, 7-13-98)  
ARTICLE VI. - TAX ON FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES 
 
Sec. 23-601. - Imposed; rate. 
Every corporation, company and association which is not incorporated under the laws of this state and which is engaged in effecting fire insurance in the village shall pay to the village treasurer for the use and benefit of the fire department a sum equal to two (2) percent of the gross receipts received from fire insurance upon property situated within the village. 
(Ord. No. 225, § 1, 8-19-27) 
State Law reference— Tax on foreign fire insurance companies authority, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1.  
Sec. 23-602. - Reports. 
Every person who acts in the village as agent, or otherwise, on behalf of a corporation, company or association upon which a tax or license fee is levied by the provisions of this article, shall render to the village clerk on or before the fifteenth day of July of each year, a full and true account, verified by his oath, of all of the premiums which, during the year ending on the first of July preceding the report, were received by him, or by any other person for him on behalf of that corporation, company or association. He shall specify in this report the amounts received for fire insurance, and he shall pay to the village treasurer at the time of rendering this report, the amount at determined by the rate fixed herein for which his corporation, company, or association is accountable under this article. 
(Ord. No. 225, § 2, 8-19-27) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1.  
Sec. 23-603. - Payment. 
Each corporation, company and association on which a tax or license fee is levied by the provisions of this article shall pay at the rate required herein, upon the amount of all premiums which have been received during the year ending on every first day of July for all fire insurance effected or agreed to be effected on property situated within the village, by that corporation, company or association. 
(Ord. No. 225, § 1, 8-19-27) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1.  
Sec. 23-604. - Effect of failure to pay. 
If the account required herein is not rendered on or before the fifteenth day of July of each year, or if the sum due remains unpaid after that day, it shall be unlawful for any corporation, company or association, so in default, to transact any business in the municipality or fire protection district until the same due has been fully paid. This section shall not relieve any corporation, company or association from the payment of any loss upon any risk that may be taken in violation of this requirement. 
(Ord. No. 225, § 3, 8-19-27) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1.  
Sec. 23-605. - Examination of records. 
The village clerk may examine the books, records and other papers and documents of an agent, corporation, company or association liable for the tax or license fee required by the provisions of this article for the purpose of verifying the correctness of the report of the amounts received for fire insurance. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-10-1.  
Sec. 23-606. - Recovery in civil action. 
The amount of the tax or license fee required by the provisions of this article may be recovered from the corporation, company or association which owes it, or from its agent, by an action in the name and for the use of the village as for money had and received. 
(Ord. No. 225, § 4, 8-19-27) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-10-1.  
Sec. 23-607. - Exemption. 
This article shall not be applicable to receipts from contracts of marine insurance, even though they include insurance against fire, where the premium for the fire insurance is not separately specified. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-10-1.  
Sec. 23-608. - Use of funds. 
All monies received by the village pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be disbursed to the designated treasurer of the fire department for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department, as determined by the rules of said Department; or, said funds collected shall be deposited in the firemen's pension fund, as established by village ordinance No. 1349, as codified in the Villa Park Municipal Code, Chapter 9, Division 2, section 9-321. Said funds shall be disbursed on an annual basis pursuant to one of the two aforestated options, to be selected by the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 225, § 5, 8-19-27; Ord. No. 2192, § 1, 7-21-86) 
State Law reference— Use of fund, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-10-2.  
ARTICLE VII. - AUTOMOBILE RENTING OCCUPATION AND USE TAX[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2009, §§ 1—3, and Ord. No. 2010, §§ 1—4, both adopted Dec. 21, 1981, as subsequently amended, did not expressly amend the Code; therefore, codification as §§ 23-701—23-707 was at the editor's discretion. 
 
Sec. 23-701. - Automobile renting occupation tax—Imposed. 
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of renting automobiles in this village at the rate of one per cent of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business while this article is in effect in accordance with the provisions of Section 8-11-7 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 2009, § 1, 12-21-81; Ord. No. 2016, § 1, 1-11-82)  
Sec. 23-702. - Same—Report. 
Every such person engaged in such business in the village shall file on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue required by Sections Two and Three of "An Act in Relation to a Tax upon Persons Engaged in the Business of Selling Tangible Personal Property to Purchasers for Use or Consumption" approved June 29, 1933, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2009, § 2, 12-21-81; Ord. No. 2016, § 2, 1-11-82)  
Sec. 23-703. - Same—Payment. 
At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the renting of automobiles during the preceding month. 
(Ord. No. 2009, § 3, 12-21-81; Ord. No. 2016, § 3, 1-11-82)  
Sec. 23-704. - Automobile renting use tax—Imposed. 
A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using in this village an automobile which is rented from a renter outside Illinois and which is titled or registered with an agency of this state's government in this village at the rate of one per cent of the rental price of such automobile while this article is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of Section 8-11-8 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010, § 1, 12-21-81; Ord. No. 2017, § 1, 1-11-82)  
Sec. 23-705. - Same—Report. 
Every such person engaged in such business in the village shall file on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue required by Sections Two and Three of "An Act in Relation to a Tax upon Persons Engaged in the Business of Selling Tangible Personal Property to Purchasers for Use or Consumption" approved June 29, 1933, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2010, § 2, 12-21-81; Ord. No. 2017, § 2, 1-11-82) 
Editor's note— Perhaps the modes of procedure to be followed are prescribed in Sections 2 and 4 of the "Use Tax Act."  
Sec. 23-706. - Same—Collection. 
The tax provided for in section 23-704 shall be collected from the persons whose Illinois address for titling or registration purposes is given as being in this village. 
(Ord. No. 2010, § 3, 12-21-81; Ord. No. 2017, § 3, 1-11-82)  
Sec. 23-707. - Same—Payment. 
At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the renting of automobiles during the preceding month. 
(Ord. No. 2010, § 4, 12-21-81; Ord. No. 2017, § 4, 1-11-82)  
ARTICLE VIII. - HOTEL OPERATOR'S OCCUPATION TAX[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2283, §§ 1—8, adopted May 2, 1988, did not specifically amend the Code, hence inclusion herein as Art. VIII, §§ 23-801—23-808, was at the discretion of the editor. Sections 9, 10 and 11, providing for severability, penalty and effective date have been omitted from codification. 
State Law reference— Authority to impose tax, rate, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 8-3-14. 
 
Sec. 23-801. - Definitions. 
The following words, as used in this article, shall have the following meanings, unless the context requires otherwise: 
Department means the finance department for the Village of Villa Park. 
Hotel means any building or buildings in which the public may, for a consideration, obtain living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations. The term includes inns, motels, tourist homes or courts, lodging houses, rooming houses and apartment houses.
